HEADLINE: Greenspan's Authority Curtailed On Interest Rates, Officials Say

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Amid a debate at the Federal Reserve Board over whether lower interest rates are needed to help the nation out of recession, the central bank's policy-making body has curtailed the authority of its chairman, Alan Greenspan, to reduce rates on his own, high Government officials said over the weekend.
In his nearly four years as chairman, Mr. Greenspan has never before been so openly challenged by other members of the Federal Reserve's policy-making body, the Federal Open Market Committee. Its members include Mr. Greenspan, the 4 other governors of the Federal Reserve Board and the 12 presidents of the regional Federal Reserve Banks. 
 While the Federal Reserve's directives are never very explicit, the reduced authority means, in effect, that Mr. Greenspan will have a harder time justifying interest rate cuts that he might want to make during the six-week intervals between meetings of the Federal Open Market Committee. Should he want to cut rates, he will have to gather more evidence of a weakening economy than he has apparently needed in recent months.
 
A Question of Authority
 The dispute has taken the form of an argument over whether Mr. Greenspan, in reducing short-term interest rates sharply since early January, went beyond the authority granted to him by his colleagues. Supporters of Mr. Greenspan's actions invoke years of tradition to defend his right to act on his own.
But despite the talk about whether Mr. Greenspan exceeded his authority, seven of the Federal Reserve policy makers said in interviews that the heart of the debate is really over this question: Is the recession ending, or is the nation in for many more weeks of hard times? Put another way, the question is whether the Federal Reserve should cut interest rates to stimulate economic growth and insure a recovery, or keep them where they are, confident that a recovery by late summer is a sure thing. Further stimulation might soon become inflationary, they say.
"Anytime people at the Fed become disgruntled with policy or uncertain about it, there is a tendency to focus on procedure," said Wayne D. Angell, a Federal Reserve governor.
High Government officials, who insisted on anonymity, said the focus on procedure prompted the policy makers, at their regular closed-session meeting on March 26, to alter a resolution that had been on the books since last summer. The resolution had put the policy makers on record as "tilted toward easing" interest rates and had given Mr. Greenspan the discretion to cut rates on his own between meetings, without first consulting with the others in a telephone conference call, if the unfolding economic data showed the economy to be very weak.
The Government officials said they did not know precisely what changes had been made, but they said Mr. Greenspan's earlier authorization to cut interest rates on his own had been diluted.
Mr. Greenspan had used that earlier power to reduce rates on three occasions since early January, most recently on March 8, the day the Labor Department announced that the nation's unemployment rate in February had risen by three-tenths of a percentage point, to 6.5 percent. A similar rise in March, announced on Friday, was not quickly followed by a rate reduction.
Lower interest rates tend to stimulate borrowing for consumption and investment, thus counteracting the recession. The Federal Reserve mainly controls the interest rates that banks pay to borrow money, which they then relend to the public for things like home mortgages and car loans. The Federal Reserve's recent rate reductions have allowed mortgage rates to decline, providing some stimulation to the moribund housing market.
The dispute over Mr. Greenspan's right to act on his own arose in February, when the policy makers began to disagree over what might happen to the economy next, the policy makers interviewed said. Until then, the open market committee had given its blessing to frequent reductions in interest rates, starting last fall, to counteract the recession.
The 17 members of the committee are now divided into two factions. Roughly half believe the recession has passed its nadir and a recovery is under way. They argue that the various reductions in short-term interest rates, totaling more than two percentage points since July, are sufficient. More reductions might encourage too much economic activity in the coming rebound, creating an inflation problem in the future, they say.
Reflecting the thinking of this group, Robert P. Black, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, said: "There is some evidence out there that a rebound might be beginning. My guess is that it will not be a terribly strong one. But economists have underpredicted in the past the strength of rebounds from recessions."
Mr. Angell is also said to be a member of the group that foresees an early rebound, as are Robert T. Parry, Roger Guffey and W. Lee Hoskins, presidents of the Federal Reserve Banks of San Francisco, Kansas City and Cleveland, respectively.
 
Need for 'a Little Insurance'
 The other group is not sure the nadir has been passed. Some believe that further rate cuts might be in order as insurance that the economy will revive.
Mr. Greenspan is reported to be in this group, which also includes David W. Mullins Jr., the vice chairman; Edward W. Kelley Jr., a governor, and three or more regional bank presidents, among them Robert P. Forrestal of Atlanta, Silas Keehn of Chicago and Edward G. Boehne of Philadelphia.
"The forecast of an economic rebound in the second half of the year is a very reasonable one," Mr. Forrestal said. "But there are risks to that forecast, and I would prefer to have a little insurance to take into account the uncertainty. My preference would be to cut rates a bit more."
That apparently was also Mr. Greenspan's preference in early February, when he lowered a bank borrowing rate by half a percentage point and was challenged by the optimists among the policy makers. Previously he had pushed rates down only one-quarter of a percentage point at a time.
At the Feb. 8 meeting, some policy makers were annoyed that Mr. Greenspan had acted so decisively just a few days before they met, without waiting to consult them.
"The question of whether the delegation of authority to Mr. Greenspan was meant to be as much as a half a percentage point, or only a quarter of a percentage point, under our directive, is the major part of the issue," Mr. Guffey said. "The other part of the issue is the need to consult when some action is taken that appears to be unusual."
The discussion continued at the March 26 meeting, but in calmer tones, the policy makers said in interviews. Some described the meeting as a reconciliation, and Mr. Parry said, "More has been made out of this so-called tiff than is really the case."
The Fed directly controls two interest rates. One is the discount rate, what the Federal Reserve charges banks that borrow directly from it. The other, called the Federal funds rate, governs what banks charge on loans to each other. In the late 1980's, interbank borrowing became far and away the most important source of money, and that made the Federal funds rate the focus of Fed policy.
 
Predicament Continues
 In the past, when the two sources of money were more equal, the Federal Reserve's chairman could alter rates between meetings without consulting but would not on his own change the difference between the discount and Federal funds rate. Some policy makers invoked this old procedure as justification for Mr. Greenspan's action in early February, when he reduced the discount rate and the Federal funds rate by half a point, to 6 percent.
Despite the big reduction, the spread between the two rates did not change and Mr. Greenspan did not have to consult the other policy makers in a conference call, they argued. Still, Mr. Greenspan remains in a predicament. By law, he and the four other governors have the right to lower the discount rate. But they share with the regional bank presidents authority over the Federal funds rate. Between meetings, Mr. Greenspan has the power to change this rate, in accordance with the policy makers' directives.
Supporters of this view say that Mr. Greenspan should continue to exercise his delegated authority without having to consult by telephone with the other policy makers each time he acts. They say that if he gives in on this point, he might undermine the future right of the chairman to act without consultation, a precedent developed over decades. But others say the issue will evaporate once the policy makers come to agreement on what's ahead for the economy.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL MEMO;
How Politics, Not Voters, Molds Budget In New York

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 7

 BODY:
Schoolchildren, motorists and nursing-home patients. Library users, beachgoers and business executives. All these groups, indeed, virtually all of New York's 18 million residents, are affected by the state budget.
But budget negotiations are rarely conducted with them in mind. Instead, like a school play put on for parents, they are usually staged for a small group of interested, or more often, self-interested, parties. 
Even with New York facing money problems of historic proportions, it is still the internal dramatics of the State Legislature, more than the needs or desires of the voters, that are shaping budget negotiations. And if these negotiations seem deadlocked six days after a new budget was due, it is not because of political pressures from the outside. It is because each legislative leader is receiving enough support from his own members and from major lobbying groups to believe he does not yet have to alter his lines.
"Obviously, they're playing to their own constituencies," one former state official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "Everybody's got a nice comfy spot."
 
'Storm and Fury Signifying Nothing'
 The major players in the budget talks -- the Governor, the Assembly Speaker and the Senate majority leader -- have real policy differences which, in turn, have substantive implications for state residents. And these differences are based on real clashes of interests, most clearly between New York City groups hoping to hang on to social services and suburbanites worried about tax increases or cuts in school aid.
But the longer the negotiations drag on, the more distant these real concerns seem to become and the more importance the daily exchange of press releases takes on.
"It becomes a self-contained universe," one Assembly staff member said. "It's a lot of storm and fury signifying nothing."
Beyond the State Capitol, however, the budget delay is exacting a real cost.
Because of the delay, the state will be unable to make $1.3 billion in payments to local school districts due the middle of the month. Many of these districts will have to borrow to tide them over, with interest they can ill afford at a time of state cuts.
New York City has already said that it will have to borrow $1 billion if state aid payments expected at the end of the month do not arrive. And uncertainty about how much state aid the city will eventually receive has prompted Mayor David N. Dinkins to seek to delay submitting his own budget, which is supposed to be presented on April 26.
"We view it as a significant problem," the city budget director, Philip R. Michael, said of the delay.
 
Like a Family Feud
 But the dismay of local officials has not yet reached a pitch that would impinge on the workings of the State Capitol. In almost daily press briefings, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has tried to manufacture a sense of urgency, but to no avail. Most lawmakers say that as long as the Governor continues to send up emergency bills to pay state workers -- something many states do not allow -- the stalemate could last for weeks.
Watching the Governor and the legislative leaders go at it, it appears that one has stumbled on to some long-running family feud in which no one can remember why he or she is angry anymore.
The heavy in this feud appears to be the Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, a Brooklyn Democrat.
Mr. Miller has broken openly with the Governor, a fellow Democrat, and over the Governor's strenuous objections, called for an income-tax increase of almost $1 billion. An informal supporter of higher gasoline taxes in the past, Mr. Miller has also rebuffed the Governor's call for a 10-cent-a-gallon increase this year.
 
Making Sense Politically
 Aides to Mr. Miller insist that he has assumed this stance simply because he believes it is the fairest solution. But the Speaker's actions make sense fully only in the context of internal politics.
Recently weakened by an indictment for mail fraud, Mr. Miller has come under strong pressure from the liberal wing of the Assembly, most notably the Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus, to restore many of the social-service cuts proposed by the Governor. The Speaker's income-tax increase is intended to do this and to mollify his traditional liberal supporters.
For Mr. Miller's traditional New-York-City-based supporters, the proposed gas-tax increase, which falls heavily on upstate residents and suburbanites, makes sense. And yet he has said it is dead, largely, it seems, to gain advantage over the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino.
Throughout recent negotiations, Mr. Marino, an Oyster Bay Republican, has maintained that he would prefer not to pass any tax increases at all, and that the state should reduce spending. At the same time, however, he has made it clear that he will not approve a budget that does not substantially increase aid to suburban school districts.
 
Maintaining Peace
 This inconsistent stance has allowed Mr. Marino to maintain peace within his own often fractious Republican conference, and to satisfy two powerful constituencies: business and suburban school districts.
"Politically, everyone is where he wants to be," the former state official said. "Mel is Mr. Liberal and Ralph is Mr. Frugality."
The Assembly Speaker's opposition to the gasoline tax has presented Mr. Marino with three equally uncomfortable options: He can resurrect the gasoline tax, an anathema to his own upstate and suburban constituents; he can offer some other tax, or he can offer spending cuts. All he has indicated is that he does not plan to openly embrace any of these options.
As the most visible politician in the state, it is Governor Cuomo who is suffering the largest political loss as the Legislature debates his controversial budget interminably. Yet Mr. Cuomo has been relatively inflexible, refusing even to discuss the possibiity of broad-based tax increases.
Aides to the Governor say that despite the obvious political costs of the delay, Mr. Cuomo is essentially comfortable with his position. Not only is it the right one for real economic reasons, they say, but also for political reasons. It shows the Governor is prepared to make unpopular decisions and stick with them.
"They're having a terrible time coming to grips with the new economic realities," the Governor's chief of staff, Gerald C. Crotty, said of the legislative leaders. "We've made the tough choices."

HEADLINE: Bush Pledges To Fight for Mexico Pact

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, April 7

 BODY:
President Bush promised today to fight organized labor "head on head" to win Congressional approval of a free-trade agreement with Mexico.
Speaking at a joint news conference with President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico, Mr. Bush said "we're in for a battle," but he emphasized that his Administration was "committed totally" to the trade accord. 
 This was the first time since the end of the war with Iraq that Mr. Bush has used the Presidential pulpit to call attention to an economic matter, in recognition that the trade issue will be a focus of political attention during the next few weeks.
Negotiation of a trade pact with Mexico and resumption of international trade talks under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade depend on Mr. Bush's ability to retain what are called fast-track procedures.
Under those rules, Congress can only approve or disapprove trade agreements in full and cannot amend them. The existing fast-track authority will extend for another two years unless the Senate or House of Representatives votes by June 1 to block the continuation.
Most of the opposition to a Mexican trade agreement comes from labor unions. They fear that American companies will move to Mexico, where wages are lower and environmental regulations more lax, and that American workers will lose jobs as a result.
In Congress, Democratic lawmakers who accept the view of labor have joined forces with colleagues from farm and textile states who want to prevent the resumption of international trade talks. Those talks, if successful, would probably lead to more competition from abroad for American agriculture and textile interests.
On the fast-track question, President Bush has solid support from Republicans in Congress and is backed by several important Democrats, including Speaker of the House Thomas S. Foley of Washington and Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, the chairman of the Finance Committee. Still, he is unlikely to prevail without a struggle.
"Some elements in organized labor are fighting it," the President said today. "They are wrong. And I'm going to take them on head on head because I know that this is in the best interest of our country."
Mr. Salinas stopped here on his way to Ottawa for a state visit. He will also make brief stops in other American cities to promote the trade agreement.

HEADLINE: Corporate Chiefs See Need For U.S. Health-Care Action

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 7

 BODY:
A survey on health care, taken among chief executives of the nation's largest companies, has found that 91 percent of them say a fundamental change or complete rebuilding of the health-care system is needed.
The survey also found that 73 percent of the executives said the problems could not be solved by companies working on their own. A majority said Government intervention was necessary. 
 The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, which had the Gallup Organization conduct the survey, said in a report, "While there may not yet be consensus on these problems, business could be a determining factor in creating the political will to proceed."
While a large number of surveys on the topic have been done, this is the first to reach a large, representative sample of chief executives of the largest corporations in America. "It is precisely those business executives who are most likely to be influential in the debate over health-care reform," the foundation said.
The report said the two main issues were control of the cost of health care and access to the system for more people. Executives said Government intervention in both areas was needed, but they varied greatly on just what the Government might do.
They were wary of direct governmental control of the health-care industry. Three-quarters said the employer-based insurance structure should be kept, while 25 percent said it should be replaced. The most unpopular proposal was for the Government to control the number of specialists in medicine -- only 6 percent said the Government should take such action now, and 12 percent said it should be considered in the future.
The creation now of a universal, Government-run health-care system was suggested by 9 percent, while 24 percent said this option should be considered for the future. The idea was opposed by 66 percent.
For years, public health officials and consumer groups have advocated an overhaul of the way people get health care and how they pay for it. These critics say the system leaves 32 million people with no insurance and perhaps another 70 million with seriously inadequate coverage, while offering a lower quality of care than in many other industrial nations by several measures.
As a matter of politics, the shift among business executives is crucial.
"We need both business and labor if there is to be any chance to get national reform adopted," said Ron Pollack, executive director of the Families U.S.A. Foundation, a nonprofit Washington group specializing in issues of concern to the elderly poor. "Especially in a Republican Administration, there is simply no chance of getting anything adopted if we don't get the support of business."
Mr. Pollack said: "It is unclear whether any of the business groups will come forward with a proposal that will get any significant support. But they are discussing the issues, they are quite serious, and it is now clear to them that things cannot go on as they are now."
 
Companies' Steps Ineffective
 It has been known for some time that the cost of health care to business was becoming more painful, and that businesses were taking action on their own and in small groups to try to cut back costs.
"What you see is business waking up to the fact that there is a serious problem, and they are waking up now particularly because they tried individually to cut costs," said Edmund F. Haislmaier, a policy analyst on health for the Heritage Foundation, a conservative policy research organization in Washington. "But now they are moving toward the realization they can't do it themselves."
The United States' health-care system is the most expensive in the world, costing 40 percent more per capita than that of Canada, the country in second place, and as much as double the cost in other nations. Businesses have watched with growing apprehension as health-care spending devoured ever larger portions of their profits. In the 1960's, businesses spent on health care about 4 to 8 cents of each dollar of profits. Now, it is 25 to 50 cents for each dollar.
 
Behind in Life Expectancy
 Even though Americans pay the most, life expectancy in the United States ranks below that of 15 nations, and infant mortality is worse than in 22 other countries.
The effects of high costs have been felt strongly by business leaders. "When we feel the heat, we see the light," said Dr. Theodore Cooper, the chairman of the Upjohn Company.
Drastic increases in the cost of the health system have now convinced them that something must be done. After trying and failing to get a grip on medical care costs themselves, they have accepted the idea that change must be national, not piecemeal or local, according to the new survey and several others conducted in the last year or so.
No agreement has been reached among businesses on exactly what kind of shift is best, and large businesses appear more ready to act than small ones, but scores, even hundreds of business coalitions and commissions have been formed and are devising plans for national changes.
 
The Emerging Approaches
The emerging approaches fall into several general categories. One is called "play or pay," in which American businesses would be required to offer health coverage to their employees or pay a premium to a Federal or state pool so that all uncovered Americans could get insurance.
Another is called a "single payer" system, in which the Government pays all health-care costs, all Americans are covered, and the system is paid for through some kind of tax.
There is a conservative approach called the "tax reform" approach in which employees are given the money employers now pay to cover workers and are expected to buy their own insurance. This money to cover insurance would be taxed at a rate that would give breaks to those with lower incomes and to those not seeking full coverage with "all the extras."
 
Types of Regulation Supported
 The following types of Government regulation were supported by the executives:
*Sixty percent said the Government should act now to "make greater use of selective contracting to purchase services under the Medicare and Medicaid programs." Another 29 percent said this should be an option for the future.
*Fifty-one percent said the Government should act now to offer tax incentives that would encourage small businesses to provide health benefits. Twenty-nine percent said the Government should require all employers to provide health benefits, and another 24 percent said mandatory coverage should be an option for the future.
*Forty-seven percent said the Government should establish standards for all medical care, and another 27 percent wanted this option considered later.
*Forty percent said the Government should expand existing public programs to cover more of the uninsured, and an additional 39 percent wanted this option considered in the future.
*Thirty-three percent said the Government should create a single set of reimbursement rules for hospitals and doctors to be used by all private insurers as well as Government. Another 28 percent wanted this option for the future.
 
End of 'Leave It Alone' Attitude
 Lawrence Atkins, a Washington health policy consultant at the New York law firm Winthrop Stimson Putnam & Roberts, said: "Not long ago another option people listed was 'leave it alone -- don't do anything major.' That option is not on the list for most businesses anymore."
He continued: "Two years ago I could characterize the business position for you quickly: Don't increase the Government role, no matter what; nothing should be mandated for employers; cost control can best be done by us operating alone. If the market is open, people said, it will come up with the right solution."
Mr. Atkins said that attitude had changed. "At a minimum, people who look into it do see a crisis, and an important role for the Government, even though they don't want the Government to run the entire system," he added.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
The Economy
The Fed's policy makers have curtailed the authority of the chairman, Alan Greenspan, to reduce interest rates on his own, officials said. The reduced authority means Mr. Greenspan will have to work harder to justify rate cuts that he wants to make between meetings of the Fed's policy-making body. [Page A1.] 
 Two elements of the Bush Administration's bank plan may become law, but lawmakers and aides say other parts, notably one that permits industrial ownership of banks, seem sure to die. [D1.]
A survey of chief executives on health care has found that 91 percent of them say a fundamental change or complete rebuilding of the health-care system is needed. [D1.]
President Bush promised to fight organized labor "head on head" to win approval of a free-trade agreement with Mexico. [D1.]
A calamity is unfolding in the San Joaquin Valley of California as a result of the December freeze that destroyed citrus crops and put thousands of people out of work. [A1.]
Jack Valenti may have pulled one more trick out of his bag. With the F.C.C.'s expected decision to give networks new rights in the rerun market, it is also expected to preserve protections for the Hollywood studios he represents. Washington at Work. [A12.]
Virtually all of New York State's 18 million residents are affected by the state budget, but the budget negotiations under way are rarely conducted with them in mind. Political Memo. [B1.]
New York fashion industry executives hope lower prices, new styles and pent-up demand will lead to a recovery. [B1.]
 
Companies
More than a dozen computer companies will announce their commitment tomorrow to a new and untried chip they hope will dominate the computing world. The extraordinary alliance underscores the extent to which competition in the computer industry increasingly revolves around different chips. [D1.]
Dozens of companies are quietly accepting the demands of pension funds to lower their takeover defenses and broaden the rights of shareholders, in hopes of avoiding messy proxy battles. [D1.]
 
International
France's Socialist Government will allow private investors to acquire up to 49 percent of state-owned companies. The reversal of policy opens the door for Credit Lyonnais to announce a cross-shareholding agreement with Germany's Commerzbank. [D2.]
 
The Media Business
When The Washington Post recently tried to drop some venerable comic strips, the response was overwhelming and angry. Indeed, while not everyone reads the comics, the nation's newspapers invest heavily each year in syndication fees and newsprint to make comics available because they are so popular with readers. [D1.]
Researchers say television commercials can induce striking changes in people's behavior regarding health. [D8.]
The Los Angeles Times has published a new, larger and more ambitious version of its Sunday magazine. [D8.]
The television industry will change irrevocably on April 20, says the president of Time Warner Sports. On that day, he says, sports executives will learn how much a boxing match the night before earned on pay-per-view TV. Bill Carter: Television. [D8.]
With the help of American Express, New York City is starting a campaign to promote the city's "welcome home" parade in June for the troops in the Persian Gulf. Kim Foltz: Advertising. [D9.]
 
Today's Columns
HomeFed once appeared to be a case history of how savings and loan deregulation was supposed to work. But as the commercial real estate market fell on hard times, the company went into a sudden and steep dive. Market Place. [D6.]
Most credit market analysts say the recession is still very much with us, despite shreds of evidence that suggest otherwise. Hopes that a turnaround may begin in the current quarter are merely that, they say. Kenneth N. Gilpin: Credit Markets. [D7.]

HEADLINE: J. C. Hill, 76, Teacher; Led Arbitration Panel

 BODY:
James C. Hill, a former arbitrator of labor-management disputes in New York, died on Tuesday at a nursing home in Fort Myers, Fla. He was 76 years old and lived in Fort Myers.
Mr. Hill died of congestive heart failure, his daughter-in-law, Florence Bramley Hill, said. 
 He became a member of the National Academy of Arbitrators in the early 1950's, after working for the New York State Board of Mediation, and was its president in 1969. In the mid-1950's he went into private practice. He retired in the late 1970's.
Mr. Hill was a member of several Federal commissions appointed to determine minimum wages in Puerto Rico in 1954 to 1956 and in American Samoa in 1959 and 1960.
He was born in Richmond, and graduated from Swarthmore College in 1935. He studied at the London School of Economics, the University of Chicago and Columbia University, where he received an M.A. in economics.
Mr. Hill taught economics at Amherst, Sarah Lawrence, Columbia and Cornell and helped to found the Lower Bay School for West Indian children in Bequia in the Grenadines.
His wife, the former Ruth Mary Lewis, died on Feb. 6.
He is survived by two sons, both clinical psychologists, Dr. Lewis Hill of Staten Island and Dr. Emory Hill of Seattle; a daughter, Julia Hill of Miranda, Calif.; a brother, Walker, of Lansing, Mich., a retired English professor, and eight grandchildren.

HEADLINE: In Freeze's Wake, Desperation for Citrus Workers

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EXETER, Calif., April 5

 BODY:
Since they were youngsters, Jose and Delia Ayon toiled under the California sun to pick and pack the fruits and vegetables that fill American supermarkets. Now they cannot get enough food for their seven children, and they face losing the small house they built with their own hands.
The Ayons and thousands of other farm workers are part of a human calamity that is unfolding across the San Joaquin Valley in central California as a result of the freeze in December that destroyed the orange and lemon crops and put thousands out of work. 
 Eviction notices, foreclosures, desperation, shame and hunger are sweeping through communities like this, overwhelming relief workers.
"I have never seen anything like this before," said Lali Moheno, a community services aide who has spent 22 years working with migrant farm workers. "This is the first time I've wanted to quit work. We are physically worn out. None of us have ever experienced such a disaster."
Unlike earthquakes, floods and other disasters, the freeze has inflicted its devastation slowly. It is only now, as workers run out of savings and realize there will be little work for another year or more, that the enormity of their misfortune has begun to sink in.
Families, almost entirely Mexicans and Mexican-Americans, line up at a food bank here, one of 50 in Tulare County. They are so hungry that they can often be seen breaking open the weekly rations as they leave.
Leaders of FoodLink, the not-for-profit agency that supplies the banks, estimate that they provide only one-third of the food that is needed. They say infants lack adequate nourishment because mothers are using dried milk instead of formula, whose cost puts it out of their reach.
Particularly poignant is the plight of the thousands of Mexican families who, under terms of the amnesty granted under immigration law, are barred from applying for public assistance, including welfare and food stamps, for five years. Faced with hungry children, many have risked applying anyway, or have returned to Mexico.
 
Cooperation Had Been Rare
 The crisis has produced a level of cooperation between employers and workers that people on both sides say is without parallel in California agriculture in the last half-century. Within days of the freeze, an Agricultural Workers Freeze Relief Task Force was formed; it now includes 80 people representing 52 organizations and businesses in Tulare County. Owners of closed packing houses have solicited food donations throughout the state, and trucking companies have provided trucks to distribute it.
Help from the Federal Government has been slow, but now appears to be forthcoming. At the request of Gov. Pete Wilson, President Bush has declared a state of emergency in 33 counties, and officials here say that on Monday or Tuesday the President is expected to sign an order authorizing emergency housing aid for up to a year from the Federal Emergency Management Agency.
Housing has become the most critical issue as families are forced to double and triple up and landlords face foreclosure on loans.
Graphic reminders of the freeze, which hit from Dec. 21 to 25, are everywhere. Millions of navel and Valencia oranges lie rotting in the groves throughout Tulare, Fresno and Kern Counties, the center of the citrus industry. The loss to the growers was $500 million, and packers and shippers lost $500 million, said Curtis D. Lynn, Tulare County director for the University of California Cooperative Extension in Visalia.
Mr. Lynn estimates that the freeze killed 52 million cartons of navel oranges, 46 million cartons of Valencia oranges and 5 million cartons of lemons. He said there was extensive damage to other crops, including avocados, olives, pistachios, sugar beets and winter vegetables.
More than 15,000 pickers and packers were laid off almost immediately, and the ripple effect has been ruinous for groceries, restaurants, clothing stores and other businesses in Exeter and nearby towns, including Lindsay, Tulare and Visalia, the county seat.
Unemployment in Tulare Countywas 21.7 percent in February, compared with 12.3 percent a year ago.
That statistic includes Delia and Jose Ayon.
 
Watching Gains Disappear
 After years of deprivation, living in migrant camps and tiny, crammed apartments, the Ayons found a measure of dignity when they built their own house three years ago with help from a Government program for low-income people. Normally, this would be the busiest time of the year for Mr. Ayon, who used to earn about $300 a week plucking navel oranges from October until May, when the Valencias start.
But since Mr. Ayon was laid off in January, the family has relied on unemployment insurance and Aid to Families with Dependent Children, a Government program for low-income people. They are a month behind on paying the mortgage, $313 a month including taxes and insurance, and they talk of closing the house, pulling the children out of school and going to Oregon and Washington to pick cherries and apples this summer and fall.
"We don't want to lose this house," said Mrs. Ayon, as six of her seven children listened in their small living room. "Who will rent to seven kids? This place was like a palace for us."
Saving families like the Ayons from homelessness has become the top priority for United Way and other social-service agencies. "It has reached the breaking point," said Cathi Lamp, an economist and nutritionist at the cooperative extension and president of the FoodLink board. "Rent and utilities are the first priority; food is a close second. It's cheaper to keep them in their homes than to get back on their feet if they're homeless."
Carolyn Rose, executive director of Community Services and Employment Training, a private not-for-profit community action organization that operates in Tulare County, said that more than 2,700 families had requested help with housing and utility payments and that the agency could help only 200. She said landlords and lenders had been extraordinarily lenient but were close to exhausting their capacity.
In addition, utility companies have been quite generous, she said. The Pacific Gas and Electric Company, for example, has set up a special $25,000 fund to forgive the bills of the unemployed.
As for food, Sandy Beals, executive director of FoodLink for Tulare County, said the agency was stretched to the limit. "The typical family comes in and says it has no food," she said. "They get a 35-pound food basket for a week. For a family of eight, that does not last long. Children are going to school hungry."
Worker advocates have been moved at the response to the workers' troubles by employers like Sunkist Growers, LoBue Brothers and Shropshire Trucking, and by the Farm Bureau Federation, which represents growers. Relations between the bureau, as a representative of the employers, and labor representing the workers have often been bitter in previous years.
There have been other sources of help.
The Farmers Home Administration is offering low-interest loans to family farmers. The Federal Department of Agriculture's Food and Nutrition Service has provided nearly half of the food supply to FoodLink, as well as school lunches in Tulare County. And the Federal Labor Department has provided disaster unemployment assistance to workers ineligible for state unemployment benefits.
In all this, one group remains in limbo -- the thousands of Mexican families who claimed amnesty after the 1987 immigration law was enacted. They jeopardize their status here if they apply for many public assistance programs to cope with the freeze.
Soledad and Herminio Cruz, from Oaxaca state in southeastern Mexico, for example, have lived in Exeter for eight years, picking fruit. They took amnesty and two years ago bought a small house behind a chain-link fence on the edge of town, where they live with their four children, ages 15 months to 10 years. Mrs. Cruz is pregnant with a fifth child.
Given their immigration status, the Cruzes hesitated to apply for food stamps. But with no savings and a family of crying mouths, they risked it. The family is trying to decide whether to sell the house and return to Mexico for now.
Little relief is in sight.
Given the damage to the citrus trees, 60 percent to 70 percent of the usual crop is expected to be harvested later this year and next. This means that unemployment and deprivation will be the norm here long after the sun has warmed the orange and lemon groves of central California.

HEADLINE: For 7th Avenue's Garment Industry, Nowhere to Go but Up

BYLINE: By WOODY HOCHSWENDER

 BODY:
Designers worked late and ate deli. Stringbean-slim models hurried up and down in grimy freight elevators for last-minute fittings. Hems were pinned up and then let down again, as the garment center, New York's No. 1 manufacturing industry, cranked up and painted its face last week for another round of seasonal showings.
The fall fashion shows, which begin today and continue almost hourly throughout the week, come at a pivotal time for the industry, with some design companies hanging by their fingertips after a period of recession and international crisis. Executives say they are banking on lower prices, new styles and pent-up demand to lead the way for an industry recovery. 
 In fashion, where spring means it is time to think fall, hope also springs eternal. But behind the exhaust-smudged facades of Seventh Avenue, where impossibly pretty women slip in and out of incredibly expensive clothes, business has been bad. Fabulously bad.
 
Mainstay of Fashion Houses
 While the rest of the country sank into a recession, New York's garment industry seemed to go underwater. Industry executives said the fashion business was already in its own recession -- brought on by the stock-market crash and a wave of retail bankruptcies -- when the general recession hit the rest of the country.
Then the Persian Gulf war further chilled consumer demand, followed by more retail bankruptcies, including those of the Carter Hawley Hale stores in California and smaller clothing chains like Buffums in California, L. L. Berger in the Northeast and Mantaldo's in the Southeast. Small specialty stores like those are a mainstay of many fashion houses.
Some executives have been privately using the "D" word: depression.
Sales in stores that specialize in clothing were down nationally 3.3 percent in January, as against the same period last year, Census Bureau statistics show, and they declined 3 percent in February. In real terms, adjusting for inflation and price changes, the declines were 8.9 percent and 7.3 percent.
"Well before the recession women had already got out of the habit of shopping," Bill Blass said on Friday, as he put the finishing touches on his collection. "Even the very rich women I know got out of the habit."
But Mr. Blass said he had to put such thoughts out of mind for the moment, as he fitted a puffed silk skirt on Yasmeen Ghauri, a model.
 
Market Has Many Levels
 Assessments of New York's garment business tend to be somewhat impressionistic. There are many levels of the apparel market, from novelty T-shirts to designer collections, and it is difficult even to get a count, since many companies have multiple divisions operating in more than one country.
The American Association of Apparel Manufacturers, an industry group in Washington, estimates the total number of apparel makers in the United States at 10,000 to 12,000, with about 2,000 to 3,000 of them in New York. But the fashion houses whose styles determine what women will wear number a couple of dozen.
As a whole, the industry has clearly been hurting, especially in recent months. Unemployment in the industry -- the largest manufacturing employer in New York City -- was 12.3 percent in January, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, almost twice the overall national average.
"November and December were really grim," said Robert Duffy, the president of Perry Ellis Sportswear, as he wove his way among seamstresses stitching sequins onto dresses and workers installing a runway in the company's showroom for this evening's show. "January and February were terrible too. But in the last three weeks, sales have increased 50 percent. I'm confident."
While Perry Ellis plans a full-scale fashion show, with more than 100 styles, many smaller houses have curtailed their collections. Some of New York's rising stars, like Ronaldus Shamask, M. W. Moss, Badgley Mischka and Gordon Henderson, have canceled their fall shows. One of New York's brightest young designers, Patricia Clyne, has closed her doors.
The number of designers who show in the ballrooms of Fifth Avenue hotels, like the Plaza and the Pierre, is down by about half the usual, to three. The cost of mounting such shows is about $250,000 (one has to sell quite a few $2,000 dresses to net that much in profit).
But some industry executives have their periscopes up, looking for brightness on the horizon. For one thing, there were fewer American retailers at the fall fashion shows in Europe last month. But with so many retail buyers having stayed away from Milan, London and Paris, fashion houses here reason that the stores will have more money to order American clothes.
 
A Revolution in Pricing
 "It's an incredible opportunity for people who have their act together to make a killing," said Randolph Duke, a New York designer whose business doubled after a well-received spring collection. "With European prices high and buyers staying away from Europe, the money is going to be here."
There is also a not-so-quiet revolution in pricing going on. Many houses have introduced less-expensive lines with much fanfare in the last year, including Michael Kors and Anne Klein.
"Business is tough, but there seems to be a glimmer of hope," said Carolyne Roehm, who also plans to introduce a lower-priced collection. Even in their regular high-end collections, designers have held prices down by emphasizing less costly fabrics.
"I'm very conscious of prices now when I select the fabrics," said Calvin Klein, whose fall fashion show tomorrow will include a group of wool-and-Lycra pieces and another group in lamb's wool mixed with cashmere.
There has been wide apprehension in the industry that the retail climate has forced many marginal or undercapitalized companies out of business. There were 87 apparel-company business failures in New York City in 1990, up from 25 in 1989, according to statistics compiled by the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation. But there were also 87 such failures in 1988 and 80 in 1984.
"For New York City in 1990, it's not an unusual figure," said Tiziana Mohorovic, a business analyst with Dun & Bradstreet. "There was a dramatic increase in bankruptcy over all in 1990, in every major industry."
Businesses may be closing their doors, but that's nothing new on Seventh Avenue.
"I take bankruptcies with a grain of salt," said Bud Konheim, the president of Nicole Miller, which is holding a show on Wednesday. "All my life guys have been filing for bankruptcy on Seventh Avenue. We had the best year of our lives in 1990, and we're 50 percent ahead of last year right now."
Mr. Konheim, who has been in business in the garment center since 1955, said he believed a sea change in fashion and disruptions in the market had caused a shake-up in the industry.
In the 1970's, he said, most Seventh Avenue companies were domestic manufacturers. Toward the end of the decade, entrepreneurs began to discover Hong Kong, where a garment bought in a New York deparment store could be copied in vast quantities at low cost.
The result was a tremendous increase in products and labels, which coincided with the fast national expansion of many retailers. But as the prices in Hong Kong and other Asian manufacturing centers went up -- and the United States retail chains began to experience problems -- the fashion business found itself overproduced and with too many stores.
Executives also said hard times in the fashion business should be viewed in the context of an overall historical trend -- the shrinking of Seventh Avenue -- rather than as a sudden precipitous decline. As Walter Mankoff, the associate director of research for the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, noted, employment in the New York's apparel industry has been declining steadily for many years.
In fact, the city's manufacturing base was eroding even before the onslaught of inexpensive Asian imports in the 1970's and 80's, as the more casual styles of the 60's and 70's led to a departure of manufacturing jobs to regions like the South and California.
"This is about as bad as it has been," Mr. Mankoff said, referring to the plight of garment workers in the city.
One thing that will drive the business this fall, Mr. Klein said, is pent-up demand. "Women who work need clothes," he said. "I think people have held back because they felt it wasn't the moment to spend money. I think that's changing. I haven't felt this optimistic in years."

HEADLINE: New Assembly Hall Opening At the Brooklyn Museum

BYLINE: By GRACE GLUECK

 BODY:
Never mind the cuts in staff, the reductions in visiting hours, the pared-to-the-bone economies that the city's financial plight has thrust on it. Tomorrow there'll be joy at the Brooklyn Museum.
Thanks to a team of top-flight architects, a pair of angels who came up with $3.5 million, New York City's capital budget and private donors, the museum will open a brand-new auditorium, the first completed public space in its drive to carry out an ambitious master plan whose eventual cost museum officials say is impossible to estimate. 
 "It expresses our confidence in the future of the museum and of Brooklyn," said the museum's director, Robert T. Buck, who pointed out that the new hall was the first formal gathering place in the Beaux-Arts building since its original auditorium was converted into the present Grand Lobby more than 50 years ago.
A jewel among small assembly spaces in the city, the new auditorium -- on the third floor of the museum -- was designed by Arata Isozaki and James Stewart Polshek. It is only the second example in New York City of work by Mr. Isozaki, the eminent Japanese architect who designed the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles. In New York, he did the interior of the Palladium, a discotheque, in 1985.
"Our auditorium is the first new architecture worthy of the concepts of McKim, Mead & White, who designed the original museum in 1893," said Mr. Buck of the Isozaki-Polshek team.
The new hall is part of a three-stage renovation that has already provided new art storage space and is to result next year in three new floors of galleries in the old West Wing. The museum is strapped for operational funds; over the last year it has cut its visiting days to five a week from six, and has eliminated a number of staff positions, among them the curatorships of the print and costume departments. But so far, nearly $25 million of the $31 million needed for the renovation has been raised. Fourteen million dollars -- almost half of the $31 million total -- was allocated in the late 1980's from the city's capital budget, and the rest has come from individual donors and foundations. The auditorium was finished with a $3.5 million gift from Iris and B. Gerald Cantor, who have made previous donations to the Brooklyn and the Metropolitan museums. The auditorium will be named for the couple.
 
Undulations of Tranquillity
 "This is the first visible piece of a very grand master plan that could go over decades before being fully realized," said Mr. Polshek, "and so we felt it had to make some statement about optimism and the future, and it had to be very special in certain ways."
Although it is an intimate room, seating only 460 people, the auditorium gives an impression of grand space. Its most distinctive feature is a ceiling of white plaster composed of a series of rhythmic undulations -- technically described as intersecting hyperbolic paraboloids -- mathematically modeled by a computer. Mr. Isozaki has used the concept, which he said was intended to evoke tranquillity, in Japanese buildings. But the auditorium ceiling in Brooklyn is technically more complicated.
"For architects, it was just a doodle on a piece of paper," said Mr. Polshek. "But for acousticians it was a difficult mathematical exercise, and they bickered over it a good deal. The doubly warped surface could be compared with dozens of English horse saddles joined together, and sound bounces off it in ways that had to be calculated very carefully."
Even so, the auditorium will be used mainly for lectures, symposiums and film and video presentations, and thus does not have the rigorous acoustical requirements of a large performance space. The ceiling's sophisticated surface is complemented by such elegant design details as the series of lighting fixtures in stainless steel that project from the walls and carry out the ceiling's curve.
The walls and movable stage partitions are paneled in bleached oak, with the grain of each panel carefully matched to the next one, and outlined by stainless steel gridding. The stage's bow front is faced with stainless steel panels with a lustrous finish achieved by a process called shot-peening, normally used for jet engines and weaponry, in which the metal is blasted by small ceramic beads. The seats -- upholstered in mohair -- and the carpeting are a cool gray, intended to harmonize with the gunmetal color of the steel.
On the large stage, Joan Darragh, the vice president for architecture and planning at the museum, pointed with pride to the way the panels of the stage backdrop parted electronically to reveal a screen for films. The panels are controlled from what Ms. Darragh called a "state of the art" podium, a kind of command center veneered with silver bird's-eye maple from which light, sound and other effects can also be regulated. The new auditorium, which has one balcony, also has a projection room furnished with sophisticated equipment. The Cantor auditorium replaces the original 1,500-seat assembly hall, now the museum's ground-floor lobby. The change occurred in the mid-1930's, when the museum's grand exterior staircase, leading to a second-floor lobby, was removed in the interests of easier access.
Since then, the museum has made do with a temporary lecture hall carved out of a gallery known as the Renaissance Hall on the third floor. As part of the renovation phase, the hall has now been refitted to provide 10,000 square feet of high-technology storage for paintings, sculptures and costume items.
The success of the Isozaki-Polshek partnership, in which two renowned architects joined forces, is unusual in the field, Mr. Buck pointed out. The architects did not know each other well before each was invited to enter the museum's master plan competition in 1986. Since the competition required that a foreign architect join with a New York firm, Mr. Isozaki -- known for his museum work in Japan, and nearly finished with the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles -- approached Mr. Polshek's firm, James Stewart Polshek & Partners.
It was a fitting match, since Mr. Polshek is known for restoration work on historic buildings, and was at that time completing the renovation of Carnegie Hall. The two entered and won the competition as a joint venture.
"The big question was, what do you do inside one of this country's most distinguished Beaux-Arts buildings?" Mr. Polshek said. "Do you use a pastiche of the Beaux-Arts style, or post-modern gimmickry? That's where we brought different strengths and attitudes to this project."
The auditorium will undergo its first public use on Saturday, with a daylong symposium, "Albert Bierstadt: Art and Enterprise," and the first in a seven-part film retrospective in the evening, "William Greaves: Chronicler of the African-American Experience."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert T. Buck, rear, director of the Brooklyn Museum, with B. Gerald and Iris Cantor in the museum's new auditorium. The auditorium was finished with a $3.5 million gift from the Cantors. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL '91BASEBALL '91;
Let the Bats and Patriotism Ring to Celebrate a New Season

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY

 BODY:
There is always an urgency for the dawning of the major league baseball season. Adults call in sick for work and sneak away to the ball park on opening day. Children buy fresh packs of baseball cards. Presidents throw out first balls.
Ever-expanding newspaper box scores are devoured and the optimistic talk about this player and that team, which dominated winter conversations and shortened cold nights, becomes real or idealistic in scenes on the diamonds before us. 
 When the first pitch of the season is thrown this afternoon in Detroit, in one of the eight games scheduled to be played, the urgency to sing the national anthem, join the seventh-inning stretch and revel in the charms of baseball may be more fervent than ever before.
 
The Time Is Right
 There is reason to stand and rejoice, what with the United States beaming over its victory in the Persian Gulf war and the economy apparently rounding into shape. Most of the memories of last year's lockout and the travails of Pete Rose and George Steinbrenner, which tarnished the season and made it ugly, have been purged.
What better time for baseball to come swinging back into our consciousness? And interest this season seems boundless.
The Mets expect to be sold out for today's opener with the Philadelphia Phillies at Shea Stadium and the Yankees could sell out their home opener next Monday with the Chicago White Sox.
 
Increased Ticket Sales
 Of the 26 major league teams, more than half have maintained or increased their season-ticket sales; there are about 50 hardcover baseball books being released this spring; USA Today introduced a weekly newspaper devoted strictly to baseball last Friday, and six cities are feverishly battling for the right to pay $95 million and become home for the two expansion teams that the National League adds in 1993.
Miami, one of those cities involved in the fight, drew 125,013 fans to two exhibition games at Joe Robbie Stadium last weekend. And the rarest baseball card in the world, a 1909 Honus Wagner, was recently purchased for $451,000. Interest? More like infatutaion.
A childlike quality has even been injected into the business of baseball cards. In honor of its 40th anniversary, Topps has inserted one of every card it has ever made in random packs. Never able to get that 1952 Mickey Mantle? Now is your chance to search for it again, a la Willie Wonka.
"People need to relax after the war and get back to basics," said Don Lepore, a baseball-card dealer from Jersey City. "They can buy a box of Cracker Jack, see what the prize is, have a few hot dogs and maybe a beer. It's relaxing. It's like going fishing."
 
Timeless and Magical
 "If you're a fan, you look forward to it an awful lot," said Richard Herrnstein, a psychologist at Harvard University. "It's an escape. Most people can't wait to get lost in a good ball game."
Although the umpires may be off the job and $5 million contracts are the latest craze -- even though homeless people who long for $5 sleep inside cardboard boxes within a sacrifice bunt of Yankee Stadium -- and Lenny Dykstra had some gambling problems and Rickey Henderson has an attitude problem, fans still love the players and the game.
How quickly they forget that a lockout spoiled spring training and delayed opening day by a week last year. The lockout ended, baseball resumed and fans returned. Just like they always do.
 
Increasing Excitment
 "It keeps you coming back for more," said Dr. Bobby Brown, the American League president. "You sit in comfort, you munch peanuts, you talk to friends. With the progression of time, you observe the excitement increase until that is what consumes you."
Opening day 1991 will be a celebration of patriotism, with virtually every team offering some sort of tribute to the troops; from flag ceremonies, to having members of the military throw out the first ball, to singing the national anthem the way Whitney Houston would.
President Bush will participate in the first ball ceremonies at Arlington Stadium in Texas tonight with Shane Wood, 13 years old. Even though he was born without hands, Shane plays soccer and football and will play baseball for the first time soon with the aid of a specially designed glove that looks like a lacrosse stick. The teen-ager may challenge Bush for the longest ovation. The President's son, George W., is the general partner of the team.
 
Thirst for the Game
 Herrnstein said he did not think American success in the war and the improving economy made the beginning of the season any more urgent. He reminisced to tougher times in World War II and said people thirsted for baseball amid the gloom then.
"If the economy had been getting worse and the war was still on, people would think the start of the baseball season would make them feel better," he said. "Don't you think so? When spring starts, ball fans are looking forward to baseball."
After he speculated that there is no greater interest in baseball this season than in other years, it took one simple question to turn Herrnstein from psychologist to fan. Asked if he was looking forward to opening day, he said: "I can hardly wait for it to start. The Red Sox look really good this year."

HEADLINE: Tough Solutions for Connecticut

 BODY:
From sea to shining sea, governors are grappling with steep budget problems, none steeper than Connecticut's. Faced with a deficit that's one-third of the whole budget, and still growing, Gov. Lowell Weicker has ordered that 2,600 state workers be laid off, and most state agencies shut down for two days a month. Mr. Weicker has always talked tough. Now he's acting, and none too soon.
Connecticut's problem isn't different from other states', just worse. Like many states -- and many businesses -- Connecticut was careless in the 1980's, riding the boom as if it would last forever. In the last five years, the state payroll has grown by 12 percent, salaries and benefits by 53 percent, and grants to towns by 81 percent. The state sank deeper into debt while recklessly neglecting to make sure there would be enough revenue when the good times ended. 
 The deficit for the remaining three months of fiscal 1990-91 and all of 1991-92 is now estimated at $2.6 billion. It grows with every new estimate, because tax collections are weak and outlays for Medicaid and welfare are rising. Other states have bigger deficits, but Connecticut's beats all in relation to its overall $7.5 billion budget. To close the gap, Mr. Weicker wants a single-rate tax on personal income of 6 percent, reductions in other taxes and spending cuts of $1.2 billion.
The idea of an income tax isn't popular, but it is better than any other revenue ideas that have surfaced so far. Milking more revenue from the sales tax is out of the question; at 8 percent, it's already the nation's highest. Indeed, Mr. Weicker proposes to cut it almost in half, and to cut the corporate profits tax, also the nation's highest, and eliminate the separate taxes on income from dividends, interest and capital gains.
The state's major business associations have swung behind the Weicker tax plan, and with good reason; it's good economics and it directly benefits business. But they also want firm controls on future spending growth -- a reasonable demand in light of the state's profligate past.
Whatever the outcome, legislation takes time. Meanwhile, Mr. Weicker must cope with a growing deficit. He asked the state unions for $400 million in concessions, largely by freezing wages, increasing employee contributions for health insurance and stretching out state payments to their pension fund -- all reasonable under the circumstances. Unable to get agreement, he initiated the new layoffs, adding to 900 he had already ordered.
The extra layoffs are not final; the unions can still negotiate concessions instead. But the Governor's message is commendably clear: it's time to settle.

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate: Don't Overreact

 BODY:
Last week the Labor Department announced that the unemployment rate jumped to 6.8 percent in March, its highest level in more than four years. About 2 million Americans have lost their jobs since last summer, more than 700,000 since January.
Along with the bad news came a cascade of sour predictions that a quick end to the recession "is not in sight." That may be so, but the unemployment rate is about the last place to look. The rate is included in the Government's index of lagging indicators -- meaning that the unemployment rate keeps rising even after the recession is over. 
 As the economy begins to recover, companies typically raise production without adding to their payrolls. New hires take place only after employers are convinced the recovery will last.
Even though it gives unclear signals about the economy, the bad employment news will spark renewed calls for the Federal Reserve Board to lower interest rates. But the Fed is caught in a tight bind. Unemployment is rising, which calls for stimulating the economy by printing more money; but inflation is nastily persistent, which rules against more money.
At this juncture, the best reaction is the least reaction. For more than a year, the Fed allowed the growth rate of the money supply to fall short of targeted levels; that failure is one reason for the recession. But of late the Fed has set money growth rates much higher.
For now, that's enough. Sound policy does not react to last week's job figures or this week's inflation numbers: such figures are an unreliable guide to the economy's needs. Maybe the Fed agrees: following the Labor Department's announcement, it did nothing special.

HEADLINE: How to Save Money in New York City

BYLINE: By Roger C. Altman and Donald D. Kummerfeld; Roger C. Altman was Assistant Secretary of the Treasury in the Carter Administration. Donald D. Kummerfeld was First Deputy Mayor under Abraham D. Beame.

 BODY:
New Yorkers are bombarded with daily accounts of the city's purported collapse. City Hall is accused of incompetence. Business and labor are said to be fleeing or ripping off the city. The public and private cooperation that rescued the city in the 1970's is deemed history.
These apocalyptic views are highly exaggerated. Today's fiscal crisis, like the last one, creates opportunities for long overdue changes. City Hall has recognized this, and budget and management reforms are emerging. If Mayor David N. Dinkins steps up the pace, government can be downsized without eliminating essential services and driving away businesses with ruinous tax increases. 
 For three months, we have been co-chairmen of a team of labor, business and city leaders appointed by the Mayor whose mission is to help work out downsizing efficiently and humanely. This panel has prepared an initial three-part package of reforms, which the Mayor is evaluating.
The first proposal would improve health care for the poor while eventually saving huge Medicaid sums. New York now provides $2 billion in annual Medicaid reimbursements; this amount, nearly 10 percent of total city spending, represents the fastest growing part of the budget. This expensive care is inadequate. Too often, the only medical service is found in a municipal hospital's emergency room, where no one knows a patient's history. This results in duplicating earlier diagnoses, overprescribing drugs and no medical follow-up.
Managed care has been instituted by 27 states. Patients must choose from designated outpatient or acute-care facilities -- an approach that promotes a one-to-one doctor-patient relationship, with the prospect of better care. It saves big money: California's Medicaid expenditures per capita are half of New York State's.
A managed-care project in Brooklyn hospitals and clinics for up to 35,000 Medicaid patients has received state approval and is ready to begin. Some oppose any approach that requires the poor to use these centers, arguing that it limits their freedom of choice. Neither the poor nor the city can afford to accept this ideology. The project must proceed, we must learn from its results and then we must extend managed care as widely as possible. Conceivably, the state and city could each save $500 million annually after five years.
Second, the city's seven economic development agencies should be consolidated. Modest budgetary savings aside, eliminating duplication and defining the benefits each office provides will improve service to business. Perennial proposals for consolidation always fall victim to turf wars, but with severe budget cuts ahead attitudes are changing.
Third, the city payroll must be cut. The latest plan calls for many layoffs, almost 8,000 in education. But they are the most expensive way to reduce personnel. With unemployment insurance and other severance benefits, it costs $7,000 to lay off a teacher.
One downsizing technique is early-retirement incentives. The city must lay off two teachers to realize the savings yielded by one retirement. If the right retirement incentives were offered before the school year ends in June, perhaps half the projected layoffs could be avoided before school resumes. There is no free lunch: Only increased pension benefits will induce an abnormally high rate of retirement. But the plan's savings and costs are balanced over the long run.
Other panel reforms are in the development stage. It is too early to judge their feasibility, but they do illustrate a potential for savings.
The city could find the cash to fix decrepit, undermaintained bridges by placing tolls on at least six East River and Harlem River bridges that now charge nothing. The revenues would support proper maintenance of all 800 city bridges as well as repair and construction of streets and highways. While environmental and congestion issues are involved, an early look suggests they may be surmountable.
How about privatizing the Sanitation Department -- that is, creating a self-financed corporation or authority? Sanitation spending would be removed from the budget; households would pay a monthly garbage collection charge just as they do for other utilities. This revenue would permit the sanitation authority to finance desperately needed new solid-waste disposal facilities, a burden that the city may otherwise be unable to handle. We would all pay more for sanitation, but we're going to do so anyway through rising taxes.
All of these structural reforms involve excruciating choices. But Mayor Dinkins has been supportive of our panel to date, and we believe he is ready to make the decisions needed to carry out major changes.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed
