HEADLINE: In Tennis, Child Prodigies Whet the Agents' Appetites

BYLINE: By ROBIN FINN

 BODY:
The next time an ambitious parent hangs a cute tennis mobile above a child's crib the way Andre Agassi's father once did, there could very well be an agent standing by to jiggle it with one hand and sign the prodigy to a business contract with the other.
In the tennis industry there is a veritable race to rob the cradle. 
 This winter, John Evert, an agent for the International Management Group as well as the younger brother of the tennis doyenne Chris Evert, flew across the country to Los Angeles on a mission after hearing of a 10-year-old who can be marketed as what her father describes as a ghetto Cinderella.
 
The Latest Prodigy
 Venus Williams, a fifth grader who practices on pockmarked public courts in Compton, Calif., with an unappealing assortment of ne'er-do-wells in the audience, wants to be an astronaut. But because she has already been appropriated as this nation's next great tennis prodigy, any career plans that do not involve becoming another of the sport's teen-age millionaires may be put on hold.
The appetite of the tennis business for newcomers grows more voracious every time a Michael Chang or Arantxa Sanchez Vicario or Pete Sampras or Monica Seles becomes a teen-age Grand Slam champion. Pure youth is in demand, as attested by the $10 million in franchise fees that 14-year-old Jennifer Capriati collected last year even without advancing beyond the semifinals of a Grand Slam event.
"The sporting goods companies are looking for the rarity, and being a minority athlete, Venus could have it made," said Nick Bollettieri, the entrepreneur whose intensive tennis training camps have gained worldwide attention for the young stars they produce, as well as a serious inquiry from the Williams family.
At least, that is what a platoon of tennis agents has communicated to Venus and, more directly, to her parents.
 
Too Young to Turn Pro?
 "And until you have experienced the sensation of having somebody sitting across the table from you and waving a check for a million dollars in your face if you'll just let them sign your kid to a contract, you can't really be judgmental about what some of these parents go through," Bollettieri said.
"I happen to think 10 or 12 is too young to turn professional, with one exception: if by doing that, an entire family that truly needs the money will benefit, I can understand it. But I'd still rather see them get the help they need in another way."
Richard and Oracene Williams's reedy little girl is indeed just 10. But the recruiting agents for tennis's triumvirate of marketeers, International Management Group, ProServ and Advantage International, as well as some of Bollettieri's European counterparts, have all already descended, carrying contracts instead of corsages, to court her favors.
 
Puzzled and Exhilarated
 "We've been offered millions of dollars, from homes to cars to anything you can name," said Richard Williams, who is both puzzled and exhilarated by the attention his daughter has received.
"I've talked to everybody, but I've signed with nobody," he maintained. "If we sign her to a professional contract when she's 10, what will she do between now and when she's 13, when she can actually play the professional circuit? I don't want her to peak at 12 and fall to pieces at 15. There's still a lot of ifs here. I've been broke all my life, and Venus doesn't want to be poor, but nobody in this house is going to push our daughter into anything."
Slade Mead, who scouts for Advantage, the smallest of the three prime agencies, advocates a truce among recruiters: drawing an age line on the signing of pre-teens. "It's gotten to the point where it almost seems pedophilic, to be sitting there telling a 12-year-old and his parents about the money you can make them," he said.
"I don't think we're vultures," said Patricio Apey of ProServ. Apey represents MaliVai Washington, who turned pro after his sophomore year at the University of Michigan when he was the top collegiate player in the country.
"When he was deciding whether to turn pro or go to school, with my ProServ hat on, I had to tell him to turn pro, but with my friend hat on, I had to tell him to try college, so what I ultimately did was stay out of it and he and his family made the decision," Apey said. "But there's a lot of parents, especially outside of North America, who aren't considering college as an option, who see tennis as a way for their kid to make a million dollars."
If this nation is mercenary, the rest of the world, say the agents, is even worse.
"In Europe you've got 12-year-olds shopping around for financial assistance," Mead said. "I'll have somebody's father turn to me and say, 'I.M.G. offered me X, what can you give me?' "
 
Never 'Too Young'
 Last year Mead traveled to France in a vain attempt to head off I.M.G. after learning that a 12 1/2-year-old Swedish prospect, Magnus Norman, was about to turn professional.
"I had spoken with his parents before, in Sweden, but at the time they seemed reluctant," he said. "I didn't want to sit in a snowbank outside their house pestering them, but obviously someone else did. These days there's no such thing as too young."
Where this recruiting trend will end is uncertain.
"The next thing you know we'll be running into each other in the maternity ward at the hospital outside the incubators," Apey said.
Venus Williams, who epitomizes this trend, hasn't yet played the Orange Bowl, Easter Bowl or Junior Wimbledon, but already in addition to her growing reputation as a potential commercial gold mine, she is an anathema to her peers on Southern California's junior tennis circuit, where she usually eliminates the other 10- and 12-year-olds by merciless 6-0, 6-0 margins.
She has hit with John McEnroe and Pete Sampras and didn't believe it when her father told her, "Mr. McEnroe took it easy on you."
 
Moving Up to the 16's
 "She told me she thought she should have beaten him," said Richard Williams, who considers himself "the quarterback" of his daughter's career and plans to move her this summer from the 10's, where she is ranked No. 1, to the 16's.
Venus is, according to her proud father, as wise off the court as on it, which is why he is considering having her skip junior high school altogether. Under that plan, Venus could be finished with high school and ready for the pro circuit, or college, by the time she's 14.
"It just so happens that Venus is a like a rose, and right now she's only budding," said Williams, whose daughter impressed Jimmy Evert, father and former coach of Chris, during a doubles exhibition in Florida.
"Tennis is one of my dreams, but I'm dreaming about getting a good education so I have something to back my life up besides becoming a professional," Venus said. "Tennis is fun right now and, yes, maybe I could see doing it as my job."
For now, Venus practices her tennis not in some plush tennis laboratory but on a court whose net is patched and preserved by chains, and she does her homework in a neighborhood where graffiti are spray-painted onto front doors, not drizzled prettily across the front of designer tennis shirts. But not for long.
"It can turn out to be a Cinderella story for Venus," said her father, who operates a security guard service in addition to his duties as Venus' primary coach. "I know she wants to be a role model for what a girl from this kind of background can achieve if she works hard enough. We put God first, then comes the family, her education, and her tennis. Who wouldn't want a million dollars?
"But I need a healthy daughter more than I need a million dollars. We want to handle this right. I don't want to see her standing on some street corner, broke, and with no education to save her, when she's 17, which is what you see happen to a lot of the black kids who don't make it."
 At 5 feet 4 inches, her limbs as lithe and spiky as the tiny braids that crown her head, Venus Williams has been described as a young Michael Jordan: a natural athlete who, although not bigger and brawnier than the competition, somehow manages to jump higher, hit harder, and cover the court with the agility of a bird in flight. As is the fashion, she takes the ball on the rise, pouncing forward from the baseline itself rather than waiting behind it. Her topspin forehand is her biggest weapon, and the shot is all the more effective because of the solid, steady two-handed backhand she has in reserve for those moments when she feels she can't risk a mistake on a winner. Already at 10, her strokes are technically sound, her court coverage impeccable.
Asked what her favorite part of the game was, Venus said, "Return of serve because you get to take control of the court from your opponent."
Zina Garrison, the top black player in the country, looked in on Venus last fall and pronounced her "the best 10-year-old I've ever seen."
Bollettieri, coach and mentor of Andre Agassi and countless other up-and-comers, agrees. He has Adidas and Donnay, two major manufacturers of sporting goods, ready and willing to outfit Venus for her climb to the top. At the moment, the companies would do it without compensation; in the future, the price would be her endorsement of their product.
"She's unbelievable, and her mentality, unbelievable, she's very bright," said Bollettieri, who invited the Williams family to visit his Bradenton headquarters with Venus and her sister Serena, who at 9 is also considered a prime prospect.
"But no matter how much potential she has, I would hesitate to say that 10 is the right time to turn pro," Bollettieri said. In any event, Venus cannot compete on the circuit until she is 13 -- unless the rules are modified for her as they were last year for Capriati.
John Evert, Capriati's agent at I.M.G., came away impressed from his junket to California, where Richard Williams squired him around town in the family's trusty but rusty van.
"She's as talented as any 10-year-old I ever saw, and I'd like to sign any young prospect who could turn out to be great," said Evert, who signed Capriati at 12 and Mary Joe Fernandez at 13. "I don't look at them and say I think they've been mismanaged, in terms of turning pro too early, but 10 is too early. Then again, that's really up to the parents."
 According to Evert, Capriati's decision to turn professional while still an eighth grader was based on lack of competition as well as economics.
"If the player has nothing more to gain at the junior level, do you make them continue to play at a level they've already dominated just for the sake of retaining the right to receive a college scholarship?" Evert said. "The deals Jennifer has made will pay for 10 college scholarships."
Capriati was the exemplar of what is fast becoming a rule around women's tennis: If you aren't signed and circuit-compatible by 15, you're considered over-the-hill.

HEADLINE: WASHINGTON AT WORK;
Hollywood's Man on the Hill Still Spinning a Web

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 7

 BODY:
Two months ago, word on the street was that Jack Valenti, a man many consider one of the best lobbyists in the capital, might be losing his magic.
It looked like the Hollywood movie studios, which Mr. Valenti represents, would be unable to keep their rights to reruns of television programs they produce, and thus would lose hundreds of millions of dollars. 
 But Mr. Valenti, the longtime head of the Motion Picture Association of America and former aide to President Lyndon B. Johnson, is likely to have pulled one more trick out of his bag.
While the Federal Communications Commission is expected Tuesday to give television networks rights in the lucrative rerun market, it is also expected to preserve important protections for the movie studios
And Mr. Valenti can spin a victory out of containing the losses as proof of his skills.
 
Civility Missing in Capital
 But the seriousness of the networks' challenge -- so deftly rebuffed a decade ago that his rivals still reel at the memory -- heralds a rougher era of lobbying, an era that Mr. Valenti laments as showing a shrinking of the "assumed civility" of his early days in the capital.
"We almost made a deal with the networks in April of last year, and I'm convinced that the sole reason that we didn't make that deal was that a couple of the networks believed that they could do better at the F.C.C. than they could at the negotiating table," said the silver-haired, dapper Mr. Valenti as he sat on the edge of a chair in his book-lined office. While the F.C.C. commissioners are "intelligent and thoughtful," he went on, they do not know the syndication business.
"It's a complex, complicated business," he said. "It's nooks and crannies that many people haven't explored. To the uninitiated the corridors are ill lit and you have to be kind of an old Indian scout who knows all the byways to know what the hell you're doing."
Mr. Valenti's opponents give him a grudging respect, often tinctured with amazement that, after 25 years, he is still weaving a web in Washington's power portals without getting brushed off.
 
'Teaching the Rest of Us'
 "He's neither Custer nor Sitting Bull in this battle," said Jay L. Kriegel, a senior vice president at CBS, in the tones of an actor forced to compliment a rival. "He'll still be teaching the rest of us years from now. He remains the master."
The 69-year-old Mr. Valenti presents himself as a diffident, old-fashioned gentleman who is only doing his helpful best for an industry he loves. Indeed, he tells a visitor that he is not a lobbyist, that he has lobbyists working for the Motion Picture Association, that, yes, he could have been a lobbyist, that he has had several offers to be a lobbyist and could make two or three times as much as the nearly $700,000 salary he does make. But, he said frankly, what has always motivated him is fun and working with creative people.
Mr. Valenti's conversation, like his arguments for maintaining the status quo on syndication rights, is erudite, spiked with references to Francis Bacon and underpinned with appeals to the sensible, the reasonable, the patriotic and the aesthetic. His opponents, he intimates, are his opposites, users of crass tactics, something, he implies, he is incapable of but willing to forget in others.
In a Texas accent scrubbed almost clean of drawl after two decades on the East Coast, he said: "We've fought hard -- and I have not been happy with the scorched-earth policy that they have been pursuing -- but I'm a great believer again, from my L.B.J. days, that you put that all behind you and try and find a solution that's in the public interest and fair to both sides."
One network lobbyist, who scoffed at Mr. Valenti's portrayal of himself as a gallant protecting American freedoms, suggested that the studios ought to erect a Valenti statue on Rodeo Drive. But it would have to be a statue that in recent months has taken some nicks.
Earlier this year, when his lobby tactics appeared in the news media, Mr. Valenti looked as heavy-handed as any novice. A serious gaffe occurred when he wanted the White House to disavow one sentence in President Bush's annual Economic Report that appeared to be sympathetic to the networks on syndication rights. He dispatched two lieutenants -- Craig Fuller, who was Mr. Bush's chief of staff when Mr. Bush was Vice President, and Kenneth L. Duberstein, Ronald Reagan's last chief of staff -- to talk to White House officials.
The offending sentence was reworked. A leak to The Los Angeles Times prompted the headline, "White House Backs Down on Syndication Rules."
Not surprisingly, the White House was upset. John H. Sununu, Mr. Bush's chief of staff, let it be known that the President had an "aversion to unnecessary Government interference with private markets."
 
Distance From Leak
 Mr. Valenti said he did not know how the news reached The Los Angeles Times, but he was quick to dissociate himself from it.
"As I told a high-ranking official in the White House, I said I worked in the White House for three years," he said. "I know how the White House works, I know how a President feels and how his aides feel. I will confess to a number of flaws, personal and professional, but I think the one thing you can't say about me is that I'm dumb.
"Obviously this was an ambush. But I understand that, that's the way this game is played so you go on to other things."
Perhaps, but the recent clashes are a far cry from Mr. Valenti's slick dismemberment of the repeal in 1983 of syndication rights that the networks had managed to obtain.
His weapon was Lew Wasserman, head of MCA and the very man who in 1966 had hired Mr. Valenti. Mr. Wasserman, it turned out, was an old friend and the former agent of President Reagan. The deregulation President overruled the deregulation.
 
Longing for Johnson Era
 Mr. Valenti seems wistful for an era when the game was more secure, and when power on Capitol Hill was concentrated in the hands of a few committee chairman, the era, in other words, of his mentor, Lyndon Johnson.
"Washington has changed a lot," he said. "There is more surliness and torment. I lament when I see somebody who as, Lyndon Johnson would say, 'cuts and runs.' I may be wrong, I may lose every now and then, on an issue I really believe in, but I don't believe my worst enemies would say that I lied and cheated or went back on my word."
What Mr. Valenti may also be lamenting is the erosion of his most potent argument: that the movie industry is a uniquely American enterprise. Four of the seven major studios are now owned by foreign companies. Increasingly, over the last several years, too, the movie industry itself has developed fragmented and competing interests -- Time Warner now owns cable and 20th Century Fox now owns a television network, putting it in the television camp on the syndication issue.
The opposition, too, has changed. It is full of hot-shot young lawyers and executives who are not afraid to cross lines in the sand or knock pebbles off shoulders.
"It's a far more competitive environment," said Lloyd Hand, a Valenti friend from the Johnson White House and a lawyer who finds himself on the opposite side of the fence, one of team that represents NBC. "That he is a focal point may be a saving grace to an industry, which is changing itself and not always sure what it wants done."
 
Enjoying the Fight
 The initial uncertainty over the syndication rights fueled rumors that Mr. Valenti might be forced to relinquish his post. But Mr. Valenti said those kinds of things do not bother him. Actually, he said, he has enjoyed the current dustup.
"I still have fun," he said. "I thoroughly enjoy a challenge and a fight. I think I'd be bored with serenity. The adrenelin runs and sometimes there's anxiety but that keeps your nerve edges taut."
Growing up in a poor neighborhood in Houston, Mr. Valenti said he always hoped for a career in public life. Portentously, he got his first job as a theater usher at age 15. He worked his way through the University of Houston and then went to work in advertising for the Humble Oil Company, and after service in World War II, got an M.B.A. from Harvard University. Back in Houston as an advertising man during the 1950's he wrote some speeches and became an unofficial adviser to Lyndon Johnson, then a Senator.
When President John F. Kennedy was assassinated on Nov. 22, 1963, Mr. Valenti was riding in the motorcade. Summoned by the newly sworn-in President, Mr. Valenti was "ordered" to Washington and the Johnson White House.
Mr. Valenti credits President Johnson with imparting the technique that has enabled him to seemingly tiptoe across 25 years as head of the Motion Picture Association.
"I never speculate, win or lose," he said. "Somebody says, 'You got the votes?' I don't know. All I know is that I'm doing everything that is humanly possible."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 13, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about Jack Valenti, head of the Motion Picture Association of America, misstated the White House response to a lobbying effort this year by representatives of Mr. Valenti, who was seeking to have the Administration change its annual Economic Report. Mr. Valenti had protested that the report favored his opponents, the television networks, in a dispute over the rights to sell television reruns. The White House response was to issue a public statement saying that the matter would be decided by the Federal Communications Commission. It did not change the report.

HEADLINE: CAREERS;
An Appraisal Of Top-Level Job Seekers

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
CANNY, BOWEN INC., a management recruiting firm based in New York, decided to survey high-level executives who had sent in their resumes. It took the step after receiving about a thousand resumes a week since the late fall.
The firm, which specializes in recruiting top executives, said the deluge was about three times the rate received a year earlier. 
 From its pool of unsolicited resumes, Canny, Bowen mailed questionnaires to a sample of 160 executives and received 100 replies. About 80 percent of the executives signed the questionnaires, though they were told they could remain anonymous,
For years management recruiters insisted that they had seldom filled jobs from among the ranks of unemployed executives or those who were about to lose their jobs. Now, with so much talent out of work, recruiters look upon unsolicited resumes more kindly.
Sometimes the names of those who submit unsolicited resumes are put into data banks, and the executives are occasionally offered as candidates to client companies.
Unfortunately, said David R. Peasback, Canny, Bowen's president, few of the job seekers who had sent unsolicited resumes could expect help from his firm.
The executives who responded to the survey had been working an average of 22 years since college or graduate school, indicating that they were in their mid-40's. Compensaton ranged from $150,000 to $350,000 a year.
About 30 percent said they had lost their jobs because of downsizing, 19 percent said they had disagreed with corporate strategy and 17 percent reported they were disgruntled because a new superior had been appointed over them. An additional 15 percent said their companies had been acquired, and 15 percent cited dissatisfaction over a change in responsibilities.
Mr. Peasback was surprised that few had said their compensation was unsatisfactory and that even fewer had objections to relocating.
Most of the job-seeking executives reported relatively generous severance packages: 31 percent reported severance of six or more months, while 44 percent indicated they had received or would receive a full year's pay or more.
At many companies severance typically runs about two weeks for each year on the payroll, but employment contracts, which some executives have, often include generous severance payments even for a short stint with a company.
"I don't think many respondents had employment contracts," Mr. Peasback said.
Despite the state of the economy, 41 percent of the job hunters said they had turned down offers, but about a third acknowledged that they had been rejected for what they had considered attractive openings.
The executives were asked what they would have changed in their careers. Some regretted that they had not done more networking -- building lists of acquaintances who could help them find a new job. Others wished they had earned an advanced degree.
Mr. Peasback was surprised that only a few of the executives had done much planning for career changes.
One respondent said: "I should have chosen my job based on people and the chemistry between them. I made the mistake of taking a position based upon analysis of the company's potential -- not people and management."
"Politics within a company," Mr. Peasback said, "can be deadly to an executive's career and always will be."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Saatchi Wins Back Britain's Conservatives

BYLINE: By Kim Foltz

 BODY:
SAATCHI & SAATCHI'S flagship London office has won back the estimated $40 million account for Britain's Conservative Party.
The victory is particularly significant because Saatchi's innovative advertising not only helped put former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in power in 1979, but it also created a name for the agency, which was little known at the time. 
 One ad that caught much attention was a billboard showing a long line of unemployed workers under the headline "Labor doesn't work," referring to the Labor Party's inability to check runaway unemployment.
The agency's close relationship with Mrs. Thatcher is widely credited with making Saatchi important friends in the London financial community and helping it find the money for its rapid acquisition of agencies in the United States. Saatchi's main holdings in New York include Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide and Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising.
Saatchi had resigned the account in 1987, after the Conservative Party began consulting other agencies for advice about its campaign for the general election. At the time, agency executives in London said party officials were not happy with Saatchi's strategy.
Saatchi had also lost a crucial executive, Tim Bell, who had worked on the Conservatives' campaign from the start and had close ties to Mrs. Thatcher.
Since then, the party had consulted with various agencies for specific projects but had not had an agency of record, said David Marshall, a Conservative Party spokesman.
After Mrs. Thatcher stepped down in November and John Major became the Prime Minister, the party decided it again needed a full-time agency, Mr. Marshall said.
The Conservatives picked Saatchi because officials thought it was the kind of agency the party needed now, Mr. Marshall said. "We'll be facing a tough battle from the Labor Party in the next general election," he said.
The Government must hold an election no later than June 1992, but some Saatchi executives said the election could come as soon as this October.
Picking up the Conservatives' account gives Saatchi a much-needed lift. The London advertising industry has been mired in a severe slump for more than a year, and like most agencies there Saatchi has found big new accounts scarce.
In addition, some Saatchi executives said the victory was confirmation that the London office was back after a group of its top executives left last year to start their own agency.

HEADLINE: Terrorism Jolts a Prospering Chile

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 5

 BODY:
A new nervousness has gripped the business community in Chile this week over whether the recent spate of terrorist actions will upset the political stability of the country and threaten the Chilean economic miracle.
Chile has built the most successful economy in Latin America, and one of the vital underpinnings of that growth was the open economic environment created by the former military dictator, Gen. Augusto Pinochet. In the year since the country's transition to a democratic Government the economy has continued to grow and foreign investment has continued to pour in. 
 But the killing on Monday of one of the country's most prominent senators, the fourth killing in the last six weeks, is raising questions about the ability of the country -- and the economy -- to stay on course.
 
Executives Fearful
 "Chile has a prosperous economy," the country's Treasury Minister, Alejandro Foxley, said this week, "but the point of vulnerability is terrorism and the problem of personal security."
Businessmen are loath to speak publicly about the problem, out of fear of offending the Government. But privately they express concerns that foreign investors will pull out of the country, to avoid attacks on themselves and their property. And foreign investment is a critical ingredient of the economy's growth.
Some say they believe that the Government of President Patricio Aylwin has finally decided to take harsh steps against terrorism, but that it will take time to see whether the battle against political violence has been won. "I think it's just too early to tell," said one American banker who insisted that neither his name nor his bank's be used. "We're rooting for Aylwin to come down strong on the terrorists."
The violence is one of the few clouds on Chile's economic horizon. While there had been some doubts about whether President Aylwin would continue the open market policies that had fostered the growth, the last 12 months have been reassuring to the business community.
It is not that President Aylwyn has left the Pinochet economy untouched. He cut the central bank free from the rest of the Government. He raised taxes on business to help pay for more social programs. He lifted the minimum wage, raising the cost of labor.
Although some of these adjustments tilt away from the Pinochet Government's fixation with free markets and to a new emphasis on social programs, so far the basic thrust of the open economy -- one with little regulation and equal treatment of foreign investors -- has been maintained. And most analysts say the economy continues to function well.
 
'A Very Interesting Time'
 "The private sector is almost starting to move into a boom phase now," said Eduardo Aninat, chief negotiator for Chile in its recent re-entry into the Euromarkets. "Business has a stability it has not seen in years. This is a very interesting time for this country."
The numbers reflect the continued strength in Chile's economy. Inflation over the last four months has averaged less than 6 percent. Economic growth is projected to be almost 5 percent this year. The savings rate is more than twice that of the United States. Foreign exchange reserves have doubled in the last 15 months. And the country's stock market has almost doubled since last fall.
Foreign investment, too, is booming again after a lull last year as businessmen waited to see what the Aylwin Government would do. Investment has been running at almost a $2 billion annual rate, close to a record.
 
Copper Developments
 The Phelps Dodge Corporation is planning a $300 million copper mine in the north. Australian, Spanish and Japanese backers have poured $1 billion into Chile's copper belt to create the world's third-largest copper mine, La Escondida, which just started operations. The Simpson Paper Company of San Francisco, together with one of Chile's largest forestry companies, is building a $400 million pulp and paper plant near Concepcion. Shell Oil also has a plant of similar size about to go into operation.
Though perhaps small by United States standards, these projects are large for a country of 15 million people that had a gross domestic product last year of $26.5 billion.
Though Chileans seem to enjoy the image of an orderly economy and the praise it brings, they cannot escape a complex mix of emotions. The economic progress has come at a high price. The human rights violations attributed to the Pinochet Government continue to haunt the country. Furthermore, an estimated five million Chileans -- one-third of the population -- still live in poverty conditions.
But at least for now, the central question of whether Mr. Aylwin would steer a different course has been answered.
"I'm sleeping much, much better than I did a year ago," said Andres Bianchi, president of the central bank.
From a business point of view, things are still going well, too. Foreign businessmen traveling in Latin America say they breathe a sigh of relief when they get to Chile.
 
'Less Corruption'
 "The costs are lower than in other Latin American countries," said one businessman, Don J. Harris. "There is less corruption, more respect for law, and all of this spills over into our software business." Mr. Harris, marketng director in Latin America for the Wordperfect Corporation, a computer software company based in Orem, Utah, said that in his two years in Chile he has had far fewer problems with pirating of software than in any other Latin country.
Jose Antonio Rivero, president of Iansa, a foreign-owned sugar company, added: "Frankly, in 10 years working here we haven't had one single occasion when we have had to pay a bribe to anybody. That is not the norm in Latin America. For business, the rules have been very defined and the Government has stuck to them."
Businessmen remark that the phones work in Chile. They can repatriate profits from an investment after the first business year and can take their capital out of the country after three years. And they say they find no discrimination against their companies by Government officials.
But bankers here warn of potential problems, too. The recent rise in political assassinations is one. Others include the economy's dependence on foreign capital and on oil imports, which leave it vulnerable to interest rate fluctuations and world oil prices.
"The worst thing for us is a big recession in the United States," said Mr. Aninat, the debt negotiator.
Still, business executives find much to praise here.
At the signing ceremony last month for Chile's $320 million Eurobond, bankers celebrated the financing, noting that it represented the voluntary purchase of Chilean debt by investors, rather than a repudiation of debt or a restructuring. They also pointed out that the issue was so popular that Chile had raised more than originally planned, and at interest rates well below what Mexico and Venezuela were paying at the same time.
"This transaction sets an important example for emerging democracies in Latin America, Europe and Asia," said Donald McCouch, executive vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, the lad bank in the Chile debt offering. "Countries with debt problems which apply sound economic policies do get well," said Mr. McCouch, who heads the bank's lending to developing countries.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises in Quiet Day; Inflation Reports Awaited

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar closed higher in quiet trading yesterday, as many currency traders stayed on the sidelines in anticipation of fresh news of the nation's inflation rate, due later this week.
The dollar ended at 1.6945 German marks, up from 1.6870 on Friday, and at 137.15 Japanese yen, up from 136.65 on Friday. 
 Trading was restrained, with dealers awaiting the Producer Price Index for March, to be released on Thursday, and the Consumer Price Index, due Friday.
Data showing moderate inflation could allow the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates, rendering the dollar less attractive to investors compared with other major currencies.
"If the inflation numbers are high, the Fed won't ease; if inflation is under control, it will," said David Wilson at Girozentrale New York. "That's the conventional wisdom."
The mark rose against the yen in early trading amid rumors that a Southeast Asian central bank was buying marks for yen. But the yen recovered late in the afternoon, helped by a large speculative order to buy yen for marks, said John Krey, international economist for MCM Currencywatch.
Market sentiment remains bearish for the mark, which suffers from the political and economic problems created by German unification, traders said.
Germany's difficulties were highlighted by this weekend's visit of Chancellor Helmut Kohl to eastern Germany, where demonstrators hurled eggs at him. The political and economic turmoil in the Soviet Union also hampers the mark, traders said.
The yen was hurt by news that the head of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic party had resigned to take responsibility for the party's defeat in Sunday's vote for Tokyo governor, dealers said.
Traders say much the dollar's direction depends on whether the Fed cuts interest rates again, a move that is likely to depend on the inflation data released this week.
Economists polled by Reuters anticipate that the March producer price data will be unchanged over all and up two-tenths of 1 percent excluding the volatile food and energy prices. Consumer prices are expected to rise by two-tenths of 1 percent over all and three-tenths of 1 percent minus food and energy.
Among other currencies, the British pound ended at $1.7635, down from $1.7670 on Friday.
The dollar ended at 1.4385 Swiss francs, up from 1.4225 on Friday, at 5.7215 French francs, up from 5.7060 on Friday, and at $1.1540 (Canadian), unchanged from Friday.

HEADLINE: WASHINGTON MEMO;
Trade Issues Enter Crucial Political Phase

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

 BODY:
At their meeting Thursday, President Bush warned Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu that Congressional concerns over Japanese trade practices could damage the relationship between the two countries. In Houston Sunday, Mr. Bush presumably told President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico that American lawmakers would require Mexico to adopt stronger environmental measures and perhaps take other steps before Congress would accede to a bilateral free-trade pact.
In part, this is an age-old dance: Lawmakers, prepared to accept a trade accord eventually, appease local interests by threatening to block the agreement. And Presidents, stepping in tune with the music, emphasize the Congressional threats when they try to win overall trade concessions from other countries. 
 But these days, beyond the familiar two-step is a genuine political tension between the President and Congress, and it will reach a critical point soon after Congress returns today from a two-week recess. One of the most important orders of business will be the request by Mr. Bush that Congress extend his authority to conduct trade negotiations without line-by-line Congressional review.
National leaders may disagree about the economic benefits of removing trade barriers, but few doubt that doing so leads to smoother diplomatic relations. President Bush, like every President since World War II, Republican and Democrat, has been a strong advocate of free trade.
Members of Congress tend to be parochial. If tariffs or import quotas help businesses and protect jobs in their states and districts, lawmakers generally support them, regardless of their international effect.
It is not coincidental, for example, that South Carolina's Senators -- Strom Thurmond, a Republican, and Ernest F. Hollings, a Democrat -- men who could hardly be less alike in temperament, politics and ideology, are the leading Senate opponents of renewed international trade talks. If those talks are successful, textile imports would probably increase, hurting a major South Carolina industry.
Two big trade issues are on the table. The first is the resumption of international trade-liberalization talks, which broke down in December but seem ready to resume soon. The talks are held under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The second is President Bush's desire to negotiate a free-trade pact with Mexico like the one President Ronald Reagan made with Canada.
The outcome of both issues turns on whether Congress extends the "fast track" procedures, which will automatically be extended for another two years unless the House or the Senate votes by June 1 to discontinue them. Under these rules, in effect since the 1970's, the President must consult with Congress before entering into a trade agreement, and Congress has the authority to approve or disapprove the eventual agreement, but Congress may not amend it.
An unusual Congressional coalition is trying to block extension of the rules:
*Democrats who are on shaky ground after the Persian Gulf war and want to look tough on a foreign-policy issue.
*Lawmakers from the Rust Belt who fear that a Mexican trade agreement would encourage manufacturing companies and jobs to move across the border.
*Those from farm and textile states who believe the GATT negotiations will reduce the protection American farmers and textile companies now have.
*Those (primarily from Florida and California) who want to avoid competition from Mexican fruit and vegetable growers.
 
'Point of Leverage'
 "Fast track is the only point of leverage that exists now, because the Administration needs it to proceed," Representative Byron Dorgan, a North Dakota Democrat, said in an interview. "So all of us who oppose one thing or another have joined forces."
Mr. Dorgan, who bows to few others in adhering to liberal principles, is worried about his home-state farmers. He is the principal sponsor of the House resolution to stop continuation of the fast-track rules.
One anomaly is that the issue has pitted liberal Democratic politicians against the majority of liberal Democratic economists, who consider the law of comparative advantage as fundamental. This precept holds that a nation should specialize in producing and exporting goods that it can make at a relatively lower cost and import goods for which it is a relatively high-cost producer.
"Protectionist measures usually rob from the many to give to the few and harm the efficiency of the world economy in the bargain," wrote Alan S. Blinder, a prominent economics professor at Princeton, in his 1987 book, "Hard Heads, Soft Hearts."
Increasingly, politicians are taking issue with liberal economic doctrine. "Academics are just out of touch with the everyday concerns of working families," a Democratic strategist said. "They are indifferent to who makes the laptop computer on which they compose their free-trade arguments."
Charles L. Schultze, a top economist in the Johnson and Carter Administrations who is now at the Brookings Institution, dismisses arguments like that with the observation that politicians invariably go out of their way not to inflict direct harm, even if the indirect harm they spread is much more severe.
In the last decade, a small number of prominent economists, many of whom have ties to organized labor, have developed the view that free trade may be an outdated notion. After all, they note, Japan has fared pretty well with one of the most restrictive trade policies in the world.
One of these economists, Jeff Faux, president of the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal research center in Washington, says the law of comparative advantage only holds when there is full employment and thus a new job for anyone who loses one.
 
The Effect on Jobs
 "When you look at the history of people who have been knocked out of jobs by imports," Mr. Faux said in an interview, "they haven't climbed the ladder into better, more productive jobs. They've stayed out of work or moved down the ladder to worse jobs."
For their part, politicians tend to be swayed by constituents, not theories. Take Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Finance Committee. He has not been averse in his career to carrying the legislative water for important constituents, like oil and gas producers. Now he is a strong advocate of a Mexican free-trade pact. Why? Largely, his colleagues say, because the Texas border towns, among the poorest communities in the nation, would benefit from increased commerce.
Mr. Bentsen, whose committee handles trade matters, is expected to call for a vote in the next few weeks on a measure sponsored by Mr. Hollings that would block the fast-track procedures. But Mr. Bentsen's colleagues say he will do so at a time when the Hollings measure is sure of losing rather than allow Mr. Hollings to bring it to a vote at a time more favorable to him.
 
Gephardt's Role
 On the other side of Capitol Hill, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, is a leader in the fight for trade restrictions. Mr. Gephardt comes from St. Louis, which is threatened with the loss of manufacturing jobs to Mexico, where the average wage is one-seventh of that in the United States.
Over the years, Mr. Gephardt has metamorphosed from being a back-bench Congressman who rode the trade issue to prominence to being an unsuccessful Presidential candidate in 1988 who based his campaign on the trade issue to his current status as House majority leader with considerable influence over trade legislation. Many colleagues believe he is planning another run for the Presidency next year.
Given President Bush's popularity and the support he enjoys on the trade issue from House Republicans, opponents of the fast-track rules have an uphill fight. They almost certainly cannot win unless Mr. Gephardt takes a prominent role, and even then the odds are against them.
The prevailing view in the Capitol is that Mr. Gephardt will continue to speak out on trade, but that when push comes to shove he will probably back off and not support the Dorgan resolution.
"If Gephardt is going to do something to take on the President," said one Democrat who has talked to him about the matter, "he wants to win. He doesn't want to go head to head with Bush and lose."
Some lawmakers suggested that the Ways and Means Committee might bottle up the disapproval resolution so that it never reached a vote by the full House.
"They'd be complaining on the floor and thanking me in the cloakroom for not making them vote," said Representative Sam M. Gibbons, a Florida Democrat and a committed free-trader who heads the trade subcommittee.
"Down deep in their bellies," Mr. Gibbons said, "they know free trade is the right thing."

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
The New Drag On Auto Sales

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
MOST forecasts that the recession is about to end assume that consumers will soon buy cars in greater numbers -- a prerequisite for an upturn since the auto industry is such a major part of the economy. The problem with this assumption is that many would-be car buyers are failing to qualify for loans.
Car loans are as essential to car sales as mortgages are to home sales. The average selling price of new cars in the United States is now more than $16,000, far above what most Americans can pay out of their own pockets. So if car sales are to rise above their present weak levels, then the credit that was available on such easy terms in the 1980's must reappear. But lenders seem determined, for the time being, not to let that happen. 
 "A lot of people who might like to buy a car today already have too many debts, or their incomes have been reduced because of layoffs or less overtime or smaller bonuses," said Fritz Elmendorf, a vice president at the Consumer Bankers Association. "The banks aren't giving these people loans because the banks don't think they can afford loans any more."
The messengers of this bad news are frequently the nation's new-car dealers. Dealers often act as loan agents too, offering a customer financing that the dealer, in effect, obtains from a bank or savings and loan association or auto company finance arm, like Ford Credit or the General Motors Acceptance Corporation. Such lenders provide more than 80 percent of all new-car loans -- and they have erected obstacles to the lending of their money.
Young, first-time car buyers, for example, can no longer purchase a car without a down payment, as they often could in the 1980's. Down payments for everyone, in fact, have risen to an average of 15 percent of a car's cost, from 10 percent nearly two years ago, according to Federal Reserve figures. The auto companies, in addition, are offering fewer low-interest loans as sales incentives. And they have divided loan applicants into four "risk" categories, to help them identify -- and discourage -- those who might default on car payments.
In place of the single interest rate that was available in the 1980's for most borrowers, four rates are now in place. The lowest rate is offered to car purchasers who own their homes, have held well-paying jobs for five years or more, have unblemished records of repaying debts and are not overburdened with other debt. Such buyers get a 10.5 percent rate at Ford Credit, or one percentage point below the national average today for car loans. The riskiest borrowers, those in the fourth category, must pay an interest rate of more than 15 percent at Ford Credit and up to 17 percent at General Motors Acceptance, if they get a loan at all.
"We are trying to price credit appropriately, so that more credit is available to the most creditworthy customers," said Randy Kniebes, Ford Credit's vice president for marketing.
A major goal, of course, is to reduce defaults, which have risen over the last 18 months. In pursuit of this goal, the banks and the car financing arms are trying to offer shorter car loans, many of which have grown to as long as 60 months, or five years. General Motors Acceptance, for example, offers a lower rate for a loan that runs 48 months instead of 60.
The shorter loan means higher monthly payments. The higher payments, in turn, bring the borrower more quickly to the moment when the resale value of his car is greater than the balance left on his loan. Once that moment is reached, car owners having difficulty making payments are no longer tempted to halt them and let the finance company repossess the car. They can sell the cars instead, pay off the loans and perhaps have some money left over.
"The auto finance companies have been burned by bad risks," said Ronald Glantz, an auto analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds in San Francisco. "And it costs them $3,000 to repossess a car."
The banks and the auto finance companies have undoubtedly benefited from their stiffer lending standards. Mr. Glantz notes that earnings have risen at operations like Ford Credit and General Motors Acceptance. But while lenders strengthen their balance sheets, the value of outstanding car loans has fallen in nearly every month since March 1990, the Commerce Department reports.
The decline clearly reflects the reluctance of many Americans, even well-off ones, to purchase cars amid the uncertainties of a recession. But it also reflects the barriers that lenders have erected to poor credit risks. Those barriers raise this question: Can auto sales rise sufficiently to help revive the economy, if banks and finance companies are reluctant to make car loans readily available to people without a lot of change in their pockets?

HEADLINE: Late Program Buying Lifts Dow to 2,918.56

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks chugged along most of the day yesterday with little movement, but heavy program buying carried the Dow Jones industrial average sharply ahead in the final hour.
The Dow climbed 21.78, or nearly 1 percent, to 2,918.56, while the Standard & Poor's 500 rose 3.30, to 378.66. 
 The American Stock Exchange's market-value index, one measure of the smaller stocks, moved ahead slightly, while the Nasdaq composite, another measure of the smaller stocks, fell a bit.
With investors and traders perplexed over the lack of movement in interest rates -- despite signs of high unemployment and a weak economy -- trading slumped yesterday to 138.6 million shares. That was the quietest since Jan. 16, the day before the air war began against Iraq, when volume was 134.6 million.
Still the market's tone seemed optimistic. Big Board advances led declines, 9 to 6. While 6 stocks slipped to new lows, 92 climbed to new highs.
One big new high ws Time Warner. It jumped 6 1/4, to 118 1/2. Its Warner Brothers subsidiary announced on Friday that it had obtained American and Canadian distribution rights for three years to about two dozen films of Morgan Creek Productions. Morgan Creek's films include "Young Guns," "Dead Ringers" and "Enemies, a Love Story."
Traders came to work yesterday knowing that the chances of a reduction in interest rates by the Federal Reserve might not come until later in the week. Most traders are paying particular attention to the figures on producer prices, which are scheduled for Thursday, and the consumer prices data, scheduled for Friday, to see whether either will be inflationary.
If the numbers, as expected, are seen as not inflationary, the chances are strong that the Fed will move to lower rates fairly soon -- possibly even before the numbers are released because the Fed gets advance notice.
 
Programs Add 18 Points
 Except for a little bargain hunting at the opening bell, which lifted the Dow briefly, stocks moved rapidly into minus territory, moved up a bit and then came back down. For most of the day, the Dow zigzagged in a narrow range.
But Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, said two waves of computer-driven buying lifted the Dow more than 20 points. One was a six-minute flurry starting at 3:34 P.M.; the other, lasting eight minutes, began at 3:48 P.M. Allowing for one selling wave, program activity lifted the Dow a total of almost 18 points for the day.
Sung Won Sohn, chief economist for the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, attributed what little activity there was in part to reports on the producer and consumer prices. Dr. Sohn said he believed the inflation picture reflected in the figures "will look good," increasing the possibility that the Fed will cut rates.
He said the March figures will show a drop in energy prices and that apparel, car, tobacco and postage prices, all of which jumped in the last couple of months, were not expected to rise again.
 
Takeover Speculation
 Takeover talk helped stocks a little yesterday.
Baldwin Piano rose 2 1/4, to 13, after Business Week said Yamaha of Japan might be interested in it. Baldwin said it had not had any takeover talks and felt Yamaha was not interested.
Pet, a food company that was just spun off from Whitman, rose 1 1/4, to 17 1/8, a new high, after William Maguire of Merrill Lynch said he regarded it as a "good takeover target."
NCR rose3/4, to 97 1/2, after NCR told A.T.& T. it would recommend an offer of $110 a share, if a deal could be made quickly.
Dillard Department Stores rose 4 5/8, to 112 1/4, also reaching a new high of 112 3/8. Last week, Vendamerica of the Netherlands sold its 25 percent stake at $99 a share.
Among the technology stocks, I.B.M. rose 3/8, to 113; Hewlett-Packard 1 3/8, to 51 3/8; Microsoft 1 3/8, to 11 3/8; Automatic Data 1 7/8, to 66 7/8, and Conner Peripherals 1 3/8, to 25 1/8. Baldwin Piano and Organ

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
On Eve of Baker Visit, Israel Says It Will Free 1,000 Palestinians

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, April 8

 BODY:
The Israeli Defense Ministry said today that it would free more than 1,000 of the approximately 14,000 Palestinian prisoners held for actions connected with the uprising in the occupied territories. The announcement came a few hours before Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d arrived for talks on Tuesday with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir.
A Defense Ministry statement described the prisoners as Palestinians not directly involved in violence, who had served most of their terms. An official said the action was timed for the end of the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan and was not connected with the Baker visit. 
 "Just a coincidence," said Danny Naveh, the spokesman. "The measures have been under consideration for some time."
Nonetheless, the move fit into the theme being emphasized by Mr. Baker, who has been seeking confidence-building measures from Israelis and Arabs to coax peace efforts forward.
Mr. Naveh said the number of those to be released was higher than in the past, and he expressed hope that in easing conditions in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, the atmosphere for political discussion would be improved.
As a further gesture, the Defense Ministry ordered tax reform in Gaza with the aim of freeing investment capital to improve economic life. The ministry said further measures, like the reopening of universities, might come next.
Israelis have awaited the Baker visit in an uneasy mood influenced by what they view as America's abandonment of Iraqi Kurds rebelling against the Government of President Saddam Hussein. The American response to the Kurdish revolt has prominently figured in remarks by Cabinet members.
 
Comments to Kurdish Jews
 Foreign Minister David Levy told the leader of the Kurdish Jewish population of about 100,000 in Israel, "What good is it to parachute food so they can die with their stomachs full?"
The Kurdish leader, Haviv Shimoni, asked Mr. Levy to plead with Mr. Baker for American assistance to the uprising. Mr. Shimoni charged that the United States spurred the rebellion only to stand by while the Iraqi Army massacred the Kurds.
Housing Minister Ariel Sharon urged the Government to impress Mr. Baker with Israel's urgent concern over "the murder of the Kurdish people now being perpetrated in Iraq, while hundreds of thousands of American and allied forces are stationed in the area of the gulf."
A senior official of the Shamir Government said, "It reminds us that we live in a very bad neighborhood and can count only on ourselves." As he spoke, a television set in his office, the sound turned down, projected Cable News Network images of the misery of Kurdish refugees.
Israel radio also said that Mr. Shamir, as well as Mr. Levy and Defense Minister Moshe Arens, would tell the Secretary of State that Israel would negotiate with a Palestinian delegation only if its members did not say they represented the Palestine Liberation Organization. As is customary in American dealings with this Government of strongly individualistic ministers, Mr. Baker will confer separately on Tuesday with each of the three.
 
Will See Some Palestinians
 Mr. Baker is also scheduled to meet at the American Consulate in Jewish West Jerusalem with a delegation of Palestinians. However, Arabs from the occupied territories will continue to be banned from Jerusalem at least until his departure for Egypt on Wednesday.
Israeli statistics in mid-March said there were 10,528 Palestinians jailed for actions stemming from the Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.
Of those, 4,221 have been convicted, 988 are charged and awaiting trial, 3,992 are being held for investigation in anticipation of charges, and 1,327 are administrative detainees.
The release will not address demands by Shiite Muslim groups in Lebanon that Israel free Arab prisoners to expedite the release of Western hostages held in Lebanon. The South Lebanon Army, an Israeli-backed militia, is believed to hold about 300 Palestinians and Lebanese Shiites.

HEADLINE: Homes for Middle Class Rise on Blighted Blocks

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Empty lots surround the two rundown apartment buildings on the north side of Jefferson Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant. A block east, three large abandoned buildings tower over the elevated subway tracks that run above Broadway in Brooklyn.
But on the south side of Jefferson Avenue, amid this sad stereotype of big-city blight, carpenters are scurrying around a construction site. They are assembling 20 prefabricated town houses, each three stories tall with light blue vinyl siding and the wide sliding glass doors more often associated with developments on Long Island or in Westchester. 
 Sixty-six town houses are to be built on the city block between Jefferson Avenue and Hancock Street in the southeast corner of Bedford-Stuyvesant called Saratoga Square. The sponsors, which include several nonprofit community groups and the New York City Partnership, a citywide nonprofit organization created by business leaders, hope that someday their light-blue vision of middle-class housing may serve as a symbol of the neighborhood's renewal.
Such symbols are easy to spot these days. The partnership, which began its housing effort 10 years ago, has overseen the creation of more than 70 small developments, making it the city's most successful middle-income housing program.
 
3,350 New Houses and Apartments
 On Intervale Avenue in the Bronx, on Sharon Street in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn and on dozens of other blocks, clumps of 50 to 100 town houses and garden apartments, as well as low-rise condominium buildings, attest to the partnership's accomplishment.
Since 1984, 3,350 new houses and apartments have been built. Another 2,370 are now in construction, and almost 1,400 are in development.
The partnership works as an intermediary, linking banks, developers and nonprofit groups in development teams. Using city and state subsidies, these teams build and sell town houses and apartments. The banks, developers and buyers take the financial risks.
The effort depends on one overriding element: "the willingness of buyers to commit all their life savings to an area that has been written off as a slum for 20 years," said Kathryn Wylde, a senior vice president of the partnership.
 
Average Income of $37,000
 The majority of buyers live in the communities where the housing is built, Ms. Wylde said. About 80 percent are black, Hispanic or Asian, she said. Half are civil servants, including many teachers and transit and hospital workers. In most of the families, both parents work and the average household income is $37,000.
"This is really the city's emerging middle class," she said. "They represent the heart of the work force, the source of stability in neighborhoods and schools that are otherwise entirely ghettoized."
These are families with few choices for home ownership. Even with the slump in the region's housing market, they are priced out of most market-rate houses and apartments.
"There is no housing; there's no place to go," said Joseph E. Holley Sr., director of the Northeast Brooklyn Housing Development Corporation, a nonprofit group marketing the Jefferson Avenue town houses. More than 500 families have applied for the 66 houses, and the first 23 have been sold.
While the development, called Stuyvesant Mews, is more stylish than some partnership projects, it is similar in design. The town houses have two spacious floors for the owners and a large two-bedroom apartment on the third floor for a tenant.
The town houses sell for about $150,000. Buyers pay 5 percent down, or $7,500. They earn from $500 to $700 a month from the rental apartment, and their monthly bills for mortgage payments and taxes total about $1,200 to $1,500, Ms. Wylde said.
The program began in working-class areas like the north shore of Staten Island and Castle Hill in the Bronx. The houses are built on vacant city-owned land, with combined city and state subsidies of $25,000 for each house.
The program has expanded in recent years throughout the city, including the South Bronx, Bedford-Stuyvesant and Bushwick. Town houses and garden apartments are often built next to abandoned buildings being rebuilt under other city programs for the unemployed and working poor.
Asked whether such neighbors made sales more difficult, Ms. Wylde replied: "The truth? There is no market except for what the local people create." Perhaps because of that, she said the financial turbulence in the banking and real-estate industries has had little effect on the program.
 
Objections From Some Advocates
 Some advocates of housing for low-income New Yorkers have criticized the city and the partnership for using government money and land to create housing for the middle class. They believe such developments should include housing for the less affluent. The Puerto Rican Legal Defense Fund has filed two lawsuits to challenge the city's awarding of several East Harlem sites to the partnership.
"There hasn't been a general objection to middle-income housing," said Arthur A. Baer, an associate counsel at the legal defense fund. The concern, he said, is that subsidized housing in poor neighborhoods that is sold only to middle-class families fosters gentrification and ultimately displaces poor people.
Ms. Wylde, along with the city's Housing Commissioner, Felice L. Michetti, and the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, said no one is displaced when houses are built on vacant land.
"Gentrification is not the issue, either," Mr. Ferrer said, "because invariably these are people who come from the same neighborhood. These are wage earners, people who are paying their bills. Without them, the city would be in deep deep trouble."

HEADLINE: Wallace Journal;
As Jobs Come Calling, The Now-Wary Unite

BYLINE: By FRANCES FRANK MARCUS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WALLACE, La.

 BODY:
Along River Road, which meanders for miles through the remnants of plantation country, the black and white residents have shared little over the years but mutual distrust and a high cancer rate, which many believe is caused by the dozens of industrial plants that line the Mississippi River.
Now they are also sharing a bitter fight against powerful local political and business interests and a large industrial company from Taiwan, the Formosa Plastics Corporation, which wants to build a $700 million plant for processing wood pulp and manufacturing rayon in this mostly black community. 
 Industry was once welcomed to this region, no questions asked, and not even the most ardent opponent of the Formosa Plastics plant denies that the area and the state need jobs. But many people say this fight is another example of new thinking in Louisiana: a stiffening of public attitudes toward industry and the politicians who entice big companies.
"This is really the first time environmental, historic preservation and minority groups have gotten together to protest a plant," said William Fontenot, an environmental specialist with the State Attorney General's office.
Members of the racially diverse alliance fear not only the potential chemical discharges from the plant, but also disruption of the community and harm to the tranquil landscape and its historic houses.
"There is great trauma for the people here." said Wilfred M. Greene, a retired school principal who owns riverfront land in Wallace that his ancestors, plantation workers, bought in 1874.
Samuel Jackson, a 34-year-old former chemical plant worker who has been unemployed for more than a year, said: "We need jobs, that's a fact. But this is more than about jobs."
Mr. Jackson said he did not relish "l0 years of making $15 an hour and then dying of cancer or liver disease or whatever."
Ten miles upriver, Zeb Mayhew, an administrator and part owner of Oak Alley plantation, said the proposed plant "scares the hell out of me."
River Road, known to tourists for its antebellum plantation houses, is known to medical researchers and the public as Cancer Alley. But the industrial plants that are widely believed to be the cause of high cancer rates have skipped over a fertile, 30-mile-residential and farming strip that includes Wallace.
People say this strip is the last green zone in the 130 river miles between New Orleans and Baton Rouge. It is part of St. John the Baptist Parish, which straddles the Mississipi, and here on the west bank, tumble-down shanties share country lanes with cottages, churches and modern brick homes in a patchwork of sugar cane fields and historic houses.
The Formosa Plastics plan to build here has been avidly supported by Gov. Buddy Roemer and local politicians. The company has bought 1,740 acres in the Wallace area, including an old rice and sugar plantation called Whitney and its plantation house.
The Whitney land, once zoned agricultural and residential, was rezoned for industrial use at a stormy meeting of the Parish Council last year. Opponents of the new plant say they face a formidable political machine: parish officials whose business interests stand to gain from new industry.
A leading backer of the plant is Lester J. Millet Jr., the council president, a businessman. A descendent of planation owners, Mr. Millet was the parish tax assessor and sheriff in the 1970's. Among other interests, he owns a motel, a small shopping center and a construction company.
Mr. Millet (pronounced MEE-yat) declined to be interviewed, but he has been quoted as saying he favors the Taiwan project because "thousands of jobs will come behind." The company says the plant will create 700 jobs.
Joel McTopy, a council member who is health and safety representative for the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union, says he worries about the record of Formosa Plastics.
Last year the E.P.A. proposed a fine of $8.3 million against the company for violations of waste laws at a chemical plant in Texas. In a recent settlement, the company agreed to pay $3,375,000. Last year it also agreed to pay a $65,000 fine for air pollution in Baton Rouge, where it has a chemical plant.
The company has asked the Environmental Protection Agency for a permit to discharge 53 million gallons of waste water a day, mostly into the Mississippi. A spokesman said the company planned to use the most modern pollution-fighting equipment available.
Carl Baloney Sr. is familiar with mortality in the region, as co-owner of two St. John Parish funeral homes. "Eight out of 10 people we bury probably have cancer," Mr. Baloney said. "Most of the deaths are cancer related."
Last year Mr. Baloney was an outspoken opponent of the new plant, but he has been quiet lately. He said his brother, who operates the only ambulance service in the parish, is a contender for a new parish ambulance contract. "The seeds were planted somewhere and it has been passed around the parish that 'Carl is hurting his brother's chances of getting the ambulance contract,' " Mr. Baloney said.
Mr. Greene, the waterfront property owner, said Formosa Plastics has approached him about buying part of his land. On a walk through the neighborhood, a strip of modest houses beside the levee, he said some neighbors have sold to the company but he wants neither to sell nor live with Formosa Plastics. "I am 68 years old," he said. "For me to move out now, where would I go?"
Mr. Greene said that in the struggle over the plant something fundamental had changed. "Whatever happens, it will never be business as usual in St. John Parish again," he said. "Politicians here never once dreamed this plant would drum up this much opposition. They will never try this again."
