HEADLINE: Detroit Strives to Reclaim Lost Generation of Buyers

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 8

 BODY:
When Sue Anderson passed her driver's exam 10 years ago, she inherited the family Mazda. After graduation from college, she bought her family's Saab. Last year, the 26-year-old graphic designer from Grand Rapids, Mich., bought her first new car. It was a 1990 Mitsubishi Eclipse.
"I never really considered buying an American car, which is not to say I wouldn't," said Ms. Anderson, who aspires to buy another Saab. "I guess buying a foreign car has been kind of ingrained in me."
 
Foreign Cars Favored
 Ms. Anderson is part of the auto industry's "lost generation." A new wave of young drivers are shopping for their first new cars and trucks, and their biases spell deep trouble for the American auto industry. In large part, they are the children of the drivers who first traded their Fords, Dodges and Chevrolets in the 1970's for Hondas, Toyotas and BMW's. As they were growing up, their family cars were typically foreign makes, and they knew mostly horror stories about Detroit's products. Shaped by their parents' tastes, these young adults rarely set foot in the Big Three's car dealerships. 
 In the last decade, the American auto industry has invested more than $100 billion to improve quality, develop new designs and make vehicles more appealing. The General Motors Corporation's $3 billion Saturn project is only the latest example. But just gaining the attention of what the industry calls "import committed" buyers is among the most intractable of Detroit's predicaments -- and among the most critical to reverse.
"If Detroit is not successful in getting these buyers back," warned Robert A. Lutz, president of the Chrysler Corporation, "market share will experience further, gradual erosion." Only last month, Lee A. Iacocca, chairman and chief executive of Chrysler, appealed to President Bush to suppress Japanese imports, warning that the weak No. 3 auto maker would be "gone" if Japanese auto makers continued to gain market share.
 
Change in Buying Habits
 The sea change in American car-buying attitudes came about even before foreign models were being offered in significant numbers. Demographers detected a radical change in buying habits around the time of the Vietnam War. Before the mid-1960's, children frequently embraced the brand of consumer products, including cars, that their parents used. Adults tended to be loyal to one brand, and their children followed suit.
But the phenomenon of "Chevy families" and "Ford families" faded when children of the baby boom after World War II reached car-buying age in the 1970's. "Baby boomers had more money and were better educated," said James Kornas, director of market assessment for G.M.'s Cadillac division. "They also were rejecting their parents' values."
One value they rejected was loyalty to their parents' brands. "They could recognize the value and utility of imports," Mr. Kornas said. "This was the original BMW and Honda Accord crowd."
As more drivers tried foreign models and liked their fuel efficiency, reliability and comfort, even for smaller models, they spread the word. Good word of mouth, automotive marketers say, is by far the best advertising. The baby boomers were not particularly loyal to individual import brands, only to the notion of avoiding domestic models. Even if they loved their Honda, they might be willing to try a Toyota next.
Many of the baby boomers' children -- today's car buyers -- have reverted to their parents' buying habits. Consider the Gribbin family's history of car ownership:
David J. Gribbin, 51 years old, of Bethesda, Md., traded his 1978 Mustang II after just one year for a Honda Accord when the Mustang's transmission burned out, and later motor oil dripped down a cable and leaked through the dashboard.
"I bought a second Honda Accord because I liked the first one," he said. Since his first Honda, Mr. Gribbin's wife, Lori, bought a Nissan Maxima, his daughter, Deborah, inherited Mrs. Gribbin's used Nissan, and their son, D. J., traded a Subaru for a Toyota Corolla.
"I watched my parents' experience when American cars hit rock bottom," said D. J. Gribbin, 27, who is a lobbyist in Washington. "It's one thing for a car to leak oil -- but through the dashboard? Foreign cars might be more expensive, but the upkeep is less."
 
Foreign-Made Flops
 Of course, there have have been foreign-made flops, too. Renault, the French auto maker, stumbled in the United States with its Dauphine in the early 1960's and has never had much success here. Mazda's first cars imported here had faulty rotary engines and other problems. Even some early Hondas had defects.
Detroit auto makers are trying to build vehicles that will erase the bitter memories of yesteryear's Pintos and Volares. The Ford Motor Company's Taurus and Chrysler's mini-vans exemplify models that have demonstrated vastly improved quality and have also been popular sellers because of innovative design.
But altering the perceptions of young buyers like Sue Anderson, who are not familiar with domestic models and never grew up with them, or the younger Mr. Gribbin, who has wanted little to do with American cars, is proving to be a daunting problem.
 
Market Share Dwindles
 "A lot of people would have trouble admitting to their peers that they bought an Oldsmobile even if they thought it was every bit as good as a Honda," said Chris Cedergren of J. D. Power & Associates, an automotive marketing company in Agoura Hills, Calif.
Over all, the Big Three's share of the United States car market has dwindled to 67 percent. That statistic, however, does not apply to all age groups equally. Generally, older drivers prefer domestic makes, while younger ones, especially in their 20's and 30's, prefer foreign makes.
According to a J. D. Power study, 86 percent of the cars bought by people 65 years of age and older are domestic brands while only 14 percent of the people in that age group buy foreign makes.
The shift is more dramatic in the 25-to-34 age group. There, 54 percent drive domestic models, while about 46 percent drive cars made by foreign manufacturers.
 
Same Old Reason
 Of course, many believe United States auto makers are failing to win back import buyers for precisely the reason they first lost them: Too few of the Big Three's models are competitive in performance, quality and style. Independent researchers still give the Japanese models generally higher ratings for quality, value and reliability.
"I don't think it's snobbism," said Martin Swig, a San Francisco dealer who sells imported and domestic brands. "Honda and Toyota haven't made many mistakes. Consumers are acting in a rational way."
Mr. Iacocca disagrees. He blames the nation's "inferiority complex" for causing consumers to choose Japanese models over Chryslers, Dodges and Plymouths, which Chrysler asserts are superior to Hondas and Toyotas.
"People think all Japanese products are good and all American products are bad," Mr. Iacocca declared last year in a televised advertisement. "Now that's got to stop."
From the earliest days of the Volkswagen Beetle, Detroit has struggled to understand why American consumers have flocked to smaller, lighter, fuel-efficient models imported by foreign auto makers. "The industry had the utter misapprehension that the people who bought these cars were second-rate buyers in education and income levels and didn't care about quality," said David E. Davis, editor of Automobile magazine.
G.M.'s Chevrolet Corvair, Ford's Falcon and Chrysler's Plymouth Valiant were low-quality vehicles aimed at Beetle buyers of the 1960's. The next generation of import fighters, the Chevy Vega, which had chronic engine defects; the Ford Pinto, which was criticized for its propensity to catch fire in rear-end collisions, and, in the mid-70's, the American Motors Pacer, an odd-shaped vehicle that used too much gas for a small car, were just more of Detroit's self-inflicted wounds,
In the 80's, Detroit tried leather-wrapped steering wheels, black molding to replace chrome strips and European-sounding names, but they did little to attract import buyers. Nor were buyers won over by the Cadillac Cimarron, a small, lower-priced luxury car that was essentially a dressed-up Chevrolet Cavalier.
The Big Three have also renamed several foreign models and sold them as their own with mixed success. Suzuki's Sprint, for example, also sells as Chevrolet's Geo Metro and has added some sales for G.M. Ford's attempt to start a Merkur franchise with two European-made models failed to attract many buyers.
Owners of foreign cars appear to be too savvy to be swayed by such tactics, said Laurel Cutler, vice chairman of the FCB/Leber Katz advertising agency and a former Chrysler vice president. "Instead," she said, "they have to hear from domestic owners, 'It's a wonderful car, I haven't had a lick of trouble.' And then it will be a long and hard battle before people change."
 
Joint Ventures Worked
 When Big Three auto makers have teamed up with Japanese partners to develop or build models, they have achieved some hits. Ms. Anderson's $12,000 Mitsubishi, for example, was designed in Japan but assembled at the Diamond-Star plant in Bloomington, Ill., a joint venture of Chrysler and the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation. Her Mitsubishi Eclipse is virtually identical to Chrysler's Eagle Talon and Plymouth Laser, produced on the same assembly line.
Of the 50 million to 60 million households that buy new cars and trucks every few years, a quarter already may be solidly committed to buying foreign brands, according to Charles Stannard of DMB&B in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., the advertising agency for Cadillac and Pontiac.
"The car makers have to try to go after the very young," he said. "By the time you get into your 40's, it's too late to win you back." He says he thinks that more daring styling might win the Big Three some converts, because the styling of current Japanese models is bland.
Data from the first few thousand sales of G.M.'s new Saturn model, a front-wheel-drive compact that costs $8,000 to $12,000, are coming in. The car is built in Spring Hill, Tenn., and went on sale in November in parts of the United States and will be sold nationwide in coming weeks. G.M. says that about half the people who have purchased Saturn models said their second choice was a foreign car.
"All things being equal, I would like to buy an American car," said the younger Mr. Gribbin. To accommodate his growing family he is considering trading his Toyota for a domestic mini-van. "It's better for our economy and our trade balance," he said. "But it's got to hold up." Power, J.D.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Big Round of Discount Fares Was a Success, Airlines Say

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, April 8

 BODY:
The big discount fares offered by most large airlines in the last four weeks attracted thousands of bookings by travelers who had sharply limited air travel in January and February because of worries about recession and terrorism related to the Persian Gulf war.
Executives at travel agencies and representatives for several airlines said that while the fare discounts, which expired today, were sold mostly to consumers planning spring and summer vacations, business travel also improved in March after a cease-fire was declared in the gulf. 
 "The sale did its job," said David Messing, a spokesman for Continental Airlines, in Houston. "Leisure travelers needed an incentive to start taking trips again. Now we have a situation where we have all the bookings that we would expect to have for this time of year. Two months ago, that was not the case."
David Paresky, the president and chief executive of Thomas Cook Travel, a national company with headquarters in Cambridge, Mass. said, "The airlines are still behind last year's load levels, but the gap is closing."
Some airlines said last week in their regular monthly reports that March air travel lagged behind the levels of last year, but not by as much as in January and February.
American Airlines, which began the round of fare discounts on March 13, said today that it had booked nearly four million passengers at the special discount fares by April 4, or more than 60 percent of all the reservations it accepted in the period.
A spokesman, Tim Smith, said that most trips were for vacations and that most were scheduled for this month and next. "At this stage, we are very encouraged by the early build in bookings based on these specials," he said, adding that the volume of calls to reservation lines had been heavy for the last week. Mr. Smith declined to say whether American anticipated a significant improvement in passenger loads this month from a year ago.
The discount fares purchased through today are valid for travel through Sept. 30, mainly for midweek travel at off-peak times and including a Saturday night stay. On the New York-to-Dallas route, for instance, American cut its lowest off-peak fare through May to $238 for a round-trip ticket, and $318 round trip from June through September, compared with $405 before the promotion.
The number of passengers and miles flown at American, the nation's largest airline, was down by 7.3 percent in March, compared with the same month a year ago, the airline said. But the March 1991 figure was up by 17.7 percent from February, and by 1.7 percent from January.
 
Fewer United Travelers
 United Airlines, the nation's second-largest carrer, said the number of passengers and miles traveled in March on all of its routes was down by 6.9 percent from the same period a year ago. But John C. Pope, the vice chairman, said, "We are encouraged by the recovery that we are currently seeing, particularly in our Pacific markets."
A spokesman at United's headquarters in Chicago, Joseph P. Hopkins, said its discount effort generated the second-highest daily volume of calls to the airline's reservations lines, on March 21. Of those calls, 39,000 were for international travel, United's highest one-day total for tickets abroad, he said.
At Delta Air Lines, the third-largest carrier, traveler interest in its discount fares increased in the last few weeks, followed by a "rush to meet the deadline," said Neil Monroe, a spokesman. Delta's count for passengers and miles flown rose by 4.4 percent in March, but the company attributed the increase mainly to the demise of one of its leading competitors, Eastern Airlines.
 
Analyst Sees Success
 Kevin C. Murphy, an analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, declared the discount fares a success. "They have stimulated consumers to dig into their pockets and start planning their summer vacations," he said. "The bookings may still be jejune, but they are headed in the right direction."
Mr. Murphy said several economists interpreted the response to the bargains as a hint of consumers' willingness to spend and that there were "some stirrings of an economic recovery out there."
Although the deeply discounted fares have ended, American said it would begin a new fare schedule that includes lower fares than existed before the March 13 promotion. The off-peak New York-to-Dallas fare is now $368 round trip for reservations made at least 21 days before the first part of a trip, the airline said.
The fare for a 14-day advance reservation is $438, and it is $538 for a seven-day reservation. Half of the seven-day fare will be refunded if the trip is canceled, American said, but no refunds would be made on the 14- and 21-day advance purchase tickets.
 
Longer Trips to Cost More
 Mr. Smith of American said the airline's revised schedule would make longer trips more expensive in most cases, except on such heavily traveled and competitive routes as New York to Los Angeles. The new fares would also provide greater discounts for tickets purchased at least 21 days before a flight's departure date than for those bought 14 days or seven days before the trip begins.
American anticipates that more than half of its tickets will be sold with the 21-day discounts, Mr. Smith said. These and other aspects of American's revised schedule were announced on March 13. The 21-day advance purchase fares were added then.

HEADLINE: Pact Reached On Brazil's Interest Debt

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Brazil and its commerical bankers announced an agreement yesterday for the country to retire $8 billion in unpaid interest.
The preliminary deal will open the way for the main round of the debt negotiations between Brazil and its bankers -- the restructuring of $50 billion in borrowings that help make Brazil the largest debtor in the third world. 
 These negotiations are expected to be difficult and will largely hinge on whether Brazil can keep its economic program on track. Brazil has yet to reach a final agreement with the International Monetary Fund on an economic program, which would provide the country with loans and also make money available to be used as enhancements for bankers to offer the country debt reduction.
 
'On the Road Back'
 If an agreement is reached, the talks would be the biggest success in the Bush Administration's efforts to reduce the debt burdens of third world nations. And it would leave Argentina as the last big debtor not to reach an agreement under the program known as the Brady plan, after Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady.
The Brazilian agreement was announced in New York and came after six months of difficult negotiations. "This is a step on the road back for Brazil," said William Rhodes, senior-executive international at Citibank and the chairman of the 21-bank negotiating committee. "Over all it took a very long time," added Jorio Dauster, chief negotiator for Brazil.
Brazil halted its interest payments in July 1989. By the end of last year, the unpaid interest totaled about $8 billion. The Brazilians resumed some interest payments in the first quarter and have paid around $400 million this year.
Under the agreement, which is still subject to approval by the hundreds of banks with loans to Brazil, about 25 percent of the unpaid interest will be paid in cash -- about $900 million 10 days after the agreement is final and the rest in installments though the end of the year. The remainder of the interest will be converted to 10-year bonds with a blend of fixed and floating interest rates that banks can choose from. The bonds will not be issued until there is an agreement on the rewriting of the $50 billion in medium- and long-term debt.
 
Tough Economic Plan
 In an interview, Mr. Dauster said the key concern for Brazil in the next round of negotiations would be to minimize its payments for the next several years. The country's economy has not nearly recovered from the recession caused by the stringent economic measures the Government imposed just over a year ago to fight inflation and to open the country's market.
Because of this, Mr. Dauster said, the Brazilians are interested in turning some of the existing debt into very long-term bonds -- as much as 45 years -- to reduce the early payments. Other options for the banks include shorter-term bonds on which the face amount of the debt owed would be reduced in exchange. The Brazilians, he added, would not ask for a debt reduction on the longer-term bonds.
"We need to have this curve where debt repayments will be quite small in the first years," he said. "We want debt reduction, sure," he added, "but we are also talking about how to pay, and there are other ways."
In addition to the $50 billion Brazil owes the banks, it has another $61 billion of debt with foreign governments and international agencies.
As the talks dragged on, the Brazilians came under increasing pressure to come to an agreement on the unpaid interest.
A potential agreement on an economic program with the I.M.F. last year was delayed. And just recently, a $350 million loan from the Inter-American Development Bank was also delayed. Officials of both the Bush Administration and the I.M.F. said they were becoming concerned that Brazil's not dealing quickly with the unpaid interest was setting a tone that could complicate debt negotiations with other countries.
Also, a recent change in I.M.F policy, which allows economic agreements to be reached and loans to be made while countries are still in arrears, was sharply criticized by bankers and was becoming an embarrassment to the I.M.F. as the Brazilian talks dragged on.
Among the debt agreements reached so far under the Brady plan are those with Mexico, Venezuela, Costa Rica, Morocco and Uruguay. Argentina, with arrears almost as large as Brazil's, hopes to begin negotiating by the end of the year. It also has to work out a new economic program with the I.M.F.

HEADLINE: A Minority Plan For City Council

 BODY:
In a preview of the possibilities and the passions that will be ignited in the quest for 51 new New York City Council districts, a private group yesterday offered a plan in which black, Asian-American and Hispanic residents represent the majority in 29 of the districts.
The Community Service Society of New York said its plan would provide for 13 predominantly black districts, 10 Hispanic, 2 in which Asians and other nonwhites dominate and 4 in which a combination of all minorities dominate. 
 "Today blacks, Asians and Latinos constitute nearly 60 percent of the population of New York City," said David R. Jones, the president of the society. "The rapidly growing population of people of color presumably should produce a similar shift in the racial and ethnic composition of the Council."
The 35-seat Council now has three Hispanic, six black and no Asian-American members.
The Council will expand to 51 seats later this year, in accordance with the new City Charter. The New York City Districting Commission is charged with creating the 51 districts, with a mandate to insure fair representation to minorities.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
The Surprise Operation That Unseated Noriega

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Since network television cameras and correspondents were not invited by the Pentagon to record the United States invasion of Panama in December 1989, tonight's edition of "Frontline" is the fullest opportunity so far for Americans to witness the brief but violent encounter. Using pictures taken by Air Force combat cameramen, "War and Peace in Panama," at 9 on Channels 13 and 49, captures the few explosive hours that brought an end to the career of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.
The program begins in October 1989, with a failed anti-Noriega coup, which Washington had encouraged but did not assist. That embarrassment led to military planning for what would be known as Operation Just Cause. The campaign, devised under Gen. Colin L. Powell, the new chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, was a small-scale preview of Operation Desert Storm: a surprise attack by overwhelming force aimed at rapid victory. 
 The account of the fighting is compelling. Along with the pictures of tracer fire against dark skies, gutted buildings, house-to-house searches and bodies on the street come personal accounts from both sides.
A United States soldier relates: "There were two Panamanians that ambushed me. And they were about 10 feet away when they opened up with AK-47's on full automatic. And it felt like someone, like Mike Tyson had punched me in the chest as hard as he could."
A Panamanian civilian recalls: "There was an explosion. The light went out. All the windows shattered and the ceiling fan fell down. My wife thought the wall was going to fall on us. My oldest daughter said, 'Mom, let's pray,' but my wife couldn't say, 'Our Father.' "
Drawing on debriefings of General Noriega's bodyguards, the program reports that the Panamanian ruler spent the hours of the attack drinking heavily, taking comfort with a woman and counting on the intercession of witches to save him. A soldier who searched his office tells of finding alcohol, pornographic treats and little statues of frogs: "He loved frogs, or something."
Aspects of the attack are criticized ("Every service got a piece of the pie," says one observer) as is the failure to capture General Noriega, who turned himself in after a few days. But most of the criticism is directed at the consequences of the war.
Robert White, a former United States Ambassador to El Salvador and a frequent critic of Reagan and Bush Administration policies toward Central America, sets the tone. He calls Washington's estimate that only about 200 civilians were killed in the invasion "an absurdly low figure," adding that the estimates by some Panamanians of more than 2,000 deaths is "absurdly high." Whatever the figure, he wants Washington to pay compensation. Ambler Moss, a former Ambassador to Panama, calls on the United States to give more aid for reconstruction.
The post-Noriega Government is faulted for failing to deal with high unemployment; staffing the police force with former members of the Panamanian army; not cracking down on drug traffic; money laundering and other varieties of corruption, and restricting press freedom. If any enthusiastic supporters of the Government exist, they are not in evidence here.
This provocative hour ends with the suggestion that the military success in Panama gave President Bush confidence to use force against Iraq. It leaves open the question of whether the consequences of America's latest victory on the battlefield will prove as problematic as its previous one.
 
Frontline
War and Peace in Panama
 
Written by Charles Stuart; produced by Mr. Stuart and Marcia Vivancos; Will Lyman, narrator. At 9 tonight on Channels 13 and 49.

HEADLINE: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
Would Straw Have Hustled To Third?

BYLINE: By DAVE ANDERSON

 BODY:
ONE small base for Hubie Brooks, one giant base for Metkind.
One run doesn't make a season. But yesterday it made a 2-1 victory that delighted 50,800 parishioners at Shea Stadium in the Mets' opener. 
 The decisive run scored when Hubie Brooks, who has succeeded Darryl Strawberry as the cleanup hitter and right fielder, scored on a double steal. But the double steal developed after Brooks tagged up at second base and hustled to third on Howard Johnson's flyball to Dale Murphy, the Phillies right fielder.
"Murphy can still throw," Mike Cubbage, the Mets third-base coach, said later, "but it was just deep enough."
Just deep enough for Brooks to slide into third ahead of Murphy's good throw. And just thoughtful enough for any Mets fan to wonder: would the Mets' previous right fielder, Darryl Strawberry, have hurried to third so that he might have been able to score on another flyball with one out?
Maybe if Darryl felt like hustling. Maybe if Darryl were in the mood.
As the season progresses without Strawberry's big bat, the Mets will need all the runs they can manufacture. They can't wait for somebody to hit a three-run homer. They must put together runs with glue and paste and twine, as they did yesterday. One run in the first on consecutive doubles by Vince Coleman and Gregg Jefferies. Another in the fourth on Brooks's double, his hustle in going to third and Manager Bud Harrelson's sign for a double steal.
Those runs were all that Dwight Gooden, with ninth-inning relief from John Franco, needed while allowing only six hits and striking out seven.
Moments after Gooden strode to the mound for the first inning, the Doobie Brothers' rendition of "Signed, Sealed and Delivered" boomed out of the public-address amplifiers beyond the center-field fence. Signed for $15.45 million, sealed through the 1994 season and delivered as the Mets' opening-day starter for the fourth consecutive year and the sixth in his eight seasons. If it's opening day, it must be Dr. K starting.
Judging by the current baseball economy, not to be confused with the national economy, "Signed, Sealed and Delivered" might soon replace "Take Me Out to the Ballgame" as baseball's anthem.
With all their millions, many sports celebrities are resented now by fans, but Dwight Gooden seems to be more cherished than ever by the Shea Stadium parishioners. Hardly a voice was heard complaining about his new contract that, if his video royalities boom, would lift him above Roger Clemens as baseball's highest paid performer. At least until somebody else gets a bigger contract than both of them.
In the eyes of the Shea Stadium parishioners, Gooden can do no wrong. Maybe because he once did wrong: his 1987 drug problem.
Until then, Gooden had been almost too good to be true. But when he required rehab, it seemed to humanize him as a person. He knew he made a mistake. And he vowed not to make it again.
"He's genuine," said Dr. Alan Lans, who supervises the Mets employee-assistance program. "He took it and he grew with it."
Unlike Strawberry, who so often seemed to say the wrong thing, Gooden invariably says the right thing. Straw had been threatening for years to join the Los Angeles Dodgers in his hometown. And as a free agent, he did just that, with waves of "I Hate New York" comments in his wake. Gooden, in contrast, spoke about how New York had become his baseball home, how the fans had supported him.
"Even through my tough times, they had every right to get on me," he said, alluding to his drug rehab. "But they stuck with me."
He remembered the June night in 1987 when he hopped out of the dugout and walked to the mound for the first time that season.
"I didnt' know what to expect," he recalled. "But when I heard those cheers, it brought tears to my eyes. It pumped me up."
He's still pumped. When his big contract was announced, Al Harazin, the keeper of the keys to the Mets treasury, described him as "the heart and soul of our ballclub." As yet, nobody in the front office has spoken of Frank Viola that fondly. Viola, of course, is about to turn 31. Apparently the Mets are concerned about his age, as well as the bone spurs in his left elbow.
"You have to look down the road," the Mets' senior executive vice-president, Frank Cashen, said, "and judge who'll be more important to you then, Viola or some kid who's just coming along now."
But if the Mets were willing to offer Viola more than $13 million for three seasons, why won't they offer him another million or two to keep him? If the Mets only produce three doubles, Hubie Brooks's hustle and a double steal that produced their first theft of home since Danny Heep did it in 1985, they need all the pitching they can get. Now and down the road.

HEADLINE: Tap the Treasure in Rent Control

 BODY:
While New Yorkers ponder emergency measures to repair their city's deteriorating financial condition, a hoard of taxable value remains untapped under the welter of rent control regulations that keep the rents for many apartments unjustifiably low.
The potential to generate new income for the city increases the need to mitigate rent regulations that have destroyed older housing and discouraged new rental construction for half a century. 
 A civic group, the Citizens Budget Commission, recently produced yet another study showing that while rent control assists a small number of low-income families, its main beneficiaries have been families in above-average income brackets, which have received an unparalleled housing bargain at taxpayer expense.
According to the commission and Prof. Elizabeth Roistacher of Queens College, who conducted a survey for the commission, tenants in apartments renting for $750 a month or higher receive on the average a gift of $4,140 a year. That's how much more rent other people would be willing to pay for the same apartments in a free market.
The apartments under regulation in New York City are relatively cheap compared with apartments of similar quality in other cities without rent regulation. The cost of this hidden subsidy is borne partly by the owners of the buildings, who receive less rent than in a free market, and partly by the city, which collects less in taxes than if the apartments rented at market rates.
The tax charges on such buildings would, by Professor Roistacher's findings, be about $100 million a year higher if rents were allowed to rise to market levels and the assessed valuation of the buildings were adjusted accordingly.
There is an easy fix for this injustice. The Emergency Tenant Protection Act, the state's basic rent regulation statute, provides that when 5 percent of the apartments in any price class are vacant, the class must be decontrolled and de-regulated. Unfortunately, state and city governments, fearful of a backlash from tenants, refuse to press for an official study testing the vacancy rate at different price levels.
If a survey indicated that, as many people suspect, vacancies now exceed the limit, the law should be allowed to run its course, subject to existing leases.
With the city cutting vital services and flirting with new taxes that could stifle the economy, rent control can no longer be viewed as a politically benign way to do a favor for tenants at the expense of everyone else in New York. Ignoring the economics of such unjustified subsidies has become political treason to the city and particularly to those in its population who depend most on public services.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Layoffs Line the Road to Recovery

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Last month's surge in unemployment made a lot of people wonder how the recession can wind down as long as workers are losing jobs. In fact, layoffs and unemployment typically keep climbing long after spending starts to revive.
 "What surprises people is that everything doesn't happen simultaneously," said Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. 
 No one can say for sure that a recovery will arrive between Memorial Day and Labor Day, as many economists expect. But the pattern of past recessions strongly suggests that the transition from economic contraction to expansion takes months and progresses in fits and starts. "Recessions are more predictable than expansions," noted Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
If the typical pattern persists, the economy will shed jobs right up until the recovery starts. What is more, unemployment will keep rising for several months after the recession ends. Not only will business bolster production, at first by extending overtime and raising productivity, but more people will flood into the labor market as the chances of quickly finding work start to improve.
"We could get another month of decline in payrolls of 200,000 or 250,000, as in March," said Stephen Roach, a Morgan Stanley economist who expects growth to resume this summer. "After that, you'd expect the declines to taper off to 100,000 to 150,000."
Here is how past recessions have ended: First, the forces that toppled the economy dissipate. The Federal Reserve provides stimulus with more money and lower interest rates. Investors and consumers turn more optimistic, and after a while, spending comes sporadically.
 
Orders Filled From Stockpiles
 Business does not rehire laid-off workers right away. Initially, companies fill orders with goods that piled up during the slump. Then the layoffs stop, usually signaling the end of the recession.
Consider the previous recession, which lasted from January 1981 through November 1982. The economy lost more than 300,000 jobs in July 1982 and roughly 200,000 jobs a month in each of the last four months of the recession. Payrolls even dipped a bit in December 1982, the first month of the recovery. Further, businesses started aggressively expanding their work forces only in March 1983, and unemployment topped out at 10.8 percent early that year.
In short, sales pick up months before companies start rehiring. Consumer spending starts to recover even though many people are still losing their jobs or are having trouble finding work. Increasingly confident consumers who have hung onto their jobs start spending, more than offseting the loss of buying power of workers being laid off.
How do economists expect this recession to end? "We've got some of the preconditions for a turnaround," Mr. Boskin said. The war is over, oil prices are down and inflation is falling. With the Federal Reserve easing monetary policy, the money supply is rapidly growing and both short- and long-term interest rates have fallen substantially from the levels of the fall. Investors have turned bullish, and consumers' spirits have revived.
"The process has already begun," said Mr. Steinberg of Merrill Lynch.
 
Housing Rebounds First
 Housing is almost always the first segment of the economy to perk up. "The reason is that as mortgage rates come down, housing becomes more affordable for people who haven't lost their jobs," Mr. Steinberg said. Now, for example, houses are more affordable than they have been in 14 years, according to the National Association of Realtors. Besides, only about a million people buy a brand-new house in any given year, and recently many fewer have been buying. It thus takes only a small fraction of the 95 million American households to spark a rebound by buying new homes.
Sales of new and existing homes jumped in February, and surveys by the Mortgage Bankers Association and the National Association of Home Builders suggest that sales -- especially of the entry-level houses that first-time buyers purchase -- continued to head up in March.
A revival in home buying typically spills over to spending on everything from sinks to sofas, as buyers feather their new nests. At the same time, consumers who had postponed car purchases start showing up again at dealers' lots.
 
Recovery Takes Time
 "This will be consumer-led, not a business-led recovery," said David W. Mullins, the new vice chairman of the Federal Reserve. But it usually takes time for the economy to shift from recession to expansion, and there are setbacks.
"There's a dissonance between attitudes and spending right now," Mr. Mullins said. "It's a mirror image of last summer, when attitudes stank, but sales kept going for a couple of months after confidence collapsed."
While consumer confidence has rebounded strongly, car sales edged up only a bit in February and March. Beyond slightly higher factory orders for consumer goods, there is no sign yet of a broader revival of spending.
Such a revival would not necessarily spell instant relief from layoffs. For starters, business outlays for machinery and buildings usually turn down toward the end of a recession. Such outlays -- which amount to about a tenth of the gross national product, compared with two-thirds for consumer spending -- rose in the first months of the recession.
More important, "when consumer spending starts to stabilize," Mr. Roach said, "the classical pattern is for business to keep trimming production and cutting costs." That is because inventories typically pile up during the first leg of the downturn.
"Clearing shelves of excess stocks can take months," Mr. Roach added. Cars are a case in point. Although the annual selling rate is running slightly above six million, the Big Three and the Japanese auto makers with United States plants are holding production below a five million annual rate.
One reason for hope this time around is that business was a lot quicker to respond to the collapse in demand. Consumption fell sharply in the fall, and businesses immediately slashed inventories at an annual rate of $28 billion -- nearly a record.
"This is the promptest move in any recession since the 50's," Mr. Roach said. Contrast that to the 1973-75 recession, when business held onto workers and kept turning out goods nearly a year into the slump. Finally, the bottom fell out of the economy and unemployment soared to 9 percent. Despite the fact that inventories are thin by past standards, Mr. Roach expects businesses to do more trimming, since they are still a bit fatter than executives would like.
But at some point, business must step up production just to keep inventories from falling further. To be sure, there are risks that this process, which seems to have started already, could be short-circuited. One risk is that the credit drought will persist. "Our concern is that if the tightness continues, it would be a substantial moderating force," said Mr. Mullins of the Federal Reserve. "We are concerned about bankers being willing to lend to home builders and exporters."
A bigger threat is that consumers will become discouraged or run out of cash before business stops retrenching. "It's a race between consumers who want to spend and business that wants to cut costs," said David Kelly, an economist at DRI/McGraw Hill. Nonetheless, he says he expects consumers to hang in there.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
SmithKline's Expiring Patents

BYLINE: By Steven Prokesch

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
SINCE last April, the prices of the British shares and American equity units of SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., the British drug company, have soared 73 percent and 80 percent, respectively.
Many analysts still recommend buying them, on expectations they could climb more. But a growing number are urging investors to be conservative in their purchases or to stop buying. They are uneasy about SmithKline's ability to come up with new drugs to take over from some of the company's main drugs on which patents have or soon will expire. Those are Tagamet, an anti-ulcer drug; Amoxil, an antibiotic, and Dyazide, an anti-hypertension medicine. 
 Analysts cite two main reasons for the rise in the stock and equity units, each of which equals five British shares. Investors poured money into drug companies because earnings were seen to be relatively immune to a recession. And SmithKline Beecham, the product of the mid-1989 merger between Britain's Beecham and America's SmithKline Beckman, has been winning over skeptical investors by carrying out many promises made at the time of the merger.
It has reduced its staff by 2,900 people, sold $1.2 billion worth of assets (mainly cosmetics and food businesses), and closed 48 factories, distribution operations and offices. Last year it increased its operating profit margin by 3.8 points, to 20.8 percent, and slashed net debt by 61 percent, to $1.31 billion. And its sales force of 6,000 has significantly raised the sales of drugs like Augmentin, an antibiotic that had revenues of $793 million in 1990.
Despite their rise, SmithKline's securities still look like a bargain to some. The 10 leading drug company stocks in the United States are trading at about 18.5 times their expected 1991 earnings. SmithKline shares have been trading on the London stock exchange at a multiple of about 16. The American depository receipts for the shares closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $70.625. Possibly because of confusion about the tax treatment of their dividends and because index funds no longer buy SmithKline, the equity units have been trading at a multiple of about 14.5 on the New York exchange, where they closed yesterday at $62.375.
London-based Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities Ltd. thinks the merger benefits will flow into the mid-1990's. It strongly recommends buying SmithKline securities. But analysts at Goldman, Sachs & Company and Merrill Lynch & Company believe the merger benefits will keep earnings growing 15 to 20 percent annually for only another year or two. They are worried about after 1992.
"The future is easier to see for other companies with more identifiable blockbuster products in their pipeline like Merck, Bristol-Myers Squibb and Glaxo," said Paul Krikler of Goldman, Sachs. He recently changed his recommendation on SmithKline from "buy" to "attractive," the equivalent of a weak buy.
The patent on SmithKline's biggest-selling drug, Tagamet, begins to expire in Europe this year, in Japan in 1992 and in the United States in 1994. That will open it up to significant competition from generic versions of the anti-ulcer drug. It continues to face tough competition from Glaxo's Zantac, a similar drug that is the market leader, and from Losec, a new competitor sold by Astra and Merck. Tagamet sales were flat in 1990, at $1.21 billion.
"I'm worried about Tagamet coming off patent," said Eile Gibson of Merrill Lynch. "I don't think SmithKline has enough firepower in its product range for the longer term."
Amoxil's and Dyazide's patents have already expired. Amoxil's sales, which analysts estimate at about $450 million, have been slipping. But Dyzazide got a break last year, when two companies had to withdraw generic versions from the American market because they had submitted fraudulent data to the Food and Drug Administration. Dyazide sales rose by 28 percent last year, to about $300 million, said Neil B. Sweig, an analyst at the Brenner Securities Corporation in New York.
"Probably not this year but more likely next, Dyazide could begin to face significant competition from generics," Mr. Sweig said. SmithKline is trying to soften the blow by supplying a generic form to Rugby, a big generic-drug company.
One promising new SmithKline drug is Engerix-B, a genetically engineered hepatitis B vaccine. Mr. Krikler of Goldman, Sachs says it had sales of about $160 million last year. Some analysts are also optimistic about Seroxat, a new treatment for depression and anxiety.
Analysts are less optimistic about other drugs that SmithKline is rolling out. These include: Eminase, for treating heart attacks; Relifex, an anti-inflammatory drug, and Granisetron, for countering nausea caused by cancer chemotherapy. Analysts question whether they will be demonstrably superior to those of competitors.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Faxes Are Coming

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
"YOU can't shake hands with a fax," headlined the ad from Go-USA, a coalition of companies seeking to put the bloom back in the cheeks of the depressed travel business. "Nothing can replace . . . the special feeling that comes only from being there." But such considerations have not stopped Arthur D. Little, a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass., from imagining an America in which improved telecommunications replaced 10 to 20 percent of the miles now logged by commuters, shoppers and business travelers.
No one really knows whether millions of Americans could be persuaded to let their fingers do most of the walking. Nor has anyone figured who would ante up the $200 billion-plus to rewire the nation for working and shopping at home, or how the services would be regulated. 
 But the study, underwritten by a communications equipment manufacturer and a handful of regional phone companies, does make a striking case for "demand side" solutions to what have always been seen as "supply side" problems of road congestion and related pollution. At very least, argues Ashok Boghani, an engineer at Arthur D. Little and the principal author of the study, telecommunications deserves a place at the planning table with expensive, high-tech transportation projects.
Suppose super-fast microprocessors, flat-panel high-definition television screens and fiber-optic cable made it practical to shop and perform most white-collar jobs by wire. The researchers estimate that some six million workers would abandon commuting, while 13 million business trips would be replaced with teleconferences each year. Householders would make three billion fewer shopping excursions; truck and airplane delivery miles would fall by 600 million annually.
That, in turn, would cut pollutants by an estimated 1.8 million tons, reduce gasoline consumption by 3.5 billion gallons and free 3.1 billion hours of time otherwise spent on the road. Plug in some plausible numbers for the value of avoiding fuel use, pollution and time in traffic, and you get a total annual savings of $23 billion.
To put this figure in perspective, the researchers made comparable estimates of the potential savings from three supply-side remedies for traffic and pollution headaches. High-speed rail systems in a half-dozen urban corridors might save as much as $1.2 billion annually. Signaling and control technologies that shoehorned more vehicles into limited road space might save $2 billion to $4 billion. Cleaner substitutes for gasoline might cut pollution costs by $6 billion to $8 billion.
These estimated benefits do not mean a great deal, of course, unless they can be compared with costs. And here the researchers offer only back-of-the-envelope calculations. At $89 billion, construction of a high-speed rail network seems a pricey fix. The $35 billion for intelligent vehicles and highways seems more within reach, as does $86 billion for a mass conversion to methanol-burning cars.
A high-technology telecommunications network would be far, far more expensive: perhaps $200 billion for the fiber-optic data network to replace copper wires in most homes and businesses, the researchers say, plus another $100 billion or so for the hardware and software to make good use of it. But the ratio of capital costs to annual benefits would be in the same ball park as fixes based on smart vehicles or clean fuels. And in any case, the savings in time and pollution measured in the study probably represent only the tail of the high-capacity telecommunications dog.
If American homes are wired with fiber-optic cable anytime soon, many experts believe, the driving force will be video entertainment. Television in general (and high-definition television in particular) uses enormous amounts of data carrying capacity, which can be most efficiently delivered with a fiber-optic network. Most likely, then, services that reduced the demand for transportation would be able to piggy-back at little cost on a system primarily designed to supply everything from choose-your-own-ending soap operas to the interactive sex shows from Bangkok.
Regulating this yet to be designed techno-miracle would pose unique problems. Peter Pitsch, a former Federal Communications Commission staff member who is now a Washington consultant, wonders how data services would be priced. Would, for example, telephones that used just one-thousandth as much capacity as high-definition television be charged just one-thousandth as much?
But all this is beside the researchers' point. Big changes in telecommunications are coming, they suggest. And while transportation savings may represent a modest fraction of the benefit, communications is bound to be a plausible alternative to getting from here to there.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
End of Slump Seen in Quarter

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP)

 BODY:
Seventy percent of the nation's top economists believe that the United States economy will pull out of the recession in the current quarter, according to a survey released today.
The survey, by Blue Chip Economic Indicators, a newsletter in Sedona, Ariz., showed that the participants were more optimistic than those in a poll in January, when 66 percent forecast that the recession would end in this quarter. 
 Seventy-six percent now believe that the recession began last August or September, up from 61 percent in January. Just 7 percent said it began last October, down from 23 percent in the earlier poll.
Thirteen percent projected that the recession would extend into the third quarter, down from 26 percent in the January survey. The average length of previous postwar recessions was 11 months.
The consensus forecast also expects a contraction in the nation's gross national product of 1.7 percent at an annual rate, compared with the average shrinkage of 2.6 percent in previous postwar downturns.

HEADLINE: Missouri Tries to Revamp Public Schools

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo.

 BODY:
This fiscally conservative state, which ranks in the bottom quarter in spending on education, is debating an ambitious plan to fine-tune its public education system and increase spending $460 million a year.
At a public meeting in the State Capitol here on Wednesday, a special legislative committee will hear from corporate leaders, educators and taxpayers on a proposed $460 million public referendum that would increase the state sales tax, cigarette tax and corporate income tax, among other changes, to raise the state's level of education spending almost 25 percent. 
 The plan would also give the state commissioner of higher education and the State Board of Education new powers to plan and carry out major education changes.
Missouri spends $1.9 billion on public education. Per student, it ranks 38th in spending on elementary and secondary schools and 46th in spending on higher education.
 
Billed as a Survival Plan
 The education bill passed the Missouri Senate last month. If the Assembly approves it, the referendum would be placed on the general election ballot in November.
Since 1980, when Missouri residents won the right to vote on any large tax changes in a public referendum, four of five propositions put before voters have been approved.
But a coalition of businesses, led by the Missouri Chamber of Commerce, opposes the referendum proposal. "To just give more money and trust they will spend it wisely is not good enough for us," said Tony Reinhart, the legislative specialist for the chamber.
State officials who support the referendum, called the Economic Survival Act of 1991, have presented it as an economic strategy for Missouri's future, predicting that unless elementary and high school education is improved, and unless more college students are educated to perform basic research and to communicate in a global economy, the state could lose its competetive edge.
The referendum would increase spending at all levels of public education, including small increases for job training and development. The largest share of the package would be used to reorganize Missouri's 10 university campuses, 3 state colleges and 12 community college districts.
Charles J. McClain, Commissioner of the Missouri Coordinating Board for Higher Education, an advisory board for the state's colleges and universities, said the current system was so unbalanced that in 1989 it awarded more than 14,000 undergraduate degrees, but only 65 of them in foreign languages, 114 in mathematics and 209 in the physical sciences, areas he called essential to Missouri's economic survival.
The same year, Missouri's public institutions awarded 3,662 degrees in business, 2,293 in education and 1,173 in engineering, according to state reports.
Dr. McClain said such imbalances have been masked by the system's overall enrollment gains.
"For too long we've been interested in quantity over quality," he said. "This is a call for the refining of missions so that every instituion doesn't try to do everything for everyone."
If the referendum is approved by voters, the Coordinating Board will be given greater authority over colleges and univerities, which now enjoy an unusual degree of autonomy. Each institution would be encouraged to become a specialized center of learning, focusing on science, for example, or telecommunications, while forgoing a more general curriculum.
The institutions would be offered financial incentives from the referendum money to comply with many of the changes, including those that could mean a drop in student enrollment. Each institution could choose to reject the board's recommendations.
"If they don't want to play, fine," Dr. McClain said. "But then they don't get the money."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "For too long, we've been interested in quantity over quality," said Charles J. McClain, head of the Missouri Coordinating Board for Higher Education. He said the current system was unbalanced. (David Hutson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bank Funds And C.D.'s Fall Again

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts fell for the period ended yesterday -- their sixth straight weekly drop -- with yield declines a little larger than the previous week.
In the New York market, were banks set yields slightly more aggressively than in most of the country, yields on certificates of deposit slipped further, with commercial banks leading the way. 
 Analysts at The Bank Rate Monitor, an interest-rate publication based in North Palm Beach, Fla., noted that many in the banking industry expected this trend toward lower yields to end in the near future.
With yields on certificates down so low, some bank customers are scrambling to find higher yields elsewhere, while others wanting to keep their cash in federally insured banks are rolling over maturing C.D.'s into those with longer maturities, trying to improve their yields somewhat.
At the Treasury Department's weekly auction of short-term bills held on Monday, average discount rates dropped sharply from the previous auction. The auction's results often influence what many banks pay on their money market accounts and certificates of deposit.
The yield on a three-month bill fell by 20 basis points, to 5.60 percent, the lowest since November 1987, while the yield on the six-month bill fell by 11 basis points, to 5.68 percent, the lowest since July 1987. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
In its weekly survey of New York area banks, the publication noted that after weeks of larger yield declines at savings institutions, commercial banks have moved out in front.
The largest yield declines for the New York region this week were recorded at the Republic National Bank of New York, which cut the yield on its money market account by 35 basis points, to 5.65 percent; on its three-month certificate by 43 basis points, also to 5.65 percent, and on its six-month certificate by 59 basis points, to the same yield.
Commercial banks this week lowered the yields on their money market accounts by 5 basis points, to 5.50 percent, and on three-month certificates by 8 basis points, to 5.93 percent. The yield on the longer six-month ceritificate was cut by 10 basis points, to 6.07 percent.
At savings institutions, the average money market account yield was cut by 2 basis points, to 5.78 percent, while that on a three-month certificate was cut by 7 basis points, to 6.33 percent, and the yield on a six-month certificate by 6 basis points, to 6.55 percent.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Decline Slightly

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dipped in listless trading yesterday, as dealers sold some securities in advance of an auction today of $8.5 billion worth of new seven-year Treasury notes.
In addition, a clear signal from the Federal Reserve Board that it has not eased monetary policy did not seem to sit well with the debt market. 
 The Fed drained reserves from the banking system yesterday when the overnight Federal funds rate was trading at 5 13/16 percent, under the 6 percent rate that is regarded as the Fed's target.
 
'Things Are on Hold'
 "The Fed made it very clear that things are on hold for the time being," said Kristin Foster, an economist at Citicorp Investment Bank.
Still, a number of analysts continue to say the Fed will push down short-term rates soon.
"We still expect the Fed to ease the funds rate to 5 3/4 percent within the next two weeks," said Maria Fiorini Ramirez, president of Ramirez Capital Consultants Inc.
Aside from watching the Fed, traders said there was little to do. With significant inflation figures expected on Thursday and Friday, traders said there was little reason for clients to do business now.
Right now, "the signals are very mixed," said David R. Duerson, manager of government bond trading at Security Pacific Bank in Los Angeles. "Customers are pretty fully invested, and the Street is confused about the market's long-term prospects."
 
30-Year Bond Yields 8.20%
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 96 3/8, down 14/32, to yield 8.20 percent, up from 8.15 percent late Monday.
Among note issues, the 7 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 6/32, down 3/8 point, to yield 8.01 percent. And the 7 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 11/32, down 3/32, to yield 6.93 percent.
In when-issued trading late yesterday, the seven-year Treasury notes to be auctioned this afternoon were offered at a price to yield 7.91 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates rose slightly.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.59 percent, up a basis point, or one one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 5.67 percent. And one-year bill rates rose by 3 basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.85 percent.
A number of issues were offered in the tax-exempt municipal bond market yesterday, including the competitive sale of a two-part $155 million issue for the State of Ohio.
The largest part of the issue, $110 million worth of serial bonds, was won by a group led by Morgan Stanley & Company.
The issue, which is insured by the Ambac Indemnity Corporation, consists of serial bonds with maturities from 1992 to 2006. The securities maturing in 1992 were not reoffered to investors.
Yields on the bonds that were reoffered range from 5.30 percent on securities maturing in 1993 to a maximum of 6.70 percent on bonds maturing in 2005 and 2006.
The issue is rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt bonds, traders said prices of most widely quoted issues declined by about 1/4 point.
Yesterday's drop of 45.54 points in the Dow Jones industrial average had little impact in the high-yield "junk bond" market. Junk bond prices are often affected by movements in stock prices, but market participants said most issues showed little change yesterday.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said prices of most issues dipped by 1/8 point to 1/4 point in light trading.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Steep Declines After German Rate Increase

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply on world currency markets yesterday as investors focused on interest rates.
Gold prices advanced. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $364.90 an ounce, up $3.10 from Monday. The Republic National Bank said gold rose $3.15, to a late bid of $363.80. 
 The dollar fell in European trading. Traders said the decline came after the German central bank notched up the interest rate on repurchase agreements to 8.6 percent.
Although the rate advanced only a tenth of a percentage point, there was concern that it signaled "the beginning of an initial tightening by the Germans," said Earl Johnson, a vice president with Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
Traders fear that the Bundesbank might be planning more rate increases in the coming weeks. Higher foreign interest rates are generally bearish for the dollar since investors who want to capture those returns must buy foreign currencies to do so. In the process, they would sell dollars.
When trading shifted to domestic markets yesterday, dealers expressed the additional concern that the Federal Reserve might proceed with a rate cut of its own, further widening the differential between United States and foreign interest rates.
Market observers said the Fed is likely to take its cue from economic data to be released later this week, especially the producer price report and Consumer Price Index for March, due out Thursday and Friday, respectively.
"Interest rates are back at the forefront of today's market," said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Mitsubishi Bank in New York "That was the catalyst that got the selling rolling."
Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar was quoted at 135.00 yen, down sharply from its previous close of 137.00. In New York, the dollar settled at 134.85 yen, down from 137.15 yen on Monday.
In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.7900, up from $1.7685 late Monday. In New York it cost $1.7945 to buy one pound, up from $1.7650 on Monday.

HEADLINE: Republicans Court Foes To Oppose Weicker Tax

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, April 9

 BODY:
The Republican Party, the long-suffering minority in Connecticut's legislature, has joined a growing list of individuals and interest groups willing to follow Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. in tossing tradition on the ash heap.
The tradition Republicans plan to toss, however, is not their opposition to a state income tax. Instead, they say they will reject orthodoxy by crossing the aisle to seek a pact with Democrats to kill Mr. Weicker's income-tax plan. 
 On the political stage transformed by Mr. Weicker's election as an independent and his sweeping tax and budget proposals, the Republicans are the latest group to declare themselves as active players who hope to influence the final result.
 
Controls on Spending
 Mr. Weicker earlier won support for his income tax from leading business groups, which like the Governor's plan to cut business taxes but are also seeking controls on state spending. Unions representing state employees are prepared to condition wage and benefit concessions on the passage of an income tax, which they see as the only way to assure stable finances in the future.
But the Republican initiative marks the beginning of what some politicians say will be the middle game in the state's attempt to resolve a budget shortfall that is now expected to reach $2.6 billion over the next 15 months.
The party's alternative budget, still sketchy in detail, is based around a rise in sales tax collections, deeper cuts in state spending and layoffs of more state employees than proposed by Mr. Weicker, but no income tax.
 
'A Defining Moment'
 If Republicans and Democrats join to pass such a plan, the General Assembly will have thwarted a governor and laid the groundwork for a bitter fight over a potential veto. If it fails, the aisle will still have been crossed.
"This is a defining moment for the legislature," said the State Senate's highest-ranking Democrat, John B. Larson of East Hartford, the chamber's president pro tempore.
The Republicans, who have 16 members in the 36-seat Senate, say they are united around their plan and need only three Democrats to pass an alternative there and 13 votes in the House of Representatives. Mr. Larson, while noncommittal, reaffirmed at least his philosophical opposition to an income tax after meeting with Republican leaders on Monday.
Some Democrats are even more to the point.
"God bless them," said Senator George Jepsen, a Democrat from Stamford and a firm income-tax opponent, referring to the Republicans. But if the traditional roles inside the General Assembly are breaking down, so too are those outside the legislature as a whole new list of players in the budget process -- notably the state's big business organizations and labor unions -- have emerged to work their influence as Mr. Weicker's allies. More characters mean a far less predictable resolution than the numbers of votes in the legislature might indicate, people in both parties say.
For example, the unions representing state employees -- all firmly in support of an income tax because they say a dependable revenue stream would make their jobs more secure in the long run -- are now negotiating with the Weicker administration on a $400 million package of wage and benefit concessions.
 
'A Pivotal Role'
 Union leaders say that whatever givebacks are finally agreed on will be contingent on the survival of the income tax. If the Weicker plan goes down, they say, all bets are off. The Republican plan, or the bipartisan plan, as Republicans prefer to call it, is hinged on the same $400 million package being sought by Mr. Weicker. Union leaders say they are a tool, or perhaps a bludgeon, ready and willing to be used Mr. Weicker against the General Assembly if he so chooses.
"As Governor, he understands that he can go to the legislature and say, I have X millions from the unions, but the whole deal is jeopardized if there isn't something that provides stability for the unions in the future," said Jerome P. Brown, president of the 18,000-member District 1199 of the New England Health Care Employees Union. "We have a pivotal role."
The business groups, led by the 7,000-member Connecticut Business and Industry Association and the Insurance Association of Connecticut, representing the huge insurance companies based mostly in Hartford, have said they would use their influence on behalf of an income tax plan if it includes signficant cuts in business taxes and some method of controlling future growth in state spending.
 
Sales Tax Collections
 Any plan that does not meet those standards will be fully and vigorously opposed, the groups say. Where the Republican plan falls is still uncertain. It would lower corporate taxes as much as Mr. Weicker's, to 11.5 percent from 13.8 percent. But collections from the sales tax, about 40 percent of which is paid by businessess, would rise significantly.
The new proposal would lower the sales tax by at least one-half of 1 percent from the current 8 percent rate, Republicans said. But previously untaxed items would be added to bring in more revenue. No list was provided because most of the details remain to be worked out in negotiations with potential Democratic converts.
Some politicians say those negotiations will make the old predictable two-party world seem like simplicity itself.
"It used to be the Warsaw Pact vs. NATO, with two defined coalitions and all the players on one side of the fence or another," Mr. Jepsen said. "Now it's back to the 1830's and days of Metternich -- coalitions are going to be free-floating and temporary and you'll see a lot of groups playing ball who until now have been shut out of the process."
Mr. Weicker proposed in February a comprehensive plan that he said would both resolve the budget shortfall and stimulate the economy. It would lower the 8 percent sales tax to 4.25 percent but expand the base of taxable items to include things like movie tickets, gasoline and inexpensive clothing.
 
Tax on Dividends
 The existing income tax on dividends and interest, which now peaks at 14 percent for incomes over $100,000, would be scrapped, as would the 7 percent capital-gains tax now assessed on profits from the sale of stock or other assets. Instead, all income would be treated equally and taxed at a flat 6 percent rate on adjusted gross income over $25,000 for a family or $12,500 for an individual.
The Republican alternative would put a cap on the dividends and interest tax, probably resulting in a tax cut for those families in top income categories, but specifics are still not available.
The Governor's press secretary, Avice A. Meehan, said Mr. Weicker would not have any reaction to the alternative until some complete proposal was presented.
"This is just selected bits and pieces," she said.

HEADLINE: New York Tests Electronic Ball and Chain

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB

 BODY:
New York City jail guards strapped electronic transmitters on the left ankles of two inmates and then opened the gates for them. As the men strolled from the Brooklyn House of Detention last month they became the first to be released under a city program in which defendants awaiting trial are placed under house arrest and monitored by electronic surveillance.
"They will be under severe confinement," said Michael DeCicco, an assistant deputy warden in the city's Correction Department, who supervises the electronic-surveillance program. "The key difference is that someone else, not the city, is paying their rent." Such routine behavior as taking a walk, visiting a neighbor, going to a restaurant or to a movie, is forbidden. 
 The program begins more than three years after the State Legislature first approved the use of alternatives to incarceration for city inmates. Under state law, inmates charged with nonviolent crimes can be released from jail and placed under house arrest and supervised by the Correction Department.
At least 40 states, including New Jersey, use electronic monitoring in one way or another.
City officials said the recent introduction of electronic monitoring makes it economically feasible to introduce a large-scale alternative program. Allyn R. Sielaff, the city's Correction Commissioner, said in an interview that successful electronic surveillance might persuade the State Legislature to give him wider authority to free pre-trial inmates charged with nonviolent crimes. Current regulations, he said, limit the program to 100 inmates, but the city hopes the Legislature will allow an increase to 1,000.
Freeing 1,000 prisoners, city officials say, would give immediate relief to overcrowded city jails, save the city $35 million a year in prison maintenance costs and alleviate the long-term need for new jail construction. Mr. DeCicco said it costs the city $158 a day to house an inmate. The cost of monitoring an inmate electronically is $60 a day. About 15,000 pretrial detainees are now in city jails.
The executive director of the Correctional Association of New York, Robert Gangi, questioned whether the Correction Department is the one to manage a large alternative program.
"These programs are tough to run and politically risky," Mr. Gangi said. "One mistake -- one violent crime committed by someone who has been released -- and the entire concept goes up in flames."
Spokesmen for legislative leaders agreed in part, saying that Mr. Sielaff's requests faced an uncertain fate this year.
"It's a very sensitive issue," said John E. McArdle, press secretary for Senator Ralph J. Marino of Oyster Bay, L.I., a Republican and majority leader of the Senate. "When cost is the consideration versus the safety of the public we get very concerned."
Fred Jacobs, the counsel to the Codes Committee in the Democratic-controlled Assembly, added, "We want to be convinced by the city administrators that they are using all the tools at their disposal before we embark on any changes."
 
Strict Limits on Behavior
 Under the city program, inmates will be screened to determine that they have nonviolent backgrounds and that they are viewed as good risks to show up in court for hearings and trials.
In each case, the inmate will be required to wear a square, black, three-ounce plastic ankle transmitter at all times. An electronic receiver will be installed in his home to pick up the transmitter's coded signal. If an inmate strays from home without permission, the signal ceases and an alarm is transmitted by a computer to the Correction Department, subjecting the inmate to instant rearrest.
At work and at home, inmates are subject to unannounced visits by correction officers. Except for traveling to and from work or to school or rehabilitation-counseling sessions, the inmates are confined to their homes until their criminal cases are resolved. To leave for personal or medical emergencies, they must get clearance by telephoning a Correction Department officer.
Present state law bars defendants who are arrested for violent offenses or who are charged with the highest crime categoriesfrom release under any alternative program.
In the opening phase of the city program, up to 30 more pretrial inmates will receive electronic anklets, Mr. DiCicco said. Electronic monitoring as an alternative to incarceration has been used in the country since 1986, mainly with convicted nonviolent offenders on parole or probation. A study last year by the United States Justice Department found that in 1989, about 6,500 convicted inmates were out of prison under electronic sanctions.
The first two city inmates under electronic supervision had never been in jail before their arrests in February. Both agreed to be interviewed on the condition that they would be identified only by their given names.
Felix, who is 28 years old and a parking lot attendant, was accused of driving while intoxicated in Brooklyn.
"It was important for me to get out because I can get into an alcoholic counseling program, and I don't want my family to go on welfare," said Felix, who was in jail for three weeks, unable to raise $750 bail. He lives with his wife and 9-year-old daugther in the East New York section of Brooklyn. John, 25, a construction worker from the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn was detained seven weeks on bail of $2,500 after being arrested on charges of unauthorized use of a car and possession of stolen property -- the car he was driving.
As conditions of their release and until they return to their regular jobs, both men agreed to work as cleaners and painters in the House of Detention in downtown Brooklyn. Like incarcerated inmates who are assigned to work details, each is paid $14 for a 35-hour week.
The men said they quickly adapted to walking, sleeping and bathing with the waterproof transmitters.
"This strap is keeping me out of trouble," said Felix in an interview at the Brooklyn jail.

GRAPHIC: Photo: An electronic transmitter on the ankle of one of the first two inmates to be released under a city program in which defendants awaiting trial are placed under house arrest and monitored by electronic surveillance. (Nancy Siesel for The New York Times) (pg. B2)
