HEADLINE: Budget Woe Gets Worse For Dinkins

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
The Dinkins administration, already struggling to balance New York City's budget, got more bad news yesterday: further erosion in tax collections and renewed refusals by municipal union leaders to cooperate by making money-saving concessions.
New figures indicate that the city will collect $90 million less in personal income taxes this fiscal year than it expected. 
 That word came as union leaders scoffed at the idea of discussing concessions at a meeting scheduled for today, just weeks after both sides had seemed to agree to cooperate.
The latest tax shortfall brings to nearly $1 billion the amount that the administration has been faced with trimming from the current budget since last summer. On top of that, there is a total projected gap of more than $3 billion in the $29 billion budget for the fiscal year that starts July 1.
 
Little Time to Recoup
 The personal income tax is sensitive to ups and downs in the city's economy and has varied widely from expectations in the past. But city officials said they were taken aback by the $90 million falloff in March receipts, since it came with only three months left in the fiscal year.
Budget Director Philip R. Michael speculated that lower corporate bonuses might have helped cut tax receipts, and he said the city was not sure whether the decline would continue.
He said he was reviewing what further service cuts or other actions the city would have to take to make up the difference. At the very least, he said, purchasing of supplies would slow.
The city has a reserve fund of $150 million in the budget, but that is already committed to covering previous tax shortfalls and reductions in state aid and other needs, budget officials said. "We're very concerned," said First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel.
Meantime, just three weeks after the city and the unions agreed in a meeting with Mayor David N. Dinkins to talk quietly about how labor could help the city control its fiscal problems in the coming months, union leaders made clear that nothing had happened on the eve of a meeting to be held with city officials today.
 
Union Leaders Balk
 Sandra Feldman, head of the teachers' union, said she would not attend the session, to be led by Mr. Steisel. "It's a discussion about concessions," she said. "We're not going to do any concessions. We've done a very substantial wage deferral, and we're not going to do more than that."
Stanley Hill, executive director of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the largest city workers union, also said he would not discuss givebacks.
Aides to Barry Feinstein, president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said he, too, planned to tell the city that he would not make concessions.
Just after Mr. Dinkins and the unions began their latest round of discussions, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said that unless the city unions agreed to concessions, he would not even considering helping the city with hundreds of millions of dollars in possible relief from bond refinancings or other fiscal maneuevers. But Mr. Feinstein and others have said they will not agree to concessions until the Governor puts whatever state-controlled money he has on the table.
Last month Mr. Dinkins said that among the "contributions" from labor that he would seek, totaling hundreds of millions of dollars, could be changes in health benefits, reductions in the number of paid holidays and changes in workmen's compensation benefits and work rules.
But union leaders said the city had not yet given them a convincing rationale for cooperating and had not shown them just what additional city programs and services would have to be cut if they did not cooperate. "There's not a feeling of any order in the situation," one union head said.

HEADLINE: Program Selling Pushes Dow Down 45.54

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Heavy waves of program selling toppled the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday, carrying the broader market down sharply as well.
Trading rose to 169.9 million shares, from 138.6 million the day before, but traders said activity was so slow at times yesterday that computer-driven selling exaggerated price movements considerably.
 
Down by 1.6 Percent
 The Dow, which advanced nearly 22 points the day before on program buying, sank 45.54 yesterday, or 1.6 percent, to 2,873.02. 
 The S.&P. 500 slid almost as much, but the smaller stocks, as measured by the Nasdaq composite and the American Stock Exchange's market value index, edged down only slightly.
Declines led advances almost 2 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange, but while 5 stocks reached 52-week lows, 90 climbed to 52-week highs.
Time Warner again hit a high of 119 before closing at 114 3/4, down 3 3/4. It rose 4 1/2 last week and 6 1/4 on Monday amid talk that it was exploring a number of ways to raise at least $500 million and possibly considerably more, including through a joint venture, to pay off part of its huge debt. One person close to senior company officials said, "None of the possibilities has any substance."
Traders attributed the selloff to Federal Reserve dealings intended to drain money from the banking system and thus raise the Fed funds rate, which banks charge one another for overnight money.
Investors had speculated earlier that the Fed had actually eased rates but soon concluded that the Fed's movements telegraphed that it was tightening rates for the moment to bring them up to its 6 percent target.
Traders said that while the plan to tighten the funds rate was not entirely successful, it signaled the Fed's present intention not to ease policy for the moment. But they argued that the Fed could still ease if inflation figures due tomorrow and Friday show, as expected, that price pressure is not strong.
Explaining how low volume affects program trading, Laszlo Birinyi Jr., president of Birinyi Associates, said, "When you have a little bit of selling in a period when activity is not that great, the impact of the selling is accentuated."
He noted that the Dow lost almost 25 points from 1 P.M. to 3 P.M., when volume amounted to only 21 million shares an hour.
Seven waves of computerized selling, he said, chopped the Dow a total of 38 points. From 1:50 P.M. on, wave after wave of selling accounted for most of it.
 
Identity Widely Known
 The identity of the traders is widely known but precisely which ones were active at any given time is difficult to determine. The New York Stock Exchange has repeatedly identified the main ones as Paine Webber, Bear Stearns, Goldman, Sachs, Susquehanna and Morgan Stanley.
David B. Bostian Jr., chief economist and strategist for Jesup, Josephthal & Company, estimated yesterday that two-thirds of the Dow's drop yesterday could be attributed to sell programs and the rest to apprehension over the inflation figures to be released this week.
"There's some apprehension the numbers may be higher than the Fed wants to see," he said, with the implication that the Fed might not ease rates if the numbers are not to its liking.
He said traders were also uneasy about what he called internal politics at the Fed, where some Federal Reserve presidents are said to have disputed the right of Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Fed, to act on his own to change the Fed funds rate.
"The market is unduly concerned," he said of the inflation figures. He said he thought the numbers "won't be upsetting" and that the Fed would lower both the Fed funds rate and the discount rate, at which it lends to banks, "before too many weeks pass." Just to play safe, he added that action could even happen much sooner.
The decline among the Dow stocks was widespread, with losses of more than a point in I.B.M., Merck, Sears, Roebuck, Eastman Kodak, McDonald's, Boeing and United Technologies.
Along with I.B.M., other technology stocks gave way. Intel fell 1 7/8, to 46 5/8; Apple Computer 1 1/4, to 68 3/4; Hewlett-Packard 1 3/8, to 50; Borland 2 1/8, to 58 3/8, and Microsoft 1 1/8, to 110 1/4.
Safeway, which offered 17.5 million shares of the supermarket chain yesterday at $20.50 a share, fell 1 1/8, to 20 1/4, with four million shares changing hands.
Gold shares rose slightly after gold prices climbed $3.10 an ounce, to $364.90.

Stocks in Tokyo Dip
 TOKYO, Wednesday, April 10 (Reuters) -- Stocks in Tokyo closed slightly lower at the end of the trading session today. The 225-share Nikkei average was down 48.53 points or 0.18 percent to 26,268.86.

HEADLINE: Rhode Island Bailout Urged

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9

 BODY:
Rhode Island's Governor and Senators today pleaded for a Federal bailout of the state's private deposit insurance system, saying the state had been plunged into a financial crisis even worse than it suffered during the Great Depression.
Gov. Bruce Sundlun, a Democrat, shut down 35 credit unions and 10 banks on New Year's Day after the private Rhode Island Share and Deposit Indemnity Corporation collapsed. 
 Thirty institutions have since reopened with Federal insurance, but 15 others remain closed and their depositors' accounts frozen.
"People have lost money set aside for weddings, had burial accounts frozen, lost homes and businesses," the Governor told the Senate Banking Committee. More than half the state's one million people have been affected, he said.
Mr. Sundlun is backing legislation, sponsored by Senator John H. Chafee, a Rhode Island Republican. It would make a $500 million pool of Federal money available for low-interest loans to states in which private deposit insurance systems collapse. No more than $150 million could be lent to a state.

HEADLINE: 'Wish List' Site for Sale But Cuomo Still Wishes

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 9

 BODY:
A Georgia developer has put up for sale a large expanse of Adirondack land that New York State wants to preserve as wilderness but says it cannot afford.
The offering raised new alarms about the fate of Adirondack Park, a combination of public and private lands that includes some of the largest wilderness tracts in the eastern United States. 
 The forest parcels, amounting to 87,000 acres, are the second major block of ecologically valuable land to be offered for development since last fall's defeat of a bond proposal that would have raised nearly $1 billion for land protection. The second block of land is Sterling Forest in Orange County, the largest woodland left in the New York metropolitan region, where a company announced plans last month to build a suburban development for 35,000 people.
 
Increasing Sales Feared
 Some lawmakers and environmental groups say Adirondack Park has been left vulnerable to development by the defeat of the bond proposal and the languishing of a package of zoning restrictions and other protective measures recommended last year by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's commission on the Adirondacks.
The Governor has not proposed turning any of his panel's ideas into law, suggesting instead that the economic downturn has slowed development pressure and taken the urgency out of the issue.
Environmentalists contend that unless new restrictions are adopted, the park could be overwhelmed by new development as the market picks up again. They said the offering being made now could be an early indication of such activity.
"This bursts the bubble of the people who are saying, 'Don't worry, with the economy down, what could happen?' " said Bernard Melewski, the acting executive director of the Adirondack Council, a private environmental group. "There are thousands of acres coming up for sale at bargain-basement prices, and the state is without any funds for the first time in 30 years to protect the park."
 
Homesites Planned
 The Adirondack parcels, offered by Lassiter Properties Inc. in Atlanta, are spread through the northern and western Adirondacks. Although they represent a small fraction of the six million acres of land in the park, they are one of the largest combinations of privately owned land in the area to go on the market in recent years.
Some tracts in the property are likely to remain as timber land, and others have partial protection against development, known as conservation easements, that the state purchased three years ago in the midst of criticism over the development company's original acquisition of the land.
But Lassiter, in a prospectus circulated recently, said many tracts were suitable for "acreage homesites" and that it planned to market them for this purpose.
The potential sale may also put new pressure on the Governor and the Legislature to include some funds for land in the new state budget.
 
Public Efforts Invited
 Mr. Cuomo, despite his aggressive lobbying for open-space protection in his unsuccessful campaign to get the bond proposal approved last November, has strongly resisted adding money for land to the budget. He cites the state's fiscal problems and what he says is the need to develop greater public support for such programs.
Although the state had drawn up long lists of land projects it hoped to pay for through the bond proposal, Mr. Cuomo has decided to wait for a new set of regional committees to advise him on future acquisition sites. That will take at least a year, and some environmental groups have criticized the delay.
Mr. Cuomo said he eventually hoped to buy land with money from an environmental trust fund he has proposed, but he has ruled out spending any money on land this year.
The State Environmental Conservation Commissioner, Thomas C. Jorling, said in an interview today that while the state knew there was a risk that the Lassiter company would sell land, none of the parcels had been considered a top priority.
"Are we worried?" the Commissioner said. "Yes, we're worried, but not any more than we're worried about a lot of other parcels that might be marketed during this period when the public has no resources to buy land."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Asset Sale By Revlon Called Near

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Revlon Inc., the cosmetics giant headed by Ronald O. Perelman, is expected to announce as early as today that it plans to sell its Max Factor division and a German subsidiary to Procter & Gamble for about $1 billion.
People familiar with the details and progress of the negotiations said yesterday that the Procter & Gamble Company and Revlon were scheduled to sign a letter of intent today and that the deal would close soon. 
 Max Factor, whose products include the Almay line of hypoallergenic cosmetics as well as the Max Factor brand of makeup, had annual sales in 1990 of $621 million, analysts estimate. The German subsidiary being sold, Betrix, is a beauty-aids company whose 1990 sales are estimated by analysts at $216 million. The operations together represent about 30 percent of Revlon's total annual sales.
A sale price of $1 billion would indicate that Procter & Gamble would pay $1.20 for every $1 of Revlon's sales, the lower end of the price range that the company was seeking.
 
Would Have 30% of Market
 Procter & Gamble has the leading brand of mass-market cosmetics, Cover Girl, which has about 23 percent of the market. Adding Max Factor and Almay would give it a 30 percent share. Some analysts had been concerned that if Procter & Gamble bought all of Revlon's mass-market brands, giving it 44 percent of the market, the company could face antitrust action.
Revlon, based in New York, has been trying to sell all or most of its assets since the beginning of the year. It has said that Mr. Perelman's strategy has been to acquire companies, improve their performance and then sell them.
The company has denied that big interest payments from its high-yield "junk bonds" have forced it to look for buyers for the assets. But analysts say Revlon has $816 million in debt due in 1992, mostly to banks, and $475 million in bond debt due in 1995.
Mr. Perelman took over Revlon in the mid-1980's and took it private in 1987 with junk bonds.
Revlon, analysts say, cannot meet those payments with cash flow from a cosmetics business hurt by recession and overbuilding by large retailers like department stores and discounters.
Details of the planned sale are sketchy, but the transaction would leave intact the Revlon brand's domestic and international cosmetics business, while paying down much of the $1.5 billion bank debt that has imposed operating constraints on Mr. Perelman and the company.
Mr. Perelman was traveling yesterday and could not be reached for comment.
At its headquarters in Cincinnati, a Procter & Gamble spokesman declined to comment on the deal.
On Feb. 28, word leaked out that Revlon had been trying to sell part or all of its assets, with Procter & Gamble and L'Oreal the most interested of several potential buyers.
What remained unclear yesterday was whether Revlon was still trying to sell the rest of its assets to L'Oreal, which had 1989 annual revenues of $5.4 billion, or to another as-yet-undisclosed company.
If all of the Max Factor/Almay division and Betrix are sold to Procter & Gamble, then Revlon, with about $1.86 billion in annual sales, would be substantially smaller than its two primary rivals in the United States, L'Oreal and Estee Lauder. Each has about $2.3 billion in makeup and fragrance sales, analysts said.
The Revlon brand continues to have substantial international sales, which Horvitz & Associates, an industry consultant, estimates at $540 million.
While it has a number of publicly owned bond issues outstanding, Revlon has no common stock outstanding, limiting the amount of financial information it has to disclose. A Revlon spokesman declined to confirm the analysts' estimates.
Procter & Gamble had 1990 revenues of $24 billion from detergent and other household products. It presumably benefits from the purchase of part of Revlon by strengthening its already leading share in mass-market cosmetics, which are sold in drug stores and discounters like K Mart under the Cover Girl name.
By apparently sticking to mass-market cosmetics, like less expensive lipsticks and makeup, Procter & Gamble also avoids the hazards of entering the entirely new and more expensive market of department store cosmetics. Marketing techniques for such upscale brands as Chanel, Lancome and Estee Lauder involve more elaborate in-store displays, splashy magazine advertisements and television ads that emphasize chic style rather than low price.
Procter & Gamble has scant experience in these areas and would also encounter global giants like Unilever, which has been growing rapidly through acquisition.

HEADLINE: Official Reported to Face Ouster After His Dissent on Iraq Exports

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9

 BODY:
The White House has ordered the dismissal of an Under Secretary of Commerce for telling Congress on Monday that the Administration ignored warnings to limit the export of American technology to Iraq before the invasion of Kuwait, Administration officials said today.
One official said that Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher was told by the office of John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, that Dennis E. Kloske, Under Secretary for Export Administration and among the top half-dozen officials in the Commerce Department, should be removed from the payroll by June 1. 
 The White House and the Commerce Department denied that Mr. Kloske's resignation had been requested. They added, however, that he has been planning to leave for some time, but has not submitted a letter of resignation.
Mr. Kloske, reached today in Brussels, where he addressed a conference, said: "I have no comment. Everything I have to say about the subject was said yesterday."
Mr. Kloske told a House subcommittee on Monday that the Administration, and the State Department in particular, had disregarded his recommendations last spring to reduce the flow of advanced American technology to Iraq because the Administration wanted to encourage better relations with Baghdad.
The reported disciplinary action against him reflects the extreme sensitivity of the Administration to criticism that it mishandled relations with Iraq and continued to provide advanced equipment to Baghdad until just a few weeks before President Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.
Democrats have charged that the Administration sought to appease Iraq until shortly before Kuwait was invaded and that the United States sent contradictory diplomatic as well as trade and economic signals to Mr. Hussein before the invasion.
Speaking on Monday to the House Foreign Affairs Committee's Subcommittee on International Economic Policy and Trade, Mr. Kloske said that because of his rising concern about developments in Iraq, he tried to outflank the Administration policy by delaying sales, which required review by the Commerce Department unit that he heads.
"I decided to employ the only option available to a bureaucrat," he told the lawmakers. "I tried to tie up all sales in red tape."
Mr. Kloske came to the Commerce Department with the Bush Administration after serving at the Pentagon and the United States mission to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
In his Congressional testimony, which was televised by C-Span, he presented a picture of interagency rivalry and dissension.
 
'Dual Use' Products
 The subcommittee hearing was called after recent disclosures that $1.5 billion worth of sensitive "dual use" products -- computers, chemicals and telecommunications equipment that have both military and civilian applications -- were approved for export to Iraq between 1985 and 1990.
Mr. Kloske provided no fresh details on exports of any specific technologies, but said he made his "views clear at the very highest levels" about the technology sales in general.
Both White House and Commerce Department public affairs officers denied that Mr. Kloske's resignation was being sought. They issued similar statements, which suggested that there had been some attempt to coordinate their comments. Both said that Mr. Kloske had been planning to leave for some time.
"The White House has not asked for Mr. Kloske's resignation, and Mr. Sununu made no phone call to Mr. Mosbacher about this," said Stephen T. Hart, a White House spokesman.
Another Administration official said there was a White House staff meeting this morning attended by Mr. Sununu at which Monday's testimony by Mr. Kloske was mentioned.
 
A Crucial Response
 Mr. Kloske especially angered the State Department, several officials said, when he set his position apart from the department's in response to a question from Representative Sam Gejdenson, Democrat of Connecticut and the subcommittee chairman.
As one official said: "In Congressional testimony, the first lesson is that you never differentiate yourself from other parts of the Administration. It's not your place to give juicy details about how decisions are made."
All of the Administration officials spoke on the condition that they not be identified.
Mr. Kloske disclosed that as early as April 1990 he had asked for an embargo of selected technology exports to Iraq and that "the State Department adamantly opposed my position, choosing instead to advocate the maintenance of diplomatic relations with Iraq."
He added that a consensus was then formed by an interagency group "in favor of continued diplomatic relations-negotiations with Iraq."
The thrust of his testimony was that, because the Reagan Administration had dropped Iraq from the list of terrorist-supporting countries in 1982 and resumed diplomatic relations in 1984, there was little he could do legally to stop advanced technology sales, especially with pressures from the business community to open new export markets.
 
The Soviet Angle
 He said he could limit exports only if he could show they would be rerouted to the Soviet Union.
To people who monitor the export-control situation, the episode demonstrates the serious disarray in Administration policies, as decision-makers are being pulled in one direction by security considerations and in another by the need to improve the nation's trade accounts.
"Unless we have a major overhaul of our policies, the Saddams of the future will continue to benefit from this disarray," Jennifer J. White, a senior associate at the Center for Security Policy, a Washington-based policy research group specializing in security matters, said in an interview today.
The export-control issues have become highly emotional, further accounting for the Administration's sensitivitiy.
In the hearing yesterday, for example, Mr. Gejdenson said that after Mr. Hussein used poison gas to kill 5,000 Kurds in Iraq in 1988, the Administration still refused to impose economic sanctions and fought hard against legislation that would have done so.
"Even in April 1990," Mr. Gejdenson continued, "after Hussein threatened to burn up half of Israel with binary chemical weapons, the State Department would not restrict the export of advanced dual-use technology to Saddam Hussein, nor would it put Iraq on the list of terrorist countries."
 
Administration's Stance
 The Administration's position is that it did all that was possible in the circumstances to deal with the issue.
The 36-year-old Mr. Kloske, a graduate of Harvard and a Rhodes scholar, has received generally high marks from the business community for his efforts to help restructure and simplify the export-control program.
Paul Freedenberg, who held the position during the Reagan Administration, said Mr. Kloske's probable departure comes at an "unfortunate" moment because export-control policies are at a critical stage of development and "need strong leadership."
The United States has been trying to reach agreement with its European allies and Japan on a streamlined core list of advanced technologies that would be banned from the Soviet Union. It is also seeking an international accord to prevent militarily useful goods from falling in the hands of terrorist countries.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
Europeans Back Off Plan to Help Kurds

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 8

 BODY:
Western nations backed away today from a proposal to set up an enclave in northern Iraq administered by the United Nations where Kurdish refugees could be protected against further aggression by the forces of President Saddam Hussein.
The retreat came after Baghdad heatedly rejected the plan, calling it a "conspiracy" to intrude on Iraqi sovereignty, and the United States gave the concept a lukewarm endorsement. Officials in Washington today expressed disappointment with Baghdad's response but said the United States did not want to press the matter because it involved further encroachment on Iraqi territory. 
 The 12 European Community countries, which endorsed the concept of a safe haven at a summit meeting in Luxembourg on Monday, now say they believe that the best way to discourage President Saddam Hussein from further repression against the Kurds is to persuade Iraq to let more United Nations relief workers establish themselves in Kurdish areas of Iraq.
Prime Minister John Major of Britain proposed the initial enclave plan at the meeting on Monday. The community quickly endorsed the idea, saying it was up to the Security Council to work out the details and leaving open the possibility that force might be needed if Iraq rejected the concept.
 
Resolution to Allow Zones
 Officials also spoke of seeking a mandatory Security Council resolution giving them the right in international law to establish such zones inside Iraqi territory.
But faced with outright Iraqi rejection, as well as clear reservations by the Soviet Union and China and the cool response from Washington, European diplomats say they have scaled back their approach to one that appears more realistic. They now say the best solution lies in encouraging Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to persuade Iraq to allow a semi-permanent United Nations humanitarian presence in the Kurdish areas.
In theory, the relief workers would be there to tend to the needs of the two million Kurds who are believed to be on the move in northern Iraq, fleeing into Turkey and Iran to escape the Iraqi military.
But the Europeans say their very presence in the region would deter the Iraqi authorities from further aggression, in effect establishing zones in which Kurds would feel more secure.
 
Easing Flood of Refugees
 This would encourage more Kurds to move to the secure areas and ease the flood of refugees trying to cross into Turkey and Iran.
"We are seeking to establish zones in northern Iraq where the Kurds would feel safer," Britain's representative, Sir David Hannay, said as the Security Council met to discuss the plan. He stressed that the zones would be "a purely humanitarian concept," not "a juridical or political concept."
A key element in the European approach is the mission that the Secretary General is sending to Iraq later this week on Security Council instructions to report on the plight of the Kurds. It will be led by Ambassador Eric Suy, a Belgian diplomat and former United Nations legal adviser.
Iraq has welcomed Ambassador Suy's visit and promised to cooperate with him and the his team of relief experts. The Europeans hope he will be able to start setting up what would effectively be a dual-purpose United Nations presence in the Kurdish region, helping the refugees as well as discouraging further repression.
 
Creating Conditions to Help
 "By getting the team in there and beginning to organize access for humitarian aid, we will begin to create the conditions for stabalizing and calming the situation," Sir David said, adding that in time the United Nations might be able to encourage the refugees to return to the towns and villages.
But Iraq's United Nations reprsentative, Abdul Amir al-Anbari, described the mission as a fact-finding one and said it would be relatively brief. In a letter to the United Nations, Iraq's Foreign Minister, Ahmed Hussein, said the best way to help the Kurds would be to lift United Nations economic sanctions.
However the United States and Britain have made clear they will oppose lifting trade restrictions on non-essential civilian imports when these come up for review in June, if the turmoil and upheaval continues in Kurd areas.
The Security Council also took another step toward formally winding up the Persian Gulf war today when it voted unanimously to send a military observer force of 1,440 to patrol a demilitarized zone along the Iraq-Kuwait frontier.
 
Deployed in Two Weeks
 The force, which is expected to be deployed within two weeks, will allow the coalition allies to complete their military withdrawal from southern Iraq. They will leave behind some 27,000 mainly Shiite Muslim refugees who fled across the allied lines after the their revolt against President Hussein was crushed.
Responsibility for these refugees will then be given to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and the International Committee of the Red Cross. Today the High Commissioner, Sadako Ogata, wrote to the Secretary General saying she wants assurances from Iraq and Kuwait that they will treat the refugees as protected persons.
There have been concerns that Iraq, which is responsibile for law and order in its portion of the demilitarized zone, might seek to punish the refugees.
The Security Council has yet to approve its formal reply to Iraq's declaration that it accepts the Security Council's peace terms without conditions. That approval is expected on Wednesday. The United States and Britain first wanted to see the text of the resolution that the Iraqi Parliament adopted accepting the Council's terms to make sure that it does not include any caveats.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
A bitterly divided F.C.C. voted to relax but not eliminate rules that prohibit TV networks from owning and selling reruns of the shows they broadcast. The new rules will allow networks to acquire full resale rights to shows accounting for as much as 40 percent of their prime-time schedules. [Page A1.] The ruling is likely to lead to ever-more-convoluted deal-making in Hollywood. [D6.] 
 The F.C.C. also adopted rules curbing advertising on TV shows for children and setting new standards intended to improve the educational quality of children's programs. [D7.]
The I.R.S. is finding far less than the usual grumbling aimed its way this tax season. There are still shortcomings, but even some of the agency's most persistent critics say day-to-day operations are generally the smoothest in a long time. [D1.]
 
International
The White House has ordered the dismissal of a Commerce Under Secretary for telling Congress the Administration ignored warnings to limit the export of American technology to Iraq before the invasion of Kuwait, Administration officials said. [A1.]
Egypt is about to receive a package of debt forgiveness and other international economic assistance worth billions of dollars, American and international economic officials said. [D1.]
A.T.& T. will increase the telecommunications capacity between the U.S. and Mexico fivefold by the end of this year, as part of a broad new focus on Latin America. [D1.]
 
Companies
Revlon reportedly plans to sell Max Factor and a German subsidiary to Procter & Gamble for about $1 billion. An announcement is expected as early as today. [D1.]
The Bank of New York said problems with business loans, many of them to finance corporate takeovers, resulted in a $63 million quarterly loss. [D1.]
Within two weeks, Digital Equipment will become the first leading computer vendor to enter the market for massively parallel processing. It will announce a joint venture with Maspar. [D1.]
Hasbro extended its deadline for Tonka's bondholders and shareholders to tender their securities. [D4.]
Some people have doubts about Donald Trump's plans to turn the Plaza into condominiums. [B3.]
 
Business Technology
New advances are being made in knee replacements intended for cases where the damage is so bad that conventional procedures will not work. [D9.]
A miniature office has been created to measure the effects of tinted window glazings on office occupants. [D9.]
 
Markets
Heavy waves of program selling carried stocks down sharply. The Dow sank 45.54, to 2,873.02. [D10.]
Prices of Treasury securities dipped in listless trading, as dealers sold some securities in advance of an auction today. [D16.]
The dollar fell sharply on world currency markets as investors focused on interest rates. [D17.]
Grain futures prices fell after widespread rain in the Midwest and forecasts for showers through next week. [D17.]
 
Today's Columns
Many business and shopping trips could be eliminated if new technology made it practical to shop and perform most white-collar jobs by wire. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Shares of SmithKline Beecham have soared in the last year. But some analysts are growing cautious. Market Place. [D10.]
Ed McCabe struck an innovative deal for Oxtoby-Smith to serve as its research department. Kim Foltz: Advertising. [D19.]

HEADLINE: Union Head Cites Difficulty In Vote by Two Film Locals

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
Although a tentative agreement was recently reached between two film unions and Hollywood producers that would end the stalemate that had shut down film making in New York City, it is "impossible to predict" whether the membership of one union will accept the agreement, said its president.
"It's a tough call; it could be very close," said the union head, Walter Stocklin, president of Local 52 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees and Moving Picture Machine Operators.
 
Overwhelming Rejection
 The union's 2,000 members have been returning mail ballots on the March 19 pact, which offered the film producers money-saving changes in overtime and weekend pay in return for greater health and pension benefits. 
 Mr. Stocklin said that he and Raymond Fortune, the union's vice president, had submitted the tentative agreement to the union's negotiating committee and the executive board, and that both had rejected the settlement "overwhelmingly."
As a result, the mailing of ballots on the proposal included a letter recommending that the tentative settlement be rejected, he said. "Now it's up to the rank and file to decide," he added. The ballots are to be counted on Monday.
The 19-week stalemate has halted movie making in New York City, a vital part of the city's economy. Mayor David N. Dinkins had pressed for a settlement along with the city's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting. Members of the other union, Local 644 of the International Photographers of the Motion Picture and Television Industries, are also voting by mail, and their ballots will be counted this month or early in May.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Record Opening-Day Salaries: Not Peanuts or Cracker Jack

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
If the fact that 223 players are making $1 million or more this year -- 32 at $3 million or more -- is not enough of an economically mind-boggling barometer of the escalation of baseball salaries, consider these developments:
 Nine teams have an average salary of more than $1 million, dividing total payroll by the number of players. The average opening-day major league salary for all players, total 708, is $890,844, and an astonishing 53 percent more than last year's opening-day average, which was in the $580,000 range. 
 In previous years, no individual team average salary ever reached this year's major league average salary. The record for a team average was set by the Mets in 1989 at $865,741.
Rosters and disabled lists -- and thus the numbers -- will change somewhat by Aug. 31, when the official salary studies are conducted by the Player Relations Committee and the Players Association. But the season-opening figures, compiled by The New York Times from contract data obtained from management and player sources, show just how meteorically salaries have risen this year.
 On opening day last year only one player, Robin Yount of Milwaukee, was at the $3 million plateau. This year Darryl Strawberry of Los Angeles, at $3.8 million, heads a hefty group of 32 floating in that economic stratosphere. Last year 153 players were at $1 million or more, this year 223.
 The Oakland Athletics, with a record $36.4 million payroll and 14 of their 27 players receiving $1 million or more, have the highest team average, $1,349,352. The Houston Astros, who lost most of their high-priced players as free agents during the winter, are at the other end of the salary standings with an average of $487,090.
 The five members of the Athletics who are signed for $3 million or more -- total $16.7 million -- make more than the entire payrolls of Houston, Baltimore or Seattle. Add Mark McGwire, and the $19.55 million total is higher than the payroll of those three teams plus Cleveland and the Chicago White Sox. Then throw in Dave Henderson, and the $22.15 million total is higher than the payrolls of those five clubs plus Texas, Montreal, Philadelphia, St. Louis, Atlanta and San Diego, or 11 of the other 25 clubs.
 After the Athletics, the Mets have 13 players at $1 million or more, Boston, California and San Francisco 12 each and the Yankees, Kansas City and Los Angeles 11 each. Baltimore and Seattle have the fewest, three each.
 Only 43 players are receiving the minimum salary of $100,000. That total is down drastically from the 1990 opening-day total of 90, although those rosters each included 28 players because of the abbreviated spring training that followed the lockout.
The average team salaries on this page are based on the opening-day rosters and disabled list. All team and individual salaries include base salary and prorated share of signing bonuses.

HEADLINE: Rochester: An Uneasy Symbol of School Reform

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, April 4

 BODY:
This is a story of perestroika, of bureaucrats fighting to keep power, citizens confused, civil servants clinging to the old ways and unions battling management amid economic chaos.
The struggle is set not in the Soviet Union but here in Rochester, an industrial city of 240,000 people in western New York that has become a national symbol of education reform. Rochester became famous overnight after it agreed in 1987 to pay its teachers among the highest salaries in the nation. The quest was one that had eluded education reformers -- overhauling not just a school, but an entire system. 
 As in the Soviet Union, these are dark days for what Rochester, too, calls "restructuring." The city's public school teachers, who have been working without a contract since June 30, refuse to take part in the new programs established with so much fanfare three years ago. Parents say they see no dramatic improvements. And New York State's fiscal crisis threatens severe budget cuts, endangering the steps taken to date.
 
The Importance of Politics
 Still, no one in Rochester seems ready to give up on the ambitious reorganization. Several schools have adopted innovative programs, executives on loan from Xerox and Eastman Kodak have helped revamp the district's hiring, personnel and planning procedures, and the city has begun to attack once taboo issues like weeding out incompetent teachers.
Chastened reformers say they are trying to put into effect the lesson they have already learned: that the politics of reform -- explaining it, selling it and involving the community in it -- are just as important as its content.
"The public is disgusted," said Peter McWalters, Rochester's Superintendent of Schools. "So is the business leadership. Everyone out there is angry. They feel left out, alienated and unconnected. They don't know whether I'm succeeding or failing."
Rochester is battling problems shared by urban districts nationwide: most of its 33,000 students are poor, nearly half are from single-parent households and most black and Hispanic students fare far worse than their white classmates. But the city's effort stands out in its scope.
Teachers received a 40 percent pay increase over three years, raising the average salary after 11 years of service to $45,000 and establishing a veteran teacher slot that could pay as much as $70,000. Teachers, principals and parents were to participate in running schools as part of "school-based management," unhindered by central office bureaucracy. Each middle and high school teacher agreed to counsel 20 students and get to know their families.
 
Partnerships Under Strain
 But in the last few months impending budget cuts and a bruising battle over a new teachers contract have overshadowed reform efforts and strained the unusual partnerships forged among the superintendent, the teachers union, business executives and parents.
"I do feel teachers have been getting bashed," said Marge Kitz, a speech specialist for 25 years. "If teachers get a positive response from the community, you work even more. But now you say, 'Why am I doing this -- nobody's appreciating it.' "
Ms. Kitz was one of the slim majority who rejected the first contract last September. Like many teachers, she was worried about provisions linking pay to performance.
That unexpected vote outraged many parents who believe well-paid teachers should be held accountable. And many minority parents questioned the mostly white teaching force's commitment
Teachers overwhelmingly approved a second contract, which would have given them a 24 percent raise over three years and included some provisions for assessment, but the school board voted that down in January.
Then the teachers erupted, asking a school board member to leave a school where he was a volunteer teacher, telling a critic they would refuse to allow students to attend one of his school speeches and, in many cases, pulling out of the school-based planning teams.
Many community leaders and parents now say they feel betrayed. "These people are public servants," said William A. Johnson, president of the Urban League, whose 1986 report urging Rochester to save its education system was a catalyst for change. "We wanted, we were willing, to pay for radical reform. Now people are saying we put up the money and we don't see the results."
Even the infusion of new teachers, lured to Rochester by the publicized pay increases, was slowed because the high salaries convinced older teachers to defer retirement.
Bill Sanders, a veteran English and reading teacher, agrees that parents came to expect more than could be delivered. "We allowed the public to believe that if they gave us more money we could somehow do things differently," Mr. Sanders said, adding that in reality, "paying me $100 a day more wouldn't make a difference, but valuing reading more than cable TV would."
Contract talks are now before a fact-finding committee, which is expected to recommend a new contract within a few weeks. The school board and the union must then vote on it.
 
Pace Seen as Too Fast
 Adam Urbanski, head of the teachers union, says he sees the union's vote as a clear sign that the pace of change was too fast.
"I can't help but believe if they were very comfortable with the reforms we signed on to, they would have accepted more reform," said Mr. Urbanski, who was widely praised as a visionary after the first contract was signed. "They obviously wanted more time."
Teacher ferment seems remote in the orderly halls of East High School, where the principal, carrying a walkie-talkie, pounces on stray students demanding passes. But at East High this year most teachers balked at the contract's requirement that they counsel students. In turn, parents refused to sign the planning document required under the new school-based management system.
"I do not have high hopes for reform, and the reason for that is that downtown always has the final say," said Dave Swanson, referring to the school bureaucracy. Mr. Swanson, a mathematics teacher for 30 years, added: "They have a very idealized view of what should happen. You go to talk to a kid and he says, 'Get out of my face!' "
Even Mr. Sanders, who is widely respected for his commitment to his students, said he does not feel connected to the larger reform effort. "I think I have some great successes, but that has very little to do with the central office," he said.
 
Many Teaching Innovations
 The successes evident in Rochester are hard to quantify or communicate. Groups of teachers are setting up two new schools, one that would extend the school day to involve more parents and another that would employ new, widely praised methods of teaching students how to read and write. Seventh and eighth grades have been moved out of high school into new middle schools with the sixth grade to conform with studies showing that these are crucial early adolescent years. The advisory system is working well in middle schools.
Teachers have proposed many innovations, and have put some of them into effect. Teachers at Elementary School No. 9 used the Genesee River, which empties into Lake Ontario near Rochester, as the basis of their entire curriculum.
A group of children classified as having learning problems sat on the school lawn recently, using yardsticks, string and calculators to compare the length of the Genesee (158 miles) to the Nile, the longest river in the world (more than 4,150 miles). The program has sent test scores and sudent motivation soaring.
Many businesses have given generously to the schools. Terry Crowley, a Kodak financial analyst, works twice a week with fourth graders, posing real-life math problems. The other day he brought in a Kodak catalogue and ordering forms, and asked the students to figure out how many items they could order without exceeding the budget he had set. The children set to work with calculators, and peppered him with questions.
 
Power to the Teachers
 Much of the hardest work involves coaxing teachers to take more power and central office bureaucrats to relinquish it. That effort has yielded mixed results. Mr. McWalters says several schools' planning teams have bogged down over such questions as whether to put air-conditioning in halls, while others have galloped ahead, experimenting with setting their own budgets.
Such changes are slow, and are not always reflected by test scores. "It's like watching Roger Smith try to change General Motors," said Skip Hansford, president of Hansford Manufacturing, who has also worked with school reformers.
Mr. Urbanski and Mr. McWalters say they believe they failed to explain the reforms better. "We should have had a strategic plan that constantly informed or engaged the other major constituents in this process," Mr. McWalters said. "Unless you work to engage the community constantly, you just lose them."
 
A Question of Accountability
 Mr. Urbanski and Mr. McWalters say that one of the most persistent sticking points remains how to insure that teachers who earn high salaries deserve them: should assessments be based on how well students do or how hard teachers try? Even conscientious teachers like Mr. Sanders at East High are wary.
"I had one girl in the ninth grade," he said. "I called home the first day she wasn't here. Her parents said, 'Why are you calling? She's not enrolled in school.' I called 10 times. But she will show up as my dropout, on my record. I don't mind being held accountable for certain things, but there are things beyond my control."
But accountability is what Rochester taxpayers want and what many educators believe they can get.
Marvin Jackson, who serves on two parent groups here, said it was possible to take into account both student performance and teacher effort. "So what if you don't reach nirvana?" he said. "You have a systematic way of monitoring performance of teachers as they go to a specific goal."
But he added: "We're talking with people who are not used to any accountability. A little seems like a lot when you're not used to any."

PUB-DATE: April 10, 1991

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 2901 words

HEADLINE: Winners of the 1991 Pulitzer Prizes in the Arts and Journalism

 BODY:

Biography
 
Steven Naifeh and Gregory White Smith
 "Jackson Pollock: An American Saga"
Crammed with anecdotes and details, Steven Naifeh's and Gregory White Smith's biography of Jackson Pollock provoked an uproar in the art world with its contention that the artist was ambiguous about his sexual identity, that he was neurotically dependent on his mother's presence and that he drew inspiration for some of his famous "drip" paintings by observing in childhood the patterns made by his father's urination on a flat stone. Mr. Naifeh, 38 years old, a native of Tulsa, Okla., and Mr. Smith, 39, a native of Columbus, Ohio, both graduated from Harvard Law School in 1977. After working in the legal profession they returned to Harvard, where Mr. Naifeh earned a master's degree in art history at the Fogg Art Museum and Mr. Smith, a master's degree in education. They both live in Aiken, S.C.
 
General Nonfiction
 
Bert Holldobler and Edward O. Wilson
 "The Ants" 
 Bert Holldobler and Edward O. Wilson have never lost their fascination with "the little creatures who run the world," and they communicate that. Ants, they write in their authoritative 732-page book on them, "represent the culmination of insect evolution, in the same sense that human beings represent the summit of vertebrate evolution." Mr. Holldobler is the Alexander Agassiz Professor of Zoology at Harvard University and a professor of behavioral physiology at the University of Wurzburg in Germany. Born in Erling-Andechs, Germany, he came to the United States in 1973 as a professor of biology at Harvard. He is married with three sons. This is the second Pulitzer Prize for Mr. Wilson, the Frank B. Baird Jr. Professor of Science at Harvard, who won one in nonfiction in 1975 for his book "On Human Nature." Born in Birmingham, Ala., in 1929, he was educated at the University of Alabama and at Harvard, where he has taught for more than 30 years. Since 1973 he has also been curator in entomology at the university's Museum of Comparative Zoology. He lives in Lexington, Mass., with his wife and daughter.
 
Poetry
 
 Mona Van Duyn
 "Near Changes"
Mona Van Duyn won for her seventh book, a 69-page collection. She sees herself as a poet of "serious play." As one critic said, she usually looks into metaphorical possibilities and implications inherent in daily life. As she demonstrates in "Sonnet for Minimalists," she can do this humorously: "The world's perverse/It could be worse." Ms. Van Duyn, (pronounced van DINE), 69 years old, was born in Waterloo, Iowa, and lives in St. Louis. In 1947, she and her husband, Jarvis A. Thurston, founded "Perspective, a Quarterly of Literature." For this, she received the $25,000 Ruth Lilly Prize.
 
Fiction
 
 John Updike
 "Rabbit at Rest"
As a two-time winner of the Pulitzer Prize for fiction, John Updike equals the record of two other American authors -- Booth Tarkington (1920, 1922) and William Faulkner (1955, 1963). Mr. Updike's second Pulitzer Prize, for "Rabbit at Rest," follows the 1982 prize for "Rabbit is Rich," the previous novel in this series of four about Harry (Rabbit) Angstrom, the former athletic star who becomes a car salesman in a Pennsylvania town. Mr. Updike, 59 years old, who has written a "Rabbit" novel in the ninth year of each decade since 1959, said yesterday that "Rabbit at Rest" is the last, not only because his protagonist dies but also because "I'm not sure I'd be around in 10 years to do another." The prolific author -- 14 novels and countless essays, book reviews, poems and criticisms -- was born in Shillington, Pa. He graduated from Harvard College in 1954 and attended the Ruskin School of Drawing and Fine Art in Oxford, England, on a one-year Knox Fellowship. From 1955 to 1957, he was on the staff of The New Yorker magazine, but on staff and off, he has been a frequent contributor to the publication. He and his wife, Martha, live in Beverly, Mass., near Boston.
 
Music
 
 Shulamit Ran
 Symphony
Shulamit Ran, a 41-year-old composer and pianist, is a professor of music at the University of Chicago, where she has taught since 1978. Her Symphony was commissioned by the Philadelphia Orchestra and was given its world premiere by that ensemble, with Gary Bertini conducting, on Oct. 19, 1990. The Symphony is in three movements and combines freely atonal, Expressionistic styles with currents of direct lyricism. Like many of her other recent scores, its movements involve expansions and transformations of themes heard early in the piece. She was born in Tel Aviv and holds dual Israeli and American citizenship. She came to New York when she was 14 to study at the Mannes College of Music. In September 1990, she was appointed composer-in-residence with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra.
 
History
 
 Laurel Thatcher Ulrich
 "A Midwife's Tale: The Life of Martha Ballard, Based on Her Diary, 1785-1812"
In 1982, working at the Maine State Archives in Augusta, Laurel Thatcher Ulrich, who teaches history at the University of New Hampshire in Durham, discovered an immensely detailed diary of a midwife who lived in Maine in the late 18th and early 19th centuries. Professor Ulrich, 52 years old, was thrilled with her discovery, she said yesterday, because the great difficulty in writing about the lives of women in the early history of the United States, which is her specialty, is the paucity of source material. "Women's lives at that time were almost completely hidden," she said. In the diary of Martha Ballard, she found evidence of the way in which women were involved in bartering and trading, and detailed information about the practice of obstetrics, in both normal and emergency cases. Born in Sugar City, Idaho, she earned degrees at the University of Utah, Simmons College in Boston and a doctorate at the University of New Hamphire.
 
Drama
 
 Neil Simon
 "Lost in Yonkers"
Neil Simon, 63 years old, won for his play set in the summer of 1942 in a two-bedroom apartment over a candy store in Yonkers. Starring Irene Worth, Mercedes Ruehl and Kevin Spacey and directed by Gene Saks, it tells of two teen-age brothers who have been forced for economic reasons to move in with their grandmother, a stern, distant and iron-willed German-Jewish refugee whose overpowering personality has stunted the adulthood of her own children. "I'm really glad I won for 'Lost in Yonkers,' " Mr. Simon said yesterday on the telephone from Hawaii. "The play came out of instinctive feelings I had and probably awakened in me things I didn't know about." He was born in the Bronx. In the last 30 years, he has written 26 Broadway plays, including "Come Blow Your Horn," "Barefoot in the Park," "The Odd Couple," "Plaza Suite," "The Prisoner of Second Avenue," "The Sunshine Boys," "Chapter Two," "Brighton Beach Memoirs," "Biloxi Blues" and "Broadway Bound."
 
Feature Photography
 
William Snyder
 The Dallas Morning News
William Snyder won his second Pulitzer Prize for pictures of sick and orphaned children living in primitive conditions in Romania. One picture shows a forlorn child in hugely ill-fitting pajamas crawling along while a worker strides past, ignoring him. Mr. Snyder, 31 years old, was a member of a three-person Dallas Morning News team that won a Pulitzer Prize in Explanatory Journalism in 1989. The team traced the movements of the National Transportation Safety Board in investigating an airplane crash. He joined The Dallas Morning News in 1983.
 
Spot News
 
 The Miami Herald
The Herald won for more than 80 articles documenting the rise and fall of a local cult leader, Yahweh Ben Yahweh, who called himself the son of God and was one of the most influential preachers in Miami. Even as top city officials praised him, his followers in the Nation of Yahweh engaged in a pattern of violence, The Herald reported. The lead reporter, Sydney P. Freedberg, tracked down defectors from the cult. Many had given statements to the Federal Bureau of Investigation and were frightened because no one had been charged. Ms. Freedberg obtained documents linking members of the sect to 14 killings. In November, the cult leader was accused of ordering the murders and indicted on Federal racketeering charges.
 
Beat Reporting
 
 Natalie Angier
 The New York Times
Natalie Angier, cited by the Pulitzer committee for "compelling and illuminating" articles on a variety of scientific topics, compares herself to the pilot of the fictional spaceship that tours the inside of a human body in the movie "Fantastic Voyage." "What I try to do is to humanize everything," she said, "to give the reader the feeling that they are right there in the middle of the scientific process." For example, in a complicated story on the cell cycle, she likened the coupling of proteins to "the vitality of young lovers galvanizing in a cascade of changes in the cell that culminates in division." A graduate of Barnard College, Ms. Angier, 33 years old, worked as an editor for Savvy magazine and as a science and environmental writer for Time magazine. She is the author of "Natural Obsessions: The Search for the Oncogene" (1988), which won the Lewis Thomas Award for excellence in writing about the life sciences. She joined The Times in March 1990.
 
International Reporting
 
Caryle Murphy
 The Washington Post
Caryle Murphy, who went to work for The Washington Post 14 years ago, has been its Cairo-based Middle East correspondent since October 1989. She arrived in Kuwait just in time to witness the Iraqi invasion. She spent the next 26 days as the only American reporter there and was cited yesterday for the dispatches she filed, some from hiding, before escaping to Saudi Arabia on Aug. 27. She is a 43-year-old graduate of Trinity College in Washington who earned her Master of Arts in Islamic studies at Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies.
 
Serge Schmemann
 The New York Times
Serge Schmemann, who joined The Times as a metropolitan reporter in 1980, was chief of its Bonn bureau from May 1987 until three months ago when he began his second stint as a correspondent in Moscow. He was cited for his reporting on the breakdown of East Germany and its merger into the Federal Republic. Born in France, Mr. Schmemann, 46, was educated at the Kent School in Connecticut, graduated from Harvard in 1967 and earned a master's degree at Columbia University in 1971. He was a correspondent in the Moscow bureau from 1981 until he took on the assignment in Bonn. Before joining The Times, Mr. Schmemann spent eight years working for The Associated Press.
 
Commentary
 
 Jim Hoagland
 The Washington Post
Jim Hoagland, associate editor and senior foreign correspondent of The Washington Post, won his second Pulitzer prize for what the committee called "searching and prescient columns" on events leading to the Persian Gulf war and on the problems besetting the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Mr. Hoagland, 51 years old, won his first Pulitzer 21 years ago, for reporting from South Africa. Mr. Hoagland said he felt that interviews with both Saddam Hussein and President Gorbachev may have added weight to his warning of the growing crises in Moscow and the gulf. He joined The Washington Post in 1966.
 
National Reporting
 
 Marjie Lundstrom and Rochelle Sharpe
 Gannett News Service
Marjie Lundstrom and Rochelle Sharpe won their prize for a four-part series that revealed that hundreds of deaths related to child abuse go undetected each year because of flaws in death investigations nationwide. The reporters did a computer analysis of all deaths in 1987 involving children under the age of 9. "One doesn't think of child abuse as a national issue," Ms. Lundstrom said. "It was astonishing to us." Ms. Sharpe, 34 years old, joined Gannett News Service in 1985. Ms. Lundstrom, 34, who worked for Gannett News Service in Washington from March to December 1990, is now a reporter at The Sacramento Bee.
 
Editorial Writing
 
 Ron Casey, Harold Jackson and Joey Kennedy
 The Birmingham (Ala.) News
The three-member editorial board, headed by Ron Casey, was cited for a nine-part series of editorials on inequities in Alabama's state tax structure. Mr. Casey was born 39 years ago in a company-owned house in a steel-manufacturing Birmingham suburb. He has worked for The News since 1973. Harold Jackson, 37, became an editorial writer at The News in 1987. Joey Kennedy grew up in Texas and Louisiana and has lived in Alabama since 1977. He joined the Birmingham News in 1981.
 
Public Service
 
 Jane Schorer
 The Des Moines Register
The Des Moines Register was awarded the Pulitzer Prize gold medal for Public Service for a series of articles about a rape and its aftermath that reopened the nationwide debate over whether rape victims should be identified by name in news accounts. In a series of stories in February of last year, Jane Schorer told of the 1988 rape of Nancy Ziegenmeyer and her subsequent experiences with the hospital, the police and prosecutors, the accused attacker and the criminal-justice system. Mrs. Ziegenmeyer called the editor of The Register, Geneva Overholser, with her story after reading the editor's op-editorial piece in The Register questioning the news media's reluctance to use rape victims' names.
 
Criticism
 
 David Shaw
 The Los Angeles Times
David Shaw won for a four-part, 12,000-word series analyzing the way the news media, including his own paper, reported the McMartin Pre-School molestation case. Mr. Shaw, 48 years old, has covered the news media for The Los Angeles Times since 1974. In his McMartin series, he concluded that his own newspaper provided the worst coverage of that story of any paper. In a series last year on minorities and the media, he concluded that The Los Angeles Times had the worst record of any newspaper for hiring and promoting minority employees. "The award is more to the paper than to me as an individual," he said. '
 
Spot News Photography
 
 Greg Marinovich
 The Associated Press
Greg Marinovich, a South African freelance photographer, won the spot-news photography award for a series of pictures he took on assignment for The Associated Press, which distributed them to its 950 member newspapers. The pictures, taken on Sept. 15, show what the Pulitzer committee, in announcing the award, called "supporters of South Africa's African National Congress brutally murdering a man they believed to be a Zulu spy." Mr. Marinovich, 28 years old, took the photographs in the black township of Soweto.
 
Editorial Cartoon
 
 Jim Borgman
 The Cincinnati Enquirer
Jim Borgman brought home The Enquirer's first Pulitzer Prize at a time when the newspaper's hometown was unusually prominent in the news. But the subjects of his cartoons included President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union as well as Robert Mapplethorpe (whose photographs were the subject of a Cincinnati obscenity trial) and Sam Wyche (the football coach who ejected women from the locker room of his Cincinnati Bengals). "In some ways, the finger of news seemed to point to Cincinnati," Mr. Borgman said in a telephone interview from the Enquirer newsroom.
 
Investigative Reporting
 
 Joseph T. Hallinan and Susan M. Headden
 The Indianapolis Star
For one year, Joseph T. Hallinan and Susan M. Headden were taken off their beats at The Indianapolis Star and assigned to examine medical malpractice in Indiana. The result was a three-part series that showed that doctors who were found liable in several major cases of malpractice had little to worry about professionally. "We found that some doctors who had been found liable in as many as five major cases neither lost their licenses, their insurance nor their hospital privileges," Ms. Headden said yesterday. Mr. Hallinan, 30 years old, joined The Star in 1985. Ms. Headden, 35, joined The Star in 1979.
 
Explanatory Reporting
 
 Susan C. Faludi
 The Wall Street Journal
"On the eve of the 1986 leveraged buyout of Safeway Stores, Inc., the board of directors sat down to a last supper." Thus began a lengthy artice in The Wall Street Journal by Susan C. Faludi that, in the words of the Pulitzer committee, "revealed the human costs of high finance." The article contrasted the assurances by the owners of the world's largest supermarket chain that no one would be hurt in the buyout that enriched a few investors to the desparation that came to many of the 63,000 employees who were eventually dismissed by Safeway. "I'm just glad that their side of the story got told," Ms. Faludi, 35, said yesterday. She joined The Wall Street Journal in 1990.
 
Feature Writing
 
 Sheryl James
 The St. Petersburg Times
After noting a rash of abandoned babies in Florida, Sheryl James waited for the next one and followed the story for several months as the mother stood trial and tried to understand and cope with her actions. The resulting four-part series began on Feb. 18. "It kept getting tougher and tougher as her legal battle got more difficult," Ms. James, 39 years old, said yesterday, "but I think it was worth it all." She joined the newspaper in 1986 after working for The Greensboro News & Record in Greensboro, N.C. She graduated from Eastern Michigan University in 1973.

A biographical sketch on Wednesday about the winner of the Pulitzer Prize for criticism, David Shaw of The Los Angeles Times, referred incorrectly to his 1990 reporting about minority employment at newspapers including his own. What Mr. Shaw wrote was, "The Times is widely regarded -- particularly by blacks, inside the paper and out -- as having one of the poorest records for minority advancement of any major paper in the country."

HEADLINE: Egypt's 'Reward': Forgiven Debt

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9

 BODY:
Egypt is about to receive a package of debt forgiveness and other international economic assistance worth billions of dollars in the wake of the Persian Gulf war, American and international economic officials said today.
The help is coming from both creditor governments and international institutions like the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. The United States, which forgave about $7 billion in Egyptian debt after Cairo backed the allies in the gulf war, has played a key role behind the scenes in winning the help for Egypt. 
 "This package has been in the works for some time and is Egypt's reward for having given legitimacy to the American intervention in the gulf," said Yahya Sadowski, a scholar on Egypt at the Brookings Institution.
 
Meeting Scheduled in May
 Western governments at a meeting tentatively scheduled for the third week in May are expected to wipe out much of the $40.16 billion of Egyptian debts to these governments, according to international monetary officals here.
This does not include $8.64 billion of debts to commercial banks and other private institutions. In addition, at least $600 million is expected to be forthcoming shortly in loans from both the monetary fund and the World Bank.
The quid pro quo for the aid is the Egyptian Government's commitment to economic reform. An I.M.F. team left Cairo today with a letter of intent just signed by the Government of President Hosni Mubarak. The letter is expected to serve as the basis for a formal agreement for a $300 million loan that is tentatively scheduled for I.M.F. board approval in mid-May. The World Bank would also kick in $300 million, its first loan to Egypt since the Gulf crisis began last summer.
Creditor governments have demanded an Egyptian reform program that wins the I.M.F.'s seal of approval before they agree to debt forgiveness.
The exercise is similar to what was put together for Poland, also largely by the United States Treasury.
A consortium of creditor countries, known as the Paris Club for the site of their deliberations, agreed last month to wipe out at least 50 percent of Poland's $33 billion in government debts.
David C. Mulford, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, said at the time that Poland and Egypt were "unique politically and economically."
Mr. Mulford explained that both countries had the highest debt burden in the world in proportion to their gross national product, and that most of their debt was owed to other governments, rather than to private banks.
On top of this, Egypt has been especially hard hit by the gulf crisis, which, among other things, disrupted its trading patterns and forced hundreds of thousands of Egyptian migrant workers back into the country, putting new pressures on domestic services.
With 55 million people, Egypt is the most populous country in the Middle East, and the second most populous on the African continent after Nigeria.
 
Latin Debt Mostly Private
 In Poland's case, the United States went beyond the 50 percent reduction agreed to by the Paris Club, forgiving 70 percent of Poland's $3.8 billion debt to Washington.
Despite the Administration's argument that Poland and Egypt are special cases, debt-ridden Latin American countries are likely to call for similar treatment.
One major difference, however, is that most of the Latin debt is owed to banks, not governments. For example, official or government debt of Argentina is only 1 percent of its total foreign debt of $56 billion.
The Egyptian package was more difficult to put together than Poland's because of Cairo's poor record on meeting I.M.F. economic conditions.
For example, in 1987 Cairo and the fund came to terms on a $250 million loan, but the Mubarak Government, failing to meet fiscal, monetary and pricing targets, fell out of compliance.
 
Riots 10 Years Ago
 It had been 10 years earlier that the fund and Egypt last came together. Then, too, Egypt, under President Anwar el-Sadat, could not meet the terms. Waves of rioting broke out in Cairo when the Government reduced some of the subsidies on foods, as was demanded by the I.M.F.
The reforms that flow from the new I.M.F. program are also likely to bring political danger, especially as they again touch on removing subsidies from essential foods and services.
In a recent interview with the Cairo newspaper Al Ahram, President Mubarak sought to demonstrate the critical need for foreign assistance.
He calculated his country's overall losses from the gulf war at $20 billion. Among other things, he said, 700,000 Egyptians who worked in Iraq and Kuwait returned jobless. Also, Egypt lost billions in tourism, and revenues from oil exports have fallen because of increases in consumption by the growing population.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 11, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:

HEADLINE: Defying the Wisdom for '92, Ex-Senator Tsongas Dives In

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOWELL, Mass., April 8

 BODY:
The heavyweights in the Democratic Party are temporizing, stalling, waiting for the odds to improve before making any commitment to enter the 1992 Presidential campaign. Paul E. Tsongas, the former Senator from Massachusetts, has simply plunged in, calmly defying the collective wisdom of the Capital Beltway.
He knows that after the party's experience with Michael S. Dukakis, the 1988 Democratic nominee, a campaign by another Greek-American liberal from Massachusetts is "fodder for Jay Leno and 'Saturday Night Live,' " as Mr. Tsongas puts it. He knows that the view of much of Washington is that President Bush is all but unbeatable and would certainly not be beatable by someone off the national political scene since 1984, when Mr. Tsongas left the Senate with a diagnosis of cancer. 
 He also knows that every time he has a chest cold, as he does now, someone will probably ask him about his health, five years after he underwent a successful bone marrow transplant for the treatment of lymphoma.
Paul Tsongas, now 50 years old, knows all these things, talks about them blithely on the veranda of his gracious old hilltop home here in Lowell -- and remains convinced that he wants to run.
He was struggling on this gentle morning with a speech he would deliver later in the week to the National Press Club in Washington. "It's hard to make people understand how I think these days," he said.
Were he thinking today as he did back in his days as an ambitious young lawmaker who considered himself a potential Presidential contender, he might make the same calculated decision that many Democrats are now making: "Decide that it's not probable," he said, "and save myself for '96."
But he is no longer a 33-year-old freshman Congressman or a 37-year-old freshman Senator. His battle with cancer, and six years working as a lawyer and businessman, have changed him, Mr. Tsongas said. He is convinced that the nation faces a serious economic decline and that neither Democrats nor Republicans are addressing it as they should. He wanted to get his ideas out. And so he runs.
 
'Pro-Business Liberal'
 Mr. Tsongas is often termed a "pro-business liberal," and he does not object to the description. His campaign white paper, "A Call to Economic Arms," paints a grim picture of "America's manufacturing base under attack," buffeted by outmoded policies and intensifying foreign competition. "Both political parties," the paper argues, "are going to have to abandon the rusty core elements of their economic philosophies and head off in new directions."
Republicans, he asserts, must accept the notion that the United States needs an industrial policy in which the Federal Government is actively involved in helping businesses develop new technologies. "American companies need the U.S. Government as a full partner if they are to have any hope of competing internationally," Mr. Tsongas wrote.
Democrats, Mr. Tsongas said, must reject the politics of "class warfare" and help spur economic growth through measures like a carefully aimed cut in the tax on capital gains. "Class warfare is certainly good politics," he wrote, "but it's good politics at the expense of the nation's industrial base."
Mr. Tsongas also breaks with the orthodoxy of many Democrats by supporting nuclear power as a means of easing the country's dependence on fossil fuels, a stance that he adopted several years ago but that he says is all the more urgent now, given the furor over global warming.
The Tsongas campaign has printed 40,000 copies of "A Call to Economic Arms," and Mr. Tsongas said he is cheered by the response. "I know the usual political analysis is that Bush is unbeatable and we should just have a coronation and skip the election, but that's Washington," he said. "Outside, people really know that the ground is trembling."
This is not a mega-campaign. Its first major fund-raising event will be Thursday night in Boston; Dennis Kanin, Mr. Tsongas's law partner and longtime political adviser, said the campaign expected to raise $250,000 that night. The Tsongas campaign hired a press secretary this week, its first paid staff member, and will open a headquarters in Boston shortly. Mr. Tsongas is expected to officially announce his candidacy on April 30, with appearances in Lowell, Manchester, N.H., and Des Moines.
Mr. Tsongas said he had sought and had received a go-ahead from his physicians before deciding to make the race. Dr. Tak Takvorian, a senior staff physician at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and Mr. Tsongas's physician, said the candidate had shown no evidence of the disease since he underwent the bone marrow transplant in 1986.
 
'Could Not Be Better'
 Mr. Tsongas, who has three daughters with his wife, Nicola, a lawyer, said, "On a personal level, our life could not be better than it is now."
He said he was urged to enter the race for governor of Massachusetts last year, but, "It just wasn't me." He said he wanted his ideas on national economic policy to be heard; some Democrats, including the poll taker Geoffrey Garin, suggest that he could play a role similar to that played by Bruce Babbitt, the former Governor of Arizona, in 1988: raising ideas, challenging orthodoxy.
"But the fact of the matter is, nobody's turned that into a successful model yet for winning the nomination," Mr. Garin said.
Mr. Tsongas said, with a smile, that he is ready to press on. "Besides," he said after outlining the rationale for his candidacy, "it's also fun. There's a magic to it."
