HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Mexico-U.S. Phone Lines To Increase

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, April 9

 BODY:
A.T.& T. announced today that it would increase the telecommunications capacity between the United States and Mexico fivefold by the end of this year, as part of a broad new focus on Latin America.
 Officials of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said the increased capacity, which will be made possible by the completion of five new fiber-optic cables across the border, is planned to coincide with an expected surge in demand for telephone and computer services after a new North American free-trade accord is reached. 

 
A Serious Impediment
 The lack of a clear, reliable communications network to the United States has in the past been a serious impediment to the growth of American business investment in Mexico, forcing many American companies that do business here to establish expensive private phone lines and courier links to their headquarters in the United States.
 The poor quality of existing connections has also placed sharp limits on the use of modern telecommunications devices, such as facsimile, computer networking and data transmission, by foreign and Mexican companies alike.
 The Mexican telephone monopoly, Telefonos de Mexico, plans to spend as much as $2.5 billion this year alone to install digital technology under the terms of a Government agreement late last year to privatize part of the company.
 "As we move toward a North American free-trade zone, improved communication is critical to businesses, travelers and individual callers," said Don Anderson, an A.T.& T. official in San Antonio, where today's announcement was made. The governments of Canada, Mexico and the United States have agreed to hold negotiations on a North American free-trade zone in hopes of joining their three economies in a new trading zone that would include more than 360 million people.
 A.T.& T. spokesmen said that each of the new cross-border cables would be able to carry the equivalent of 37,800 simultaneous voice conversations and would permit the installation of new digital transmission equipment and services as part of a major planned expansion of A.T.& T.'s business in the region.
 Within the next two years, the new cables are to be connected to an 8,000-mile Mexican fiber-optic "backbone network" that will link up 54 Mexican cities with high-quality digital transmission technology. A.T.& T., which now has some 2,000 employees in Mexico, will build 60 percent of that network, and has also announced its participation in a new $500 million fiber-optic underseas communications cable that will connect Mexico with the United States, the Caribbean and Spain.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Record Opening-Day Salaries: Not Peanuts or Cracker Jack

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
If the fact that 223 players are making $1 million or more this year -- 32 at $3 million or more -- is not enough of an economically mind-boggling barometer of the escalation of baseball salaries, consider these developments:
 Nine teams have an average salary of more than $1 million, dividing total payroll by the number of players. The average opening-day major league salary for all players, total 708, is $890,844, and an astonishing 53 percent more than last year's opening-day average, which was in the $580,000 range. 
 In previous years, no individual team average salary ever reached this year's major league average salary. The record for a team average was set by the Mets in 1989 at $865,741.
Rosters and disabled lists -- and thus the numbers -- will change somewhat by Aug. 31, when the official salary studies are conducted by the Player Relations Committee and the Players Association. But the season-opening figures, compiled by The New York Times from contract data obtained from management and player sources, show just how meteorically salaries have risen this year.
 On opening day last year only one player, Robin Yount of Milwaukee, was at the $3 million plateau. This year Darryl Strawberry of Los Angeles, at $3.8 million, heads a hefty group of 32 floating in that economic stratosphere. Last year 153 players were at $1 million or more, this year 223.
 The Oakland Athletics, with a record $36.4 million payroll and 14 of their 27 players receiving $1 million or more, have the highest team average, $1,349,352. The Houston Astros, who lost most of their high-priced players as free agents during the winter, are at the other end of the salary standings with an average of $487,090.
 The five members of the Athletics who are signed for $3 million or more -- total $16.7 million -- make more than the entire payrolls of Houston, Baltimore or Seattle. Add Mark McGwire, and the $19.55 million total is higher than the payroll of those three teams plus Cleveland and the Chicago White Sox. Then throw in Dave Henderson, and the $22.15 million total is higher than the payrolls of those five clubs plus Texas, Montreal, Philadelphia, St. Louis, Atlanta and San Diego, or 11 of the other 25 clubs.
 After the Athletics, the Mets have 13 players at $1 million or more, Boston, California and San Francisco 12 each and the Yankees, Kansas City and Los Angeles 11 each. Baltimore and Seattle have the fewest, three each.
 Only 43 players are receiving the minimum salary of $100,000. That total is down drastically from the 1990 opening-day total of 90, although those rosters each included 28 players because of the abbreviated spring training that followed the lockout.
The average team salaries on this page are based on the opening-day rosters and disabled list. All team and individual salaries include base salary and prorated share of signing bonuses.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Fifteen pitchers who last year had won-lost records of .500 or worse will earn a total of $38,262,503. The group includes some who began this season on the disabled list, such as Orel Hershiser, above, and such high-paid underacheivers as Mark Langston and Mark Davis; dollar for dollar, Ken Griffey Jr. of Seattle, at $535,000, is very likely the best player in the majors. He may continue to be one of the best players around after this year, but his salary next year is likely to soar to $2 million; the Tigers will pay the most money for missing the most pitches. Cecil Fielder, above, Mickey Tettleton, Rob Deer and Pete Incaviglia struck out a total of 635 times last season, and the Tigers will pay them a total of $5,816,667 this year; after the Reds won the World Series, Lou Piniella got his boss to make him the highest-paid manager when she nearly doubled his salary, from 350,000 to nearly $700,000. Nice as the raise was, the new salary would place him only 13th on the Reds' players' pay list; Dwight Gooden of the Mets, above, and Roger Clemens of the Red Sox have recently signed the richest contracts ever based on average annual value, but they do not have the top pay on their respective teams this year because the contracts are extensions that begin next year. Each is No. 4 on his club for 1991.

PUB-DATE: April 11, 1991

SECTION: Section A; Page 11; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1294 words

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
Kurds Assert Few Outside Iraq Wanted Them to Win

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DAMASCUS, Syria, April 10

 BODY:
As they contemplate the swift and bloody collapse of their revolt in Iraq, the exiled foes of President Saddam Hussein have come to some bitter conclusions about their defeat. Partly, they say, they were outgunned and partly overwhelmed by the speed and scope of an uprising that took even them by surprise.
Partly, too, they made their own, severe blunders, they say. But beyond those reasons, they assert in homes and offices across Syria's capital, they lost because very few people outside Iraq wanted them to win at all. 
 It is, perhaps, one of the most savage realizations of the Persian Gulf crisis and the subsequent turmoil in both north and south Iraq that the allied campaign against President Hussein brought the United States and its Arab coalition partners to a strikingly unanimous view: whatever the sins of the Iraqi leader, he offered the West and the region a better hope for his country's stability than did those who have suffered his repression.
 
Military Coup Called Object
 "Those who are concerned with the situation in Iraq prefer a solution from inside the establishment," said Fakhri Kareem, a member of the leadership of the 17-party coalition of exiled opposition groups that is based here and includes Kurds, Islamic fundamentalists, Baathists, Communists and others.
In other words, he said, "U.S. officials make no secret of it -- they want a military coup" in Baghdad to topple President Hussein and are prepared to wait for it.
The revolt first broke out in southern Iraq when American and allied forces routed Iraqi forces from Kuwait and President Hussein's enemies sensed his vulnerability. It spread to Kurdish-speaking northern Iraq with such ease and speed, according to Western assessments, that Kurdish insurgents found towns falling to them virtually without a fight.
But President Hussein, marshaling a rump army based on the elite Republican Guard and helicopter-gunship forces held in reserve during the gulf war, turned his forces first on the Shiite Muslim insurgents in the south, then on the Kurdish guerrillas in the north.
 
Ill Prepared for the Uprising
 "We lost," said Izzedine Barawi, a Kurdish spokesman here, "because we were lightly armed and they had heavy weapons, because our people were starving and because we simply could not marshal the large numbers of people who had joined in the uprising." With its speed, seeming spontaneity and broad scope, many exiled Iraqis say, the uprising caught them ill-prepared.
Those were not, however, the only reasons. Islamic fundamentalist officials here acknowledge that by casting the southern revolt as a holy war in the revolutionary style of neighboring Iran they not only invited disputes with secular members of the opposition coalition, but also frightened Iraq's Arab neighbors.
Syria, for instance, "does not want to see mullahs in Baghdad," said an official here, referring to the idea of an Islamic fundamentalist regime in Baghdad that might foment a resurgence of Syria's own Muslim militants. "Syria is in complete agreement with Washington on this," said the official, who requested anonymity. Neither did the Sunni Muslim royal family of Saudi Arabia wish to invite a Shiite revolutionary regime to its borders.
While Western diplomats say Iran apparently provided weapons, moral backing and other support for the rebels in the south, Iraq's Arab neighbors did not. "Syria was a point of passage, a shelter for the exiled officials, but nothing more," an official said. "There was no economic or military aid to the Kurds or anyone else." Syria sided with the United States in the gulf crisis.
 
A Letter Awaits Baker
 At the same time, the United States matched its refusal to be drawn into the civil war with a refusal to talk to those involved in fighting it.
When Secretary of States James A. Baker 3d arrives here on Thursday to discuss the Middle East with President Hafez el-Assad, he will find waiting for him a letter from the opposition groups requesting a meeting. "We hope that your Government will respond positively" to the request, the letter, delivered to the United States Embassy here, says. So far, Iraqi exiles say, there has been no reply to it and the embassy's doors remain closed to them.
Bush Administration officials have met with exiled Iraqis in Washington, but members of the coalition here maintain that those figures have no links to the insurgency.
Moreover, United States policy, reflecting a widespread regional view, is apparently based partly on the conclusion that those who fought the civil war would have wound up fighting one another if they had won, splitting the country into sectarian chunks reminiscent of Lebanon.
"We've seen these guys -- Kurds and Shiites -- threatening one another publicly, in front of reporters," a Syrian journalist said. "You get the Shiites saying they want an Islamic state and the Kurds saying, 'Well, if you do that we'll take up arms against you'."
"A separate Kurdistan," said a Syrian official, "is a casus belli for both Turkey and Syria." Both countries have Kurdish minorities likely to be inspired by a Kurdish state on their borders in northern Iraq.
 
A Weak Hussein Called Aim
 The United States' attitude, a senior regional diplomat said, has also brought several Arab governments to the more cynical conclusion that "Washington wanted a weak Saddam to sign up for the cease-fire terms" set out by the United Nations Security Council last week. These deny Iraq the ability to rebuild its military strength and mortgage part of its likely oil revenues to pay reparations.
"Saddam Hussein has to be made responsible for the postwar conditions in Iraq," the diplomat said. "A new government would have denied the obligations. As it is now, the hardships of postwar Iraq will be the responsibility of Saddam Hussein."
Mr. Kareem, the opposition coalition member, who is also a leader of the exiled Iraq Communist Party, said, "The U.S. seems interested in keeping Saddam as a weakling, an invalid, in order to get his signature on the Security Council resolution."
That argument evokes the question: Who do Iraq's neighbors want to see running the country? The answer, though not unanimous, is a strongman from the military or the Baath Party whose policies will not challenge the region's monarchies and dictatorships by setting an example of democracy.
"Syria would prefer a Baathist government without Saddam Hussein," an Arab envoy said, "not a democractic one, not a Shiite one, not a Kurdish one and probably not a pro-Western one."
Syria and Iraq, longstanding adversaries, are led by rival wings of the Baath Party, which is nominally committed to Arab unity, socialism and freedom, but which in reality is more a principle sinew of power for unelected ruling elites.
"On the other hand," the diplomat said, "a reunited Baath Party under Syrian influence might well be seen as a new regional power bloc, which neither Turkey nor Saudi Arabia would approve."
The calculations reflect another reality, particularly for Iraq's Kurds, a non-Arab Sunni Muslim group that makes up minorities in Iraq, Iran, Syria, Turkey and the Soviet Union.
In 1920, the Treaty of Sevres regulating the break-up of the Ottoman Empire promised the Kurds a state of their own, but the treaty became a dead letter when Mustafa Kemal led a Turkish revolt against its terms, and its promises were never redeemed. Since then none of the Kurds' host countries have seen an interest in even contemplating a revival of the pledges. Countless Kurdish revolts have been crushed.
"Unfortunately," said Massoud Barzani, a leader of one of the two main Kurdish insurgent groups in the fractious coalition, "the Kurds have no friends."

SECTION: Section D; Page 2; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 782 words

HEADLINE: Talking Deals;
Larger Mergers Delayed by War

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
THE economies in the United States and Britain were slumping, Saddam Hussein had invaded Kuwait and President Bush was building an international coalition to oppose the Iraqi leader. But the business of buying or merging companies apparently went on almost as usual late last year, except that some big deals seemed to fall by the wayside.
But when the Persian Gulf war began in January, activity plunged. By then the United States and Britain were in recession, and European economies were beginning to slide as well. Banks were still tight with loans, and executives were not traveling to make deals or look for them. 
 That's the picture that emerges from data released yesterday on the buying and merging of companies in Europe and elsewhere for last year and the first quarter of 1991.
According to Translink's European Deal Review, mergers and acquisitions in Europe rose to a record last year, as the rush continued to prepare for the economic union of Europe in 1992.
Companies in Sweden, which is not a member of the European Community but wants to join, scurried most frantically to be well placed for 1992. Companies in this small economy wound up ranked fourth in the number of deals and second in the total value of deals whose prices were reported (Because prices are not reported in some deals the dollar comparisons are a less precise indicator of activity). The money spent in 1990, $12 billion, was six times that paid in 1989, the data show.
The United States was third among the acquirers of European companies, with 177 deals, down from 182 in 1989, when it was second. The value of the deals was $11.8 billion, also putting it in second place, but down from $15.3 billion. The big American deal of the year was Philip Morris's $3.8 billion purchase of the Swiss candy maker Jacobs Suchard, accounting for 32 percent of the American total.
But according to a survey of the first quarter of 1991 by KPMG Peat Marwick, both foreign acquisitions in the United States and American acquisitions worldwide fell sharply. The number of foreign mergers or acquisitions fell 53.2 percent, to 66, in the first three months of this year from 144 in the fourth quarter. The value of the deals in which prices were reported plummeted 75.2 percent, to $3.3 billion from $13.3 billion. The Dutch, followed by the Japanese and the British were the leading foreign acquirers.
The number of American company acquisitions abroad dropped 52.9 percent, to 49 from 104, while the value of the mergers or acquisitions was off 53.6 percent, to $1.3 billion from $2.8 billion.
"The economy was part of it," said Herb Adler, a Peat Marwick international mergers and acquisitions partner. "But people were not even going on airplanes. You didn't go and look at a acquisition and you didn't go and see an investment banker." But he said he has seen signs of revival since.
Over all, according to Translink, 1,467 deals took place in Europe in 1990, compared with 1,266 in 1989. The value of the deals in which prices were reported rose 24 percent, to $62 billion from $50 billion. Britain remained the favorite country to buy in, followed by France and Germany. The data include deals that have not necessarily closed.
The leading deal makers were the French in both the number of deals, 263, and the value reported, $13.6 billion. But their aggressive buying, according to Translink's editor, Mark Dixon, is also causing some friction in the European Community because many mergers and acquisitions are by state-owned or controlled companies. The British have tried to block such deals.
There was a drop in the deals by German companies, a clear reflection of the concentration on the rebuilding of eastern Germany. More than 85 percent of eastern German companies are being bought by Germans in the west. Compared with 1990, German mergers and acquisitions were down to 111 deals, from 128, and down to $2.5 billion, from $8.5 billion, in reported value. But the interest in Germany from abroad held up well.
In comparing the first half of the year with the second half, the main impact from the Persian Gulf crisis came right away. Then the rate of deal-making recovered. But it appears from the value of deals reported that some expensive transactions might have been put off because the value of deals does not recover as much.
In August, total deals fell 32 percent, to 95, and the value 80.6 percent, to $1.4 billion. But in September, the number was back to 121, just 19 below the July level. But the value had come back to only $3 billion, still less than half of the $7.2 billion in July. By December there were 134 deals with a reported value of $3.4 billion.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up on Soviet Unrest; Gold Prices Mostly Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday, strengthened by heightened unrest in the Soviet Union and reports of large dollar purchases by a large Asian bank.
Gold prices rose in Asia but fell elsewhere. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $364.40 an ounce, down 50 cents from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $363.10 an ounce, off 70 cents from its quote of late on Tuesday. 
 The dollar, which rose in European trading, continued to strengthen in New York trading after reports that a large Asian bank had bought dollars.
Further fueling the rise were news reports that Georgia, the southern Soviet republic that declared its independence on Tuesday, was planning a strike to protest the presence of Government troops.
The dollar was helped by a rumor, that later proved untrue, that Georgia had declared a state of war against the Soviet Union. Unrest in the Soviet Union is viewed as hurting neighboring economies, like Germany's.
Also affecting yesterday's trading were expectations on two important economic reports, the Producer Price Index due today, and the Consumer Price Index, due out tomorrow. If inflation seem relatively subdued, traders say the Federal Reserve Board may move to ease interest rates to speed the nation's economic recovery.
Lower interest rates generally hurt the dollar by eroding the value of dollar-denominated investments and making them less attractive.
But Tom Benfer of the Bank of Montreal's New York office, said he was "not totally convinced" a move to lower interest rates would hurt the dollar. He said recent trading activity had anticipated a move by the Fed.
Lower inflation could also ultimately help the dollar against foreign currencies by giving an extra lift to the United States economy, he added.
"I think the dollar still remains and continues to have underlying strength," Mr. Benfer said.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7800, from $1.7900 late on Tuesday. Sterling also weakened in New York, fetching $1.7760, less than the $1.7945 late on Tuesday.
Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 137.20 Japanese yen, unchanged from Tuesday. Later in London, it fell to 136.30 yen, and in New York it rose to 137.43 yen, from late Tuesday's 134.85 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late on Tuesday, included: 1.6800 German marks, up from 1.6655; 1.4295 Swiss francs, up from 1.4080; 5.6815 French francs, up from 5.6360; 1,246.00 Italian lire, up from 1,236.50, and 1.1513 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1525.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gasoline Prices Climb by 2 On Report of Supply Drop

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The wholesale price for May deliveries of unleaded gasoline gained more than 2 cents a gallon on the New York Mercantile Exchange yestesday after a report showed a sharp drop in United States gasoline stocks.
Crude oil and heating oil futures also rose. 
 Unleaded gasoline futures settled 1.25 cents to 2.19 cents higher in New York, with the contract for delivery in May at 70.67 cents a gallon; crude oil was 35 cents to 79 cents higher, with May at $21.05 a barrel; heating oil was 1.26 cents to 1.56 cents higher, with May at 56.02 cents a gallon; natural gas was 0.7 cent to 2.3 cents lower, with May at $1.376 per 1,000 cubic feet.
 
Off 4.9 Million Barrels
 The selloff in petroleum followed Tuesday's weekly inventory report by the American Petroleum Institute, which said the supply of gasoline in large domestic terminals and pipelines totaled 206.5 million barrels as of last Friday, down 4.9 million barrels from the previous week.
Gasoline stocks are only slightly above 205 million barrels, which is recognized by the Energy Department as the minimum operating level before supply shortages could develop, according to the Pegasus Econometric Group of Hoboken, N.J.
The fall in gasoline supplies indicates "the recession is losing its grip on gasoline demand" as the summer driving season approaches, Pegasus said in an analysis of the report.
James Ritterbusch, an energy analyst for Paine Webber in Chicago, said gasoline shortages would not necessarily develop if inventories fell below 205 million barrels. He said the Midwest would likely be the first region to feel a gasoline shortage because inventories there are tighter than in other parts of the country.
Grain and soybean futures prices rose modestly on the Chicago Board of Trade in advaance of an Agriculture Department report that indicated export demand for corn and wheat had weakened and wheat consumpution was rising.
The rally partly reflected position-evening ahead of the monthly supply-and-demand report, which was released after the close.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
U.S. Supercomputer Plan To Spur G.N.P., Study Says

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
A Government-financed study says that a proposed $1.9 billion Federal program to develop improvements in supercomputers will generate more than $10 billion in revenue for the United States computer industry by the end of the decade.
The report on the fastest computers, which was released yesterday, was prepared by the Gartner Group, a market research firm, for the Department of Energy. The economic impact study estimates that the program will add significantly to the United States gross national product, increasing it by sixth-tenths of a percent to 1.7 percent in the year 2000.
 
The 'Leading Edge'
 The report calls the supercomputer business the "leading edge" in information technology and says that advances made in the design of the fastest computers in turn affect competitiveness in many other American industries. 
 Congress is considering a five-year high performance computing initiative to begin in 1992 and to gradually increase Federal spending for advanced computing research from its present level of about $500 million a year to more than $1.1 billion a year. The additional Federal money would help create a "national data highway" that would link the nation's supercomputers at speeds greater than a billion bits of data a second. It would also supply research financing for advanced computing technologies.
Federal spending to develop supercomputer technologies will do more for productivity and international competitiveness than other Government spending, according to the report's authors.
"Spending for new knowledge probably brings more of a return for your investment than any other expenditure," said Herbert E. Striner, a professor emeritus and former business school dean at American University and senior consultant for the report.
Mr. Striner said that keeping the United States' lead in supercomputer technology was critical to the nation because the ability to process information quickly had a significant impact on decision-making that directly affects competitiveness.
The industries that will probably be helped most by advances in supercomputer technology are aerospace, chemicals, electronics, petroleum and pharmaceuticals, the report said.
The report asserts that Japanese supercomputer companies are now stronger than United States companies, noting that Cray Research Inc., the largest American supercomputer maker has less than $1 billion in annual revenues, while other American supercomputer companies are under $200 million. By comparison, the annual revenues of Fujitsu, Hitachi and NEC ranged from $17 billion to $45 billion.
The report said the number of supercomputers installed in the United States had fallen from 81 percent of the world's total in 1980 to 50 percent of the world's total in 1990. During that period the Japanese total rose to 28 percent from 8 percent.
The report predicts that with Federal support the average parallel supercomputer will double in speed by the end of the decade, reaching speeds up to 1.3 trillion mathematical operations a second.
The report was financed jointly by the Energy Department and the Los Alamos National Laboratory.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Market Yields Down After Being Mixed 5 Weeks

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down for the period ended yesterday, after five weeks of being mixed.
Analysts at IBC/Donoghue's expect money market yields to remain in flux, leaning more toward the downside as the fixed-income market continues to wait for some Federal action to influence short-term rates. 
 "Everything points to a further decline in yields in money market funds, at least until there are firmer signs that the economy is bottoming," said Walter S. Frank, chief economist at Donoghue's. "Right now the news is not bad, but not great."
Tax-exempt money fund yields fell sharply after four weeks on the rise, as demand has finally begun to outstrip the supply of new issues. The average number of days to maturity of securities held in portfolios declined to 49 days, from 50. Assets rose by $1.9 billion, to a total of $92.1 billion.
The average seven-day compounded yield for the period ended yesterday is 4.22 percent, down 25 basis points, while the 30-day compounded average yield, because it lags, rose slightly to 4.35 percent from 4.33 percent.
The taxable equivalent of the current seven-day tax-exempt yield is 5.86 percent for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, and 6.29 percent for those in the 33 percent tax bracket.
 
Taxable Assets Up
 Of the tax-exempt funds with assets of better than $100 million, which are monitored by IBC/Donoghue's, the Strong Municipal Money Market fund produced the best return on investment for the third straight week, with a yield of 5.25 percent, or about 103 basis points more than the seven-day compound yield. The fund is managed by Strong/Corneliuson Capital Management Inc. in Milwaukee.
Assets of taxable funds rose by $6.7 billion, to a total of $465.1 billion. Institutional funds accounted for $5.2 billion of the gain, to a total of $116 billion, as they sought the higher money market yields that lag other markets. Consumer assets rose $1.5 billion, to a total of $349.1 billion.
The average seven-day compounded taxable yield fell by 9 basis points, to 6.12 percent, while the 30-day yield fell 6 basis points, to 6.20 percent. The fund with the best return on investment for the period ended yesterday was Olde Premium Money Market Series, with a yield of 7.04 percent. The distributor is the Olde Discount Corporation of Detroit.
By comparison, bank money market accounts that compete with the money funds fell 3 basis points, to 5.48 percent according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index.

HEADLINE: Workers Must Choose As Jobs Move

BYLINE: By EDWARD B. FISKE

 BODY:
Lucy Carrero started working for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company as a part-time messenger when she was a 17-year-old high school student. Eighteen years later she is still there, now as supervisor of 35 medical claims approvers.
"It's a good job," Ms. Carrero said Monday. "I like it." 
 Unfortunately, hers is among thousands of middle-level positions that Metropolitan Life is relocating. So Ms. Carrero, who has lived all her life in the Bronx, may soon have to decide whether to follow her job to Tampa, Fla. Most likely, if given the chance, she will.
"It will be a big change in terms of my personal life," said Ms. Carrero, 35, who supports her two children, ages 10 and 14. "But I need my job. I don't want to have to start all over again."
 
Moving Jobs, Not Headquarters
 Last week Metropolitan announced that it would relocate 3,000 jobs from its headquarters at 1 Madison Avenue to nine other sites around the country, including 1,200 to a new administrative center in Bridgewater, N.J. Another 1,000 jobs will be eliminated altogether, while 5,000 others, including those of all the top managers, will remain in New York City. The company is still notifying employees whether they will be asked to move.
A look at Metropolitan -- where the president, Robert G. Schwartz, emphasized that the company was "committed to keeping our headquarters at 1 Madison Avenue" -- shows that such a move affects not only a business, but people who have spent years or decades there.
Since 1987, New York City has lost more than 100,000 jobs, many of them white-collar positions. But at the same time, the exodus of headquarters seems to have slowed since the late 1970's and early 1980's, as more companies that move jobs are still keeping some ties to the city.
That is the pattern here. Metropolitan Life's decision would result in an immediate loss of 4,000 jobs from the city with no guarantee that they would return.
City city and state officials fear that several other large companies, including Smith Barney, the Morgan Stanley Group, the Bear Stearns Companies and Paramount Communications, could follow Metropolitan, and by doing so not only cut current job levels, but limit expansion and job growth in the city.
 
Keeping the 'Creative People'
 Another worrisome feature of the Metropolitan announcement is that, unlike some other companies, it is moving middle-level managers rather than back-office employees.
"New York's a great place," said Harry P. Kamen, an executive vice president. "But it's not all things to all people."
Mr. Kamen said that Metropolitan wants to keep its "creative people, the investment people, the ones who will develop new ideas" in New York City.
"But when you get to the middle-level managers and the technical people, New York City may not be the most efficient place to operate," he said. Because of the cost of living and other factors, "it's tough to move a middle-management person from Aurora or Wichita to Manhattan."
 
Big Elevators
 The company's decision was prompted by the renovation of one of the buildings in its headquarters -- two block-sized structures linked by tunnels and a 10th-floor skywalk on Madison Avenue between 23d and 25th Streets. Dating from 1929, the building is poorly designed for today's office needs.
"It was organized for large open spaces with row upon row of desks for clerks doing manual entries into ledgers and keeping records on enormous numbers of policies for very small amounts," said Mr. Kamen. "Even the elevators are large -- built for the coming and going of large numbers of people all at the same time."
Now, record keeping is done by computers and the legions of clerks have been replaced by programmers, systems designers and other technical and professional workers managing an increasingly diverse range of services.
"You have work stations and spacious offices," Mr. Kamen said. "Our percentage of clerical workers has dropped in half, from 4 out of 10 to 2 out of 10."
 
'We'll Try to Be Flexible'
 After the work is done in 1996, the building will have room for 6,000 workers.
Company officials say no decision has been made on how many of the 3,000 relocated employees will return, but company officials suggest one likely scenario is none.
"We're talking five years down the road, and we'll try to be flexible," said Mr. Kamen. "But people who relocate to Bridgewater won't be relocated again."
Some of the 4,000 employees affected by the decision have reacted with mixed emotions.
Tom Thurber, a 28-year old software trainer whose job will move to Pearl River, N.Y., said that he was "extremely happy." Mr. Thurber started working for Metropolitan four years ago in its Pearl River office, and was transferred to Manhattan. The commute from his Leonia, N.J., home will now be 20 minutes instead of 45.
Vicki Danaro, who is 38 and has been with Metropolitan for 21 years, has decided not to follow her job to New Orleans. "I don't want to go," she said. "Everything is here. I'm single and live at home, so I'm not all that worried. This is the third time my job has moved, but the other two times I found another one here in New York."
For Jack Davenport, a 52-year-old information services director whose job will shift to Bridgewater, working there would mean having to drive to work from his home in Manalapan, N.J., instead of taking the bus.
"I did a trial run Saturday, and it took me 55 minutes to drive to Bridgewater," he said. "In traffic, that means an hour and a quarter. Right now it takes me an hour and three quarters door to door, but I like other people to drive. I'm very impatient."
Mr. Davenport, who started working for the company as a high school student 34 years ago, said that with the last of his four children about to start college he cannot consider early retirement or accept a severance package.
 
Tough Trips
 The trip to New Jersey will be especially tough on some of his subordinates. "One is an Orthodox Jew who lives in Brooklyn," Mr. Davenport said. "He could not find the same sort of community in New Jersey, so he will have to commute for two hours."
The 1,000 eliminated jobs are a small percentage of Metropolitan's 54,000 employees nationwide. But for a company with a tradition of lifetime employment, the announcement constitutes what Bob Wright, a marketing analysis unit official, called "a break in the culture."
"It's hard to face the reality that after all those years of growth MetLife is downsizing," said Mr. Davenport. "All in all, the reaction is more negative than positive."
One claim approver in her 40's, who declined to give her name, said she expects to be laid off after 16 years. "My job is moving to Florida, but I don't expect to be eligible to go there," she said.
She said she is not fearful, though many of her colleagues are. "Some people have been here for 20 or 30 years," the woman said. "It's very scary for them. There are a lot of unanswered questions."
Mr. Wright suggested that even Snoopy, the cartoon dog who exudes reassurance in Metropolitan Life's advertising, has offered no advice.
"Snoopy's keeping mum," he said.

HEADLINE: Need Is Seen Approaching For Health-Care Rationing

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
A new study by Tufts University economists says that employers and the Federal Government have virtually run out of ammunition in their battle to slow the growth of spending for health care.
"We are running out of ways to make savings and approaching the point where we will have to ration health care," said William B. Schwartz, a professor of medicine and a medical economist at Tufts. 
 He said that the savings resulting from the system of pre-set hospital fees, which was introduced in the early 1980's, had been "overwhelmed" by explosive growth in medical technology, as well as by rising numbers of aging patients.
Dr. Schwartz and health-care economists at other universities said that efforts to reduce hospital admissions through health maintenance organizations and through networks of hospitals that provide discounts made little difference in the overall growth of hospital spending in the 1980's.
Hospital costs are the largest ingredient, about 45 percent, in the nation's health-care spending.
"The era of easy reductions" in the number of days that patients spend in hospitals "is largely over," Dr. Schwartz and Daniel N. Mendelson say in an article appearing in The New England Journal of Medicine.
 
'One-Shot Effect' Cited
 Dr. Schwartz said the nation's spending for care for short-term illnesses in community hospitals was growing by 6 percent, or $11 billion a year, in constant dollars, from a base in 1989 of $185 billion. "And if we bring the poor into the system, that would add another $60 billion to the base and $3 billion to $4 billion to the growth each year," he added.
"We never discovered how to control the forces that are driving costs upward," said Mark Pauly, chairman of the health care systems department at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School.
Dr. Pauley said efforts to slow rising costs through health maintenance organizations and medical reviews of expensive cases had only "a one-shot effect" on savings. "Employers say the same thing," he added. "All the devices helped for a while, they say, but now health insurance premiums are going up by 15 to 20 percent a year."
As for making patients and their families pay more of the cost of care, "the jury is still out," he said. "We don't know for sure if it slows the rate of growth." He said a recent study contradicted earlier findings that said increases in health costs had slowed when patients had to pay part of their medical bills.
Frank A. Sloan, a health economist at Vanderbilt University, said that Dr. Schwartz's analysis of the underlying trend was correct. "I buy the rationing argument," he said. But Professor Sloan said there was "undoubtedly still room for savings." He added, "There are lots of surgical procedures and hospital admissions" that could be eliminated because they are not appropriate. Surgical procedures among the elderly, for example, are increasing and should be studied to see whether all of them are justifiable, he said.

HEADLINE: Despite Some Gains by Hispanics, Report Finds Their Income Lags

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 10

 BODY:
Hispanic Americans have made some economic strides in recent years but they still lag well behind the rest of the nation's population, according to a Census Bureau report issued today.
The study, based on a bureau survey taken a year ago, before the completion of the 1990 census, said nearly two-thirds of Hispanic Americans were of Mexican origin, with Puerto Ricans (10.5 percent) and Cubans (4.9 percent) making up the other largest groupings. 
 In all, the report said, people of Latin American origin account for 13.7 percent of the nation's population.
The bureau said that more than 90 percent of Hispanic Americans lived in cities and that 23.4 percent of Hispanic families were poverty stricken. The poverty figure, based on a cutoff of $12,675 in annual income for a family of four, was an improvement from 1982, in the midst of the last recession, when the bureau conducted its last such survey focusing on Hispanic Americans. That year the proportion of hispanic Americans living in poverty was 27.2 percent.
But even the latest figure was far higher than the 9.2 percent rate of poverty that the bureau found among non-Hispanic families.
 
Decrease in Jobless Rate
 The report did not offer comparisons with other minority groups, like blacks or American Indians. But an earlier bureau report on blacks, based on figures from 1987, found that 30 percent of the black families in the United States were poor.
The latest report said the unemployment rate for Hispanic Americans also decreased over the eight-year period, to 8.2 percent in March 1990 from 16.5 percent in 1982. But that rate, like the poverty rate, was still well above the rate for non-Hispanic workers, which was 5.3 percent.
The report paralleled figures from the 1990 census in reporting a large increase in the number of Hispanic Americans in the last decade. According to the report, in 1990 about 5.9 million American households were Hispanic, an increase of 1.9 million since 1980.
About 82 percent of the Hispanic households were made up of families, with the remaining 18 percent composed of unrelated people living together or an individual living alone. Only about 70 percent of non-Hispanic households in the United States are family households, the report said.
 
Hispanic Groups Compared
 The report tended to confirm some anecdotal evidence about the relative success of various Hispanic groups in the last decade. Cubans had the highest average family income, $31,300, compared with $22,200 for Mexicans and $19,900 for Puerto Ricans.
In all, however, the median income of Hispanic American families was $23,400, just two-thirds of the median income of non-Hispanic families -- $35,200.
About 30 percent of male Hispanic workers were concentrated in lower-paying jobs like laborers or assembly-line workers, compared with 19.5 percent of non-Hispanic male workers.

HEADLINE: Toyota to Sell Cars in Israel, Officials Say

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 10

 BODY:
The Toyota Motor Corporation is expected to announce that it will begin selling cars in Israel despite the continuing Arab economic boycott of that country, officials of the Japanese auto maker said today.
For the last two years, Toyota officials say, they hve been under mounting pressure from Jewish organizations in the United States to begin sales operations in Israel. The pressure has taken the form of letters to Toyota and to newspapers but has not involved any threats of a boycott, according to the officials. 
 All 21 members of the Arab League refuse to have any economic dealings with Israel, and 13 of them participate in a secondary boycott against companies doing business there. Companies that break the boycott can be blacklisted.
 
Boycott Never Acknowledged
 Toyota has never acknowledged that it was complying with the boycott. Rather, company officials insisted they did not have the resources to sell cars in Israel, and "when the time was right they would consider it," a Toyota spokesman said.
Several other Japanese auto makers, including Honda's United States subsidiary, sell vehicles in Israel. Toyota is known as the most conservative of Japanese auto makers, so it is not surprising that it has allowed others to go first.
Like many Japanese companies, Toyota is acutely aware of American political currents. This week, 82 United States Senators signed a letter to the Emir of Kuwait requesting that his country drop the boycott.
And in recent weeks Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has been urging Arab governments to drop economic sanctions against Israel, saying it could reduce tension in the region and "build confidence" in advance of peace negotiations.
In their talks last week, President Bush asked Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan to clarify the Japanese Government's stance with respect to the boycott, a State Department spokesman said.
The Japanese Government, which imports most of its oil from the Middle East, is thought to have counseled some Japanese companies against economic ties with Israel, said William Maslow, general counsel of the American Jewish Congress. The organization publishes a newsletter that monitors developments concerning the 42-year-old boycott.
The Toyota officials said they had been planning to begin exporting cars from Japan to Israel before the Persian Gulf conflict but they suspended the plan because of the crisis. Toyota's decision comes against a backdrop of heightened United States diplomatic action toward easing tensions in the Middle East.
Toyota will begin by selling its 1.6-liter Corolla subcompact and may add more models later. The No. 1 auto maker in Japan hopes to sell 5,000 cars in Israel in 1992, which would amount to about 5 percent of the annual new-car market there.
The company's goal is to grow to about 20 percent of the market within a few years, its officials said. Last year Israelis bought about 109,000 new cars, 15 percent more than the previous year.
"Israel is not a huge market but it is significant," a senior Toyota official said.
The Corollas will be exported directly from Japan, the officals said, but American-built vehicles may eventually be exported to Israel.
Because the United States and Israel have a free-trade agreement, Honda and other Japanese auto makers that export from this country enjoy a considerable advantage over other auto makers, which must pay a stiff tariff.

HEADLINE: Costs Soar for On-the-Job Injuries

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
The workers' compensation system of insurance, the 80-year-old program in which employers pay for job-related injuries, is struggling to stay afloat in at least seven states.
Surging medical costs and multimillion-dollar lawsuits brought by injured workers pushed national spending on workers' compensation up nearly 13 percent last year, to $53 billion. Since 1985, the spending has jumped a stunning 83 percent. 
 Insurers say employers are not paying enough to cover the program's costs. All told, workers' compensation insurers estimate that they suffered $5.7 billion in losses last year.
In the latest action to deal with the towering costs, the National Workers' Compensation Reinsurance Pool, which keeps track of the finances of 600 insurer members, has just ordered them to raise their reserves for future claims by 15 percent, or $1.4 billion. Insurance companies say the pressure to hold down rate increases is so severe that several are abandoning the business.
 
Burden on Employers
 Faced with sharply higher insurance premiums in some states, some indignant employers are threatening to move. One Texas boot maker expanded by opening a plant in Missouri instead of Texas, where workers' compensation costs are among the nation's highest.
"The system clearly isn't working," said Donald Elisburg, executive director of the Occupational Health Foundation, a research and legal advisory group sponsored by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. "The insurance industry talks about losing money. Employers and insurance agencies complain about high costs. And we have enormous problems with workers who can't get the system to work right and wind up going to a lawyer."
Workers' compensation pays the medical bills and an average of two-thirds of the wages lost by workers who are injured at work or become ill because of job conditions. Workers typically send their claims to an insurer representing the employer. Disputed cases may be appealed to a state agency or hearing officer or fought over in a lawsuit.
The coverage, which is regulated by the states, is usually compulsory. In Texas and a few other states where it is not required, employers are increasingly dropping the insurance and gambling that they will not be hit by large medical claims.
Workers' compensation laws typically require employers to pay 100 percent of medical costs resulting from on-the-job injuries. And in many states an injured worker is free to choose a doctor and then switch to another if the first physician seems unwilling to certify that an injury will be seriously disabling. Employers say the system is also abused when some employees claim workers' compensation for injuries suffered off the job that are not fully covered by other health insurance.
Around the country, workers' compensation programs, once the arcane province of state labor and insurance departments, legal specialists and union leaders, are being hotly debated by lawmakers who are feeling pressure from small and large employers. Texas and Florida enacted sweeping changes last year -- which are now being challenged in court -- to curtail lawsuits and big lump-sum settlements. The new Florida law allows employers to reduce medical benefits for injuries suffered on the job. In Michigan, employers say lawmakers have improved the system by cracking down on retirees who were claiming workers' compensation as a virtual supplementary pension.
Employers and insurers say the system is also in serious trouble in Maine, Louisiana, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island.
Medical payments under workers' compensation have risen even faster than other health-care costs paid by employers. Insurers say this is largely a result of state laws that prohibit cost controls such as requiring employees to go to certain doctors and to pay more of their medical bills.
In some states, red tape has created backlogs of thousands of cases of workers waiting to be paid.
A typical dispute involved Debra Townsend, who has been fighting for 11 years with M-R Products Inc., which operates a small plastics factory in Copemish, Mich., over payments for a back injury she suffered when she lifted molds from a vat on April 28, 1979.
She insisted that she could not do factory work and waited 14 months for the first hearing by an administrative judge. The judge awarded her two-thirds of her $91.49 average weekly pay, but she waited four more years for the money. "The employer flat-out refused to pay," said Timothy Bott, Mrs. Townsend's lawyer. "We had to garnish the employer's bank account."
Geoff Smith, a lawyer for M-R Products, said the payments were delayed because the company's insurer filed for bankruptcy and the company itself had trouble paying bills as Michigan plunged into recession. In June 1984, Mrs. Townsend was awarded $19,458 in back payments, Mr. Smith said, but she did not collect until late in 1985. A state appeals court awarded her an additional $22,500 in penalties, but the Michigan Supreme Court limited the penalty to $1,500.
Mike Russo, the owner of M-R Products, wants his money back, but he too has had to wait for a new hearing -- for four years. "She is still getting compensation from us, but we think she can work," he said. "We offered her a job, and we expect to sue for the money she got."
 
Premiums Vary Widely
 Private employers pay premiums average 2.3 percent of their payroll, though for accident-prone occupations, like construction, premiums can exceed 40 percent of the payroll in some states.
The Vogel Brothers Building Company, a contractor based in Madison, Wis., pays some cement workers in Florida $400 a week. Their workers' compensation premiums add $177 to weekly labor costs, said Daniel Vogel, a company vice president.
The workers' compensation system was started in seven states in 1911, when workers were typically young and suffered injuries like chopped fingers and crushed limbs. In today's service economy, the work force is aging, which can mean more accidents and illnesses. In addition, courts in some states have stretched the coverage to include treatments for stress, back pain and injuries from repetitive tasks at computers.
As insurers shun unprofitable customers, abandoned employees are placed in state insurance pools. In Massachusetts, one of the hardest-pressed states, the pool was responsible for more than half of all workers in 1990. And as costs for the pools mount, private insurers and employers are taxed to pay those costs on top of their own insurance expenses.
 
Wisconsin Removes Uncertainty
 Workers' compensation is supposed to pay promptly without assigning blame. The system works well in states like Wisconsin, where a state agency determines the amounts that injured workers may receive and insures that payments are prompt. By reducing the uncertainty, Wisconsin makes it less likely that workers will shop around for sympathetic doctors or file expensive lawsuits, said Richard A. Victor, executive director of the Workers' Compensation Research Institute, a nonprofit group in Cambridge, Mass. In New York, where payments have been relatively low, injured workers have been more likely to file lawsuits.
In about 15 percent of all cases, the injured workers hire lawyers to put pressure on employers for large settlements. In California, fees for lawyers on either side, and for doctors who testified as experts, exceeded $1 billion of the $9.2 billion total cost of workers' compensation in 1988.
Gary Countryman, chairman of the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company, the nation's largest workers' compensation insurer, said regulators had blocked rate increases that would make up for "rapid cost escalation" in a number of states. Trying to catch up after several years of rebuffs by regulators in Rhode Island, for example, insurers there are requesting a rate increase of 128 percent.
In Florida and Texas, where employers were hit with rate increases of 30 percent in 1989 and 37 percent last year, business lobbyists pushed through laws to roll back rates, reduce coverage for workers and limit lawsuits.
Employers and insurers, sometimes joined by labor unions, have pushed through changes that reduced costs in states like Michigan, one of the highest-cost states until the early 1980's.
Alan H. Strohmaier, director of unemployment and workers' compensation at the General Motors Corporation, said that "in the 70's workers' compensation became a supplemental pension" that many disabled workers who retired could add to Social Security and other benefits. The law was tightened in 1982.
"Now there is a rigorous test to make sure a person is eligible," he said. As a result, he added, Michigan has become "an average-cost state" for workers' compensation.
But in Florida and Texas, labor unions went to court, contending that new laws denied injured workers the right to due process and a fair hearing.
In trying to curb expensive lawsuits, the Texas law would set guidelines for lawyers' fees, replacing their customary 25 percent of any settlement. Employees could not collect lump-sum settlements until after they returned to work. Ombudsmen stationed around the state would help injured employees to obtain their benefits.
The Florida Legislature has enacted changes intended to remove constitutional problems, and the State Supreme Court is expected to rule soon on the appeal. Chapin Clark, a senior vice president with the National Council on Compensation Insurance, said insurers would need further rate increases of 87 percent in Florida and 68 percent in Texas if the laws did not survive in the courts.
In its novel approach, Florida would offer an option that would combine workers' compensation with cost-containment features often found in other employee benefits. Under the option, known as 24-hour coverage, employees would no longer have to prove that they were hurt at work, for example, but they could be asked to pay a share, or a deductible, of the medical bills and a percentage of the charges thereafter.
"Florida is a state where the labor movement is weak enough so that some of these things get passed," said John F. Burton, director of the Institute of Management and Labor Relations at Rutgers University. "It wouldn't go in a lot of states."
Todd W. Thomas, president of the Florida Employers Safety Association, a lobbying group, said, "Labor and the trial lawyers hate the new law."

HEADLINE: Caution Urged on Recovery

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 10

 BODY:
The White House said today that it was too early to say the recession is ending, despite some hopeful signs.
But the Presidential spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said at a news conference that the Administration still believed that the downturn, which began in the second half of last year, would be short. 
 "I don't know if I can point to any new signs" that the recession is ending, Mr. Fitzwater said in response to a question. "You're familiar with leading indicators, housing starts, and there are a few hopeful signs in that area. But I think it would be a little premature to try to reach a firm conclusion at this point."
Administration officials have said they expected the economy to start rebounding by the second half of this year.
Mr. Fitzwater refused to say whether the White House supported the Federal Reserve's policy on interest rates. With a record budget deficit discouraging moves to end the recession through new spending programs, the Administration has left much of the recession-fighting to the central bank.

HEADLINE: New Cuts Sap Feeble School Districts

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTA CRUZ, Calif., April 4

 BODY:
While California lawmakers wrestle with a record budget deficit, the Superintendent of Schools in this beachfront city hunches over his ledgers, looking for programs to cut and teachers to dismiss from a near-bankrupt school system where fat has long since given way to bone.
The choices are grim, said the Superintendent, Dale E. Kinsley. Can he expect teachers who have been sent pink slips to continue to spend their own money for classroom supplies? Can he ask principals to give up weekends to paint dilapidated school buildings? 
 Can he dismiss more custodians without leaving the schools unsafe and unsanitary? Can he trim counselors without abandoning abused or suicidal children? Can he cancel music lessons in elementary school, drop-out prevention classes in junior high and sports programs in high school, which are among the few specials activities left for the 8,400 students here?
"How far do you go before you say this is not an acceptable environment for students to learn in?" asked Mr. Kinsley, whose district is one of two dozen in the state on the brink of bankruptcy. "There's not much more I can do here without closing the doors, handing the keys over to the state and saying, 'You guys run it.' "
 
More and More of Less
 Mr. Kinsley could barely balance his budget when Gov. Pete Wilson was projecting a $7 billion budget shortfall for the state and calling for $2 billion in cuts in public education. But now it is clear that the financial picture is far bleaker. With a gap of $12.6 billion, a deficit larger than the general funds of all but four other states, public education is expected to lose even more.
"How do we do the same with less, less, less?" asked Dan Cavanaugh, the principal of the Bay View Elementary School here, where the custodian already doubles as the playground attendant and the kindergarten teachers sell flavored ices to pay for art supplies.
Public education was once a jewel in California's crown. But the state that was consistently in the Top 10 in the 1960's and early 70's has fallen to the middle or the bottom of the pack in indicators like per-student spending and student-teacher ratio. The precipitous decline in the last decade, experts say, is largely the result of a 1978 ballot measure that limited local property taxes, which are a major source of school financing elsewhere in the nation.
The current recession has plunged many other states into budget crises that are likely to squeeze the public schools, but none are shackled like California in ability to tax and spend locally for education. California spends $4,598 a student, 24th in the nation, with New York in first place at $8,439. These numbers are for the 1989-90 school year, the most recent data available from the National Education Association and the Federal Department of Education.
 
A City of New Pupils a Year
 Complicating matters further in California is the staggering population growth, which has swamped a school system of 5.3 million with more than 200,000 new students a year, many of them poor, minority youngsters who speak little English and require extra attention. The student-teacher ratio here is 22.7, ranking California 50th in the nation, although actual class size is considerably larger because of the number of specialized teachers. Connecticut, with 13.1 students for each teacher, ranks first in this category.
California's public schools, excluding the public university system, gobble 40 percent of the state budget, or $25.3 billion out of $55.7 billion, a level guaranteed by another of the ballot measures that complicates governance here. To cut the education budget below the 40 percent mark, as Governor Wilson suggests, the Legislature must suspend that 1988 measure by a two-thirds vote. The alarming deficit projections make a suspension likely.
Education advocates recognize that the budget crisis is unlikely to be solved without slashing school spending, but they argue that taxes should be raised to limit the damage.
"I understand the Governor is in a tough place," said Bill Honig, the state Superintendent of Public Education and a defender of guaranteed school spending. "But it all comes down to choices. The cuts that are contemplated will set this state back for a decade."
From one end of California to the other, educators are braced for a hard fight. Recent school board meetings have been crowded, rowdy affairs. At a demonstration last week at the state Capitol in Sacramento, 8,000 protesters carried balloons saying "Save Our Kids" and placards demanding "Schools, Not Prisons."
Among the protesters were four teachers from Bakersfield, with 80 years of experience among them. The morning before the demonstration, they visited Old Sacramento, a riverside reconstruction of a frontier town, complete with a one-room school with hand-pump and wood-burning stove. "It's better than what I've got right now," said Pam Baugher, who teaches fifth and sixth grade in a school where the pipes burst in December's freeze and have yet to be repaired.
Such tales of woe have grown more common as districts consider the new round of cuts.
In San Francisco, at least $25 million must be chopped from a $424.8 million budget, which may mean closing two schools, canceling interscholastic sports and shortening the junior high school day to five periods by eliminating elective courses. In Los Angeles, where the gap is $317 million in a $3.9 billion budget, more than 2,000 of its 30,200 teachers have received layoff notices, out of 10,000 sent statewide.
 
Less Help for Young Mothers
 The Fresno school district is considering trimming a program for teen-age mothers that provides child care so girls can continue in school. And in San Jose, it may be necessary to scale back bilingual education, despite the fact that the district's children speak 58 languages. Also at risk in San Jose is the bus transportation required by a court-ordered desgregation plan and a project to remove asbestos from school buildings.
In Santa Cruz, where $2 million must be pared from a $34 million budget, librarians, music teachers and counselors, already in short supply, will be cut further. Those with teaching credentials will move into classrooms, bumping teachers with less seniority.
Adrienne McGuire, a fourth-grade teacher with seven years of experience and a $25,000 salary, may be among the displaced. Ms. McGuire, who is pregnant with twins, received a layoff notice but will not know if it is final until the state budget is completed in June.
In the meantime, like many teachers here, Ms. McGuire reaches into her pocket to buy the supplies the school can no longer afford, at a cost of about $700 a year.
 
Buying Sheep Brains
 Lately she has bought puzzles, batteries, magnets, a fish tank, a tape recorder, 50 pounds of clay and a half-dozen sheep brains for dissection. Along with the brains, Ms. McGuire bought rubber gloves, masks and barbecue skewers, in place of the real probes that she could not afford.
"It set me back a few bucks, but it was so neat," Ms. McGuire said. "You wouldn't not do it just because the school can't pay. All the research says that children have to touch things, and that's what gets eliminated."
Without music teachers, Zoli Torkos, a Bay View fourth grader who hated school until he started violin lessons, will no longer be learning the "Blue Danube." Without money for dropout prevention classes, eight junior high boys, many of them on probation, will be moved back into regular, overcrowded classrooms.
"It's a real smart move that Governor Wilson appropriated large amounts of money for the jail system because that's where these kids will end up," said Susan Toohey, who teaches the special class.
With fewer custodians in Santa Cruz, the broken public address system and the clogged drains at the Bay View Elementary School will not be fixed soon. With fewer counselors, an eighth grader at Branciforte Junior High who came looking for help this week after a beating by her father may find an empty office the next time it happens.
"Suppose I hadn't been available and she ran away?" said Curt Coleman, a counselor. "Suppose she stayed with her boyfriend and got pregnant or got a sexually transmitted disease? The cost to society is tremendous."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "How do we do with less, less, less?" asked Dan Cavanaugh, left, a school principal in Santa Cruz, Calif., where the school district is on the brink of bankruptcy. He helped a custodian, Mike Wehrman, set up chairs in the cafeteria, which doubles as an auditorium at Bay View Elementary School. (Terrence McCarthy for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Quick Steps Urged on Warming Threat

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 10

 BODY:
In a report that was welcomed by the White House and environmentalists, the National Academy of Sciences said today that the United States should act promptly to reduce the threat of global warming.
An academy panel recommended a variety of steps, including raising overall mileage standards for new automobiles to 32.5 miles per gallon from 27.5; increasing Federal support for mass transit and reforestation, and developing a new generation of safe and efficient nuclear power plants. The warming is feared as a result of the steady accumulation of waste industrial gases like carbon dioxide. 
 The steps necessary to address global warming have been a matter of fierce political contention between the Bush Administration and environmental groups. Even within the Administration, the Environmental Protection Agency has favored quicker action against global warming, which the President's chief of staff, John H. Sununu, has opposed.
The report from the academy, the leading independent source of scientific advice for the Government, seems intended as an adroit compromise between the various factions, and was praised on all sides.
 
Rudiments of National Policy
 Although its recommendations are somewhat general, they point the way to a broad-based national program for reducing carbon dioxide emissions. They lay down the rudiments of a national energy policy, which the Administration has long resisted.
William K. Reilly, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, called the report "a step forward," although he said that he did not necessarily agree with everything in it and that his agency had not yet studied it in detail.
The study was commissioned by Congress, and many of its recommendations would require Congressional action.
A senior Administration official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said he was pleased the report had not recommended "draconian changes." He also praised the report's cautious stand on the uncertainties of global warming, its cost-benefit analysis, its refusal to propose target dates and quotas for reductions of carbon dioxide emissions, and the importance it places on eliminating another trapper of heat, chlorofluorocarbons.
Dr. D. Allan Bromley, the White House science adviser, said, "I am delighted with the report, as are all my colleagues in the White House." He said actions already taken by the Bush Administration would result in emission reductions on the order of those proposed by the academy.
The academy report "should put an end to the debate over whether it pays to act to slow global warming," said Dr. Michael Oppenheimer, an atmospheric scientist at the Environmental Defense Fund. "It makes a prima facie case for acting now."
 
'A Nimble Policy'
 Even though the report does not set targets for reducing carbon dioxide, as environmental groups have long advocated, it was described as "a nimble policy" by a member of the panel, Dr. Jessica Tuchman Mathews, vice president of the World Resources Institute.
The panel said the prospect of global warming "poses a potential threat sufficient to merit prompt responses," even though it acknowledged that there was great uncertainty about its extent, timing and impact.
The panel said its proposed measures were all of "low cost," meaning they were cheap ways of reducing carbon dioxide and other waste gases. Low cost was defined as less than $10 per metric ton of heat-trapping gases eliminated per year. The panel did not calculate the total value of the initial investment.
The panel said the United States "should resume full participation" in international programs to slow population growth. Daniel J. Evans, the chairman of the panel, called population "the biggest single driver of atmospheric pollution." Mr. Evans, a Republican, is a former Governor and Senator from Washington.
The panel encouraged development and testing of a new generation of safe, efficient nuclear power plants to replace those that burn coal and oil. Its report did not go as far as many environmentalists have advocated in reducing carbon dioxide emissions, concluding that "options requiring great expenses are not justified" now.
Administration officials say steps already taken will allow overall emissions of "greenhouse" gases in the United States to stabilize in the next decade. But they argue that this is nevertheless consistent with the possible reduction of 10 to 40 percent that the academy said could be achieved if its measures were followed.
This is because the academy figure represents the reduction that would occur if all the measures were in effect now. By that measure, said Michael Deland, the chairman of the White House Council on Environmental Quality, the actions already taken by the Administration would amount to a 20 to 25 percent reduction.
The effects of any such measures do not suddenly materialize in one year, but rather come into play over a period of years, in which economic and population growth cause emissions to grow. This is not accounted for in the academy analysis, Mr. Deland said. Mr. Coppock, the director of the academy panel's staff, said that was true.
Environmentalists say the steps already taken by the Administration are not enough to achieve an absolute reduction in the greenhouse emissions in the United States, but would merely allow them to stabilize in the short term while resuming their growth in the long term.
They also assert that some of the important steps recommended by the academy have been specifically rejected by the Administration. Among them are the increase in gasoline mileage standards for new cars to 32.5 miles per gallon and stronger Federal support for mass transit.
Dr. Oppenheimer said the academy's recommendations "go a long way toward meeting the goal of keeping the climate from going haywire."
The panel did not propose target dates and quotas for carbon-dioxide reductions of the kind that some European countries have adopted and that some environmentalists have urged. Members said that was because rapidly changing knowledge about global warming and climate change was certain to render targets and quotas obsolete.

GRAPHIC: Chart: 'The Academy's Call to Action'
 Declaring that "despite the great uncertainties, greenhouse warming is a potential threat sufficient to justify action now," the National Academy of Sciences called for these measures:
--Adopt nationwide energy-efficient building codes.
--Improve the efficiency of the U.S. automotive fleet through the use of an appropriate combination of regulation and tax incentives.
--Strengthen Federal and state support of mass transit.
--Improve appliance efficiency standards.
--Encourage public education and information programs for conservation and recycling.
--Reform state public utility regulation to encourage electrical utilities to promote efficiency and conservation.
--Sharply increase the emphasis on efficiency and conservation in the Federal energy research and development budget.
--Utilize Federal and state purchases of goods and services to demonstrate best-practice technologies and energy conservation programs. (Source: "Policy Implications of Greenhouse Warming," National Academy of Sciences)
