HEADLINE: Health Care Plan Falters In Massachusetts Slump

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
The Massachusetts plan to guarantee health insurance for all, once hailed as a model for the nation, is faltering under the weight of a soured economy, a hostile new Governor and the fierce opposition of small-business owners, who would be required to pay for coverage of employees.
The pathbreaking plan was adopted in 1988, as Gov. Michael S. Dukakis promoted universal health care in his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, and was to be phased in over several years. Major parts of it resemble proposals being considered in other states and Congress as the nation confronts spiraling health costs and widening gaps in the insurance system.
 
Governor Threatens Repeal
 The plan's centerpiece -- a requirement that businesses employing six or more workers offer them health insurance or pay the state to do it -- was originally scheduled to take effect next January. But it now seems unlikely to materialize for years, if ever. The new Governor, William F. Weld, a conservative Republican, has asked the state legislature to repeal it, calling the requirement "an obstacle rather than a vehicle for improved health benefits for all." 
 Here as elsewhere, nearly all larger companies offer health insurance but many small and low-wage businesses do not, leaving many workers and their families unprotected from the often startling costs of medical care. Society's poorest people receive public insurance through Medicaid, and it is the working poor who account for most of the uninsured.
Requiring employers to offer health insurance has been a commonly proposed answer. But the stalling of the Massachusetts plan shows how hard it will be to achieve consensus on redesign of the nation's health care system.
 
Fear of Negative Message
 Promoters of the employer requirement insist it is a sound approach being aborted by ideology and ignorance.
"It's distressing to me to see the message that wholesale repeal would send to other states," said State Representative John E. McDonough, a Boston Democrat who is a main supporter of the plan. "It's being killed not because of the design of the program but for political reasons, and because of a recession."
Opponents say that in the absence of other measures to control soaring medical and insurance costs, the plan would place crushing burdens on fragile businesses and a broke state government, and put the state's economy at a competitive disadvantage.
"Just mandating something doesn't make it work," said Charles Baker, the new Under Secretary for Health. "I'd rather try to get at the root causes of the problem through hospital financ- ing and the insurance system. We can try to lower the cost of insurance, and get more people into it that way."
Even proponents of the mandated employer benefits want a delay to let the recession ease, and the Democrat-controlled state legislature voted last month to postpone the requirement until 1994.
But Governor Weld, who took over from Mr. Dukakis in January, vetoed the delay and demanded repeal. Though consumer groups and unions are fighting to save the employer requirement, legislators say the political mood has shifted and the Governor has a good chance of having his way.
Parts of the 1988 plan are alive and well. Programs providing low-cost health insurance to the disabled and to temporarily unemployed workers and health centers for the poor, for example, have helped tens of thousands of people and will be continued.
"We feel good about what we have accomplished so far," said James Hooley, until recently head of the Department of Medical Security, the agency implementing the new plan.
The debate on the plan has galvanized Democrats, Republicans, and consumer and business groups alike to begin rewriting the insurance rules. Their goal, as outlined in the 1988 law, is to assure more stable, affordable policies for small companies. Under current practices, small firms often pay far more for insurance per person than large ones, and they are experiencing huge jumps in premiums and ever-greater restrictions on coverage.
But the far-reaching and controversial change in the 1988 law was the requirement that companies with six or more workers either offer health insurance or pay a tax of up to $1,680 per employee. The state would use the proceeds for bare-bones policies that would be offered to all uninsured workers, who would pay premiums linked to their incomes. The tax would rise with inflation. While some state subsidies would be required, employers and workers would be the main financers.
Only Hawaii, a small, insular state with a different social tradition, has required employers to offer health insurance.
Massachusetts has fewer uninsured people than most states -- an estimated 8 percent of residents, nearly half a million, as opposed to 13 percent of people nationwide.
Mr. Hooley, the former state official, said his experience had only reinforced his belief in the need for requiring employer payments.
"Our goal from the beginning was to work with business to encourage them to offer insurance voluntarily," Mr. Hooley said. "But you need that mandate out there as a statement. Our system of health insurance will never be universal unless you have something like this."
In the new economic and political climate, larger companies' support for the law has faded, and the owners of small businesses who long opposed it have intensified their attacks.
Restaurant owners have been among the most outspoken foes. Even those that already offer insurance argue that the mandate would impose intolerable costs on a labor-intensive industry with many low-paid workers.
Bob Shaughnessy, owner of The Other Place in Boylston, in central Massachusetts, said he offers to pay part of the cost of health insurance for his 32 employees -- 25 percent after six months of employment and up to 75 percent for long-time workers. Only six, all but one of them managers, have taken the offer, and his current annual outlay for insurance is $ l6,248, he said. Under the state mandate, he would have to pay $53,780 -- an amount that could bankrupt him, he said, or force him to raise prices steeply.
"I'm not against universal insurance," Mr. Shaughnessy said, "but this is not a fair way to fund it, and it should be done at a Federal level."
Less typically, perhaps, Chris Anslono, owner of Lynn Carburetor and Auto Service in Lynn, north of Boston, said he favored the 1988 plan. A fee of $1,680 per person, he said, would be less than the price of most insurance policies now offered to small groups, and he would be willing to pay such a fee to obtain coverage.
For now, Mr. Anslono and his three employees are benefiting from subsidized insurance offered through a small state pilot project. Previously he had been unable to find an affordable policy for employees, Mr. Anslomo said, making it hard to keep them. "I had trouble getting help," he recalled. "They all wanted to go to the big dealers because I just couldn't offer the benefits."
 
'More Ideological Than Rational'
 The law's proponents say that companies already offering insurance would actually benefit from the mandate because they are now, in effect, subsidizing companies not offering it. The hospital costs of uninsured patients in the state are paid through a 10 percent surtax on bills of insured patients -- bills paid, in the end, by companies through their premiums.
"The business opposition is more ideological than rational," said Robert Restuccia, director of Health Care for All, a consumer advocacy group in Boston.
But many business leaders doubt they would ever see financial gains. In any case, some privately say, the opposition is driven by a visceral distrust of government control.
Former Governor Dukakis, who spoke Tuesday by telephone from Hawaii, where he is lecturing on health care, said he still believes employer requirements are essential. "It's the right thing and the fair thing and it's in the interest of business as a whole," he said.
A threat to any plan for broader insurance is the spiral in medical costs, especially hospital costs. Alan Sager, an expert at the Boston University School of Public Health, argued that the 1988 law was destined for failure because it failed to couple universal access with meaningful cost controls.
No state by itself can have effective cost controls, Mr. Dukakis asserted. "The states are going to continue to struggle with these issues until we get leadership from Washington," he said.
Even as they struggle to save the 1988 plan, consumer groups are offering more sweeping proposals for change that they say would provide universal access while holding down costs. Mr. Restuccia's group has proposed financing all care through taxes, with strong cost controls. But in the meantime, he said, "We see the employer mandate as an important step forward."

HEADLINE: For Foreign Films, Vita Is No Longer Dolce

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 10

 BODY:
For a decade the Unifrance Film office here was the French Government's outpost in Hollywood, a tireless promoter of French films and film makers. This month, however, the French shut the office in favor of a much more modest effort based in the French consulate, thereby significantly scaling back their presence in a city that regards itself as the world movie capital.
The change was made, said Catherine Verret, head of the French film office in the United States, because it no longer made economic sense to maintain a separate operation here, "given the number of our films actually bought in Los Angeles." But in a large sense, the decision also symbolizes the difficulties and limited prospects foreign-language films encounter in the American market these days. 
 Though Americans spent $5.1 billion at the box office last year, foreign-language films accounted for no more than 1.5 percent of that figure. When in January the trade journal Variety published a list of the 60 most successful foreign-language films to be released in the United States, only one of the top 10 was made during the last decade: "Cinema Paradiso."
 
Young Audiences Turn Away
 The days when a foreign-language film like "La Dolce Vita" or "La Cage aux Folles" could earn $18 million at the box office and compete with home-grown offerings are long gone, many film distributors and exhibitors reluctantly conclude. And also gone is the notion that hip, educated young audiences can be relied on to provide traditional support for foreign-language films.
"For the most part, the young audience has been drifting away," said Steve Rothenberg, vice president of theatrical distribution at the Samuel Goldwyn Company, whose most recent foreign-language release is "La Femme Nikita." "There's a whole generation of college students that hasn't been weaned on top-notch foreign-language films the way people in the 60's and 70's were, and that affects the grossing potential of these films. It means you're not getting an audience that is between 18 and 50, but only one that is over 30."
The success of "La Femme Nikita," which has quickly become a favorite among young moviegoers since its release a month ago, is the exception that may prove the rule, film distributors and exhibitors said. Through special mailings and screenings for "young sophisticates" who frequent nightclubs, art galleries and fashion shows, Goldwyn has worked assiduously to build a word-of-mouth campaign around the film, an unsettling mixture of American violence and gloss, in the mode of "Total Recall" or "Die Hard," and French sentimentality and style.
 
Escapism in French
 "It's a pure escapist entertainment that happens to have been made in French," said Gary Meyer, executive vice president of Landmark Theaters, the country's largest theater chain specializing in foreign-language films. Most of the time, he added, "the under-30 crowd, which was our principal audience when we started this business 16 years ago, is much harder to pull in on a regular basis now," and as a result, "we have changed our programming and booking philosophy."
In some respects, never have so many foreign-language movies been so readily accessible to American audiences. On cable channels like Bravo, Cinemax and Arts & Entertainment, foreign movies have become a staple of programming, and even mom-and-pop video stores are now likely to carry prestige titles like "Manon of the Spring" or "My Life as a Dog."
But in first-run movie theaters, where film reputations are made or broken, it is a more complicated story. Since the mid-1980's, the centralization of theater ownership in the hands of a few giant national chains, often affiliated with Hollywood studios, has resulted in fewer and fewer films playing in more and more theaters at the same time, a situation that does not favor foreign-language films.
Hollywood studios, several of which operated "classics" divisions a decade ago in order to distribute and promote foreign-language films, have closed those divisions and largely abandoned the arena to much smaller independent distributors. Those companies may be enthusiastic about foreign-language films, but cannot afford to spend the average of $11.6 million per film that Hollywood studios spent on advertising and print costs last year.
"Most of them just don't have the money," said Gabriel Desdois, who has been buying and selling rights to French films in the United States since 1957.
Some of the multiplex theaters, especially those in urban areas, have been willing to reserve a screen for what are euphemistically called "specialty films." But distributors complain that the large chains have neither the patience nor the willingness to nurture a foreign-language film seen as a difficult sell, and in many cases quickly pull such movies in favor of a similar release or when quality English-language fare becomes available.
 
Hollywood's Own Versions
 Increasingly, Hollywood studios are also competing with foreign-language films by doing their own versions of hit European films. They may retain the original director and writer for the remake, but in order to appeal to a mass audience that would normally shun any movie with subtitles, they substitute American actors, locations and situations for the French, Spanish or Italian originals.
"A lot of studios have their people in Europe looking at these movies, in some cases securing the remake rights even before the movie itself has been sold," said Russell Schwartz of Miramax Films, a New York-based independent distributor whose recent releases include China's "Ju Dou," Germany's "Nasty Girl" and Spain's "Ay, Carmela!" "Disney in particular has really mined that."
Indeed, Walt Disney Studios' "Three Men and a Baby," based on the French film "Three Men and a Cradle," and its sequel, "Three Men and a Little Lady," have together earned more than $235 million at the box office. Disney has also scored hits with "Down and Out in Beverly Hills" and "Three Fugitives," and other studios have had success with "The Woman in Red" and "The Man With One Red Shoe," all based on French films.
 
More Remakes Planned
 Most recently, Warner Brothers has acquired remake rights to "La Femme Nikita," which many film industry executives think has the potential to be a big hit if the right actress can be found to play the glamorous assassin around whom the story revolves. No casting or shooting schedule has yet been announced, but Julia Roberts, Demi Moore and Debra Winger are rumored to be interested in the role.
In addition, Jane Fonda has acquired the rights to the Spanish director Pedro Almodovar's farce "Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown," which earned about $7.5 million in its original version. Also, Disney plans to redo the French-made "Mama, There's a Man in Your Bed," about the romance between a white executive and a black cleaning woman.
"I certainly would not say ours is a growth segment of the industry, and now we have the studios in our backyard," Mr. Schwartz said. "But I'm also not a doomsayer. It's a tricky thing, you have to be careful, you have to work harder, but foreign-language films can work and they are not going to disappear."

HEADLINE: Early Action Rescuing Troubled Families

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

DATELINE: NEW LONDON, Conn.

 BODY:
THE turning point in Connie Neer's life, after a history of beatings, bouts of drinking and hitting bottom, came when she decided to fight to keep custody of her 2-year-old daughter, Nicole.
The state had already taken two older girls from Ms. Neer, 25, an admitted drug and alcohol abuser, before Nicole was born. A minor car accident last fall revealed she had violated her promise to the courts to remain sober. 
 But an agent of the state who showed up on her doorstep did not come to carry away Ms. Neer's youngest daughter. Instead, as part of a local program based on successes that are transforming the nature of social work across the nation, Ms. Neer agreed to meet with a family therapist in her home several days a week for a month.
The therapist was to be an advocate for the mother, not her keeper, giving pointers on how to manage her life successfully and to move her gently away from behavior that had caused her to drink and to neglect her children. For the first time in her life, Ms. Neer was taking lessons from an expert on how to be a responsible grown-up and parent.
Mother and child are reaping the benefits of a national movement in social work to cut through red tape by intervening directly inside troubled homes before children suffer serious neglect or abuse. The technique comes under the rubric of family preservation: the re-orienting of the child-welfare system to assist families in crisis before it is necessary to remove children from their homes.
"People are realizing that intensive intervention in the home at the first sign of a problem can dramatically improve family functioning," said Kristine E. Nelson, director of research at the University of Iowa's Family Resource Center on Family Based Services.
Advocates of this approach, now used in some 30 states, say it not only keeps families together but also reduces the burden on state budgets by producing huge savings for welfare agencies and the courts.
"The pace is accelerating because states have learned that intervention produces dramatic results," explained Peter W. Forsythe, vice president of the Edna McConnell Clark Foundation of New York. "One of the most exciting things just becoming clear is its impact in urban centers of chronic neglect."
Others in the field say inner-city turmoil defies the best of intentions.
"The problems are so overwhelming in cities like New York and Chicago, especially as funding for social programs drop, that I sometimes walk away shaking my head," said Marcia Allen, director of Iowa's National Resource Center.
There are about a half-dozen intervention programs in the New York metropolitan area, and many more are planned if the current state budget is approved. New Jersey was a pioneer in financing the programs, but support has flagged because of budget problems.
The movement is a response to the view that child welfare agencies are losing the fight to address the best interests of abused children.
"With the breakdown of family life and divorce, substance abuse and unemployed parents dumping on their kids, we are seeing more abused children at a younger age and far sicker than abused kids 10 years ago," said Judy Allen, a program supervisor at the Connecticut Department of Children and Youth Services.
State agencies beleaguered by backlogged caseloads often took action only after a child was severely mistreated and had to be protected.
But removing children from homes did not guarantee a bright future. The quality of life in foster homes or state schools could be more emotionally damaging to children than the homes from which they were rescued, according to experts.
In intervention cases, parents agree to undergo counseling as a way to work out abuse problems before the state moves more aggressively against them. For the parents, it is a way to hold the authorities at bay and to keep a child they care for and want.
Although there are variations in the methods that are used, the underlying premise is that a caseworker can quickly identify problems and rectify them after observing a family at home for several hours a day, several times a week.
In some homes, the problem is communication. In others, it may be the division of household chores or the unsettling effects of the behavior of one member of the household.
The program in Connecticut, in a typical pattern, is run by private agencies paid by the state. Free of rigid office schedules and paperwork, caseworkers make themselves available any time family members need them.
If a parent's work schedule prevents daytime counseling, the caseworker will be there in the evenings or on weekends. If there is a crisis, he or she will respond in the middle of the night.
"It's very hard for public agencies to bend to these hours," said Susan Morton, program coordinator of the Child and Family Agency of Southeastern Connecticut, a private non-profit agency that handles the state referrals in a two-county area.
Intervention is also proving to be cost effective. Thomas P. Gullotta, chief executive officer of Ms. Morton's agency, said the cost of placing an abused child in foster care or a shelter and providing care by psychologists and specialists could be as high as $80,000 a year, as compared with only about $4,000 for intervention programs that prevent a family breakup.
Connecticut officials say the state program has been credited with preserving the homes of some two dozen children, including Ms. Neer's, in the first six months of operation.
Seated on a sofa in her apartment on a bluff above the Thames River, Ms. Neer spoke of the dark days in her life.
"I was sexually abused constantly in my childhood," she said. She had her first drink at 11 and was an alcoholic by 16, a year before giving birth to her first child.
By 20, she said, she was smoking crack and living with a man "who would punch me and kick me when I was pregnant."
Ms. Neer said she did not strike her children when she was drunk, but ignored them. Her behavior attracted attention, and eventually the custody of her two older daughters -- now 6 and 8 -- was given to her mother in another city, Ms. Neer said.
She was ordered to attend alcohol and drug abuse programs and said she was getting her life back on track until the accident last autumn alerted the authorities that she was drinking again. To keep Nicole, she reluctantly agreed to participate in the intervention program.
"My attitude at the time was it was going to be a hassle to let some social worker practically move into my home, but I figured I'd do it to keep everyone off my back," she recalled.
Into her life walked Mary Cay Whewel, a therapist from Mr. Gullotta's agency whose first goal was to win Ms. Neer's confidence.
At first, there were long discussions around the kitchen table on household budgets and ways Ms. Neer could continue working while attending night school.
"It was awkward at first," Ms. Neer said. "But after the first week I discovered it was nice having someone smart to talk to and learn from but who wasn't bossing me around."
Soilo Arroyo, Ms. Neer's 22-year-old fiance, said he also benefited from the caseworker's advice.
"Pretty soon she helped us bring out things we were hiding in ourselves about Connie's past mistakes that limited our relationship," he said.
After four weeks, Ms. Whewel moved on to other clients. Ms. Neer, fortified by a new confidence, says she has not had a drink since the accident and hopes one day to get her older daughters back.
In Higganum, 30 miles north of New London, Franklin and Barbara Bruce await the day that their son Arthur, 13, will be permitted to return home.
He was placed in a state school last fall after neighbors reported seeing his father strike him with a cane, and intervention was arranged to protect the family's three other children.
Lorraine Plante, who was given permission by the Bruces to discuss their case, said that they were typical of intervention families "who have trouble making things work in their lives and who handle every conflict by yelling or striking out."
"But in its own way this family is bonded," she said. "They love each other."
She has met with them on weekends, when Arthur visits, to work on communication skills. The Bruces say they are hopeful Arthur will be home this summer -- for good.

HEADLINE: TOPICS OF THE TIMES;
Mr. Cuomo's Board Walk

 BODY:
In 1976, a newcomer to New York State government named Mario Cuomo served on a panel that urged major pruning of the do-little boards and commissions that provide patronage for the Governor and the Legislature.
Now, in his ninth year as Governor, Mr. Cuomo has rediscovered his reformer's passion. Seeking to close a huge deficit, he proposes with new conviction to eliminate dozens of boards and commissions and their superfluous or overpaid positions. Even so, his hit list is far too short. 
 It overlooks, for example, one padded agency cited in the 1976 report: the Unemployment Insurance Appeals Board, whose five supposedly full-time members could well be replaced by one full-time chairman with other members serving part time.
The top-heavy Workers Compensation Board and the Racing and Wagering Board, both missing from the list, also seem choice targets. So does the Labor Relations Board, whose members earn a generous $65,702 a year for part-time work. The Governor plans to merge this board with the three-member Mediation Board, but he would eliminate only one of the six full-time board members.
With the budget in dire straits, is this really enough?

HEADLINE: Bring Germany Into New World Order

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Bonn correspondent refers to "suggestions being made in Bonn that the Government renege on its pledge of $11 billion to help defray the costs of the gulf war" (news article, March 22), presumably because the United States is seen as seeking far more than the actual cost.
The German attitude to the Soviet Union is somewhat different. Large sums were paid for Soviet concessions on matters of German national interest -- ultimately serving United States interests as well. This included 5 billion marks in aid, an incentive for Soviet acceptance of a unified Germany in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, and 12 billion marks as a grant for troop withdrawals and housing for them in the Soviet Union. There was a 3 billion mark interest-free credit and also nearly one billion marks raised privately by Germans as charity for the Soviets. 
 Bonn is not making an issue of 1.2 billion marks the Soviets owe German companies. Yet now Moscow is dragging out the troop withdrawals and demanding further payments. It is not clear what German opposition there is to this apparent extortion.
But generosity is not the issue, and the Germans are free to decide who their friends are. More important, the unseemly haggling over the German (and Japanese) contribution to the Persian Gulf action suggests a missing link in the new world order. Germany and Japan should be brought into the United Nations Security Council as permanent members. Their absence is due solely to their defeat in World War II. Their development and economic weight entitle them to rank with the major powers responsible for world order.
Contrary to Lenin, a defeated adversary is not to remain defeated forever, and a new world order would surely benefit for admitting these nations to responsibility. Their inclusion may provide an impulse for amending their constitutions to accord with their status in the international community.
 
KARL REYMAN
Glen Head, L.I., March 24, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Joule Division Names Chief Operating Officer

 BODY:
Mary Ann Pope has been named chief operating officer of the temporaries division of Joule Inc., a regional temporary services company in Edison, N.J.
Mrs. Pope, who is 51, joined Joule this week after a 20-year career with Olsten Services, a national temporary services concern based in Westbury, L.I. At Olsten, Mrs. Pope rose from payroll clerk to office manager to head of the company's operations in Pennsylvania and New Jersey. 
 She moved to Tampa, Fla., in 1986 to oversee the company's Florida operations, but left last fall and moved to Cherry Hill, N.J., to be closer to her four sons and two daughters, aged 20 to 28, who are scattered across New Jersey and New York.
Mrs. Pope said that because she was raising six children she never expected to work outside her home. But in 1970, her husband, Antonio, a businessman, became ill and Mrs. Pope went to work to support her family.
At the same time, Mrs. Pope, who graduated from Blessed Sacrament High School in Newark in 1958, enrolled in classes at Montclair State College in Montclair, N.J.
"You just do what you have to do," she said. "I had tremendous support within the family. And I liked what I was doing."
Mrs. Pope began working as a consultant for Joule in February and said she looked forward to playing a senior management role at the company, which had sales of $36 million last year. She said the recession and the layoffs that have accompanied it should increase demand for the concern's temporary employees.
"Companies still have to provide their services," Mrs. Pope said. "And they use temporaries because they don't have to make commitments to them. It's extremely cost-efficient. You can shut it off, just like the water."

HEADLINE: WASHINGTON TALK;
An Oddity In a City That Seeks Publicity

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 10

 BODY:
In this city of publicity hogs and monstrous egos, Nicholas F. Brady is an oddity. The Treasury Secretary is so diffident, so uncomfortable in the limelight, so averse to making news that his influence in the Government is difficult to assess.
He has had some real accomplishments. Early on, he engineered passage of legislation to deal with the savings and loan mess. His plan to cut the debt of third-world countries has generally worked. He got Robert L. Clarke reappointed as comptroller of the currency over the objection of John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff. He negotiated generous contributions from Japan and Germany to the Persian Gulf war effort. And early this year he presented Congress with a comprehensive plan to revamp the nation's anachronistic banking laws. 
 But he has been so careful to wipe away his fingerprints that he has received little credit, and he has been widely portrayed in the press as a lightweight. The Wall Street Journal, for instance, wondered in a front-page profile in January whether Mr. Brady was "up to the task," and said that under his leadership the Treasury had often "seemed asleep at the switch."
Fred Barnes of The New Republic may have put his finger on the Treasury Secretary's bad press in an article in The International Economy magazine. "Brady," Mr. Barnes wrote, "is simply not a Washington person."
Certainly not like James A. Baker 3d. When Mr. Baker was Treasury Secretary in Ronald Reagan's second term, reporters followed him almost everywhere, much as they do now that he is Secretary of State. Mr. Baker operates masterfully. His quotes enliven broadcasts and fit neatly into the third paragraph of news articles. His staff is adroit at the kind of leaks that make the boss look good.
That may explain why Mr. Baker received most of the credit for the enactment of tax reform in 1986 and for the rapprochement between President Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev. It may also explain why Mr. Baker has largely escaped blame for the savings and loan disaster, which happened on his watch at the Treasury, and for his State Department's miscalculation of Saddam Hussein's threat to Kuwait.
By contrast, Mr. Brady has little use for the press. When he left Tuesday for a 10-day trip to Europe and the Middle East, a trip billed as an examination of what is needed to get the world's economy back on a growth path, nary a reporter was on his plane. He has never made news on a foreign trip before, and no one expects him to do so this time.
Until he came to Washington, Mr. Brady had spent his adult life on Wall Street as an investment banker with Dillon, Read & Company. He made his living cutting back-room deals that would have fallen apart if word had seeped out, his staff says, so he is naturally mistrustful of reporters.
He gives a terrible interview. Normally relaxed and charming, Mr. Brady tenses up when the tape recorder goes on. At the beginning of an interview last month, a reporter tried a new tack and threw him the softest of lobs. Was there anything, the reporter asked, the Secretary would like to talk about? No, Mr. Brady responded, looking at his watch. Let's get the questions over with.
On Tuesday, just hours before he left for Europe, his staff persuaded him to call reporters from The New York Times and The Washington Post to his office to promote his trip.
He was like a circus barker with laryngitis. He said absolutely nothing controversial, or even insightful. Then he asked that the entire session be "off the record" or "on background," meaning he could not be quoted. But neither reporter had anything to write, and Mr. Brady left town without fanfare.
At a news conference in Houston last weekend, Mr. Bush joked that he was happy for the third-world debt strategy to be called the Brady Plan while its success was still in doubt, but that now it should be called the Bush Plan.
That's fine with Mr. Brady. He insists that he is fundamentally a staff man, that his only goal is to serve his friend, George Bush, and that he will be recorded favorably in the history books as long as Mr. Bush is a successful President.
And his ambitions beyond that? "I'm not running for anything but the city limits," he says.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Drop by 70,000

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11 (Reuters)

 BODY:
The number of new unemployment insurance claims dropped by 70,000 in late March after soaring to the highest level in more than eight years, the Labor Department said today. But analysts cautioned that the drop might not be a sign the nation's jobless situation was stabilizing.
New applications for unemployment benefits fell to a seasonally adjusted 473,000 in the week ended March 30, compared with 543,000 the week before. 
 People actually receiving benefits under regular state in the week ended march 23, the latest period for which the figure was available. That was a decrease of 97,000 from the previous week's seasonally adjusted revised level.
The last week in March included Good Friday, which could have reduced the number of people filing claims and could be a reason for the decline, analysts said.

HEADLINE: Curb Deadly High-Tech Trade

 BODY:
The Bush Administration routinely approved sales of U.S. arms-related high technology to Iraq right up to the time that the Iraqi Army marched into Kuwait. Now that its own Under Secretary of Commerce has expressed second thoughts about that shortsighted practice, how does the White House respond? It tries to fire him, only to learn he's already resigned.
What's really needed from the White House is a frank acknowledgment of past mistakes and a tougher policy to control sales of advanced technology that can be put to military use. That policy won't be easy to devise, given the economic incentives to promote exports. But it won't work at all unless President Bush takes the lead. 
 The Commerce Department official who irked the White House, Dennis E. Kloske, told a Congressional hearing Monday that he tried to "tie up all sales in red tape" last April after Saddam Hussein threatened to destroy Israel with chemically armed missiles if it attacked Iraqi weapons plants. He blamed the State Department for "choosing instead to advocate the maintenance of diplomatic relations with Iraq" by continuing sales.
But Mr. Kloske's own office is just as blameworthy for vigorously promoting high-tech exports to Iraq. Between 1985 and 1990 it approved 771 licenses to export $1.5 billion worth of computers, chemicals and communications gear that Iraq could put to military as well as civilian use. In 1989 Iraq bought command-and-control equipment that U.S. planes targeted two years later.
That's why licensing decisions can't be left up to the Commerce Department without strengthening the hand of other agencies in setting policy.
Export of technology with both civilian and military applications poses an exceptionally tough problem for arms control. For instance, krytrons, which can be put to innocent use in ordinary office copiers, are also well designed for triggering nuclear weapons.
To ascertain what use an importing country intends to make of krytrons takes knowledge of what other weapons components it has been buying and from whom. Intelligence-sharing among supplier states is thus essential to controlling sales.
The global diffusion of technology makes it impossible for the U.S. to bar sales on its own. A unilateral embargo is more likely to harm U.S. industry than to slow the spread of weapons. Foreign manufacturers, a recent National Academy of Sciences study found, often buy technology elsewhere to avoid U.S. controls on re-exporting.
Technology is advancing so rapidly, and spreading so widely, that it would be impossible to embargo every potentially dangerous item. Unless arms controllers concentrate on building higher fences around fewer technologies, they'll be overwhelmed.
Mr. Kloske's self-serving testimony suggests that there's plenty of bureaucratic blame to share for transferring arms-related technology to Saddam Hussein. But preventing another dangerous dictator from getting his hands on deadly technologies requires a new policy that gives priority to leaving new orders unfilled.

HEADLINE: Central Europe's Central Need

BYLINE: By William H. Luers; William H. Luers, president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, was Ambassador to Czechoslovakia.

 BODY:
To head off further deterioration in Central Europe, beset by fragmenting ethnic nationalism and collapsing economies, the industrial democracies must help provide the region with a new political structure. The West and Japan should not become so mesmerized by Soviet disorder that they fail to contribute to the democratic development of Central Europe and the Balkans.
Tensions are so rife that Eastern European political leaders and intellectuals will meet in Prague this weekend to ponder a response to them. They will be mindful of the murder of Detlev Karsten Rohwedder, who ran Germany's office responsible for liquidating some 8,000 companies in eastern Germany. 
 The Soviet Union's lurch backward toward a more conservative, controlled system threatens Central Europe. And while the Warsaw Pact is dead, the troublemaking potential of the Soviet police and Communist network in the region isn't.
What can the West do? Economic assistance, partly motivated by a desire to retard large-scale migration to Western Europe, is growing. Private investment is barely beginning. The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development is being installed. But Westerners are showing impatience with the slow pace of change while Eastern European leaders cry out for closer, more structured ties to the West.
Membership in the European Community and NATO is out of reach for any of the nations in the next decade. Membership in the International Monetary Fund, World Bank and Council of Europe is not sufficient to give them a true sense of belonging, nor enough to provide the security and incentives needed to save themselves from a spiral into chaos.
The Europeanwide structure, the 34-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, suggested as the vehicle for incorporating these new states into Europe won't work.
Western Europe want to keep the 12-member European Community exclusive. NATO cannot help: Its military strength makes it attractive to the new, insecure Central Europe but frightens the weakened Soviet Union. Germany could help but, going through troubling changes, is preoccupied with its own agenda.
The U.S., with Germany, should encourage Western Europe to build a new political and economic organization to nurture the emergence of the new democracies. It would be underwritten by NATO and the European Community but offer looser criteria for admission, and covenants that reduced any implied threat to Moscow.
This organization, with industrial democracies as full members, would be open to all Central European countries that reached certain thresholds in democratic institutions and market economies. It would stress regional cooperation and concentrate on economic and political development. It would seek to enlarge significantly public and private funds directed to the region. It would be designed to discourage local conflicts and head off Balkanization. And it would include a collective-security component in which the Central European members would provide the defensive military force. NATO's role would remain ambiguous but implied.
The key obstacles to such an enterprise would be Western European indifference and resistance to yet another European organization, Central European enmities and Soviet fears.
U.S. and German leadership could overcome Western indifference and resistance and diminish Central Europeans' fear of German dominance. Central European enmities could be subdued if the political and economic benefits to regional cooperation were substantial enough.
Overcoming Soviet fear that this new grouping would extend NATO to the Soviet borders would be the most formidable obstacle. The Soviets should appreciate that stability in Central Europe is in their interest.
The new organization need not involve a huge bureaucracy. But it must be committed to building democracy and economic stability in this cauldron of some of modern history's most violent wars.

HEADLINE: Rights and Economy Aren't Separate Issues

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is unfortunate that in "Rights Movement in Struggle for an Image as Well as a Bill," your April 3 front-page article about renewed efforts for the civil-rights legislation that was vetoed last fall by President Bush, you treat the civil-rights movement as if it were a monolithic entity struggling to define itself.
Today's civil-rights movement is, as it has always been, a multifaceted coalition of organizations, each of which concentrates on different aspects of the effort to achieve parity for African-Americans. 
 Thus, the National Urban League strongly supports the civil-rights bill so urgently needed to repeal Supreme Court decisions that make it easier for employers to discriminate. But the bulk of our advocacy and our service programs focuses on two areas critical to minority Americans and the poor: education and career development, and employment and training.
Those who accuse civil-rights groups of ignoring the crucial economic problems of African-Americans or who condemn them for not transcending black concerns, conveniently choose to ignore the National Urban League's Urban Marshall Plan proposal.
The Urban Marshall Plan calls for investments in this country's human and physical infrastructure to benefit all of the disadvantaged and lay the groundwork for United States economic resurgence.
We object to articles that misinform the public into believing that civil rights and social problems represent an either/or choice for the civil-rights movement. Both need to be pursued, and both are being vigorously pursued.
 
JOHN E. JACOB
President & Chief Executive Officer
National Urban League
New York, April 4, 1991

HEADLINE: Bush Aide Sees Recovery Soon

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
The chief White House economic adviser, Michael Boskin, said today that the economic recovery had not yet started but that certain precursors had been seen that precede a recovery by two to five months.
Interviewed on NBC television's "Today" program, Mr. Boskin said the recovery should begin in the next few months. 
 "First, we will see the economy stabilize, stop contracting," he said. "We'll see some mixed signals for a few months. Then in the second half of the year we will probably see the economy growing in the 2 to 3 percent range at an annual rate."
Mr. Boskin said precursors of a recovery were present, including lower interest rates, a growth in the money supply, lean inventories and rebounding consumer confidence.
"All of these are good signs and generally precede a turnaround by a period of from two to four to five months, usually," he said. "I must emphasize that the recovery has not started yet. These are preconditions."
Mr. Boskin said the Federal Reserve Board had begun to ease monetary policy more aggressively, but said there was room for interest rates to fall.
"We do believe there is ample room, as conditions warrant, for rates to fall further," he said, adding that this should be true unless inflation, which seems quiet now, is worse or if the recovery is faster than expected.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Subaru Puts $60 Million Account in Review

BYLINE: By KIM FOLTZ

 BODY:
EDWARD VICK, who became the president and chief executive of Levine, Huntley, Vick & Beaver just two months ago, is facing his first big test: Subaru of America, the agency's biggest client, said yesterday that it had put its $60 million account into review.
Fred Heiler, a Subaru spokesman, said the company was not specifically dissatisfied with Levine, Huntley's work but wanted to talk to other agencies to make sure it was getting the best work available. 
 Executives at Subaru and Levine, Huntley said the Japanese car maker had been considering switching agencies since late last year. It began to think about new marketing strategies after it was acquired by Fuji Heavy Industries in 1990.
Last year, Subaru's sales were somewhat disappointing, but in the first quarter of this year the company gained sales and market share despite the economic slowdown. For January through March, its share of the United States market rose to nine-tenths of 1 percent from seven-tenths of 1 percent, and for March it soared to 1.4 percent. The improvement is due mainly to the Legacy sedan, Subaru's new compact, which ranges in price from $12,600 to almost $20,000. Legacy sales rose to more than 11,000 in the first quarter, from fewer than 4,000 in the period a year ago.
Mr. Vick was brought in to replace Robert Schmidt, the former chairman of Levine, Huntley who abruptly left in January. Mr. Schmidt had close ties to Subaru, which has been the agency's client for 16 years.
Mr. Vick was considered an ideal replacement by many in the industry because he had worked with BMW while he was an executive at Ammirati & Puris during the 1980's. "Subaru needs to be repositioned so it will be on more people's shopping lists," Mr. Vick said. "I see us as a new agency that has a new point of view on the car."
Subaru, which had been marketed as a reliable car, now wants to position itself so it will be attractive to more affluent car buyers, executives at Subaru and the agency said.
Previous commercials for Subaru have taken a humorous approach, demonstrating the car's solid, no-nonsense construction. One spot showed a young man racing over a rainy road littered with obstructions like fallen trees, to reach a young woman's house before her parents return home.
Mr. Heiler would not say what agencies Subaru was considering. The initial list is likely to be long, because an account this size will set off a free-for-all among scores of agencies hungry for business. Because of its high visibilty, a national car account is prized by small and midsize agencies trying to make names for themselves.
Some agency executives speculated that the most likely candidates for the short list of finalists would be Bloom FCA; Rosenfeld, Sirowitz, Humphrey & Strauss; TBWA Advertising, and Altschiller Reitzfeld Tracy-Locke.
Subaru has hired Ernst-Van Praag, a New York consulting firm, to help it find an agency.
Levine, Huntley will also be included in the review, but the agency's chances of winning are probably slim. An incumbent rarely wins in reviews because the client is already dissatisfied enough to start looking elsewhere.
What is more, Levine, Huntley has already been given a second chance. Subaru agreed to delay the review, giving Mr. Vick and the agency an opportunity to come up with fresh ideas.
The agency presented those ideas earlier this week. And, although neither the agency nor client would discuss the outcome of that meeting, it seems clear that Subaru was not impressed.
Still, Mr. Vick said his agency had a good shot at keeping Subaru. He recently hired Tom Benghauser, an advertising executive who has worked on a number of auto accounts, to take charge of the Subaru business. In addition, Mr. Vick said he had restructured the top management at the agency. Now, the executives who work the most closely with clients report directly to him.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines Worldwide On Sales and Price Reports

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar headed steadily lower on world markets yesterday as investors continued to view the climate as favorable for lower United States interest rates.
Gold prices also declined. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $362.90 an ounce, off $1.50. The Republic National Bank said gold had declined $1.20 an ounce, to $361.90. 
 The selloff in the dollar was touched off by drops in the retail sales figures and the Producer Price Index. Traders said the data might encourage the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates. Such an action is historically bearish for the United States currency because lower interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less valuable to investors.
 
Short-Term Speculation
 The Labor Department said the Producer Price Index, which measures the prices of finished goods before they reach the consumer, fell three-tenths of a percent in March, the fourth consecutive monthly decline. The figure was in line with expectations.
But the Commerce Department separately reported a greater-than-expected decline in retail sales, which dropped eigth-tenths of a percent last month,
The reports spurred "short-term speculation of the possibility of lower interest rates," said Michael Malpede, a senior analyst at the Refco Group in Chicago.
The dollar declined in Europe, and the selling continued when trading shifted to domestic markets. "The dollar gradually wound lower, finishing the session at the bottom of its trading range," said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the consulting firm IDEA.
Despite the decline in producer prices, the underlying inflation rate, which excludes energy and food costs, rose two-tenths of a percent, half of the February gain. While economists view the advance in the underlying rate as moderate, Mr. Chandler said it tended to lag and might encourage the Fed to keep rates at current levels.
Dealers said much activity centered on trading in the Japanese yen and the German mark, which continued to be under pressure from the economic toll of unification.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 136.65 yen, from 137.20 yen on Wednesday. Later in London it fell to 135.90 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 136.20 yen, down from 137.43 on Wednesday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7905, from $1.7800 late Wednesday. In New York, it cost $1.7904 to buy a pound, more expensive than Wednesday's $1.7760.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.6705 German marks, down from 1.6800; 1.4118 Swiss francs, down from 1.4295; 5.6485 French francs, down from 5.6815; 1,239.75 Italian lire, down from 1,246.00, and 1.1506 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1513.

HEADLINE: J. P. Morgan Has a Surge In Earnings

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
J. P. Morgan & Company said yesterday that profits after one-time items were excluded rose 61.5 percent in the first quarter, mostly because of strong gains in foreign exchange and bond trading.
The company had net income of $273 million in the quarter. Last year it had net income of $399 million in the quarter, but that figure included a $230 million gain from an accounting change. 
 Morgan, the country's fourth-largest banking company, avoided the losses on bad loans that have badly hurt other banking companies recently. Loans to commercial real estate projects and highly indebted companies -- two areas in which other banks grew rapidly in the 1980's and are now suffering heavy losses -- were much less prominent at Morgan. Its losses on all kinds of lending have been minimal.
 
Better Than Expected
 Morgan earned $1.40 a share, up from 86 cents, excluding the effect of the accounting change that had added $1.23 a share in the first quarter of 1990. First-quarter profits were about 40 percent higher than analysts had expected, and Morgan's stock rose sharply, to its highest level of the year. The stock closed yesterday at $50.625, up $3.25.
The $461 million in gross earnings from all kinds of trading at Morgan was the largest ever for any bank in a single quarter. Gross earnings from foreign exchange trading were $109 million, up 49.3 percent from a year earlier. Other trading profits, particularly from bond trading and interest-rate and other swaps, rose 151.4 percent, to $352 million.
Morgan set aside only $10 million to its reserve for bad loans, while its holdings of delinquent or other troubled loans excluding loans to third world countries, fell to $269 million from $295 million at the end of the year. Both the amount added to the reserve and the level of troubled loans are small fractions of the levels at other banking companies, which have fewer loans.
 
Problems at Other Banks
 For example, Fleet/Norstar Financial Group in Providence, R.I., said yesterday that its troubled loans and holdings of real estate acquired in foreclosure increased by about $65 million, to $1.45 billion, in the first quarter. Among its five New England banking units, Fleet Norstar said, the greatest increase in troubled loans occurred at its banks in New York, rather than in New England, where problems were most severe in 1990.
Over all, Fleet said it expected to earn $25 million to $26 million in the first quarter, compared with a loss of $98 million a year earlier. The company will announce complete results next week.
The Bank of New York Company earlier this week announced a $254 million increase in delinquent and other troubled loans, to $1.85 billion. Because of the rise in bad loans, and the need to add $343 million to its reserve for bad loans, Bank of New York lost $63 million in the first quarter.
Raphael Soifer, a banking analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman, noted that while other large banks were still coping with increases in their bad loans, Morgan was well positioned to gain some business.
Although Morgan has pushed development of its trading and financial advisory services and reduced emphasis on corporate lending over the last decade, it noted in its 1990 annual report that "good lending opportunities have resurfaced."
One sign of those opportunities, analysts said, was the increase in its holdings of loans to highly indebted companies to $2.2 billion, from $1.9 billion at the end of the year. Many other banking companies have been trying to reduce their holdings of such loans.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Strong Profits Are Reported At Intel and Advanced Micro

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 11

 BODY:
The Intel Corporation and Advanced Micro Devices Inc. reported unexpectedly strong first-quarter results today. They attributed the results to strong demand for microprocessors, the computers-on-a-chip that are the brains of personal computers, as well as some larger machines.
"We are delighted with this performance, given the current turbulence in the economy and in our industry," said Andrew S. Grove, Intel's president and chief executive. All Intel products exceeded order and shipment goals, he said. 
 One sign of the turbulence in the industry was the International Business Machines Corporation's announcement a few weeks ago that first-quarter results would total about half the company's profit a year ago. The disclosure stunned Wall Street, delaying trading in I.B.M. shares for 90 minutes because of an order imbalance.
Indeed, analysts said yesterday that Intel's results seemingly belied the downturn affecting the economy and most of the personal computer business. One possible explanation is that the jump in sales represents Taiwan and Hong Kong clone makers who are only now beginning to get volume shipments of the 386 chip, which had gone to larger customers.
"The rate at which Intel is growing its microprocessor business does not seem consistent with what we are seeing in the overall PC market," said Rajiv Chaudri, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York. "My suspicion is you are seeing a product cycle ramp that will probably run out of steam in another three to four months. The other explanation is that we are all very wrong about the strength of the PC market."
During the quarter, Advanced Micro began volume shipments of its long-awaited AM386 chip. A clone of Intel's 386, the Advanced Micro product breaks Intel's monopoly on the chip at the heart of I.B.M.'s powerful personal computers and compatibles.
At the same time, Intel's 386 and 486 microprocessors are moving to more mainstream use, increasing sales. Next week, Intel is expected to introduce a lower-cost version of the 486, its top microprocessor, which is expected to further spur demand.
Many analysts increased their earnings estimates today for the companies. Intel's shares rose $4.50 each, to $52, in over-the-counter trading. Advance Micro's stock gained $1, to $12.625 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.
For the quarter, Intel reported earnings of $197.4 million, or 95 cents a share, up 37 percent from $143.7 million, or 73 cents a share, for the comparable period a year ago. Its revenues rose 27 percent, to $1.13 billion from $894.4 million.
Largely on the strength of its 386 clone and other new products, Advanced Micro returned to profitability in the quarter after a $45.6 million loss in its fourth quarter. The company's earnings totaled $4.2 million, or 2 cents a share, down sharply from $13.1 million, or 13 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago. Its sales grew slightly, to $274.3 million from $271.4 million.
"A.M.D.'s plan for returning to solid profitability in the current quarter is on target," said W. J. Sanders 3d, Advanced Micro's chairman and chief executive. "Cost-containment measures implemented in the past two quarters are contributing significantly to improved operating results."
At more than $10 million, shipments of the AM386 chip exceeded the company's expectations, and it is increasing production rapidly, Mr. Sanders said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Investigators Tell of Abuses In Sale of Nursing Home Insurance

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
Investigators from the General Accounting Office told Congress today that they had found numerous abuses in the sale of private insurance intended to cover the high costs of nursing home care for elderly people.
The testimony laid a foundation for Congressional efforts to set minimum standards for such insurance, perhaps as early as this year, even though insurance executives insisted there was no need for Federal regulation. 
 The Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services, Richard P. Kusserow, seemed to lend support to the call for minimum Federal standards. He reported that only 17 states had adopted all the standards recommended by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, an organization of state officials, for the regulation of long-term care insurance policies.
The market for nursing home insurance is booming, as people try to protect themselves from the ruinous costs of long-term care. Nursing homes charge residents an average of $68.50 a day, or $25,000 a year, and in big cities the annual cost often exceeds $40,000. The Reagan and Bush Administrations have encouraged the development of a market for private insurance to cover such costs, hoping that it would reduce the demand for an expensive new Federal program.
 
Pitfalls for Elderly
 Nearly two million people now have private insurance to help pay for long-term care. The number of people with such policies has more than doubled in the last three years and is sure to grow as the elderly population increases.
At a Congressional hearing, Janet L. Shikles, director of health financing and policy issues at the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, testified today that purchasers of long-term care insurance faced "unpredictable premium increases." In addition, she said, they had little or no protection against inflation in the cost of such care, had difficulty getting the benefits to which they were entitled and might lose their entire investment if they missed a premium payment after 20 years.
Aggressive sales agents have sold policies to consumers who do not need them, including low-income people who may be eligible for Medicaid, she said at the hearing of the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health. In California, she reported, agents sold an elderly man 16 different health insurance policies over four years, half of them with nursing home coverage.
Representative Ron Wyden of Oregon and Senator David Pryor of Arkansas, both Democrats, said they would soon introduce legislation to protect consumers by setting minimum Federal standards for long-term care insurance. Such insurance covers nursing home bills and may also help pay for health-care services provided to elderly people who live at home.
Last year, Congress set tough new Federal standards for private health insurance that fills the gaps in Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly and disabled. Mr. Wyden said that as the Federal Government tightened standards for such Medigap coverage of hospital and doctor bills, unscrupulous insurers were shifting their attention to the market for coverage of nursing home care.
Senator Pryor said the Inspector General's findings suggested that many purchasers of long-term care insurance remained "extremely vulnerable." Mr. Kusserow, the Inspector General, reported that "only nine states were able to provide data on administrative and enforcement actions" against companies and agents selling insurance for long-term care.
Representative Pete Stark, a California Democrat who is chairman of the health subcommittee, predicted that Congress would soon set minimum standards for such insurance, just as it did for Medigap insurance last year, because states are not moving fast enough to prevent abuses.
Spokesmen for the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association and for the Health Insurance Association of America, which represents more than 300 companies, testified against Federal standards, saying they would stifle development of the market for long-term care insurance.
Mary Nell Lehnhard, vice president of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, warned that if the Government required insurers to provide too many benefits, policies would become so expensive that people would not be able to afford them. Protection against inflation is particularly expensive, she said.
But Joshua M. Wiener, an economist at the Brookings Institution, the research organization, testified that without such protection, "the buying power of most policies erodes dramatically over time." The erosion is significant because there may be an interval of 20 or 30 years from the time a person buys a policy until the time it is used.
The average age of people admitted to nursing homes is 80, and the average age of people buying insurance for long-term care is 70, Mr. Wiener said. Insurers are encouraging people to buy such policies at younger ages, in their 40's or 50's, so the premiums will be adequate to cover later costs.
Policies now on the market typically pay $50 to $100 a day for nursing home care. The average premium rises with the buyer's age: $505 a year for a person who is 50 years old, $1,055 for a person who is 65 and $3,815 at age 79.
Gail E. Shearer, manager of policy analysis at Consumers Union, testified that "the private long-term care insurance market is not serving consumers very well," and she appealed to Congress to set minimum national standards. In the absence of uniform definitions for such terms as "skilled nursing care" and "medically necessary," it is virtually impossible to compare policies, she said.
 
Reluctance to Send Copies
 Ms. Shikles, from the General Accounting Office, said that consumers often had difficulty getting insurance companies to provide copies of the long-term care policies they were selling. "If you call them on the phone, they don't want to send you the policy they send to agents," she testified. "They send you marketing material, but not the policy." Another problem, Ms. Shikles said, is that most insurers do not offer any refund or partial benefits to people who discontinue their policies.

HEADLINE: Congress Still Uneasy on Cambodia

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
The Administration's freeze on aid to the non-Communist guerrillas fighting in coalition with the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia has dampened but not silenced Congressional criticism of the United States role in Cambodia.
Washington announced the suspension of at least $7 million in aid to the non-Communists on Wednesday because officials had found evidence that the rebels violated a Congressionally mandated restriction against battlefield coordination with the Khmer Rouge. The Chinese-supported force has been held responsible for more than a million deaths from killings and starvation when it held power in the 1970's. 
 In a hearing of the Senate subcommittee on East Asian and Pacific Affairs today, several Senators continued to express criticism of a peace process backed by the Administration that allows the Khmer Rouge to take part in a Supreme National Council that would help the United Nations and Government oversee proposed elections. But the sparks and harsh confrontation that characterized the hearings on Cambodia last year were absent.
Senator Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska and a leading critic of the Administration's policy, appeared to express the tone of his colleagues' opinions when he said, "I do not doubt the wisdom of cutting off aid." But he added that the Administration should lift its trade embargo on Cambodia as a way to encourage democracy.
 
Support for Coalition
 Since Vietnam invaded Cambodia and installed the Hun Sen Government in 1979, Washington has backed a loose coalition of guerrilla groups, including two non-Communist groups dominated by Prince Norodom Sihanouk and the Khmer Rouge. That policy became increasingly unpopular in Congress after the withdrawal of ost Vietnamese military forces in 1989 and as the Khmer Rouge made steady military progress.
Under Congressional pressure, the Administration last year dropped its support for a Cambodian delegation at the United Nations that included members of the Khmer Rouge and began contacts with Cambodian Government officials. Congress also halted covert aid to the rebels, and approved legislation that pressed the Administration to broaden ties with the Hun Sen Government.
A senior Senate aide who monitors Cambodia said the Administration's suspension of aid "has muted the reaction." The official also noted that members were pleased that the Administration was beginning to accept bids from humanitarian organizations seeking to distribute more than $5 million in aid for needy children living in areas governed by Phnom Penh.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy has introduced legislation to cut off aid to the Cambodian opposition permanently, but few members have expressed support for his bill so far. But the debate will most likely heat up again should the Administration reinstate aid to the guerrillas or should the Khmer Rouge open a major military offensive. There is currently a lull in the fighting.
 
Accord 'Within Reach'
 Richard H. Solomon, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, testified today that the diplomatic process to bring about a cease-fire, an interim government supervised by the United Nations, and free elections was making progress despite reports that it had stalled.
"A comprehensive settlement agreement is now within reach," he said, "if the Cambodian parties and others -- including Vietnam -- will cooperate."
That assessment was contradicted by several Senators.
"The Administration says that it wants to isolate the Khmer Rouge through the settlement process," said Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California and chairman of the subcommittee. "Let us be clear about what the proposed settlement does: It gives the Khmer Rouge political legitimacy."
Senator Frank H. Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, asked rhetorically, "Why are we indirectly supporting the Khmer Rouge by supporting the non-Communist allies of the Khmer Rouge while trying to defeat the only Cambodian force fighting the Khmer Rouge?" Mr. Murkowski suggested that the Administration was wrong to isolate the Hun Sen Government given that it had begun to privatize the economy.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Consumers' Role In a Recovery

BYLINE: By Sylvia Nasar

 BODY:
THERE is less to the consumer debt crisis than meets the eye. Some economists doubt that households are too deeply in debt to spend the nation out of a recession. As the economy recovers, slow growth in incomes is more likely to restrain consumer spending.
True, Americans borrowed during the 1980's as never before. They increased their debts, including mortgages, to almost a year's income, compared with a couple of months' income in 1950. 
 But even if consumers are not about to fuel another 1980's-style boom, debt will not keep them from spending.
First, consumers seem to be handling their debt well. Loan delinquency rates are not alarming. Late payments on mortgages are declining and late payments on installment debt, while high, are well below the levels of a few years ago. Thomas A. Durkin, an economist at the Federal Reserve, said the households that took on much of the debt during the expansion were those most able to afford it.
Consumers borrowed not only to ski in Vail, but also to invest in securities and homes. "To look at debt and not assets is silly because debt is such a small part of the balance sheet," said John D. Paulus, the chief economist at Morgan Stanley, who has just studied consumer balance sheets. Consumers added $9 trillion in assets but only $2 trillion in debt during the expansion from 1982 to 1990, according to the Federal Reserve. At the end of the expansion last year, husehold assets equaled more than five times their debts.
Not all the gains in assets reflected new BMW's, Sub-Zero refrigerators or inflated house prices on the two coasts. The value of households' financial assets -- including securities, savings accounts and insurance policies -- rose by roughly $7 billion during the expansion, more than twice as fast as the value of so-called tangible assets. Even the increase in financial wealth wasn't just the result of a free ride up the Dow Jones average. It mostly reflected bigger bank balances and more purchases of Treasury securities and corporate bonds.
Consumers' net worth was 70 percent higher -- or 30 percent after inflation -- last year than in 1982. Consumers accumulated wealth so consistently that they finished the decade with net worth of more than four times after-tax personal income -- the same as at the end of the 1960's.
The fear that consumers will have to prune spending to avoid bankruptcy is overblown because they can cash in much of their wealth in the time it takes to call a broker or stop at a teller machine. The most liquid financial assets, including bank accounts but not stocks, exceed debt by a wide margin.
It stands to reason that consumers have been prudent: It is the only group that spends its own money. Managers spend their shareholders' money and bureaucrats, the taxpayers'. Households, those supposed profligates, not only pay their own way, but are also net lenders to business and government.
But the good news about debt is not sufficient to guarantee a robust economy recovery. That is because consumer spending depends primarily on income. Consumers typically spend 80 cents of each extra dollar of income, compared with a nickel of each extra dollar of wealth. "Historically, consumer spending reflects income growth," not indebtedness, Mr. Paulus said.
During the next expansion, consumers are therefore likely to raise spending about as fast as their incomes allow. But income growth will probably be anemic compared with past recoveries, said Richard B. Berner, a Salomon Brothers economist.
Incomes may lag because employment is unlikely to grow as much as in past recoveries. Unemployment has remained lower than in some past recessions, and service companies are likely to remain cost-conscious. Wage gains are likely to be slight.
In addition, the $700 billion that households earn from interest is shrinking as rates fall. And tax increases at all levels, according to Mr. Berner, are draining about $36 billion from consumer budgets this year -- more than the cost of last summer's oil shock.
If incomes grow only modestly, consumers are also unlikely to increase their rate of savings, which has recently fluctuated between 4 and 5 percent. Saving often does rise during economic expansions, said Edward F. McKelvey, an economist at Goldman, Sachs. But that is because income growth is usually so strong that consumers can afford to both save and spend more.
Far from worrying about levels of debt, some economists say the nation has more to fear if consumers suddenly become much more thrifty. A panicky cutback in spending was enough to set off a recession last year. An abrupt rise in saving would keep the recovery away.

HEADLINE: Job Prospects for Graduates Seen as Bleak

 BODY:
After investing tens of thousands of dollars and countless hours in legal education, a substantial number of third-year students at law schools nationwide may graduate this year without job offers.
Though the situation is most acute in New York and other major cities in the Northeast, law firms are being forced by the recession to reduce the number of entry-level positions they offer, recruiters say. Citing economic reasons, some of the same firms only recently laid off scores of associates. 
 "I don't know what these students will do," said Lujuana Treadwell, executive director of the National Association for Law Placement, an organization of law firms and law schools that researches legal recruiting. "I'm sure some of them will take the bar exams and get jobs after they've been admitted to practice. Others will turn to jobs in other areas that use their legal backgrounds."
 
Tough Going for Class of '91
 Ms. Treadwell said the Class of 1991 faces the bleakest job prospects since the early 1980's.
Some entry-level jobs do exist. "You always have to have entry-level people," said Robert J. Kafin, the chairman of the hiring committee at Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn in New York. "You have to be able to advance entry-level people. And to advance entry-level people, you have to bring in someone to do the jobs they used to do."
But most larger firms have already given the bulk of these jobs to students who worked for them last year as summer associates, said Jody Greenspan, director of recruitment at New York University Law School.
 
Recruiting Was Down
 The National Association for Law Placement will not begin collecting data on the employment status of 1991 graduates until the fall. But 70 percent of the law schools that responded to a December 1990 survey by the research group reported that fewer firms traveled to their campuses to interview third-year students last fall. This is taken as an indication that, unlike in past years, many firms had little need to look beyond the talent tapped last summer.
Those third-year students who did not convert their summer employment into permanent jobs face the greatest difficulty because they are likely to be overlooked by firms that are hiring, experts said. But Ms. Treadwell said that these students and many who were spurned by larger firms last fall may find work at smaller firms or in Government agencies, which interview in the spring.
Like many other large firms, Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn continued to recruit at the nation's top law schools this year, but it bypassed many of the regional schools that helped fill its personnel needs in the boom of the middle and late 1980's, Mr. Kafin said.
One whose job search may have been hampered by the recession is Diane Vogel, a third-year student at Albany Law School.
Ms. Vogel, who is on the law review and heads the international law society at Albany, worked last summer at one of the largest firms in New York. But no offer of a permanent job followed, and Ms. Vogel, who has student loans to repay, is concerned about her prospects.
"I have faith that I'll find something; I don't have faith I'm going to find the optimal job," she said. "People are jumping at the first job that comes along."
