HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Up Moderately

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Fresh reports presenting a mixed picture on the economy and inflation had little impact in the credit markets, where prices of Treasury securities moved modestly higher yesterday in light trading.
Analysts noted that another important inflation report, one on consumer prices, is scheduled for today. 
 Analysts and market participants were mostly puzzled by a report on retail sales, which showed that sales fell a sharp eight-tenths of a percent last month.
That number, which suggests continued weakness in the economy, would have been greeted more favorably had it not been accompanied by a huge upward revision in February's sales figures. Retail sales rose by 2 percent in February, not the eight-tenths of a percent increase that was originally reported.
"That big upward revision made people think twice about what the March numbers really might be," said Richard B. Berner, a vice president and economist at Salomon Brothers Inc.
A report showing that initial unemployment claims fell by 70,000, to 473,000, in the week ended March 30 was also somewhat troubling, even though the figures were skewed because of the Good Friday holiday.
The inflation numbers carried a less ambiguous message.
 
Producer Index Up
 Excluding food and energy, the Producer Price Index rose by two-tenths of a percent in March, down from a rise of four-tenths of a percent in February. Over all, the index fell three-tenths of a percent in March, the fourth straight monthly decline.
The report sparked some speculation that the Federal Reserve might move soon to lower short-term interest rates. Reflecting that, short-term money market rates moved down fairly sharply. But bond yields were little changed.
The Fed, however, chose not to take that step yesterday.
For the second straight session, the Fed entered the market to drain reserves from the banking system at a time when the overnight Federal funds rate was trading under the 6 percent level that is seen as the Fed's target.
"The market's tepid reaction to the reports has implications for the Fed," said Dana Johnson, chief money market economist at the First National Bank of Chicago.
"The Fed really wants to be in a situation where they are following the market, not leading it."
The pending release of the consumer price report may also have been a reason for the market's measured reaction. "There is considerable risk on Friday," one Government bond trader said.
In advance of the report, most economists projected that excluding food and energy prices, the Consumer Price Index will show a rise of about three-tenths of a percent for last month, a big drop from the large rise of seven-tenths of a percent recorded in February.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 95 27/32, up 1/8 point, to yield 8.25 percent, basically unchanged from Wednesday.
Among note issues, the 7 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 97 7/8, up 2/32, to yield 8.06 percent. Anticipating a possible easing move by the Fed, the 7 1/8 percent two-year notes rose by 5/32, to a late price of 100 13/ 32, to yield 6.89 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates fell fairly sharply.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.52 percent, down 8 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 6 basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.63 percent. And one-year bill rates fell by 8 basis points, to a late rate of 5.81 percent.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday that two of the three measures of the nation's money supply fell in the week ended April 1.
M-2, the monetary aggregate most closely watched by the Fed, fell by $2.1 billion. It was the first time in weeks that M-2 had not posted an increase. The report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said that prices of most issues rose one-eighth to a quarter of a point.
Participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal securities said that prices of most widely quoted issues rose by about one-eighth.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Fell 0.8% In March

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
In the clearest evidence to date that revived confidence has done little to spur consumer spending, the Commerce Department estimated today that retail sales fell eight-tenths of 1 percent last month. That put sales slightly below the level of March 1990.
Analysts said the decline, which was widespread, indicated that the economy remained mired in recession and that the Federal Reserve had compelling reason to make another round of cuts in interest rates to hasten a recovery.
 
Producer Prices Fall
 Giving the Fed still further maneuvering room, the Labor Department reported today that prices received by American finished-goods producers eased by an unexpectedly large three-tenths of 1 percent in March, the fourth straight monthly decline. 
 The "core rate," which excludes food and energy, rose a reassuring two-tenths of 1 percent, less than half the average for the two preceding months. [Page D8.]
Partly in reaction to the producer price numbers, stock prices rose sharply today, with the Dow industrials gaining 30.95, to 2,905.45. In the credit markets there was little reaction, with many analysts and traders puzzled by the retail sales numbers.
A report of higher chain-store sales today offered some grounds for optimism, some said, even though it was discount stores that posted the biggest gains. Low inflation, in fact, has been one of the factors holding down retail sales volume. [Page D8.]
Yet another report showed that initial claims for state unemployment insurance fell 70,000, to 473,000, in the week ended March 30. But this was generally disregarded, partly because of the Good Friday holiday.
 
February Figure Revised
 The retail sales figures cover everything from gasoline to refrigerators but do not count real estate or intangibles like college tuition.
As grim as they seemed, the retail figures had a bright side: Sales in February were revised to show a 2 percent gain instead of the eight-tenths of 1 percent gain that was initially estimated.
This, noted John D. Paulus, chief economist for Morgan Stanley & Company, means that the most recent two months have posted an average six-tenths of 1 percent gain in contrast to an eight-tenths of 1 percent average decline for the October-January period.
"There's some evidence here that the consumer may be bottoming out," Mr. Paulus said.
The March decline, though, might have been greater had it not been for the fact that Easter fell in March this year, while last year it fell in April.
Mr. Paulus and other economists said they expected the Fed to move as early as Friday to cut rates, providing the "core" Consumer Price Index, published at 8:30 A.M., rises no more than, say, four-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Discount Rate May Be Cut
 A Fed move will presumably include a cut in the discount rate, now 6 percent. Some economists, however, said they thought the Fed would defer further easing until it saw more economic deterioration.
Still, the finished-goods P.P.I. has not declined for such a sustained period -- albeit mainly because of energy -- in five years, and analysts also noted that the indexes for goods at the intermediate and crude stages both fell sharply last month.
Unlike some recent months, retail sales figures were not dragged down by the automotive sector, which fell by the same eight-tenths of 1 percent as the overall tabulation.
But while the March decline was sizable and widespread, the upward revision for February took much of the sting out of it and analysts said these and other figures represented early signs of economic recovery that most still believe likely by mid-year.
 
Economy Seen as Healthier
 "The economy looks less unhealthy than a month ago," commented Gilbert Benz, an economist for the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York.
March retail sales totaled $149.6 billion, adjusted for seasonal, holiday and trading-day differences but not for inflation, the Department reported. This compared with $150.8 billion, upon revision, for February.
Durable goods fell nine-tenths of 1 percent to a level 4.8 percent below March 1990, with sales of building materials posting the biggest percentage loss -- 4.4 percent. Sales at furniture, home furnishing and equipment stores rose five-tenths of 1 percent.
Sales of nondurables -- about two-thirds of the total -- fell eight-tenths of 1 percent last month. General merchandise stores had a decline of 2.2 percent and there were also declines for gasoline stations (1.5 percent), apparel and accessory stores (4.9 percent) and eating and drinking places (1.8 percent).
Gains were posted by drug and proprietary stores (1.1. percent) and by food stores.

HEADLINE: Sewage Plant Near Capacity After 5 Years

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

 BODY:
Five years after it opened, the $1.1 billion North River sewage plant serving most of the West Side of Manhattan is treating almost as much sewage as it can handle, raising questions about the future water quality of the Hudson River and the future of West Side development.
Today, it is scheduled to reach a milestone when it begins secondary treatment of its sewage, aerating the water to remove more impurities. 
 Environmentalists agree that the Hudson has been cleaner since the plant opened on a sprawling riverfront site between 137th and 145th Streets in Harlem. But they worry that if the plant exceeds capacity, it will have to treat sewage less, and discharge dirtier effluent into the river.
That could prompt the state to restrict new sewer hookups, which could halt new development on the West Side, stifling plans for high-rises, midtown office buildings and projects like Trump City.
The plant has other problems, as well. An elaborate 28-acre park on its roof is at least a year behind schedule and will not open until spring 1993. And the plant continues to release odors that have exasperated Harlem residents since the day it opened.
 
Volunteer Noses Get Training
 "All I can say is, it stinks," said L. Ann Rocker, who lives at 142d Street and Riverside Drive and heads a citizens advisory group concerned about the plant.
Mayor David N. Dinkins, who residents say is more sensitive to the issue than his predecessor was, has gone so far as to organize local odor volunteers trained to tell the difference between West Side Highway car fumes and plant emissions like hydrogen sulfide. But much dissatisfaction remains, despite promises of better monitoring and filters, and some residents think the plant's design is fundamentally flawed.
The secondary treatment due to begin today -- in which air is bubbled through the sewage to make more solids settle out as sludge before the water is chlorinated -- should remove 85 percent of the pollutants, up from 60 percent or less. Most plants in the United States have long operated at the 85 percent level, the Federal requirement, but North River's construction lagged so far behind schedule that environmental officials allowed it to open below standards.
"It is a momentous occasion," said Katherine Kennedy, a lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental organization monitoring city sewage plants. "But simultaneously, that the plant appears to be at design capacity is depressing because it shows a lack of planning."
Still, New York City has come a long way: before the plant opened in 1986, raw sewage from Manhattan's West Side poured untreated into the Hudson. Now, it handles waste from 550,000 residents and a huge transient population, from Bank Street in Greenwich Village to Manhattan's northern tip.
Sewage treatment plants are designed to work for at least 25 years. Almost from the moment it began operation, the North River plant was at or near capacity -- 170 million gallons a day. To save money in the late 1970's, officials decided to lower its capacity from 225 million gallons.
When a plant takes more sewage than it is designed for, it holds the sewage less time, so fewer solids settle out.
 
Mariner's Nickname for Hudson
 "A plant that is operating right at capacity is stressed, like operating an auto at maximum speed," said Dr. Alan I. Mytelka, director of the Interstate Sanitation Commission, a regional regulatory agency.
New York State grants plant permits, and can halt sewer hookups in the area drained by a plant if it exceeds capacity.
Besides North River -- a mariner's nickname for the Hudson River dating to the 1700's -- at least two of the city's 14 sewage plants run at or above capacity. The Wards Island and Newtown Creek plants operate under consent orders requiring city officials to pursue water conservation and increase treatment.
City officials say careful water conservation would keep the North River plant at or below capacity, even with new development. There are no plans to expand the plant.
Carol Ash, regional director of the state Department of Environmental Conservation, said conservation could work, especially since she expects little new West Side development because of the city's economic doldrums. But the state will stay on the alert.
"We don't want it to go over capacity, that's for sure," Ms. Ash said.
A study released last month by State Senator Franz S. Leichter of Manhattan found that the plant may be over capacity right now and that the threat of a state development moratorium is real once the economy picks up. In addition, he had doubts that the city's conservation program could save as much water as it claims by 1998: 18 million gallons, or 10 percent of the sewage expected to be generated.
Senator Leichter said he is concerned that expensive high-rises and office buildings will be built before affordable housing, which could be shut out of the market if the state later declared a moratorium. He said the city should enact a short-term building moratorium in the North River service area to establish development priorities before the economy begins to grow.
One problem is knowing exactly how much sewage goes through the plant. Between November 1989 and last June, New York City had no firm idea how much was. At first, the city said malfunctioning equipment let river water into the plant, then blamed seasonal changes. Finally, it said meters had malfunctioned.
That has been fixed, officials say. Now they must figure out how to keep the plant from stinking. All sewage plants have some odor problems, but not all are so close to homes.
North River, most of which is on a platform over the river, is only a few hundred feet from the closest apartments. From the day it opened, it has been plagued by odor problems, although the city Department of Environmental Protection says only 11 formal complaints have been recorded in the last two years.
"Last summer, I never opened my window because it's so bad when it's warm weather," said Mertis Hightower, whose 15th-floor apartment at 626 Riverside Drive faces the plant.
To mollify Harlem residents who opposed the plant, officials agreed to build a park atop it, which will include indoor and outdoor pools, a skating rink, ballfields, a carousel, a restaurant and athletic and culture centers. Bridges to it have been built over the West Side Highway.
"I've never picked up too many odors on the rooftop," said Warren Holliday, program manager for the state Office of General Services, which is overseeing park construction.
Local residents, city officials and environmentalists are skeptical, and say the Koch administration ignored the odor problem. But some are equally unconvinced that the Dinkins administration will effectively control it by measures like installing filters. They want major design changes.

HEADLINE: Weicker Vows to Veto Budget Plan That Does Not Include Income Tax

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, April 11

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. today placed his administration squarely in the crossroads of a confrontation with the broad middle belt of the General Assembly by vowing to veto a no-income-tax budget plan that had seemed to be gaining support in both parties.
Mr. Weicker said he could not now imagine any budget he would sign if it did not include an income tax. He had previously encouraged lawmakers to seek another way to solve the state's budget deficit and recession and thus avoid the sweeping overhaul he proposed to the legislature in February. 
 Today, he seemed to close off those options. He said the counterproposal offered by Republican leaders, who pledged to skirt the income tax through an increase in sales tax collections and deeper cuts in spending, would worsen the state's recession and saddle taxpayers with budget gimmicks.
 
A 'Flawed' Proposal
 "It's flawed to the extent that it promises no more than what we've got," Mr. Weicker said at a news conference in his office. "I don't want any more of what we have."
Mr. Weicker, a former Republican United States Senator who gave up on his party to run last year on his own third-party ticket, said the Republicans had fashioned a document that is "clearly antibusiness," rife with "gimmicks" and "totally speculative" in adding up projected dollar savings.
The Republican plan had drawn nods of admiration, if not outright support, from many Democrats, including the State Senate and House majority leaders. With Democrats split over an income tax, Republicans believed a bipartisan coalition to break Mr. Weicker's budget plan was within view.
Some lawmakers, mostly liberal income-tax supporters, said the veto threat had effectively killed the plan because a two-thirds majority needed to override a veto was impossible to obtain. Gov. William A. O'Neill, Mr. Weicker's predecessor, never had a veto overridden in 10 years in office.
Other lawmakers said the Governor's words would simply harden the resolve and deepen divisions within the Democratic Party and between the legislative and executive branches of the government.
 
'A Major Blunder'
 "Attempting to intimidate the General Assembly is only going to be counterproductive -- all it's going to do is weld the non-income-tax group together," said Senator James H. Maloney, Democrat of Danbury, vice chairman of the Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee. "It was a major blunder."
Mr. Maloney said he believed that enough votes already existed in the 36-member Senate to pass an alternative budget and that hackles raised by the Governor today could help push a simple majority into a two-thirds majority, or 24 votes, needed to override a veto.
The Republicans have 16 seats in the Senate to the Democrats' 20. In the House, Republicans have 63 seats to the Democrats' 88. Overriding a veto in the House requires 101 votes.

HEADLINE: Stocks Rise And the Dow Gains 30.95

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
The stock market rebounded yesterday, largely because the Government reported a modest rise in wholesale prices for March. The report was in line with expectations, and analysts expect the report on the March Consumer Price Index, which is due before the market opens this morning, will also be well received.
Program trading by institutions continued to dominate the blue chips, but individual investors seemed to favor shares in the over-the-counter market. As a result, the Nasdaq Composite Index climbed 8.55 to close at a record 499.31, toppling the previous record of 497.57 that was set only a week earlier. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue chips added 30.95 to close at 2,905.45, a gain of 1.08 percent. In all, 1,108 issues closed higher on the New York Stock Exchange, while 508 declined.
 
Volume Soars
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange soared to 196.6 million shares, from 167.9 million the day before. Technical analysts cited as a positive sign the strong close of the spot June futures in the Standard and Poor's stock index on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Index futures trade 15 minutes after the Big Board closes.
The 500 futures closed at 381.50, almost 4 points above the "cash," or actual S.&P. 500 index, which ended up 4.48 at 377.63. According to several Wall Street technicians who guide program trading strategies for their houses, the June futures should have a premium of roughly 2.10 points over the actual index. Instead, the June futures closed a premium of 3.47, compared with one of 1.85 at the previous close.
Futures usually trade above cash prices because the futures price includes the theoretical cost of carrying the underlying goods and related expenses. But the larger the premium on the 500 futures, the better the odds that the market will open higher the following morning, because the program traders will sell some of their futures to take profits and then buy the shares in the less expensive actual S.&P. 500 index.
 
Relief on Producer Prices
 Yesterday morning, a combination of relief on the Producer Price Index's performance, combined with program traders switching out of futures and into the cash market, sent the market sharply higher after the opening. As measured by the Dow average, the market was up over 40 points before traders inevitably began to cash in some profits.
Given the absence of any strong market trend, many blue chips favored by program traders of late were among the most active Big Board issues. American Express led the list, slipping 1/8, to 27 5/8, on a turnover of 5.2 million shares. RJR Nabisco Holdings was second, rising 3/8, to 11 1/2, on a volume of 4.2 million shares.
Among the stocks on the list of 10 most active with the largest price changes, Laidlaw Inc. B fell 1, to 12 7/8; Advanced Micro Devices rose 1, to 12 5/8; Waste Management fell 1 7/8, to 36 7/8, and Upjohn fell 1 3/4, to 46 1/2.
"While the rich closing premium of the 500 futures augers for a good opening Friday, what follows will depend on whether the C.P.I. March index provides no surprises," said Bernard Spilko, senior vice president at the New York branch of Bank Julius Baer of Zurich, which manages huge amounts of pension funds, as well as other investments.
 
'Awash in Cash'
 Mr. Spilko said that what impressed and many of his peers was the continued strength of the over-the-counter market. "The institutions, which are still awash in cash, have been more or less marking time by engaging in program trading involving the blue chips, such as the 500 indexes," he said. "But individual investors are buying what they perceive as tomorrow's blue chips in the over-the-counter market."
This trend continued despite some fears earlier in the day that the modest rise in wholesale prices would deter the Federal Reserve from easing credit further. These fears were bolstered somewhat when the central bank actually pushed up interest rates a bit by draining reserves from the banking system in what was considered a technical move.
The belief that the Fed will eventually lower credit costs as a means of stimulating the economy was also evident at the American Stock Exchange, where their Market Value Index closed up 2.96, at 365.47.

HEADLINE: Seidman Asks Stiffer Bank Curbs

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
L. William Seidman, the nation's senior banking regulator, asked Congress today to reverse sharply the deregulatory trend of the last two decades and adopt a law that would make it harder for banks to issue loans for construction and purchases of raw land and other real estate.
Whether or not Congress acts, the pronouncements alone by Mr. Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, are expected to reduce credit further in already tight markets for certain real estate loans. Analysts expect that his recommendation will translate into a tougher stance toward such loans by Government examiners, who have the authority to impose restrictions on the institutions they supervise to insure their safety and soundness. 
 Appearing today before the House Banking Committee, Mr. Seidman attributed much of the blame for the current banking crisis to a loosening of the banking laws in 1974 and 1982, as well as a laxness among regulators, that enabled banks to make real estate loans that have since turned into monumental losses in several regions of the country, notably the Southwest and the Northeast. Before 1974, banks had been restricted in making such loans.
"It is time for insured institutions to return to old-fashioned standards of safe and sound banking," Mr. Seidman said. "The restrictions lifted by Congress in 1974 and 1982 should be reinstated."
 
Treasury Officials Disagree
 In recent weeks, Mr. Seidman has delivered several speeches before bank and savings and loan organizations stressing the need for caution in real estate lending. That position has put him at odds with Treasury officials, who declined to include his proposal in their plan to overhaul the banking system that was presented last month.
The Treasury officials said in their presentation to Congress that statutory prohibitions on certain types of bank loans would only aggravate problems that have arisen from already stingy lending for commercial real estate.
The Treasury Department has responded to criticism from bankers and other businesses about the tight lending by seeking to ease accounting standards to coax banks to extend more credit. Both the General Accounting Office and some lawmakers have attacked this approach.
It is too early to tell how receptive Congress will be toward Mr. Seidman's proposal to restrict lending.
In a sign that he was leaning toward endorsing such a move, the House Banking Committee chairman, Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas, said at today's hearing that he had voted against the legislation in 1982 that had eased restrictions on lending practices and was troubled by the enormous amount of real estate lending by the banks.
Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., the Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, is said to be considering throwing his support behind restricting certain kinds of real estate loans.
On the other hand, real estate and banking lobbyists are expected to wage a hard campaign to keep the law from changing.
"Our initial reaction is that this does nothing to address today's paramount crisis, which is the credit crunch," said Steven A. Wechsler, president of the National Realty Committee, a trade organization in Washington representing developers and other business executives involved in real estate. "These suggestions address what could be tomorrow's problem if history repeats itself. Today's problem is the credit crisis."
"I do find it interesting that in 1982, when these statutory restrictions were lifted, they were done to provide the regulators with flexible and realistic standards," he added. "Given the fact that the flexibility has been available, it's not clear what legislation would do."
 
'Paying the Consequences'
 In his testimony today, Mr. Seidman said the F.D.I.C. "has been paying the consequences" ever since Congress and the White House decided in 1974 and 1982 to ease restrictions on real estate lending. The rising number of bank failures has left the fund that protects deposits at its lowest ratio to deposits since its creation in 1934. Mr. Seidman today reiterated his prediction that the fund would probably not be insolvent this year unless the economy failed to recover in the next few months. Many economists and officials have forecast an upturn.
"There may be a time when the taxpayer has to pick up the bill," Mr. Seidman said of the federally guaranteed fund. "I do not believe we have arrived at that point now, and I hope we never arrive at that point."
Mr. Seidman said that whether any new borrowing to keep the bank insurance fund afloat would come from the Treasury or the Federal Reserve was "of secondary significance." The Administration has sought to have $25 billion of the $70 billion in new borrowing authority that the White House has requested be available from the Fed. But some senior Fed officials say that using the central bank for a possible taxpayer bailout sets a bad precedent. The General Accounting Office has also come out against tapping the Fed.
In recent months, Mr. Seidman, who has enjoyed a strong reputation in Congress, has come under increasing political pressure as the bank insurance fund's problems have grown. Many members of Congress continue to praise him. But some lawmakers have begun to draw comparisons between him and M. Danny Wall, the former head of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, who has been accused of failing to adequately warn Congress of the growing problems of the savings and loan industry.
Mr. Seidman, who will be 70 years old at the end of the month, has deflected the comparisons with good humor. Introducing his wife to the committee today, he remarked, "I think she came to watch the slaughter."
He has also declined to pin down his plans, other than to say he expects to leave before his term expires. His term is scheduled to end in October, but the F.D.I.C. has obtained a legal opinion that an ambiguity in the law may allow him to continue serving through February 1993.
 
Three Changes Criticized
 In his testimony, Mr. Seidman cited three changes in the banking laws that he said contributed significantly to the current banking crisis. The changes, many of which came under the Garn-St Germain Act of 1982, permitted nationally chartered banks to make loans on raw land; allowed loans on construction projects even when the builder contributed less than 25 percent equity, and eliminated restrictions on a bank's total real estate loan portfolio.
"In the three years following the passage of the Garn-St Germain Act, construction and land development loans by Texas commercial banks doubled as a percentage of assets and nearly tripled in dollar terms," Mr. Seidman said.
Congressional aides noted today that the savings and loan bailout legislation adopted in 1989 had restricted some forms of real estate lending and that Congress was likely to be similarly inclined to impose some restrictions on banks.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Fell 0.3% in March

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
Prices at the producer level fell in March for the fourth straight month, the first time that has occurred in five years, the Government said today.
The Labor Department said its Producer Price Index fell three-tenths of a percent last month, reflecting continued big declines in energy prices. 
 The Government also said that the underlying inflation rate, which excludes energy and food costs, rose a modest two-tenths of a percent -- just half of the February gain. Analysts said that bolstered their belief that big gains in the core inflation rate in January and February had been based on temporary factors.
 
No Big Inflation Seen
 "Anyone reading this report can't be saying that inflation is about to roar off," said Donald Ratajczak, head of the forecasting unit at Georgia State University.
He said he was expecting the Consumer Price Index for March to be up about one-tenth of a percent when it is issued on Friday.
The three-tenths of a percent drop in wholesale prices in March left prices declining at an annual rate of 3.9 percent for the first three months of this year, sharply below last year's 5.6 percent rise. That increase was attributed to the big jump in energy prices after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait.
So far this year, energy prices have been falling at a steep annual rate of 35.4 percent as oil prices retreated from the levels reached in the months immediately after the invasion.
 
Food and Energy Costs
 In March, food costs one step short of retail prices rose a modest two-tenths of a percent as small increases in a variety of products offset actual declines for beef, poultry and vegetable prices.
In energy, gasoline prices fell 5.8 percent, while home heating oil costs dropped by 16.5 percent.
Women's clohing prices continued to spurt upward, rising by seven-tenths of a percent. But that was slower than the February increase.
Prices for new cars rose just two-tenths of a percent, far below the gains in January and February, and prescription drug prices, which had been racing ahead, fell eight-tenths of a percent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
Companies
California regulators seized control of Executive Life Insurance, which had been among the largest purchasers of high-risk "junk bonds" under its high-flying chief executive, Fred Carr. It was the largest failure yet of an insurer. California's insurance commissioner said the state had taken over management because the company was in a "hazardous condition." [Page A1.] 
 Ford cut its dividend nearly in half, to 40 cents a share, saying business conditions were even tougher than those usually encountered when car sales are soft. [D1.]

Intel and Advanced Micro Devices reported unexpectedly strong quarterly results. The companies cited strong demand for microprocessors. [D1.]

The New York Times Company reported that quarterly income fell 69 percent. The company cited declining ad revenues. [D7.]
Jim Landis quit as editor in chief of William Morrow, after what was described as a personality clash. [D7.]
A BellSouth unit agreed to buy mobile telephone systems in 18 Midwestern markets from McCaw for a total of $410 million. [D4.]
 
The Economy
Retail sales fell 0.8 percent last month, to slightly below the March 1990 level, the Commerce Department reported. The report, which covers everything from gasoline to refrigerators, was the clearest evidence to date that revived confidence had done little to spur consumer spending. [D1.] The big retailers alone, meanwhile, reported generally improved sales last month, with the discounters and apparel chains doing the best. [D8.] Producer prices fell in March for the fourth straight month. [D8.]

International
A powerful computer that Bush approved for sale to a Brazilian aircraft company has yet to be shipped because Brazil has not provided guarantees that the technology will not be used for military purposes. [D2.]
 
Markets

Prices of Treasury securities moved modestly higher in light trading, with economic reports having little impact. [D6.]

Near-term cotton futures prices fell sharply, but analysts predicted that the setback would be short-lived. [D14.]

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 5; Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 2008 words

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
'Miss Saigon' Arrives, From the Old School

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
THERE may never have been a musical that made more people angry before its Broadway debut than "Miss Saigon."
Here is a show with something for everyone to resent -- in principle, at least. Its imported stars, the English actor Jonathan Pryce and the Filipino actress Lea Salonga, are playing roles that neglected Asian-American performers feel are rightfully theirs. Its top ticket price of $100 is a new Broadway high, sprung by an English producer, if you please, on a recession-straitened American public. More incendiary still is the musical's content. A loose adaptation of "Madama Butterfly" transplanted to the Vietnam War by French authors, the "Les Miserables" team of Alain Boublil and Claude-Michel Schonberg, "Miss Saigon" insists on revisiting the most calamitous and morally dubious military adventure in American history and, through an unfortunate accident of timing, arrives in New York even as the jingoistic celebrations of a successful American war are going full blast. 
 So take your rage with you to the Broadway Theater, where "Miss Saigon" opened last night, and hold on tight. Then see just how long you can cling to the anger when confronted by the work itself. For all that seems galling about "Miss Saigon" -- and for all that is indeed simplistic, derivative and, at odd instances, laughable about it -- this musical is a gripping entertainment of the old school (specifically, the Rodgers and Hammerstein East-meets-West school of "South Pacific" and "The King and I"). Among other pleasures, it offers lush melodies, spectacular performances by Mr. Pryce, Miss Salonga and the American actor Hinton Battle, and a good cry. Nor are its achievements divorced from its traumatic subject, as cynics might suspect. Without imparting one fresh or daring thought about the Vietnam War, the show still manages to plunge the audience back into the quagmire of a generation ago, stirring up feelings of anguish and rage that run even deeper than the controversies that attended "Miss Saigon" before its curtain went up.
Challenged perhaps by the ill will that greeted their every move, the evening's creators, led by the director Nicholas Hytner, have given New York a far sharper version of "Miss Saigon" than the one originally staged in London. The much publicized (and inane) helicopter effect notwithstanding, this is the least spectacular and most intimate of the West End musicals. The most stirring interludes feature two or three characters on an empty stage or in a bar girl's dingy hovel, and for once the production has been made leaner rather than fattened up for American consumption. (Though the Broadway Theater is among the largest Broadway houses, it seems cozy next to the cavernous Drury Lane, where the show plays in London.) If "Miss Saigon" is the most exciting of the so-called English musicals -- and I feel it is, easily -- that may be because it is the most American. It freely echoes Broadway classics, and some of its crucial personnel are Broadway hands: the co-lyricist Richard Maltby Jr., the choreographer Bob Avian, the orchestrator William D. Brohn.
Without two legendary American theatrical impresarios, David Belasco and Harold Prince, there would in fact be no "Miss Saigon." It was Belasco's turn-of-the-century dramatization of the Madame Butterfly story that inspired Puccini's opera, and it was Mr. Prince who, inspired by Brecht and the actor Joel Grey 25 years ago, created the demonic, symbolic Emcee of "Cabaret," a character that is unofficially recycled on this occasion in a role called the Engineer and played by Mr. Pryce. These two influences are brilliantly fused here. Altered substantially but not beyond recognition, the basic "Butterfly" premise of an Asian woman who is seduced and abandoned by an American military man is affectingly rekindled in "Miss Saigon" by Mr. Schonberg's score and Miss Salonga's clarion, emotionally naked delivery of it. Whenever that tale flirts with bathos, along comes the leering, creepy Mr. Pryce to jolt the evening back into the hellish, last-night-of-the-world atmosphere that is as fitting for the fall of Saigon as it was for the Weimar Berlin of "Cabaret."
The theatrical poles of "Miss Saigon" represented by its two stars are equally powerful. Miss Salonga, whose performance has grown enormously since crossing the Atlantic, has the audience all but worshiping her from her first appearance as Kim, an open-faced 17-year-old waif from the blasted Vietnamese countryside who is reduced to working as a prostitute in Saigon. As her romance with an American marine, Chris (Willy Falk), blossoms "South Pacific"-style in a progression of haunting saxophone-flecked ballads in Act I, the actress keeps sentimentality at bay by slowly revealing the steely determination beneath the gorgeous voice, radiant girlish features and virginal white gown. Once Chris and his fellow Americans have fled her and her country, the determination transmutes into courage, and the passages in which Kim sacrifices herself for the welfare of her tiny child, no matter how hokey, are irresistibly moving because Miss Salonga's purity of expression, backed up by the most elemental music and lyrics, simply won't let them be otherwise.
Mr. Pryce, a great character actor whose nasty streak has been apparent since his memorable Broadway debut in Trevor Griffiths's "Comedians" 15 years ago, makes disingenuousness as electrifying as Miss Salonga's ingenuousness. The Engineer is a fixer, profiteer and survivor who can outlast Uncle Sam and Uncle Ho: a pimp, a sewer rat, a hustler of no fixed morality, sexuality, race, nationality or language. Wearing wide-lapelled jackets and bell bottoms of garish color, he is the epitome of sleaze, forever swiveling his hips, flashing a sloppy tongue and fluttering his grasping fingers in the direction of someone's dollar bills or sex organs. With his high-domed forehead and ghoulish eyes, Mr. Pryce is also a specter of doom, and he manages to turn a knee-jerk number indicting the greedy "American Dream" into a show-stopper with the sheer force of his own witty malice.
As choreographed by Mr. Avian in demented parody of an old-fashioned Broadway song-and-dance turn, "The American Dream" looks like the Fellini-esque "Loveland" sequence in the 1971 Stephen Sondheim musical "Follies," and no wonder, given the song's imitation Sondheim lyrics and the fact that Mr. Avian was Michael Bennett's associate choreographer on "Follies." Among the other old favorites in "Miss Saigon" are a balcony scene out of "West Side Story," a departing refugees scene out of "Fiddler on the Roof," an Act II song for Mr. Pryce that recalls Fagin's equivalent solo in "Oliver!" and some dancing North Vietnamese who seem a cross between the Peronists in "Evita" and the ritualistic Japanese dancers of "Pacific Overtures." It is only when "Miss Saigon" imitates West End musicals of the 1980's, however, that it goes seriously astray. The helicopter stunt, which will most impress devotees of sub-Disney theme parks, is presented out of historical sequence in an Act II flashback, for no good reason other than to throw Andrew Lloyd Webber fans a pseudo-chandelier or levitating tire. A neon-drenched Bangkok nightlife spectacle in the same act is a grim reminder of the ill-fated "Chess."
Of all the failings of modern British musicals, the most severe has been their creators' utter bewilderment about what happens between men and women emotionally, psychologically and sexually. "Miss Saigon" is not immune to this syndrome, either, and it shows up most embarrassingly in the lyrics characterizing Chris's stateside wife, who, despite a game portrayal by Liz Callaway, induces audience snickers and giggles in her big Act II solo. Chris himself is nearly as faceless, and Mr. Falk, a performer with a strong pop voice and a Ken doll's personality, does nothing to turn up the hero's heat.
If anything, "Miss Saigon" would be stronger if Mr. Battle, who plays Chris's best friend, had been cast instead as Kim's lover. Mr. Battle's grit and passion are far more redolent of the marines who fought in Vietnam than Mr. Falk's blandness, and his one brief encounter with Miss Salonga has more bite than any of her scenes with her paramour. Mr. Battle, who has heretofore been better known as a dancer than a singer, also rescues the sanctimonious opening anthem of Act II -- a canned plea for homeless Amerasian children -- with a gospel delivery so blistering and committed that he overpowers an onslaught of cliched lyrics, film clips and a large backup choir.
With the aid of his designers, especially the lighting designer David Hersey, who uses John Napier's fabric-dominated sets as a floating canvas, Mr. Hytner usually keeps the staging simple. An opening "Apocalypse Now" sunrise that bleeds into a hazy panorama of a Saigon morning is as delicate as an Oriental print, and the Act I climax, in which boat people set off for points unknown, is stunning because it relies on such primal elements as an outstretched helping hand and the slow exit by the characters to the rear of a deep, darkened stage stripped of most scenery.
To be sure, the hallucinatory view of Vietnam familiar from the films of Oliver Stone, the journalism of Michael Herr and the fiction of Robert Stone, among many others, is beyond Mr. Hytner's mission, if not his considerable abilities, just as any thoughtful analysis of the war is beyond the libretto. The text of "Miss Saigon," second in naivete only to "Nixon in China," says merely that the North Vietnamese were villains and that the Americans were misguided, bungling do-gooders. Facts and haircuts are fudged, the corrupt South Vietnamese regime is invisible and any references to war atrocities are generalized into meaninglessness.
Yet the text is not the sum of a theatrical experience, and however sanitizing the words and corny the drama of "Miss Saigon," the real impact of the musical goes well beyond any literal reading. America's abandonment of its own ideals and finally of Vietnam itself is there to be found in the wrenching story of a marine's desertion of a Vietnamese woman and her son. The evening's far-from-happy closing tableau -- of spilled Vietnamese blood and an American soldier who bears at least some responsibility for the carnage -- hardly whitewashes the United States involvement in Southeast Asia. "Miss Saigon" is escapist entertainment in style and in the sense that finally it even makes one forget about all the hype and protests that greeted its arrival. But this musical is more than that, too, because the one thing it will not allow an American audience to escape is the lost war that, like its tragic heroine, even now defiantly refuses to be left behind.
 
Miss Saigon

HEADLINE: Auctions

BYLINE: By Rita Reif

 BODY:
Rayographs in Demand
Predictably, next week's photography auctions at Christie's and Sotheby's in Manhattan are much smaller than in recent seasons at these houses, offering fewer images in the $500 to $2,000 range. 
 The recession and lackluster auctions of photographs at both houses in October prompted the cutbacks. Following a three-year boom in the photography market, during which sales doubled in size and the prices for some works went from 3 to 10 times what they had been in the mid-1980's, scores of photographs estimated by the auction houses to bring $2,000 or less did not sell six months ago.
Photographs that had been expected to bring higher prices were also affected at these sales, especially some images by Robert Mapple thorpe. An unenthusiastic response to his floral and erotic photographs left some unsold, while others brought lower prices than the houses had expected.
The bidding for some rarities of the 1920's and 30's, however, was as intense as ever. At Christie's, Man Ray's 1920's Rayograph of a double brush that looks like a ragged bow tie, suspended over a candle, was auctioned for the first time and brought $126,500. The price was the highest paid at auction for a single photograph. At Sotheby's, Alfred Stieglitz's 1922 portrait of Georgia O'Keeffe was sold for $99,000, a record at auction for a Stieglitz photograph.
The success in the fall of the Man Ray work spurred the unidentified owner of an earlier Rayograph to send it to Christie's. He had purchased the 1922 photograph, a strange image of a one-armed doll suspended in air, at Sotheby's in London in 1985 for $11,935. Now Christie's estimates the Rayograph will sell for $100,000 to $125,000 in an auction to be held at 10 A.M. and 2 P.M. next Tuesday. The sale of 439 photographs or groups of photographs is estimated to total $1.7 million to $2.2 million -- about two-thirds the value and size of the house's October auction. Of the 769 offerings in that sale, 497 were sold for a total of $1.8 million against the house estimate of $2.2 million to $3 million.
At Sotheby's sale, to be held at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. on Wednesday, the most important offering is also for an advertising image -- Paul Outerbridge's "Marmon Crankshaft," from 1923. Lighted to show the satiny texture of the metal, the photograph of a Marmon car's crankshaft is signed and dated, one of two prints known of this subject. Sotheby's estimates it to bring $100,000 to $120,000.
"There has never been a print of this image auctioned," said Beth Gates Warren, who heads photography sales at Sotheby's in New York. "The heart of the market seems to be in images of the 1920's and 30's." Sotheby's sale of 480 offerings is expected to total $2.2 million to $3.2 million, compared with the October sale of 755 offerings estimated to bring $2.9 million to $4.3 million. That sale, in which 465 works were sold, brought a total of $2.3 million.
 
Pillows and Fairings
 A wealth of Victorian decorations -- beaded pillows, dried flowers in bell jars, dolls, miniature furniture and shell paintings -- collected by Joshua and Nedda Logan is to be auctioned on May 1 at William Doyle Galleries, 175 East 87th Street, Manhattan.
"Visiting the Logans was a trip to a magic shop," said William Doyle, the auctioneer.
The decorations, theater posters and memorabilia that filled the Logans' fancifully decorated nine-room apartment at River House on the East River are to be sold from their estates. Mr. Logan, the director, writer and producer, was 79 at his death in 1988 and his wife, the actress Nedda Harrigan, the daughter of the vaudevillian Ned Harrigan, died less than a year later at the age of 91.
The auction of about 250 items or groups of items, estimated to bring $100,000 to $150,000, does not include the couple's large collection of automata, which Mrs. Logan bequeathed to the Museum of the City of New York.

HEADLINE: Diner's Journal

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER

 BODY:
Onda
 Affected by the sliding economy last year, Karen Hubert and Len Allison found it necessary to close their sumptuous Huberts on Park Avenue and move to more modest quarters downtown. Their latest effort is called Onda. 
 The long, mahogany-lined dining room is austere but comfortable, with brass candle sconces and religious paintings from Peru on the the walls. Frosted glass conceals most of the kitchen. Tables are draped in paper, waiters wear open white shirts and waitresses don white turtlenecks. Entrees and some appetizers have two prices, one for individual portions and another for family style.
 Typical of Mr. Allison's cooking style, the food is a weaving of international threads. A hearty starter is pansotti, a Ligurian ravioli, filled with spinach and enlivened with a ground-walnut-and-herb sauce ($7.50, $13.50).
Shrimp with radish pudding and Chinese sausage is an intriguing combination ($7.50). The quickly cooked shrimp is also flavored with ginger, onions and peppers. The radish pudding is gummy but tasty, and the lean Chinese sausage is a nice contrast to the sweet shrimp. Deep-fried oysters, almost like tempura, are crunchy and light but lack flavor ($8.50).
 For main courses there is a good Chinese-style roasted duck with a sweet layer of skin and an undercoating of fat. It comes with rape ($16, $30). Veal shank is moist and full flavored in its tomato-and-onion sauce with slices of toasty polenta ($14, $26).
And fusilli tossed with white beans, herbs and tomato is a gutsy combination ($7, $12.50).
 Onda (430 Broome Street, at Crosby Street, in Manhattan) serves lunch from noon to 3 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner from 6 to 11 P.M. daily; brunch noon to 4 P.M. Saturday and Sunday. Mastercard and Visa are accepted.
Alcohol is not served pending approval of a liquor license. Telephone: (212) 925-4743.
 
An Appointment
 Alain Sailhac has been named director of culinary arts, which is the highest teaching position at the French Culinary Institute, the professional cooking school in SoHo.
Mr. Sailhac, best known for his nine-year tenure as chef at Le Cirque, has also been chef at Le Cygne, the "21" Club and the Plaza Hotel.

HEADLINE: Chamorro at Managua Helm: Beloved but Also Under Fire

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, April 11

 BODY:
As she winds up her first year in office, President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro finds herself widely loved personally but with her Government besieged on all sides.
Labor groups affiliated with the opposition Sandinista Front have been using the freedoms they did not enjoy under their own Government "to invent new ways almost every day to go on strike, but without knowing how to distinguish between a strike and a takeover," as Mrs. Chamorro notes dryly.
 
A National Healing Process

 At the same time, there have been reports from the countryside that groups of former contras, the rebels who fought the leftist Sandinista Government for a decade with United States support, are rearming to defend themselves against what they say is repression by the army and police, still controlled by the Sandinistas. 
 Finally, the country's pro-private-enterprise groups, which led the opposition to the Sandinista Front during its nearly 11 years in power and played a major role in Mrs. Chamorro's dramatic election victory over the Sandinista Front, are dissatisfied with the slow pace of economic recovery and are angry over her retention of Gen. Humberto Ortega Saavedra, a Sandinista, as head of the army.
Mrs. Chamorro knows the divisiveness that came with the Sandinistas' Marxist revolution; two of her four children backed it and two opposed it. She takes the view that she is presiding over a national healing process and that more time is needed for everything to come together.
She treats the nation of 3.5 million people in a motherly way, calls ministers and advisers "my love," and has brought back into style the Spanish honorifics Don and Dona. Everybody calls her Dona Violeta.
"I know many people don't like the Sandinistas," she said in an interview. "But they have to accept that the Sandinistas are Nicaraguans and are going to live here too."
 
A Visit to Washington
 Although the Bush Administration shares the dismay of many of Mrs. Chamorro's supporters over her continued backing of General Ortega and would like to see her confront the Sandinistas more decisively, on Monday she is to begin an official visit to Washington that includes a state dinner at the White House and an address to a joint meeting of Congress.
Mrs. Chamorro, tall, silver haired and 61 years old, was thrust into revolutionary tumult after the her husband, a crusading newspaper editor named Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, was killed in January 1978. Although the assassination was never traced to the Government of Anastasio Somoza Debayle, the killing was the spark that set off the insurrection that ended the Somoza dictatorship and brought the Sandinistas to power.
When the new Government was formed in 1979, Mrs. Chamorro served on the governing junta presided over by Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the Sandinista whom she defeated last year and brother of the army chief. But she soon resigned from the junta and became a critic of the Sandinistas.
Ten years later, under the pressure of rapid change in the Soviet bloc and growing internal dissatisfaction, the Sandinistas called free elections, and Mrs. Chamorro emerged as the only candidate who could unite the disparate opposition forces. On April 25 she will complete her first year as President.
 
The 'De Facto President'
 Admittedly a political novice, she is surrounded by a small group of ambitious young men, led by one of her sons-in-law, Antonio Lacayo. Officially Minister of the Presidency, Mr. Lacayo is called the "de facto President" by others in the Government. Also of importance is Alfredo Cesar, president of the National Assembly.
Defending her Government from accusations that it has acted too slowly to reduce inflation and impose a market economy, Mrs. Chamorro said the circumstances in which she inherited the country left her no choice but to deal with matters of war and peace during her first year and only now turn to the economy.
She said her decision to keep General Ortega at the head of the army had been necessary to tame the "wounded tiger" that the Sandinista Front became after its electoral defeat.
"I believe the Sandinista Front now accepts that it lost the election," she said. "But it hasn't been easy for them to do that."
Part of the deal in which General Ortega kept the army command required him to reduce the size of the army drastically. Mrs. Chamorro also won the pledge of some 20,000 former contras to lay down their arms in return for promises of land and temporary assistance.
 
Size of Army Reduced
 Mr. Cesar said it would not have been politically possible for Mrs. Chamorro to change the army leadership while at the same time cutting the size of an army indoctrinated with Sandinista thinking. The Government says the conscript army has been cut from 90,000 to 28,000 and the officer corps from 15,000 to 10,000.
"Once the difficult stages are over, President Chamorro will change the leadership of the army," Mr. Cesar said.
But Ramiro Gurdian, president of a farmers' organization and a decadelong opponent of the Sandinistas, charged that Mr. Lacayo negotiates almost daily with the Sandinista Front on virtually everything the Government wants to do and that the Sandinistas often renege on their promises to him.
He said, for example, that he liked the Government's free-market economic policies, but that the Sandinistas were frustrating them by using the army and police to continue to take over farms and to avoid returning confiscated businesses to private owners.
"The fact is that nothing is done in this country without the approval of the Sandinista Front," he said. "Antonio Lacayo dedicates all of his time to the Sandinista Front and has no time for other things."
 
'Part of Our Culture'
 Mr. Lacayo countered that he talks less with Sandinista leaders than President Bush talks with Democratic leaders, but said it "may be more frequently than is the norm in Latin America for Government leaders to talk with the opposition."
"We think we have to begin to move away from the Nicaraguan attitude that he who is in power is the one who orders and arranges, is the owner of life and wealth, and the other person has no right to express an opinion," he said. "The thinking has traditionally meant that if that person does express an opinion he should be taken prisoner, as Somoza did and Daniel Ortega did."
"That wasn't the discovery of Somoza or of Daniel," he said. "That comes from the last century. It's part of our culture."
Foreign Minister Enrique Dreyfus, who served time in jail in 1981 and 1982 as leader of a business group that criticized the Sandinista Government, argued that the continued influence of the Sandinistas over the army here was not substantially different from the situation in Chile and El Salvador, where elected presidents must tread carefully in dealing with powerful armies.
Acknowledging that the Chamorro Government still faced major challenges in repairing the economy and keeping the peace, Mr. Dreyfus said that "there may be chaos here, but no political prisoners."
 
More Civil Liberties
 Indeed, it is generally accepted that Nicaraguans are enjoying more civil liberties now than possibly at any other time in their history. In addition to broad freedoms of press and expression, the country has its first-ever elected municipal authorities.
"But you can't eat freedom of expression," Mr. Gurdian said. "People are hungry here. The G.N.P. fell 5.7 percent last year, and she did nothing on the economy."
"It's been difficult to criticize her because she's a lady," he added, "but we have to stop thinking of her as a woman -- she's the President of Nicaragua."

HEADLINE: John Humpstone, 86, Real Estate Executive

 BODY:
John H. Humpstone, a real estate executive and former Foreign Service official, died yesterday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 86 years old.
He died of cardiorespiratory failure, said his son Charles. 
 Mr. Humpstone, who lived in Washington, was assistant to the president of Previews Inc., an international real estate clearing house, from 1956 until he retired in 1968.
He joined the company in 1954 after serving with the Economic Cooperation Administration in Europe. Earlier, after receiving a degree from Williams College in 1926, Mr. Humpstone worked in banking and construction in Manhattan before joining the Glen L. Martin Aircraft company in Baltimore as project administrator in 1940.
He is survived by his wife, the former Maribel Cheney; two sons, Charles, a lawyer, of South Woodstock, Vt., and John Jr., a retired business executive of Locust Valley, L.I.; a sister, Nancy Gardiner of Hightstown, N.J., five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Nemuro Journal;
Kaese! Japanese Refugees Fight to Reclaim Islands

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEMURO, Japan, April 10

 BODY:
Mitsuo Yanami still remembers well the day in early September 1945, hours after Japan's unconditional surrender aboard the battleship Missouri, when Soviet soldiers overran the tiny island where he lived, just north of here in the frigid northern Pacific.
"We were shocked," recalled Mr. Yanami, who was 17 years old at the time. "At first we thought they were Americans. After all, the Americans had just won the war, and we didn't even know the Soviet Union was one of the Allies. But then we overheard them talking about Stalin." 
 The Soviets took the last of the islands a day after Japan's formal surrender, expelling Mr. Yanami and 17,384 other residents -- the Japanese are nothing if not precise, and they have accounted for everyone -- and leaving behind a legacy of bitterness that the Government maintains is shared by all of Japan.
On Tuesday, building on a four-decade-long public relations campaign, the aging refugees of the islands off Japan's northern coast see one great chance to win their Northern Territories back: the arrival of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the first Soviet leader ever to visit Japan.
 
Soviets Seek Japan's Help
 The 46-year-old occupation of the islands -- Etorofu (which the Soviets call Iturup), Kunashiri (Kunashir), Shikotan and the Habomai group -- has turned into something of a national obsession in Japan, an obsession fed by influential right-wing groups, powerful fishing organizations and the former islanders themselves. For years this fast-declining fishing town has been dotted with signboards with the rallying cry "Kaese!" -- "Give them back!" -- and the Government has made it clear that a give-back will be the price next week if Mr. Gorbachev wants billions of dollars of Japanese consumer goods, technology for Soviet factories and Japanese-financed oil exploration in Siberia.
It is a price that many Japanese officials suspect Mr. Gorbachev will be unable or unwilling to pay. Yet here in Nemuro, the former islanders who live within sight of their old homeland -- the closest island is only two miles away -- are spending their days spreading and dashing rumors of a secret deal in the works.
For several weeks hopes have risen on reports that Japan may be prepared to pay upwards of $28 billion, masked as economic aid, to regain sovereignty over the islands. That comes to roughly $22,680 an acre for one of the world's most remote, ice-blocked and inhospitable corners. Then the other day a Japanese newspaper quoted the Soviet Defense Minister, Dmitri T. Yazov, as saying there would be absolutely no deal.
Mr. Gorbachev's staff also tried to reduce expectations as they arrived in Tokyo this week. "This is a problem that has gone on for a hundred years," said Vitaly N. Ignatenko, Mr. Gorbachev's spokesman. "It will not be solved overnight."
 
Nasty Battles Brewing
 Even though it is hard to find anyone here under the age of 70 who says he is actually willing to move back to the islands, nasty battles are already brewing as Japanese families jostle for long-lost property rights.
Mr. Gorbachev may well offer to acknowledge Japanese sovereignty over two of the islands closest to Japanese shores and promise to talk about the other two, a deal that the Soviets briefly put forward and Japan rejected a quarter-century ago. Taking an uncharacteristically hard-line stance, Japan's Foreign Ministry has left little room for such compromises, saying that for the visit to be a success Mr. Gorbachev must now recognize Japan's claim to all four -- even if the actual turnover takes years.
No one can quite explain why the issue has such an emotional appeal for Japan, save for the fact that the Japanese are inculcated from childhood that they live in a small country with no land to spare. When foreigners suggest that the loss of the islands was a relatively small price for Japan to pay for its colonial forays into Korea, Manchuria and vast stretches of Southeast Asia, islanders here respond with cold stares.
 
U.S. Is Blamed Too
 "Certainly Japan was responsible for starting the war," Mitsuo Takaiwa, a prosperous-looking former fisherman. But, he said, the Soviets are more to blame for exploiting Japan's helplessness in the last days of the war, in violation of a nonaggression pact between the two nations. "The U.S. is responsible, too," he said, "for allowing the Soviet Union to do that."
More than 9,000 fishermen have been detained by the Soviets for poaching in the island waters, and fishing seems to be one major reason Japan wants the territory back. The area around Nemuro was harvested to the point of depletion, and major fisheries stand to gain millions of dollars if the islands come back.
But the people of Nemuro say they do not want to kick out the 20,000 to 30,000 Soviet citizens now living on the disputed territory, a figure that includes a large number of military personnel. "I think it may be possible to live together," says Hirotoshi Kawata, a 56-year-old city official who remembers befriending a soldier named Aleksei who was part of the invading party.
But for the 11,000 surviving islanders, the war will not really be over until the islands are repatriated.
"The islands were rich when I was there, and I have always dreamed of returning," Shoji Ashizaki, who once lived on the Habomais. "We Japanese know we can make them rich again."

Many see next week's visit to Japan by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev as an opportunity to regain the territories. (David E. Sanger/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Has Broad Advance; Price of Gold Moves Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced worldwide yesterday in erratic trading despite new economic data that were widely interpreted as setting the stage for a lowering of American interest rates.
Gold prices were mostly lower. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $361.30 an ounce, off $1.60 from Thursday. The Republic National Bank said gold fell $2.40 an ounce, to a late bid of $359.50. 
 The Labor Department reported that consumer prices fell one-tenth of 1 percent in March, the first decline in five years, as energy costs continued to fall and price increases for other goods moderated.
The favorable news on inflation, coupled with signs that the recession is holding on, prompted much speculation that the Federal Reserve would move to cut interest rates.
Lower interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less valuable for investors.
The dollar initially fell on the report, but within minutes the currency was in demand, said David Ogg, a vice president at Credit Suisse.
Trading was volatile worldwide, reflecting general nervousness about the dollar's direction and the inclination among traders to seek quick profits, dealers said.
The dollar's advance was supported when the Federal Reserve later drained reserves from the banking system, a move interpreted by many economists as a clear signal that the Fed is not yet ready to push rates lower.
"The dollar showed a lot of strength," especially when it became apparent that interest rates would not be cut, said John Marchese, chief economist at Pegasus Econometrics Group in Hoboken, N.J.
Some people in the markets say the dollar, which has risen sharply during the last few months, can afford to slip a bit.
Against the German mark, the dollar rose in New York trading to 1.6880 marks, from 1.6705 on Thursday.
Also in New York, the dollar edged up to 136.40 yen, from 136.20 yen on Thursday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 135.85 yen, from 136.65 yen at Thursday's close. In London, it rose to 136.30 yen.
The British pound fell in London to $1.7775, from $1.7905 late Thursday. In New York, a pound cost $1.7725, down from Thursday's $1.7904.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.4320 Swiss francs, up from 1.4118; 5.7020 French francs, up from 5.6485; 1,252.25 Italian lire, up from 1,239.75, and 1.1509 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1506.

HEADLINE: Talks Set on Eastern Europe Aid

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, April 12

 BODY:
Eastern Europe's difficult transition from Communism to capitalism and the growing political and economic chaos in the Soviet Union are expected to be the focus when heads of state and finance ministers of more than 40 countries gather here this weekend.
At the same time, finance ministers of the Group of Seven -- the United States, Germany, Britain, France, Italy, Canada and Japan -- will gather informally on Sunday night for dinner at the official residence of the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Norman Lamont. 
 American and British officials say they expect no major decisions to be made, and they said no communique would be issued after the dinner.
 
Trade Is on Agenda

One of the issues the group is expected to discuss is the global trade talks that were brought to the brink of collapse in December by a dispute between food-exporting nations, including the United States, Canada, Australia and Argentina, and the European Community, over agricultural subsidies in Europe.
Another issue is the dollar, whose value against other major European currencies has risen by about 10 percent in the last month. Officials of the United States Treasury say they will not be unhappy if their foreign counterparts agree to try to keep the dollar from rising further.
Central bank heads from the Group of Seven are not expected to be present; the regular group meeting is set for Washington later this month.
About 30 heads of state and government will attend Monday's inauguration of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, set up a year ago to help the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe make the transition from state-run to market economies. The bank has an initial capital of $12.4 billion and the mission of encouraging the development of private business and banking institutions there.
Western delegates will expect Prime Minister Valentin S. Pavlov of the Soviet Union to outline improved conditions for Western investment in the Soviet Union, limited now by bureaucratic restrictions on repatriation of profits and currency conversion.
Jacques Attali, president-designate of the new development bank, said Thursday that about $25 trillion would probably be needed by the Soviet Union in the next 20 years. "The main portion will come from a reorganization of their own assets," he said, "but we know you cannot change overnight five centuries of command economy and bureaucracy."

HEADLINE: Long-Term Rates Decline Sharply

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Bond prices surged and long-term interest rates fell sharply yesterday, as traders bought securities in the wake of positive evidence that the recession is finally beginning to have an impact on inflation.
Market participants began buying securities almost immediately after the Government reported that the Consumer Price Index fell by one-tenth of a percentage point last month, the first monthly decline in nearly five years. 
 Moreover, excluding food and energy prices, the "core" inflation rate rose by just one-tenth of a percentage point, well below Wall Street forecasts, and a relief from the numbing increase of seven-tenths of a percentage point recorded in February.
 
 Second Good Report

It was the second good inflation report in two days. On Thursday, the Labor Deparment reported that the Producer Price Index, excluding food and energy, rose by two-tenths of a percentage point, less than half the average for the preceding two months.
Bond traders, who are especially fearful of rising inflation because it erodes the real return of long-term securities, were further encouraged that the Federal Reserve did not respond to the good news by signalling that it had lowered short-term rates.
Around midday, hours after the inflation report was released, the Fed drained reserves from the banking system at a time when the overnight Federal funds rate was trading at 5 3/8 percent, under the 6 percent level that is still regarded as the Fed's target.
For a variety of reasons, the funds rate has traded under the 6 percent level all week. It traded as low as 5 percent yesterday.
"From my perspective, the longer they wait the better," said James R. Capra, a principal at Moore Capital Management, a money management firm.
Later on, bond prices got a further lift when a Fed governor, Wayne Angell, a staunch inflation fighter, commented that the prospects for lower inflation were promising.
Predictably, not all analysts shared the conviction that the Fed has not eased policy.
 
Policy Change Seen
 "You can't unquestionably confirm it, but I think the Fed has made a policy change," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and credit markets. "We have seen the funds rate trade below 6 percent all week, and it seems to me the Fed has orchestrated that. And a lower funds rate is certainly justified by these last two inflation numbers."
By late yesterday, the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 96 30/32, up 1 1/8 points, to yield 8.14 percent, down sharply from a yield of 8.25 percent late Thursday.
Among note issues, the 7 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered in late trading at a price of 98 18/32, up by 23/32, to yield 7.96 percent. And the 7 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 1/2, up 3/32, to yield 6.84 percent.
 
Bill Rates Down

Short-term Treasury bill rates fell.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at 5.49 percent, down three basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by five basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.75 percent.
A number of corporations took advantage of the sharp drop in bond yields to price long-term issues.
Among the issuers was the ITT Corporation, which offered $150 million worth of 30-year bonds through an underwriting syndicate led by Salomon Brothers. The 9.5 percent bonds, which mature April 15, 2021, were priced at $98.925, to yield 9.61 percent, 1.40 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds at the time of pricing.
The securities, which are noncallable for 10 years, are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A-plus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
