HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Post 0.1% Drop

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12

 BODY:
Consumer prices edged down in March, for the first monthly decline since early 1986, the Government reported today.
It was the second encouraging inflation report in two days. On Thursday, the Government reported that producer prices fell for the fourth straight month. 
 Tumbling oil prices were the main factor in the overall price decline of one-tenth of 1 percent, but even when the wide-swinging energy and food components were excluded, the Consumer Price Index rose a scant one-tenth of 1 percent after two months of sharp advances.
 
 Reassurance on Inflation

The results, which were better than expected, provided what many analysts said was reassurance that inflation was being kept in check, reassurance they said the Federal Reserve needed to relax monetary policy another notch. This would presumably drive interest rates down again, thereby speeding economic recovery.
There was quick reaction in the credit markets, with bond prices surging and long-term interest rates falling sharply. And the report helped lift stocks, too, as the Dow industrials gained 15.34, to 2,920.79. [Page 40.]
"It took the pressure off the Fed," said Alan C. Lerner, a senior economist at the Bankers Trust Company. The central bank, he said, can now move to shore up the weak economy without losing credibility as an inflation fighter.
 
 Some Aberrations Seen

And Marilyn Schaja, an analyst for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said, "The data suggest that the past two months' statistics were aberrations and that inflation is under control."
Yet the figures, which showed inflation running at a modest 2.4 percent annual pace for the year's first three months, do not mean that the risk of serious inflation has been eliminated.
"Core" prices, which do not count food and energy, still climbed at a 6.8 percent annual rate for the three months ended in March, up from 3.8 percent in the December quarter and 6 percent in the quarter ended last September, other analysts noted.
To some extent, said Patrick C. Jackman, a Labor Department supervisor responsible for consumer price data, the index magnified price pressures early in the year and probably understated them in March. He predicted that core inflation for the year would be about the same as the 5.2 percent posted in 1990.
"The recession will not have that much effect," Mr. Jackman said.
The March core rate was the best since December 1982, when interest rates were plummeting and the index's housing component was calculated differently from the way it is now. The overall index had not shown a decline since those of February, March and April 1986, when oil prices were collapsing because of production increases by Saudi Arabia.
 
 Producer Prices Off

On Thursday, the Commerce Department reported that prices received by producers for finished goods fell three-tenths of 1 percent in March, the fourth straight decline. The core producer index rose two-tenths of 1 percent, only half as much as in February.
Today's report of subdued consumer inflation, some analysts noted, reflected the current recession -- and the slack demand that characterizes it -- but the data also gave some encouragement about a recovery.
"As the inflation rate goes down, the real value of incomes rise, which translates into stronger demand," said Gordon Richards, an economist for the National Association of Manufacturers. "At the same time, as inflationary expectations decline, this should facilitate a decline in long-term interest rates."
The Federal Reserve exerts some control over short-term rates, but long-term rates, a key to corporate investment and thus to business expansion, are determined by the market.
 
 Big Decline in Energy

Today's report showed a 5 percent drop in the price of petroleum-based energy, which is now 18 percent below its November peak. Sharp drops in the price of apparel and out-of-town lodging also contributed heavily to the overall decline.
Food prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent last month after falling five-tenths in February, mainly reflecting a sharp upturn for fruits and vegetables. The price of bananas jumped 18.6 percent, partly because of reduced supplies and partly because consumers were buying them instead of oranges, which have shown price increases of 57.8 percent this year, including another 5 percent last month, the department said.
The price of housing, the most heavily weighted element in the index, rose just one-tenth of 1 percent in March after a rise of five-tenths in February. Cable television fees jumped 1.8 percent.
The transportation component dropped 1 percent, the third straight decline of this magnitude, reflecting a 4.9 percent drop in gasoline prices and declines for used cars, automobile parts and equipment and automobile finance charges. Airline fares fell 2.5 percent, partly offsetting a 14 percent increase during the preceding six months.
 
 Decline in Apparel

Apparel fell 1.2 percent after two big increases that reflected earlier-than-usual introductions of spring wear, the department said.
Medical care rose six-tenths of 1 percent, to a level 9.5 percent above that of March 1990. Big increases were also posted for reading materials, tobacco products, legal and financial services and funeral costs.
Before rounding, the index covering all urban consumers fell 0.0740192, a rate that if sustained and compounded for 12 months would produce an annual rate of price decline of nine-tenths of 1 percent. The index stands at 135, which means that a group of goods and services that cost $10 in 1982-84 now costs $13.50.
Services, which account for nearly 55 percent of the index, rose two-tenths of 1 percent, while commodities, with just over 45 percent, fell four-tenths.
Among the five metropolitan areas for which figures are collected monthly, prices eased one-tenth of 1 percent in New York and Los Angeles while rising modestly in Philadelphia and San Francisco and by five-tenths of 1 percent in Chicago.
An alternate index covering urban wage earners and clerical workers also edged down one-tenth of 1 percent last month.
The regular index's 2.4 percent annual rate of increase in the first quarter was the slowest since the third quarter of 1986, a pace far below the 6.1 percent rate recorded in 1990.
Commodities not including food and energy climbed at a 7.9 percent pace during the latest quarter, up from 3.4 percent last year.

HEADLINE: Earnings Plunge At I.B.M.

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
Stung by declining sales across almost its entire hardware product line, I.B.M. said yesterday that its operating earnings plunged 48.7 percent in the first quarter of 1991 and revenue fell 4.5 percent.
The computer maker, which is based in Armonk, N.Y., sent its stock into a tailspin last month after warning Wall Street analysts that first-quarter results would fall 50 percent short of its quarterly results a year ago. Most I.B.M. watchers were predicting that first-quarter earnings would be flat. 
 The stock, which had risen to $127.875 before the company's warning on earnings, tumbled $12.75 that day. Yesterday, it fell $2.125 a share to close at $108.50 on the New York Stock Exchange, where it was second on the most active list.
 
 In Line With Prediction
 The earnings results announced yesterday were generally in line with what the International Business Machines Corporation had predicted last month. But the company's poor performance raised questions for a number of financial analysts who suggested that the giant computer maker had erred in minimizing the difficulty surrounding its current shift to a new generation of mainframe computers.
For the first quarter of 1991, revenue amounted to $13.5 billion, down 4.5 percent from the previous year's $14.2 billion. Net earnings from operations for the three months amounted to $532 million in 1991, compared with $1.04 billion in 1990, or 93 cents a share, compared with $1.81 in 1990.
I.B.M. actually reported a net loss of $1.73 billion for the quarter, but that largely reflected a one-time accounting adjustment of $2.26 billion, or $3.96 a share, to take account of what the company expects it will eventually pay out in health benefits for retirees.
 
Part of Personnel Costs

The theory is that the eventual retirement health benefits of today's employees are part of a company's personnel costs and they should be charged against current profits even though the actual outlays are many years down the road. I.B.M. is one of the first of the nation's leading corporations to comply with the new accounting rule.
The company said it had double-digit revenue declines in a number of its product lines, including both mainframe and personal computers. The company's rapidly growing RS/6000 work station line, introduced last April, was the one positive factor in the hardware sales. But an I.B.M. spokesman said sales of those models had also been disappointing during the first quarter.
"It looks like it could get worse before it gets better," said Steven Smith, a financial analyst at Paine Webber.
Sales of computer hardware declined 17.2 percent worldwide in the quarter over the corresponding three months last year. In Europe, sales of computers were still slightly positive for the quarter, analysts said. But after subtracting for the effect of the dollar, sales also declined there.
"There was one aspect that was truly stunning," said Marc G. Schulman, an analyst at UBS Securities. "I.B.M. indicated that its PC revenues declined as much as its overall equipment revenues. I have to conclude that there is a slowing of the PC market worldwide."
Both software sales and support services, however, increased substantially in the quarter. Revenue from services grew 18.9 percent, while software sales rose 13.9 percent.
 
Confidence Shaken

The unusual weakness of I.B.M.'s first quarter seemed to shake the confidence of a number of analysts who said they were considering further rollbacks in their annual earnings estimates, lowering their forecasts significantly below last year's $10.51 a share.
The company gave no indication that it expected any significant financial improvement until the international economy improved. In a statement, I.B.M.'s chairman, John F. Akers, said, "The worldwide economic slowdown has created an uncertain and difficult business environment." He added that he believed the strength of I.B.M.'s product line would permit the company to revive quickly once the economy improved.
I.B.M. said in March that it planned to reduce worldwide employment by 14,000, or 3.8 percent, this year, but the company said yesterday that the employee cuts would not have a financial effect on the first quarter or the rest of the year.
 
No Layoffs Planned

I.B.M. shed 4,000 employees after the sale of the company's office equipment division last month. An additional 10,000 employees will be reduced through attrition. No layoffs are planned but I.B.M. will try to persuade employees to leave by offering early retirement and voluntary resignation incentives.
Several analysts said they believed that while the company has been attributing its earnings decline exclusively to the world economic climate, its product offerings may be causing it more difficulty than it is willing to acknowledge.
"They continue to blame the entire shortfall on the worldwide economy and I think that's hurting their position," said John B. Jones, Jr., an analyst at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. "The survey data we have show that mainframe sales have fallen off dramatically." Earnings from mainframes make up more than half of I.B.M.'s total profits.
Mr. Jones suggested that a significant revenue decline was attributable to the delay in introduction of the most powerful members of I.B.M.'s new System/390 mainframe family. While it is now shipping air-cooled versions of the new computers, the most powerful high-speed water-cooled machines will not be available for sale until the third quarter, pushing significant revenues toward the end of the year.
An I.B.M. official disputed the suggestion that the company might be suffering the effects of a product introduction delay. He restated that the company believed its revenues were being depressed by a worldwide economic recession.
"I.B.M.'s plan for the first half of the year says flat to down," said Rick Martin, an analyst at Prudential Securities. "That sounds like transition to me."
In the market for personal computers, which is a small but growing part of I.B.M.'s business, representing less than a fifth of its sales, Mr. Martin said that the industry had been seeing rather weak growth for the last three or four quarters and that that trend had now been compounded because the average selling price peaked last year and had now started to decline.
I.B.M. is particularly vulnerable to large-scale trends because it is the only personal computer maker that has products at every level, from cheap home personal computers to some of the largest and fastest machines that act as storage systems in office networks.

HEADLINE: SALES-TAX FUNDS DECLINE BY 8.4% IN NEW YORK CITY

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
Sales-tax collections in New York City dropped sharply over the winter, according to figures released yesterday, raising new alarms about the city's economy, and forcing city officials to scramble to close a new gap of several hundred million in the city's current budget.
"New York City's economy is in free fall," said James W. Wetzler, the New York State Commissioner of Taxation and Finance. "Whether it will continue is a matter of speculation." 
 Mr. Wetzler, who released the figures, said the first accounting of sales-tax collections for the quarter beginning in December, including the peak of the Christmas shopping season, showed that New York City sales-tax revenue fell by $55 million or 8.4 percent over the previous winter, suggesting a deep decline in local retailing.
 
'Not Seeing Any Light'
 Since then New York City retailers have reported no signs of a turnaround. The sales-tax figures, coupled with a recent $90 million drop in income-tax withholding in the city below the level forecast, suggests that the deep recession here could be getting worse, even as economists predict a turnaround in other parts of the country.
"We are not seeing any light at the end of the tunnel," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
City officials, who had been in the midst of a methodical review of proposals to close a $3 billion gap in the $29 billion budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1, immediately shifted their attention to a search for extraordinary measures simply to keep this year's budget in balance in the remaining 11 weeks of the current fiscal year.
Among other measures, city officials are considering closing down portions of the government and furloughing city workers, deferring wages of city employees and asking the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation to step in and provide the city with surplus funds. Such measures have been questioned in the past by the city's two bond-rating agencies.
"It is very difficult to cut the budget at this late stage in the year," said Norman Steisel, the first deputy mayor. "We have to turn a lot of buckets upside down."
Mr. Steisel said that the decline in income- and sales-tax collections alone would create a gap of $200 million in the current year. He suggested that the gap could be even worse but would not provide details.
Other officials noted that with $1.6 billion more in income and sales taxes due before the end of the fiscal year, tax receipts could fall further. And with the poor economic news likely to lead to higher welfare and Medicaid costs they said the city's budget gap could increase to $300 million this year, even after using a $150 million reserve fund in the current financial plan.
This could require a virtual halt in new hiring -- except for police officers, correction officers and teachers -- and a suspension of all but the most essential city purchases, and even this would not suffice, city officials said.
The Dinkins administration has begun seeking concessions from municipal unions in order to avert layoffs and deep service cuts in the next fiscal year. In the last few days, city officials began calling union leaders and apprising them of the worsening fiscal news in preparation for intensified negotiations.
The union leaders in turn have refused to consider concessions, questioned whether any were needed and demanded that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo intercede to help the city find cash to balance the budget. Governor Cuomo has insisted that the unions make concessions first.
In a measure of the nervousness over the worsening situation, city officials who met with Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday reported that the Mayor, known for his non-confrontational style, was growing increasingly piqued at the Governor and the State Legislature.
"The Mayor is getting increasingly frustrated with the whole scene in Albany and at the posturing of the Governor, even though the posturing is a part of an effort to be helpful to the city," said one city official, who insisted on anonymity.
Yesterday, Stanley Hill, the executive director of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State County and Municipal Employees, said that city officials apprised him of the declining tax receipts and called a meeting for next Tuesday, but said that union leaders were unwilling to make concessions.
 
Retailing Picks Up Elsewhere
 Mr. Wetzler said that the deep decline in sales taxes reflected a weakness in the economy, with Nassau and Suffolk Counties reporting lesser declines in tax revenue, of about 3 percent; Westchester County showing a tiny increase, and New York City the weakest of all.
He said that out of the 8.4 percent decline in the city, six percentage points were clearly the result of a falloff in sales, while the remaining percentage points appeared to result from more technical, if equally telling factors -- including the failure of several large well-known and financially troubled retailers to file quarterly sales-tax payments on time.
With the end of the Persian Gulf war, retailing has picked up in other parts of the country, and has been seen as an early sign of the winding down of the national recession.
But the falloff in income-tax witholding in the city in March suggests the opposite is happening here, though analysts say they cannot rule out the possibility that the poor results were a fluke until they review another month of data.
Mr. Ehrenhalt said that the current recession has been broader and deeper than the other recessions in the last decade, making it exceedingly difficult for economists to forecast when it might end in New York City. "The forecasts have not been very good," he said, "because there are a lot of surprises, a lot of jokers in the deck."
As a measure of the problems in retailing, he noted that of the 100,000 jobs lost in the city since the recession began in September 1989, about 37,000 were lost in the retail and wholesale trade.

HEADLINE: As Bases Are Closed, Some Towns Transform Setback Into Advantage

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12

 BODY:
What happened to the 86 military installations that the Department of Defense planned to close or scale back in 1988 after a bruising battle with Congress over how to reduce military costs?
One closed.
Of the major installations picked for closing, only Pease Air Force Base at Newington, N. H., has actually ceased operating. And that did not happen until April 1, when the last of 3,700 military personnel and their dependents as well as 1,000 civilian employees departed the 4,255-acre base, leaving nothing but a cold Atlantic wind to whistle down the 11,300-foot runway. 
 Most of the larger bases scheduled to close or reduce operations are steadily moving in that direction, including the Presidio, overlooking San Francisco Bay, Fort Sheridan on the shores of Lake Michigan north of Chicago and Fort Dix, N.J. Fort Dix was schedfor cutbacks two years ago but has now been scheduled to have its role as a troop training center ended.
Many smaller installations -- like isolated office buildings, housing for military families and military laboratories, which accounted for two-thirds of the marked installations -- have been phased out or have completed their reductions in personnel.
 
Completion Set for 1995
 The closings and reductions, intended to save the Pentagon $5.6 billion, began in January 1990. They are scheduled to be completed by October 1995.
Civilian workers at the installations and local businesses nearby are finding themselves caught in an economic squeeze as the Pentagon order is implemented. But at the same time, local governments and local real estate concerns are scrambling to acquire the properties, hoping that they, like many others who previously have felt the impact of military belt-tightening, can turn adversity into advantage.
Also, for every community that looses troops and, by extension, money, another gains. For example, communities in South Carolina, Kentucky and Missouri stand to profit from the shifting of Fort Dix's troop training operations to bases in those states.
 
Plans to Meet the Schedule
 The pace of the closings and reductions ordered in 1988 has not moved more rapidly, military and Congressional officials say, because of time-consuming logistical details, not foot-dragging. Not only must uniformed personnel and major pieces of equipment be transferred to new bases but equipment and other material left behind must be disposed of safely. That includes dangerous toxics and military refuse that have accumulated over the years in various base dumps and pits.
"The task will be completed, on time, and there's no stopping it," said Glenn Flood, a Pentagon spokesman. "But there are a great many details involved, particularly in shutting down a large base and making sure a safe environment is left."
A study conducted in early 1990 by the Pentagon's Office of Economic Adjustment of 100 base closings over the past 30 years found that the net effect was often positive over the long term, despite initial short-term economic pain.
 
Civilian Employment Improved
 Three-fourths of the closed installations were acquired at minimal cost by local governments or private business and were converted to office and industrial parks or were used to house educational institutions. Many of the air bases became municipal airports.
In the end, the study found, civilian employment on the former military sites climbed more than 50 percent above what it had been when the Pentagon was running things.
Many of the community recovery efforts the study found in earlier closings are under way at bases being closed or reduced in size under the 1988 order. For example, several Southern California communities near George Air Force Base, east of Los Angeles, already are competing to acquire that installation, hoping to turn it into a commercial airport that will improve the region's economy.
"The history of base closings has been that many communities often prosper in the long run, though jobs and income are lost at first," said Andrew A. Feinstein, a base specialist on the staff of the House Subcommittee on Military Installations and Facilities. "Many bases have excellent buildings and roads and other infastructure that can be turned around for community use. When the Government surrenders the bases, the cost to the buyer is usually minimal, or maybe even nil if the buyer is a local government."
 
U.S. Agencies Get First Choice
 Initially, a base bein closed is offered to any other Federal agency, including another branch of the armed services, that can make a case that it needs the land and buildings.
In the case of the Presidio, which sits on one of the most spectacular pieces of real estate in the country, an agreement has been reached to incorporate the site in the Golden Gate National Recreation Area.
If no other Federal agency seeks a closed base from the Pentagon, the property can be sought by state and local agencies and governments, as in the case of George Air Force Base. If there is no state or local government interest in the property, it can be sold to private interests like a developer.
"No matter who gets the property in the end," Mr. Feinstein said, "the Federal Government hardly ever recovers its original investment in land and buildings."

GRAPHIC: Chart: COUNTDOWN TO SHUTDOWN
Twelve dates in the base closing process
 
April-June -- The Defense Base Closure Realignment Commision holds public hearings on Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's proposals.
 
July 1 -- The Commision sends its recommendations to the President.
 
July 15 -- Deadline for the President to either accept the list, reject it, or return it to the commision for revision. If he rejects it, the process stops. If he returns it, the commision has four more weeks to revise the list to satisfy the White House. Once the President approves the list, he sends it to Congress, which has 45 legislative days to reject it before it takes effect. Congress cannot modify the list. If Congress rejects the plan, no bases will be closed.
 
Aug. 15 -- Deadline for the commision to submit a new report, if the President disapproves the first one.
 
Sept. 1 -- Deadline for President to approve or disapprove a revised commision report. If the President disapproves, no bases will be closed. If he approves, he sends it to congress for action.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

The Economy
Consumer prices edged down in March, for the first monthly decline since early 1986, the Government reported. Tumbling oil prices were the main factor in the 0.1 percent decline, but even the "core" rate rose a scant 0.1 percent after two months of sharp advances. [37.] 
 Stocks of unsold goods held by businesses fell in February while sales rose, the Commerce Department said, in a sign that inventories were being held tightly in check. [38.]
 
Companies
I.B.M. said its operating earnings plunged 48.7 percent in the quarter and revenue fell 4.5 percent. The company has been stung by declining sales across almost its entire hardware product line. I.B.M. actually reported a net loss of $1.73 billion, but that largely reflected an accounting adjustment. [37.]
RJR Nabisco has fundamental problems in its tobacco business. And the company counts heavily on cigarette revenue to help pay off its remaining debt and stem yearly earnings losses. The company's problems center on an especially sharp drop in the sales of full-price brands. [37.]
A European consortium pressed ahead with its offer to acquire Executive Life, while policy holders and other customers tried to assess their risk of losses. [37.]
The collapse of Executive Life will prod the House to try to impose Federal regulations on the insurance industry, lawmakers and their aides said. [41.]
Wells, Rich, Greene lost the $20 million Benson & Hedges account to Leo Burnett after a long battle to hang onto it. The shift is a significant blow to the agency, which helped create the brand's image as a hip cigarette when it was introduced in 1966. [37.]
Consumers Union suspended its chief financial officer, saying he had been involved in a commission-kickback scheme. [39.]
Microsoft said the F.T.C. had expanded an investigation of its competitive practices. [39.]
Many restaurants no longer accept American Express cards because the fees are too high. Consumer's World. [50.]
 
International
Germany's banks are discovering credit cards after decades of scorning them as a plastic plague threatening the nation's economic health. [37.]
When heads of state and finance ministers gather in London, the focus is expected to be on Eastern Europe's difficult transition from Communism to capitalism and the growing political and economic chaos in the Soviet Union. [38.]
 
Markets
Bond prices surged and long-term interest rates fell sharply, as traders reacted to evidence that the recession is finally having an impact on inflation. [40.]
The stock market ended the week on a strong note, with three leading indexes posting records. The Dow rose 15.34, to 2,920.79, for a gain of 24.01 for the week. [40.]
The dollar advanced worldwide in erratic trading despite new economic data widely interpreted as setting the stage for a lowering of American interest rates. [45.]
Cotton futures rallied strongly as a surge of buying erased the previous day's losses. [45.]
 
Today's Columns
The owners of closely held businesses who have planned for an orderly succession may have unwittingly set a trap, but the situation can be rectified. Your Money. [38.]
An air-conditioner that blows air over ice has been patented by a New Jersey company. High technology it's not, but the inventors see many advantages. Patents. [38.]

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 1602 words

HEADLINE: Plan to Close Bases Is Met With Protests From Affected States

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12

 BODY:
Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney faced an expected wave of Congressional protest today as he formally announced his recommendation to close 31 major military installations.
House Armed Services Committee analysts estimated that the closings would wipe out nearly 70,000 military and civilian jobs by 1997, or 3.3 percent of the 2.1 million military and civilian personnel serving in the United States. The Pentagon runs 485 installations around the country. 
 Mr. Cheney expressed understanding for the outcries by lawmakers from the 20 states affected by the move, but he said that if local opinion was allowed to prevail it would be impossible to close any bases.
"The fact is that a shrinking budget clearly requires us to make some hard choices and to establish priorities," Mr. Cheney said at a Pentagon news conference today. "We have to concentrate on unglamorous things in the future, like operations and maintenance, if we're going to maintain a combat-ready force."
The Pentagon plan, which goes to the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission for further review and action, must be approved by President Bush and Congress before taking effect.
But the plan, which hits California, Arkansas and Indiana the hardest, must first survive the lobbying efforts of members of Congress. Many denounced the plan today, while lawmakers from areas where bases will remain open praised Mr. Cheney's wisdom and claimed victory to home state voters.
"This is a terrible recommendation," said Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, where more than 5,500 employees stand to lose their jobs at England Air Force Base.
 
'Dodged a Bullet'
 "The Pentagon's recommendation is unwise, unfair and unacceptable," Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said of the plan to close Fort Devens in his home state.
In contrast, Senator Wendell H. Ford, a Kentucky Democrat, praised Mr. Cheney for sparing Fort Knox, near Louisville. "In a time of scarce defense dollars and base closures all across this country, I think Kentuckians can take heart that we dodged a bullet today," Mr. Ford said.
Arkansas would be hardest hit in percentage terms by Mr. Cheney's plan, losing 7,000 jobs, or 49 percent of its military-related employees, with the closing of Eaker Air Force Base and Fort Chafee. Indiana would lose more than 8,000 military and civilian jobs with the closing of Fort Benjamin Harrison and the Grissom Air Force Base, nearly 40 percent of its military-related personnel.
California stands to lose the most jobs, however, with nearly 27,000 military and civilian personnel who would be affected with the closing of major installations like Fort Ord, a sprawling base on valuable seaside property near Monterey. In its report, the Pentagon estimated that the shutdown of Fort Ord would result in a loss of 17.5 percent of jobs in the surrounding community.
 
Disappointment and Relief
 Representative Leon E. Panetta, Democrat of California and chairman of the House Budget Committee, said he was displeased but not surprised by the decision to close Fort Ord, which lies in his home district. "At the same time, there is a certain relief in knowing that this year, one way or another, this issue will finally be decided," he said.
As part of the plan, Mr. Cheney will also ask the commission to close 12 minor installations and reduce or realign 28 others. Mr. Cheney defended the overall reduction plan as a necessary step toward bringing the military infrastructure in line with its personnel, which he said would decline by 25 percent by 1995.
The secretary said any charges that he factored political considerations into the decision process were "goofy."
"There is nothing to be gained by a Secretary of Defense trying to play base closings for some political purpose," said Mr. Cheney, asserting that budget cuts had prompted the base closings and would force 521,000 layoffs by 1996, nearly the number of troops sent to the Persian Gulf.
 
No Partisan Protests
 Despite protests from some lawmakers today, Mr. Cheney's decisions raised little of the broader-based political protests that followed his 1990 plan to close 86 military sites. Then, Democratic lawmakers charged they were disproportionately hurt by the proposed closings, and the plan was scrapped.
The Democratic Study Group praised the recommendations as "serious and credible," and Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said the list "at first glance appears to be fair."
Analysts for Mr. Aspin's committee determined that 60 percent of the large bases to be closed were in Democratic districts and 37 percent were in Republican districts. The remaining 3 percent is accounted for in one base that straddles two districts represented by one member of each party.
But the analysts determined that when Pentagon-recommended transfers and reductions were factored in, districts represented by Democrats would absorb almost 70 percent of the personnel losses.
The recommendation to close the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard and Philadelphia Naval Station would cost Pennsylvania 20 percent of its military jobs, and some of the angriest reaction to the Cheney plan came from Representative Thomas M. Foglietta, a Democrat who represents that district.
"This is unfair and unjust," he said.
 
Spending to Save
 Senator Ernest F. Hollings, a Democrat of South Carolina, was equally blunt. "This decision just doesn't make sense," he said, criticizing Mr. Cheney's decision to include the Myrtle Beach Air Force Base on his list. "Myrtle Beach's A-10 Warthogs won the gulf war, and now the Administration is shutting them down."
Mr. Cheney estimated that the closings he had recommended would cost $5.7 billion over the next five years but save $6.5 billion over the same period. After 1998, the Pentagon estimates, reduced operating costs would save $1.7 billion each year.
"There is no question that it costs money up front," Mr. Cheney said. "It's like a large business enterprise. It costs money to save money."
Mr. Aspin predicted Congress would accept whatever the commission recommended.
The commission, an eight-member panel headed by James A. Courter, a former Republican Congressman from New Jersey, will formally receive Mr. Cheney's recommendations on Monday. The panel will then hold public hearings and review Mr. Cheney's findings, which it can amend.
The panel will send its report to the President on July 1, and Mr. Bush will have two weeks to consider the report. If he approves it, it will be sent on to Congress, which must accept or reject the entire list.
Mr. Cheney said closings were under way at 198 foreign bases, action that did not require Congressional review. He said 24 other bases abroad could be closed after further consultation with allies.
The Defense Secretary said he accepted the recommendations on closings passed on to him by the secretaries of the Army, Navy and Air Force with little alteration. He has also recommended through a separate process that reductions be made in the Army Corps of Engineers.
By law, the services are directed to choose bases for shutdown based on military value, the return on investment and the economic impact on the communities in which they are located. But Mr. Cheney stressed today that military considerations received preference.
"My first obligation as secretary is to provide for the nation's defense," he said. "And the judgments and decisions the departments, the services have made were driven first and foremost by military value, not by economic considerations, although economic factors were taken into account."
This rationale provided little comfort for several lawmakers who were headed to their home districts today with a vow to fight for their local bases.
"It is important to understand that the Secretary of Defense's recommendation for base closings is only the first step in the process," said Senator Sam Nunn, a Georgia Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee. Moody Air Force Base in Valdosta, Ga., is on the Cheney list and would lose 3,800 employees.
Mr. Nunn said he would lobby to retain Moody and was "puzzled" by the Air Force's decision to include it on the list.
Senator Dan Coats, Republican of Indiana, while noting it would be "hypocritical" to welcome base closings everywhere but in his state, criticized the decision to close two installations and shrink two other minor facilities. More than 8,000 military and civilian employees would be affected, according to the Pentagon.
"This is a difficult proposal to swallow," Senator Coats said.
 
Citing Roles in Gulf War
 Most lawmakers representing regions affected by Mr. Cheney's announcement cited the districts' contributions to the Persian Gulf war as a reason to keep the bases open.
Mr. Kennedy cited Fort Devens's role in the conflict and accused the Pentagon of violating the 1988 base closing commission's recommendation to keep the base open.
"I regard today's action as a serious breach of faith by the Administration in its dealings with Congress," Mr. Kennedy said.
Mr. Cheney, who said he has entertained a stream of phone calls and visits from lawmakers in anticipation of the base closing announcements, said he has "enormous sympathy" for the affected communities.
But he rejected arguments that it would be more costly to close down facilities than to leave them open.
"Under that rationale," he said, "the solution for my budget problems is to open bases all over America."

HEADLINE: Labels That Tell the Testing Story

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
Opponents of animal testing are urging companies that do not use animals in testing new products to say so on product packages.
Two national groups are involved in the effort, the Humane Society and People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, known as PETA. The groups have somewhat different philosphies: PETA, for example, is a vegetarian organization; the Humane Society is not. But both groups hope to end all use of animals in tests of cosmetics and other personal-care products. 
The labels show drawings of rabbits, an animal used frequently to test cosmetics, and either say or convey by image the fact that animals have not been used to test the product.
Some manufacturers use tests on animals to make sure that a product is safe. For example, a sample of a new product may be placed in the eye of a rabbit to see whether it produces irritability and if, so how much. Sometimes a product is fed to an animal to see how large a dose is poisonous.
In recent years, opponents of such testing have argued that alternatives to the use of animals exist. And some companies have replaced animal experiments with other tests that use tissue cultures or computer models.
Thus far, the labeling campaigns, which began last year, are proving a mixed success. Several corporations such as the Body Shop and Tom's of Maine have started labeling their products with anti-animal testing certifications from PETA or the Humane Society.
But though some major cosmetics producers such as Avon Products Inc. and Revlon Group Inc. have stopped animal testing, they have decided not to label their products.
"We are not using the fact that we are not testing on animals as a marketing tool," said Elaine Benvenuto, a spokeswoman for Avon. Dan Moriarty, a spokesman for Revlon, said that company does not use endorsements or certifications from outside groups in marketing products.
 
Health and Safety
 Some comestics industry executives oppose to an end to animal testing, asserting that it remains a vital safeguard, particularly where the testing of new product ingredients is concerned.
"For ingredients already in use, some companies can rely wholly on existing data and the judgments of scientists and non-animal tests," said Irene Melbin, a spokeswoman for the Cosmetic, Toiletry and Fragrance Association, a trade group in Washington. "But for products formulated from new ingredients, you can't abandon animal testing and assure human health and safety."
PETA opposes animal testing for any reasons and is also against the use of animal byproducts in commerical products, said Kathy Snow Guillermo, a spokeswoman for the Group.
For its part, the Humane Society does not oppose drug testing involving animals or the use of animal parts as product ingredients. "If you are going to eat the animal, you might as well be using all the animal," said Ms. Mitternight.
The groups also use somewhat differing criteria to determine whether a company will get to use its label. If a company wants to use its label, PETA requires that the company's suppliers of ingredients also not test on animals. That is a requirement that the Humane Society does not make.
The PETA label is used by about 30 companies, who are charged from $100 to $1,000 for its use; the Humane Society, whose label is used by 26 companies, charges up to several thousand dollars, said Ms. Mitterwald, who declined to provide a specific cost range.
Many companies that use the labels sell their goods principally through health food stores, drug stores and supermarkets. Some companies choose to advertise that their products do not use ingredients tested on animals but do not use either group's label.
Although many large corporations have jumped on the environmental marketing bandwagon, most larger cosmetics companies are taking a wait-and-see approach before using animal testing as a major marketing issue.
Part of the reason is a desire by many companies not to raise an unpleasant subject with products that often use fantasy as their strongest selling point. Revlon, for example, uses the phrase "non-animal tested formulas" in promoting it New Age Natural lines of cosmetics, but not with other lines that are also not tested on animals.
 
Pending Litigation
 The case of Carme Inc. shows some of the rancor the issue is producing. For many years, Carme operated as an independent company producing popular shampoos and other personal-care products that were not tested on animals under such labels as Biotene, Jojoba Farms, Mill Creek and Country Road.
But when Carme was acquired in 1989 by the International Research and Development Corporation, which operates laboratories in which animals are used to test the safety of pharmaceuticals, opponents of animal testing moved to organize a boycott of Carme products. International Research fought back with a lawsuit against, among others, a distributor of natural products, claiming economic interference with its business. The suit is pending.
Officials of International Research said in interviews that they have tried for eight months to get the Humane Society to act on Carme's application to use the group's label on its product, but that their efforts have been ignored.
Ms. Mitternight, the Humane Society spokesman, declined to comment on the situation.

HEADLINE: More Restaurants Are Just Saying No to American Express

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Consumers across the country are leaving home without their American Express cards because many restaurants are no longer accepting them. The fees for the card, restaurateurs say, are too high.
The restaurants include places like Jasper's in Boston, Cafe Provencal in the Chicago area and Orso in New York and Los Angeles. Most are white-linen restaurants, although others are casual. 
 "You're talking about some serious money," said Joe Allen, owner of Orso, as well as the restaurants bearing his name in New York and Paris, which also do not accept the American Express card. Orso serves moderately priced Italian food while Joe Allen serves moderately priced American food.
Diners can still charge their meals at establishments that do not take American Express, but they have to use other credit cards, like Visa or Mastercard. Many restaurants will also set up house accounts for regular customers who can then simply sign their checks.
Many of the restaurants that dropped the Amex green and gold cards say they also will not honor the Optima card, the revolving credit card issued by American Express. Executives of those restaurants say the commission charged on Optima cards is also too high, compared with the charges on Visa and Mastercard cards issued by banks and other financial institutions.
Some restaurants that now accept the American Express card are planning to stop or are considering dropping it.
According to The Nilson Report, a Los Angeles credit-card newsletter, the commission on American Express charges, also known as the discount rate, ranges from 2 1/2 percent to 5 percent of the amount charged by diners, as against 1 1/4 percent to 3 1/2 percent charged by bank cards.
 
Percentage Varies With Volume
 The percentage typically declines as the volume rises, so that the smallest restaurants pay the biggest commissions.
Still, the large rate difference between American Express on one hand and Visa or Mastercard on the other angers restaurant owners.
Many of them have long expressed resentment about the high American Express fees, but in the last year or so, the complaints have grown in volume and intensity as the recession gained strength and as Americans sharply reduced spending on dining outside the home. Restaurant owners began re-evaluating their expenses and seeking lower prices from suppliers.
When American Express refused requests to lower its fees, restaurants in Boston, Atlanta, Washington and other cities said that they were dropping the card or that they intended to do so.
"I will not carry the American Express card after April 15," said Jasper White, owner of Jasper's in Boston, an expensive American-style restaurant. "We're paying 2 percent extra, and that is on the gross, including tips and state taxes. It's not worth it to me to carry it any longer."
Officials at American Express say they are aware of the concern about the fees. But they note that American Express has been planning for a year and a half to adjust commissions and that it will announce a new fee schedule by May 1. And Norma Arnold, senior vice president for marketing, said that by focusing purely on rates, restaurants ignored other important factors in comparing cards.
"We acknowledge that we have a premium rate, but we provide extra services," she said. These include promotions like making a list of card holders available to participating establishments.
Ms. Arnold added that American Express did not charge for having the transaction approved or for some other services that restaurants pay extra for when they use bank cards.
Restaurants that dropped the American Express card are unpersuaded by this argument.
In Atlanta, Brad Saltz, chief financial officer of Houston's Restaurants, a chain of 22 moderately priced American-style establishments, said the company discontinued the American Express card last month for only one reason: the commission is higher than those of the bank cards.
In the Washington area, John Laytham, an owner of Clyde's, a group of moderately priced American-style restaurants, said, "We opened a new restaurant six weeks ago and decided not to use American Express there." His company operates seven other restaurants that do accept the card. He said the new Clyde's, in Reston, Va., "has been doing very, very well and the complaints from customers have been pretty minimal."
One of the sharpest protests against American Express was made by Cafe Provencal, a high-priced French restaurant in Evanston, Ill., that dropped the card about 11 months ago. "I decided I didn't need them as much as they needed me," said Andrew Reis, the owner.
Mr. Reis went further by posting a sign on his front door showing the American Express card with a red line through it. The sign also says: "For several reasons, including the reneging on the original commitments made to this merchant, Cafe Provencal no longer accepts the American Express card. Cafe Provencal will gladly make alternative payment arrangements with any customer who expected to pay with American Express."
Some restaurateurs who continuing to accept American Express think that the difference between its rates and those of the bank cards is too large. "They're entitled to be higher than the other guys, but are they entitled to be twice that of the other guys?" asked Richard Melman, president of Lettuce Entertain You, a chain of 30 inexpensive theme restaurants based in Chicago. "I don't think so."
In Atlanta, John Bolen, finance director of Peasant Restaurants, a chain of 18 restaurants that includes upscale and casual places, said: "I don't think most customers know that restaurants also pay a fee when a customer uses a card. We are now in some discussions with American Express about the level of their rate."
Credit cards have been used by Americans since 1915 and are now a $366 billion annual business in the United States. RAM Research, a credit-card research company, reports that more than five million establishments around the world accept Visa and Mastercard and about four million accept American Express. Experts say most holders of American Express cards also have at least one bank card.
All of these cards are used for many other purchases besides restaurant meals. But stores, theaters and mail-order companies, for example, do not seem to be voicing the same resentment against American Express's commissions.
Specialists in the credit-card field say several restaurants that considered dropping American Express over the years have hesitated because so many expense account diners use the card for business purposes. "Somebody may not want to put that purchase on their personal credit card," said Kurt T. Peters, editor of Credit Card News, a trade publication.
American Express officials say one step they will take soon will be to institute a two-tier pricing mechanism. The company plans to charge half of a percentage point less to restaurants that file credit data through electronic terminals than to those that use paper slips and imprinters. Officials say the program was successful in a test.
"We haven't raised our rates in 13 years," Ms. Arnold said. "In the Northeast particularly, we want to develop business-building strategies with restaurants."
 
Rebellion in the Northeast
 Yet it is in the Northeast, especially Boston, where the movement to drop American Express seems to be showing its greatest strength, taking on the nature of a rebellion or boycott.
A group of Boston restaurateurs met with American Express representatives on March 29, but no firm decisions about pricing were reached. Now some of the restaurant owners plan to announce whether they will accept the card on May 1, depending on what American Express does or does not do at that time.
Steve Di Fillippo, owner of three Davio's Northern Italian Restaurants, which range from informal to formal dining in the Boston area, said that more than 50 Boston restaurants would independently stop carrying the card unless the discount was cut.
"A whole city has banded together," said Mr. Di Fillippo, who has been a leader among the protesters. "If nobody takes it, how can it hurt me?"
And Lydia Shire, owner of Biba, a moderately priced American restaurant in Boston, which dropped American Express on April 1, said: "We're under a lot of pressure to be competititve. We'll take all other different forms of payment, including cash, and we'll even take a check."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Booz, Allen & Hamilton Picks New Chief Executive

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
William F. Stasior, 50, has been elected chairman and chief executive of Booz, Allen & Hamilton, the consulting firm. Mr. Stasior, the firm's president and chief operating officer, succeeds R. Michael McCullough, who will become a senior partner.
Mr. Stasior, who has spent his entire career at Booz Allen, recently started the firm's technology consulting business. As Booz Allen's sixth chairman since its founding in 1914, he will supervise 3,000 professionals in 50 cities. Mr. Stasior becomes chief executive on July 1 and chairman on Oct. 1. 
 "I'm inheriting a financially strong and sound business so I'm going to continue the agenda we began in the last couple years of globalizing our operations," Mr. Staisor said.
He said that the last year, despite the recession, was one of the firm's best in the last decade. "It was one of those years when all our business units hit home runs," especially because of rapid growth abroad, he said.
Mr. Stasior named three partners to his management team. Martin Waldenstrom became president of Booz, Allen & Hamilton Worldwide Commercial Consulting; Gary Mather, president of Booz, Allen & Hamilton Worldwide Technology Consulting, and Cyrus Freidheim, vice chairman of the firm.
Mr. Stasior joined the firm in 1967 and became a partner in 1976. He received bachelor's and master's degrees in electrical engineering from Northwestern University.
Mr. Stasior will remain in the firm's Bethesda, Md., office.

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Neighborhood Stores;
Columbia Street Tips Hat to Commerce

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
EVEN an optimist would be hard-pressed to make the case that Columbia Street in South Brooklyn will recover the commercial vibrancy it enjoyed years ago. For Destiny has dealt it a series of blows.
First came the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway in the late 1940's, dividing Brooklyn at Hicks Street and isolating the Columbia Street district. Then came the movement toward containerization in the shipping industry, which shifted waterfront activity out of South Brooklyn, mainly to New Jersey. 
 Then there was the disruption of a new city interceptor sewer built deep in the watery ground below Columbia Street. The decisive blow was the collapse of several buildings during that work, causing fatalities and widespread property condemnations and vacancies. Commerce shifted, primarily to Court Street.
But in the 80's housing development gradually led the comeback of population and property values along Columbia Street. Now there is a tentative sign of retail revival -- usually a laggard behind housing's heel.
It is showing itself currently in the fifth and final phase of a 212-unit, low-rise condominium development known as Columbia Terrace, built on land acquired from the city. The development is offering four stores for sale as retail condominiums, as well as 32 residential condominiums. Retail condominiums as part of a city-assisted low-rise condominium are a rarity.
"They may be ahead of their time on Columbia Street," said Frederick W. Hilles Jr., who certainly hopes not, since he is offering the 850-square-foot spaces for about $100 a square foot. The residential condominiums of Columbia Terrace, on the other hand, are part of the steady march of residential resurgence in the entire stretch from Atlantic Avenue to Hamilton Avenue on the harbor side of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway.
Recession has restrained the march. One sign of it is the struggle of a 70-unit converted warehouse called 63 Tiffany Place to sell half its units so that a condominium plan can be declared effective and buyers moved in. The developer, the Cuneo-Leider Management and Development Corporation, has meanwhile put two other condonominium conversion plans on hold.
The commercial side takes on a special interest because commercial projects are so unusual as part of city-assisted for-sale housing developments. Occasionally a few stores will be built in the base of a high-rise, as at the Harlem Gateway condominium built in the mid-80's opposite the northwest corner of Central Park in Manhattan. New commercial condominiums as part of a low-rise development can fairly be described as experimental.
Forcefully encouraged by Community Board 6, Mr. Hilles has become the experimenter.
"In this phase it was very much the sentiment of the community and the board that the project should offer come commercial space," said Robert Acito, district manager of Community Board 6, which covers South Brooklyn and Park Slope. "There is a vision that one day Columbia Street will recapture what it once was -- a thriving commercial street with a dense residential population."
SO Mr. Hilles has built stores at the base of four of the development's 12 three-story attached town houses. Two of the stores are in a simple freestanding brick building on Union Street, in appearance an extension of the older stores lining that commercial sidestreet. The others are at the Union and President Street corners of the residential strip along Columbia Street. These houses present their rear facade to the tree-lined block of Columbia Street between Union and President Streets. The fronts face a private common area at the interior of the property, which is entered through gates on the sidestreets. The development provides no on-site parking.
An incentive for a buyer of a store is that it qualifies, like the housing itself, for 20 years of frozen property taxes under the Section 421a tax abatement program. "Imagine a commercial owner having real estate taxes fixed at $5 or $6 a month for 20 years," said Mr. Hilles.
Frank Mattioli, for one, imagined it, liked the idea and bought the space at the Union Street corner for a showroom and storage area for his Arden Painting Corporation. He is a 38-year-old artisan who arrived from Italy in 1967 and worked in a family painting business on President Street for some years. He established his own firm three years ago and now has 14 people working for him, mainly doing specialty work in glazing, gold-leaf and marble treatments for the likes of Luciano Pavarotti and Pia Lindstrom.
"I prefer to own my own property so no one can kick me out or raise my rent," he said.
The store buyer who can afford to put in, say, $30,000 in cash for a 850-square-foot space selling for $85,000 can come away with monthly occupancy costs of about $550, Mr. Hilles said. A bank can be expected to make a loan for a store at about two-thirds of the property's value. The buyer might be an investor who rents out the space.
MR. HILLES, who is in partnership with Nicholas Lembo, a contractor and developer in Brooklyn, has developed condominiums on Columbia Street since 1984 in the four earlier phases of Columbia Terrace. They began selling for $57,000 under the Federal Section 235 program. The market proved strong enough to allow unsubsidized sales in later phases. People lined up to buy, Mr. Hilles said.
Phase 4 was sold at prices of $124,000 to $142,000, with State of New York Mortgage Agency loans. Phase 5 was put under the development auspices of the New York Housing Partnership, which makes it likely that buyers will have incomes between $36,000 and $53,000. The Partnership began taking applications in March, with occupancy expected by late summer.
Retail space in conjunction with new assisted housing usually is not possible, according to Kathryn Wylde, president of the Housing Partnership, because the obtainable rents are generally not high enough to support the cost of construction. "There is no government aid program to finance new construction of retail space," she said. "On Columbia Street it was felt that the government was responsible for destroying retail space so it ought to be rebuilt."
It is not unusual for New York City to seek out ground-floor store uses in the reconstruction of smaller city-owned buildings in retailing locations, however. Carroll Gardens Association, under the chairmanship of Salvatore Scotto, has sponsored the restoration and rental of four mixed-use buildings at Columbia and DeGraw Streets. Three of the stores have been rented out -- to a butcher, a liquor store and the owner of a street-cart vending operation. Eleven residential tenants live upstairs.
The association also expects to renovate a larger city-owned building with 24 apartments and five stores at DeGraw and Kane Streets. "We will be the largest single owner of commercial property on Columbia Street," Mr. Scott said.
At least 450 new families have come to the area as a result of conversions, rehabilitations and new construction, according to Bette Stoltz, executive director of the South Brooklyn Local Development Corporation. The conversions, in midrise warehouse buildings, provide no retail space.
THE first major conversion, at One Tiffany Place, sold out in the mid-80's at average prices of $190 a square foot, said Andrew Leider, one of the principals in the development group. Since then the sales slowdown have left it uncertain when the second 70-unit building will be able to open. Listed prices start at $157,000 for one-bedrooms and $219,000 for two-bedrooms.
Retail rents in the area run from about $6 to $8 a square foot a year, said Frank Manzione, who has a real estate office at 223 Columbia Street. "We need a pharmacy, a florist, a shoe store, a drygoods store, a liquor store, a restaurant," he said.
If they want to come, Greg O'Connell will be ready. He bought two small buildings on Columbia Street from the city 15 years ago and only recently began to renovate them.
"We've been holding them," he said. "We didn't want to be the lone wolf. But this year the industry is slow and we need work for the men, so we're renovating them." There will be a store below and three apartments above.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Frank Mattioli at Columbia Terrace, where he bought retail space. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Cryptozoologists Stalk Elusive Beasts

BYLINE: By CAROLYN BATTISTA

 BODY:
DID a sea serpent visit New Haven harbor in 1896? Do strange big cats roam Connecticut today? Where on Lake Champlain might the legendary monster Champ raise its head? And what's new with Sasquatch, the creature said to leave huge footprints across the Pacific Northwest?
Several Connecticut residents say they love trying to answer those questions. They are members of the International Society of Cryptozoology, an organization devoted to investigating what it calls "all matters related to animals of unexpected form or size or unexpected occurrence in time or space." Cryptozoology means the study of hidden animals, and the professional and amateur scientists who belong to the society study any clues they can find of Champ, Sasquatch and other notable mysteries. 
 J. Richard Greenwell, secretary of the International Society of Cryptozoology at its headquaters in Tucson, Ariz., said he has searched in African swamps for a dinosaurlike creature and in China for a wild man. Other society members, like Gary Mangiacopra of Milford, scour library stacks for accounts of unexpected animals.
Cryptozoologists note that several recognized animals once caught scientists by surprise. In 1938, for instance, Comoro Island fishermen found in their nets a strange, hideous fish that turned out to be a coelacanth, which was presumed to have been extinct for 60 million years. The megamouth shark, a new species, was discovered in 1976.
 
Generally Undaunted
 Such findings should encourage people to view cryptozoology with some seriousness, society members said. But they are used to, and generally undaunted by, other responses.
Cryptozoologists "get a lot of laughs, but they just point out that they're doing it scientifically," said Quentin Keynes, a society member from England who lives part of the year in Riverton. Mr. Keynes, a great-grandson of Charles Darwin and a nephew of the economist John Maynard Keynes, called himself a professional explorer and said he is driven by "intellectual curiosity."
Mr. Keynes makes documentary films about his travels, including one about the Comoro Islands. "I got involved in the coelacanth fish business," he said. "It's my kind of thing."
Russ Kinne, a photographer and writer in New Canaan who has made several trips to the Pacific Northwest to seek Sasquatch, joined the society when it was founded in 1982."Science, with a capital S," may not recognize the huge creatures reported, but never found, over centuries, he said. But scientists should not have the attitude that "we don't find them, so they don't exist," he said. "My bottom line is, it's worth investigating."
Jameston Deveroux of Hamden is another society members and fan of the elusive giant of the Northwest, also known as Big Foot.
"As young teens," in Oregon, "my friend and I were going to be the ones who found Big Foot," Mr. DEveroux recalled. Still fascinated by the subject, he said, he is dismayed by supermarket newspaper headlines like "Sasquatch Jumped Into a U.F.O. and Took Off With Me."
 
'Seen by 200 People'
 Mr. Mangiacopra, a graduate student in biology at Southern Connecticut State University, has spent years researching sightings of unusual water-dwelling creatures. He has unearthed old newspaper stories like that of a sea serpent reported off Lighthouse Point in New Haven on the sunny afternoon of July 19, 1896. "It was seen by 200 people, for half an hour," he said.
He said he has also corresponded with viewers of odd beasts at sea, like the captain of a fishing vessel who sent him a sketch of a 40-foot creature with a mane and bulging eyes that he said he observed in 1957 off the Grand Banks near Newfoundland. Mr. Mangiacopra has written magazine articles on such sightings and is working on a book about them.
In the late 1980's, he also traveled to Lake Champlain to join a team using sonar to determine the water's depth at places where appearances of Champ had been reported.
"Those appearances occurred where the lake was shallow," said Mr. Mangiacopra, adding that such information bolstered the reports' validity.
William Konrad, a retired electronics engineer who lives in Niantic, brought his own sonar equipment to aid the hunt for Champ. "I was only about one-third thinking that there was such a thing, but it was fun to do," said Mr. Konrad, who, although not a member of the International Society of Cryptozoology, helped write an article on the sonar tracking for the group's journal.
Mr. Mangiacopra also keeps a thick file on sightings of wild, unidentified felines in Connecticut. Those reports also intrigue Mr. Deveroux, he said, adding that as a youth in Florida he dreamed of finding the Skunk Ape that is said to stalk the Everglades. Now, he said, he's ready for the Connecticut catamount.
 
'Enormous Scientific Interest'
 "If there was a sighting in Connecticut today, I'd be up tomorrow looking for it," said Mr. Deveroux. "There are lots of things that exist that we just do not have evidence on yet."
Mr. Kinne, a nature photographer, said he will return to the Northwest in the spring to search for Sasquatch.
"I've never come out and flatly said, 'I believe these creatures exist,' " said Mr. Kinne. But, he said, "if they do exist, they're of enormous scientific interest."
Both Mr. Kinne and Mr. Keynes have studied a film that has become a sort of cryptozoology classic, shot in the 1960's by a Northwesterner who died a few years ago. It shows Sasquatch -- or some hairy, hulking creature. Both men said the film seemed legitimate.
"The film was not monkeyed with," said Mr. Keynes. "But, that's not to say it wasn't a man in a monkey suit." Still, he said, "no one has ever come forward and said, 'If you pay me $5,000, I'll tell you how I got up in the monkey suit.' "
As in most matters cryptozoological, the definitive answer remains hidden. Most of the society's 900 or so members have jobs and other responsibilities that limit their pursuits of nature's truth. The society "lives on a shoestring," said Mr. Keynes. But he has tried to help. "I've made a lot of people join," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Quentin Keynes, a member of the International Society of Cryptozoology and a professional explorer, makes documentary films about his travels. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: SoHo Hotels;
Moving Beyond the Talking Stage

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
HOTELS have been the talk of SoHo since the early 1980's. That is all they have been. Now, however, two young developers have come forward with a project at Mercer and Prince Streets that they say is fully financed and ready to begin.
Two other hotel projects that have won city approval are stalled for want of financing. One would face both West Broadway and Wooster Street, between Prince and Houston Streets. The other would be on Houston Street, between Greene and Mercer Streets. 
 Both delayed projects would be new from the ground up. In contrast, the two young developers, Andre T. Balazs and Campion A. Platt, would create their hotel out of an abandoned six-story, 103-year-old, red-brick Romanesque Revival building. The hotel, to be known as the Mercer, would have 81 rooms (including three in a new roof penthouse), a 90-seat restaurant, meeting rooms, a pharmacy and other small stores. The design team includes Harman Jablin Architects, Serge Becker and Tsao & McKown Architects, all of Manhattan.
"We plan to begin construction, probably in two weeks," said Mr. Balazs, who may be best known in New York as a partner in the M.K. nightclub on lower Fifth Avenue.
Neither he nor Mr. Platt, both of whom are in their early 30's, has ever developed a hotel before, although Mr. Balazs said they acquired the well-known Chateau Marmont hotel in Hollywood last year.
Their $33 million SoHo project is being financed by debt and equity. The lender, Mr. Balazs said, is a Japanese bank called F.A.D., which he said was "very active in home mortgages." Mr. Balazs said he and Mr. Platt are among a group of individual investors that includes a Japanese real-estate developer and financier, a Japanese retail and clothing executive, a Japanese architect and a Hong Kong hotelier.
The property was bought two years ago, for $8.2 million, from the real-estate developer Lewis Futterman. "I think he had some plans to do something along the same lines," Mr. Balazs said. "For years, it's been an obvious choice for a hotel."
One of the biggest obstacles to hotels has not been zoning, which allows them as a matter of right in SoHo, but rather local opposition. Neighbors fear that hotels would transform SoHo into an ersatz tourist district, with traffic jamming the streets and rents rising beyond the means of residents, artists and galleries.
"There is, I think, a very, very legitimate fear of the crass commercialization of SoHo," Mr. Balazs said. "It has stabilized as a legitimate business-residential community, as opposed to a shopping phenomenon. I find that very heartening because that's certainly the premise behind the hotel -- that this is a burgeoning, vital community that has its own spirit and deserves its own focal point."
Although Community Board 2 approved the developers' request for a special permit allowing hotel, retail and restaurant use on the ground and cellar floors, it did so by a vote of 19 to 9, stressing that its action was "based on the unique nature and location of this particular" building and "should not be taken as a precedent for any future such application or for support of any hotel use in the SoHo District."
The Community Board resolution also explicitly noted the owners' agreement not to install a discotheque or other "entertainment use" in the hotel. Mr. Balazs acknowledged that his involvement in M.K. would have prompted such concern but said, "It makes no sense to wish to develop an intimate, sophisticated, quiet hotel whose very draw is privacy and, at the same time, willingly put in an establishment downstairs that violates every one of those things."
The hotel project on West Broadway and Wooster Street would be undertaken by Richard E. Talmadge of Manhattan and Hawthorn Suites of Waltham, Mass., a Pritzker family concern. The architects are Gruzen Samton Steinglass of Manhattan.
THE irregular building site runs through the middle of the block. At this time last year, the plan was for a 12-story structure on the Wooster Street side, which has a 50-foot frontage, and a one-story structure on West Broadway, where there is a 26-foot frontage. But that was not greeted favorably by the Landmarks Preservation Commission. It has reviewed all three hotel projects because they are within the SoHo-Cast Iron Historic District.
In the revised plans, which won approval from the commission, an eight-story structure would be built on Wooster Street with a facade whose broad and deeply recessed window bays echo those of adjoining loft buildings. The top two stories would be set back 20 feet from the street wall and concealed behind a high parapet.
On West Broadway, there would be an eight-story building with simpler, smaller, sash windows, looking much like its neighbors. The top two stories would be set back 18 feet from the street wall. The landmarks commission determined that the upper stories of the two buildings "will not be visible from the street."
The two structures would have a total of 44 suites and seven single rooms. Between them would be a courtyard, some of it used as an outdoor extension of the restaurant.
"I think it would be very delightful and quite unique in its way -- an open courtyard that is somewhat residential in character and yet has activity in it," said Ralph Stein-glass, one of the architects. "We're quite pleased that what we've come up with -- mainly to devise a plan that would be more contextual -- has also produced a hotel design that is more intriguing, more appropriate to the particular niche that it's seeking to place itself in."
Financing, or the lack of it, seems to be the question now. "I don't know if I'd call it an obstacle," Mr. Talmadge said, "but with the current economic climate, we want to get a better sense of where the market's going. It certainly tempered the sense of urgency. But we hope to have the project going sometime late this year or early next year."
Another project, for a 78-room hotel on Houston Street, has been on the drawing boards for a very long time. The design, by Der Scutt of Manhattan, is a contemporary evocation of cast-iron facades and it won an award from the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects -- in 1985.
A year ago, the developer, Hank Sopher, said that while "financing is hard to come by," he hoped to start by the end of 1990.
This month, he updated his assessment: "It hasn't gotten any better. As a matter of fact, it probably got worse. Nothing's going to be done there until the banks open up again. They've closed their doors. They spend 100 percent of their time calling in loans."
Nevertheless, he said, "Eventually I think it's going to be a big winner."
"The most viable area in Manhattan today is the Chinatown-Little Italy-SoHo area," Mr. Sopher said. "A lot of that is due to the influx of Hong Kong and Chinese money and to New York University, which is constant in good times and bad times."
"We've had overtures from nonprofits," Mr. Sopher said. "We've had one very interested institution that would love to build community facilities there, housing for its people." Besides saying that the institution in question was not New York University, he did not further identify it.
"As far as a commercial hotel," he said, "unless someone wants to build it all-cash, it's not going to happen."
