HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:

Rejection on Refinancing
 
Question: I asked permission from our co-op board to take out a home equity loan to help pay my son's college tuition. I had no mortgage and the co-op permits up to 80 percent financing for new stockholders. The board rejected my request, so I had to take a personal loan, with almost no tax benefit. Was the board's action legal? . . . Candy Eng, Jackson Heights, Queens
 
Answer: Legal experts are unsure. Stuart M. Saft, a real estate lawyer and chairman of the Council of New York Cooperatives, said the answer depends on whether your co-op lease requires approval for financing. If it does, he said, the next question is whether the board "treats everybody in the same situation equally." The board might distinguish between existing owners and new buyers, he said.
Michael R. Finder, a Manhattan housing lawyer, said the case as described "sounds suspect to me, a loose or ill-defined policy or practice that doesn't seem rational." You might appeal to the board to reconsider its policy. A letter or visit from a lawyer might help, but taking the board to court could be prohibitively costly. Another approach would be a petition from shareholders seeking a revised policy.
Mr. Finder said your neighbors might be supportive both out of fairness and self-interest, because they, too, might want to refinance some day, and an overly restrictive policy could affect the marketability and value of apartments.
 
Electricity Charges
 
Question: I own a rent-stablized co-op in Tudor City. The maintenance charge was changed, making a separate bill for electricity. Can this be added to the rent my tenant now pays me? . . . Daniel E. Ronan, Oyster Bay, L.I.
 
Answer: No. Thomas R. Viola, spokesman for the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal, said a landlord cannot change the terms of a lease in a stabilized apartment. Anthony J. Colella, Tudor City's managing director, said your building, the Essex, converted to submetering a year ago. Removing electricity costs from the overall budget resulted in a 6.1 percent saving in the maintenance fee. The size of your individual electric bills, and whether you have a net gain or loss under the new system, depend on how much power your tenant uses.
 
Man of Many Hats
 
Question: The co-op sponsor of our Washington Heights building placed it under a 25-year wraparound mortgage, charging 15.5 percent, with himself as lender and beneficiary. Now that market rates are lower, the co-op would like to refinance, but he refuses. He also gave himself a low-cost 30-year lease for the garage, which he rents out at a sizable profit. He is the building manager and holds two seats on the board. Are these practices legal and what can be done to remedy them? . . . J. Backer, Manhattan
 
Answer: They may be legal, depending on the offering plan and mortgage terms. Mr. Saft of the Council of New York Cooperatives said the practices are legal if they were accurately disclosed in the plan and if the sponsor has met all his responsibilities. The co-op could circumvent the refusal to refinance if the mortgage terms permit prepayment (using the proceeds of a new loan from another lender) without prohibitively expensive prepayment penalties. As for the garage lease, Mr. Finder, the housing lawyer, said that depending on the details, you may have recourse under the Federal Condominium and Cooperative Conversion Protection and Abuse Relief Act. Some garage leases held by sponsors have been found illegal under the act.

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

 BODY:

 
 
'VOICE OF THE PRAIRIE'
 A Midwesterner who becomes a popular radio personality during the 1920's is the principal character in "The Voice of the Prairie," a play by John Olive opening on Friday at the Schoolhouse in Croton Falls. It runs through May 5.
 The character, David Quinn, parlays a natural talent for storytelling into a successful career, spinning tales of his youth for the radio audience. His fame is instrumental in reuniting him with a long-lost sweetheart.
 The play was performed to flattering reviews in 1987 at the Hartford Stage Company and at the Chelsea Stage in Manhattan last December.
 "Three actors play many roles," said James Shankman, artistic director of the Coyote Theater, a company of professional actors from New York, based at the Schoolhouse. "It's a memory piece," he continued, "with suggested sets, and items of clothing that are put on or taken off onstage as the characters switch roles or move back and forth between the 1890's and the 1920's."
 Mr. Olive's plays, including "Killers," which had its premiere in 1989 with Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago, "are being seen more and more in regional theaters around the country," Mr. Shankman said.
 "The Voice of the Prairie" will be performed Fridays and Saturdays at 8 P.M., Sundays at 7 P.M., with matinees April 28 and May 5 at 3 P.M. Tickets are $12.50 and $15 and can be reserved by calling 277-8477.
 
SKETCHES SOARING
 The days when pencil sketches and other graphics were priced at a markedly lower range than paintings are apparently coming to a close. Thirty-six black-and-white sketches by 25 major artists, being shown today through May 12 at Nardin Fine Arts in Cross River, are as costly as many paintings.
 "It's outrageous, but that's how it is, in spite of the depressed economy," said Concetta Nardin, the gallery's owner.
 The list of artists is impressive, and the works are all framed, some in the original frames and mountings. Most of the works were done in pencil, but some are in conte crayon, ink or charcoal. They include a 9-by-12-inch charcoal sketch of a standing woman by Bonnard for $36,000.
 A 7-by-8-inch preliminary sketch for a painting by Mary Cassatt is priced at $16,000. The most expensive piece is by Yasuo Kuniyoshi, a pencil sketch of two girls in Paris, measuring 12-by-21 inches, and important, Ms. Nardin said, "because it is different from his other work -- more rigid, calculated." It costs $45,000.
 A few drawings cost about $900, including one by Max Weber and another by Raphael Soyer. Whistler, Hopper, Stella, John Marin, Marsden Hartley, Marsh, Noguchi, John Sloan, and Milton Avery are some of the other artists in the show.
 The gallery is on Route 35 in Yellow Monkey Village, open Tuesdays through Sundays from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Call 763-8451 for more information.
 
ROGER McGUINN RETURNS
 Are you close enough to the 60's to remember "Turn, Turn, Turn," the Byrds, and Roger McGuinn, leader of the band?
 Well, he is back, appearing at the Music Hall on Main Street in Tarrytown this evening at 7:30 with a new band that features Tom Petty, Elvis Costello and Michael Penn. The group has recorded an album, McGuinn's first in 10 years, titled "Back From Rio," which Rolling Stone magazine dubbed "the first great album of 1991."
 Tickets are $20 and can be reserved through Ticketmaster or by calling 332-8497.
 
ONE-DAY BOOK SALE
 New Rochelle Library's yearly spring-weekend book sale has been compressed from two days to one because of budget reductions requiring the building to be closed on Sundays.
 The sale, with up to 10,000 items, will run from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. Saturday. The selection will include hardcover and paperback fiction, mysteries, biographies, history, sociology, psychology, religion, philosophy, political science, children's books, reference books, multi-volume sets, large-print books and a selection of records and some framed prints that were part of the library's collection.
 Everything is in good to excellent condition and prices are 25 cents to $50 for a set of encyclopedias. Leftovers will be sold for $1 a bag the following Monday. The library is downtown at Library Plaza.
 
MANAGING RISK
 "Risk Management Challenges in the U.S.S.R. and Changing Eastern European Economies" are to be discussed when the World Trade Club meets for lunch Wednesday at the Rye Town Hilton.
 Sharon R. Fitzsimmons, director of finance and treasurer of Philip Morris International, will be the speaker, focusing on her own recent experiences in the volatile climate under which trading and investing in those parts of the world must be accomplished. Ms. Fitzsimmons is a graduate of the International Senior Management program at Harvard's Graduate School of Business.
 A reception will begin at 11:45 A.M., with lunch served at 12:15 P.M., followed by Ms. Fitzsimmons's talk and an open discussion. Tickets are $40 and can be reserved by calling 948-6444.
 
NOT SO RETIRING
 Workshops for people middle aged and older who want to put their skills and experience to profitable use are being held this spring by the American Association of Retired Persons. The series begins with a session on assessment and planning, from 9 A.M. to 12:30 P.M. tomorrow.
 Six additional sessions, scheduled on April 18, 22, 25 and May 2, 9 and 16, will deal with identifying skills and work preferences, collecting information, barriers to be faced, communicating effectively in interviews and the workplace, becoming acquainted with realistic job options and creating and implementing a job-search plan.
 All sessions will be held from 9 A.M. to 12:30 P.M. at MONY Financial Services, at 4 Manhattanville Road in Purchase. There is no charge. Registration will be available tomorrow morning at the meeting, or call 381-2048.
 
RUSSIAN CHAMBER CHORUS
 A Manhattan-based choral society called the Russian Chamber Chorus will perform in a two-part concert Friday at 7 P.M. in the O'Byrne Chapel of Manhattanville College in Purchase.
 Under the direction of Nikolai Kachanov, the program will span the rich choral repertory of Russian music, from ancient sacred chants to contemporary works, followed by 19th- and 20th-century classical and folk songs. Admission is free.

HEADLINE: Sunday Outing;
A Visit to the Bayou, 26 Miles From New York

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
Just 26 miles west of New York City, a bit of the bayou flourishes. It's the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge in Meyersville, N.J., and for lovers of wildlife, particularly bird watchers, spring is an opportune time for a visit.
The Great Swamp Refuge, operated by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, contains 7,000 acres of woodland, marshes and swamps, much of it inaccessible to visitors, by Federal law. But in one area, two boardwalks wind briefly through the Great Swamp, taking visitors though a still, eerie but beautiful world of marsh plants, rotting trees and water, colored myriad shades of green by moss and pond scum. 
 The boardwalks lead to bird-watching blinds, small sheds with slits cut in their walls that allow visitors to observe without disturbing the animals. Some 222 species of birds have been sighted in the Great Swamp. Some make it a permanent home; others use it as a stopover on migratory flights.
Bird species commonly sighted in spring include Canada goose, wood duck, mallard, American kestrel, mourning dove, downy and hairy woodpeckers, Eastern bluebird, great blue heron, yellow warbler, hummingbird and cardinal. Binoculars are essential, and a bird-watching guide is a handy reference tool.
 
Cold-Blooded Creatures, Too
 On a sunny day, painted turtles sun themselves on tufted grasses that dot the Great Swamp, and a patient, keen-eyed visitor may hope to spot several species of snakes, including the Northern water snake and Eastern ribbon snake. Mammals common to the Great Swamp include white-tailed deer, red fox and river otter.
The Great Swamp also attracts plant enthusiasts. Spring wildflowers commonly seen there include several species of anemone, blackberry, lily-of-the-valley and wild violets.
The Great Swamp, bounded by the towns of Chatham and Gillette, was formed more than 25,000 years ago when a retreating glacier helped create a giant lake, which scientists estimate covered an area 30 miles long and 10 miles wide.
As water slowly drained from the lake, several extensive marshes and swamps formed. By the mid-1800's, farmers had drained most of the marshes. But the small farms eventually proved economically unfeasible, and the area soon reverted to wilderness.
A proposal in the 1950's to fill in the Great Swamp and built an airport that galvanized local conservationists. They raised more than $1 million through donations, and the money was used to buy 3,000 acres that forms the nucleus of the wildlife sanctuary.
 
Beware Wet Feet and Ticks
 Rangers recommend that visitors wear sneakers or waterproof shoes, although the boardwalks remain dry. The best times for observing wildlife are early morning and late afternoon. Spring is a particularly good time because foliage is still scant, making bird watching easier.
Because the area is a swamp, expect to find numerous mosquitoes and ticks from mid-May to September. Deer ticks, which can transmit Lyme disease, have been found in the area. As a result, insect repellent is advisable, as are long-sleeved shirts, and trousers rather than shorts. In April, however, the Great Swamp is relatively insect-free.
There are also some hiking trails in the Great Swamp refuge, but some are several miles by car from the wildlife observation area. Parking areas are provided at various access points to the swamp. Parking along roads in the area is prohibited. Most of the trails are short walks through woods and thick bambles. They are particularly well-suited to families with small children.
There is no food service in the refuge. Some nearby parks have picnic areas. In Meyersville, Casa Maya serves unusually good Mexican food. It does not have a liquor license, so those wanting beer or wine must bring their own.

 
 
 
Getting There
 The Great Swamp can be reached by car from New York City by taking the New Jersey Turnpike to Exit 14, Interstate 78. Take I-78 west to Exit 40 and proceed north along State Highway 531 to State Highway 638. This will lead to Meyersville. Follow signs for the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge.
Brochures detailing the types of wildlife found in the Great Swamp are available from the visitors' center, which is open daily from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M., except for holidays. Information: (201) 647-1222.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Great Swamp, bounded by the New Jersey towns of Chatham and Gillette, was formed more than 25,000 years ago when a retreating glacier helped create a giant lake, which scientists estimate covered an area 30 miles long and 10 miles wide. (Barry Meier/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Business Diary/April 7-12

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:
COMPANIES
 
Kerkorian's Strategy for T.W.A.: Cold Cash
 

Last week, Carl C. Icahn, chairman of T.W.A., kept asking Kirk Kerkorian, the Beverly Hills financier, "where's your plan?" Mr. Kerkorian wants to buy T.W.A. from a resistant Mr. Icahn. Late Friday, he delivered the plan. With the help of T.W.A.'s unions, he is petitioning Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner to stop the sale of T.W.A.'s trans-Atlantic routes to American Airlines. This would deprive T.W.A. of $445 million to pay off some of its $2.7 billion in debt. He is also petitioning Mr. Skinner to allow direct talks between Mr. Icahn and himself, which the American agreement precludes. And he is promising cash -- lots. First there is $250 million in working capital from his Tracinda Corporation. Then there is $441 million in union givebacks. The plan also calls for keeping existing routes and buying new planes -- something Mr. Icahn could not afford to do. Can Mr. Kerkorian pull it off? He is asking Mr. Skinner for 60 days to try.

Hollywood's Lobbying Loss
 
For Jack Valenti, the $700,000-a-year lobbyist for the Motion Picture Association of America Inc., it was a rare defeat. After months of wrangling and one postponed vote, the Federal Communications Commission decided last week to let the television networks in on the $3 billion rerun market. Since 1970, largely through Mr. Valenti's deft lobbying efforts, they have been prohibited from owning the prime-time shows they broadcast. The rationale Mr. Valenti has been using for the last 21 years is that ownership would concentrate too much power with the networks. With last week's 3-to-2 vote, however, the F.C.C. finally recognized what almost everyone else already knew: the networks have lost much of their clout. The networks now get full resale rights to as much as 40 percent of their shows and royalties on the rest. The losers? The studios. They must share the loot.
 
The Teflon-less Nancy Reagan
 
It seems Nancy Reagan has little of the stuff her husband has: teflon. Everything seems to stick to her surface, whether warranted or not. The former First Lady has been portrayed unflatteringly by authors as diverse as Donald Regan, former White House chief of staff, and her daughter, Patti Davis. But now Mrs. Reagan has joined the oeuvre of Kitty ("His Way," a biography of Frank Sinatra) Kelly. Ms. Kelly's treatment of her latest subject gives Reaganomics, and "trickle up," a new spin, especially for the publisher, Simon & Schuster, a unit of Paramount Communications Inc. The book, which sells for $24.95, sold 90,000 copies in the first two hours. The initial print run was 925,000.

Digital Takes a Partner
 
Until now, if the Digital Equipment Corporation sold it, chances were it invented it and manufactured it too. But after four years of trying to develop its own "massively parallel" supercomputer -- a machine that achieves blistering speeds by dividing calculations between many different microprocessors -- Digital gave up on going it alone. Digital -- with $13 billion in sales -- has thrown its lot in with tiny Maspar Computer Corporation, a computer maker in Sunnyvale, Calif., with just $8 million in sales. Maspar makes machines with as many as 14,000 microprocessors. The companies will form a joint venture to produce a quick number-crunching machine with at least 128 microprocessors. Will the corporate cultures mesh as well as the microprocessors? Jeff Kalb, president of Maspar knows Digital well. He was once a vice president there.
 
Last week in Tokyo, Cray Research Inc. announced a new mid-priced supercomputer called the Y-MP4E. The machine, which is not based on parallel processing architecture, will be available in May and will sell for $7.3 million, about two-thirds the price of the average Cray computer.
 
J. P. Morgan & Company has a reputation for doing things right. Last week it did it again. The nation's fourth-largest bank reported a 61.5 percent increase in first-quarter profits, to $273 million. It attributed this rise to its foreign-exchange trading operations.
 
Revlon's New Look
 
Max Factor's luscious lashes will soon belong to the Procter & Gamble Company. Revlon Inc., which owns Max Factor, is selling the line along with Betrix, a German beauty-aids company, and Almay, a line of hypoallergenic cosmetics, for $1.14 billion. For P.& G., which owns Cover Girl, the biggest mass-market cosmetics brand, the addition of Max's lashes will put its domestic market share at about 30 percent of the market and give it added strength in Europe. For Revlon, the deal means cash to pay down some of its $800 million in bank debt due in 1992 and some of its $1.1 billion in "junk bond" debt. It cannot pay these from cash flow. What kind of gloss do the analysts give the sale? At $1.20 for each $1 in sales, they say P.& G. got itself a deal.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY


Hints That the Fed Will Act
 
Consumer prices fell in March, along with a lot of other indicators, a sure sign that the recession is beginning to cleanse the nation of inflation. It also gives the go-ahead to the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates. According to the Labor Department, prices were down 0.1 percent, the first decline in five months. But even though the numbers look good, "one swallow doesn't make a summer," said Francis Schott, chief economist of Equitable Life Assurance Society in New York. It is the year-to-year figures the economists really look at. "Those numbers still show inflation hovering at about 5 percent." Still too high to bring much joy to a pensioner's heart, but low enough that the Federal Reserve may lower rates. "Fed fund rates will come down to 5.75 percent -- enough to shake the prime rate loose, down to 8.5 percent within four weeks," said Mr. Schott.
 
Inflation Worries Recede
 
There are other negative numbers for March that look surprisingly positive: producer prices fell by 0.3 percent, the fourth straight month of declines, according to the Labor Department. Declining producer prices send another strong signal that inflation is easing throughout the economy. "This is really welcome news," said Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at CRT Government Securities in New York. But the decline in producer prices comes at a price: the economy is limping along at barely 70 percent of its capacity and wages are not growing at all -- more fallout from the recession. Although four months are still not enough to signal the beginning of a larger trend toward stable prices, "it is quite a good start that provides room for the economy to bounce." The economy is laying its own foundation for a smooth recovery.
 
Retailers Out in the Cold
 
Retail sales are languishing too -- bad news for the nation's debt-encumbered retailers, but more good news on the inflation front. Sales fell by 0.8 percent for March, according to the Commerce Department. The biggest declines in sales were for big-ticket, durable items. These goods are the most sensitive to changes in interest rates. For the Federal Reserve, which watches these numbers closely, the evidence continues to mount that if it lowers rates, the economy will respond.
 
Companies Still Skeptical
 
Consumers may be confident, as the surveys show, but companies are still scared stiff. Businesses are not willing to spend. According to the Commerce Department, businesses are planning to expand their investment this year by a very cautious 3.2 percent after inflation, the weakest increase in five years. This follows rises of 4.5 percent in 1990 and double-digit increases in '89 and '88. According to Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist at Fuji Securities Inc. in Chicago, all optimism should be guarded. "The numbers still do not indicate the end of the recession is here."
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
OPEC's Cash Pinch
 
Once OPEC was flush with cash, now all it has is oil. The situation has gotten so bad for the cartel that its Secretary General, Subroto of Indonesia, said last week in Washington that OPEC could not afford to raise production without first getting financing from abroad. Cash-strapped during the 1980's, OPEC neglected to invest in new production capacity. "They're going to have a tough time financing expansion," said Hossein Askari, an adviser to the Petroleum Finance Company in Washington. "Especially Saudi Arabia since it also has to pay for an expanded military." OPEC countries dipping into the world's pool of capital could help send interest rates higher. But if they don't dip in, oil supplies could be tight by mid-decade, analysts say.
 
Mexico and U.S. Get Cozier
 
They used to refer to themselves as distant neighbors. Now they are worried they can't get close enough. In Houston last week, President Bush and President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico embraced the idea of a free-trade pact between the two countries. Although there is opposition to such a pact in Congress -- many fear it would bring down American wages -- Mr. Bush is pushing ahead with negotiations under a so-called "fast track" provision. Unless Congress revokes the provision this June, the only vote permitted will be yea or nay when a treaty is finally negotiated. Congress can make no amendments. Mr. Bush pledges to make the pact a priority. He is likely to get his way.
 
The Little Stock Exchange
 
When Poland's new stock exchange opens next week in Warsaw, it will be housed in the former headquarters of the Communist Party, a fitting tribute to the changes in Eastern Europe. At first the exchange will be tiny -- shares of just six companies will be traded and the exchange will be open just one day a week. But Poland has high hopes. The Government is mulling over a plan to give each adult a voucher that could be used to purchase stock.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 12; Column 3; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: World Markets;
The Dollar and Overseas Stocks

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
For foreign companies that do business in the United States, a rising dollar may look like a good bet. There is the bonus of translating dollar profits back into their home currencies and the competitive edge of their exports to America. But looks can be deceiving.
Take, for example, the Sedgwick Group P.L.C., a British commercial property and casualty insurance broker. More than 50 percent of its sales come from the United States. But since the dollar began to rally in February, the company has underperformed the Financial Times world index for the London market -- rising 7.8 percent compared with 11.7 percent for the index. Meanwhile, a group of other dollar-positive stocks with smaller percentages of sales in the United States have outperformed the market. 
 The problem is that the benefits of a stronger dollar can be overwhelmed by other factors. In Sedgwick's case, according to Roger Harvey, an insurance analyst at Kleinwort Benson Securities in London, investors were disappointed that insurance rates didn't rise as much as expected this year. The stocks of insurance companies and brokers like Sedgwick rallied at the end of last year on the hope of increases. And this disappointment, he said, has undercut the dollar's lift.
In addition, the benefits of a dollar rally could be muted for many companies because they had already hedged their exposure to the dollar, meaning they may not now get the full benefit of a rally. And each country in Europe is affected differently by a dollar rally.
Paul Feldman and Sushil Wadhwani of Goldman Sachs & Company in London and Mushtag Shah, a research associate at the London School of Economics, have examined these issues in a new analysis of the dollar's rally. "The idea of this was to alert people that they should not just buy the stocks that have U.S. dollar earnings," said Mr. Feldman. "Maybe this will make people go back to their analysts and ask, 'Why did this stock do that?' "
They concluded that the Dutch market should benefit the most from a dollar rally. Into this calculation goes a measure of earnings of companies in these countries that are dollar sensitive, a count of imports and the impact of a lower local currency on domestic inflation. Also included is what they call a "market sacrifice ratio," which seeks to rate a country's willingness to accept a little more economic growth in exchange for a little more inflation. For example, Italy is very willing but Germany is not.
From this, and some additional equations and market assumptions, the team has concluded not only that the Dutch market is the biggest beneficiary but that it is followed in decending order by Switzerland, Germany, Italy, Britain and France. With a 10 percent increase in the dollar, the Dutch market could rise 3.9 percent and Switzerland 0.9 percent, not counting other market influences. But there are losses of 0.1 percent for Germany, 0.2 percent for Italy, 1.3 percent for Britain and 1.9 percent for France.
The Dutch and the Swiss markets have the highest earnings exposure to the dollar. While British stocks have a higher earnings exposure than Italian stocks, they have a more negative dollar response because of Britain's greater concern about inflation. This means interest rates are apt to be relatively higher than Italy's.
On individual stocks, the Goldman report tries to pinpoint companies whose dollar bias will allow them to outperform their local market as a whole. The picks are based on analysis of stock movements compared with currency fluctuations since 1986.
But the list is no sure thing. Sedgwick, which has the highest dollar exposure, is on the list of 15 British stocks. Still, as a group, the 15 outperformed the rest of the London market by an average of 4 percentage points from Feb. 11 to April 2, during which time the dollar rose 13.6 percent against the sterling.
Also among the 15 are BTR, Lonrho, Glaxo, BOC and Shell. Both Shell and BOC have underperformed the market but for no clear reason, which leads Goldman to believe that they may have some good gains ahead.
Among the companies on the other country porfolios are KLM and Ahold in the Netherlands, Pirelli & Company and Eridania in Italy, Tattinger and BIC in France, Ciba-Geigy and Nestle in Switzerland, and BMW and Hoesch in Germany.
 The portfolios from other countries did better in outperforming their markets than those on the British list. Based on history, the British companies were expected to outperform the market by 3.5 percentage points, just below the actual 4 percent gain.
And making the various choices even more difficult, the analysts found that while overall markets might have declined during a dollar rally, the portfolios in these countries did as well or better than the Netherlands and Switzerland.
 For example, the Dutch portfolio on average rose 4.8 percent, 1.92 times the predicted rate of 2.5 percent. But the German portfolio outperformed the market by 9 percent, 1.96 times the predicted rate. The Italian portfolio was 1.75 times the predicted rate, while the Swiss portfolio was just 1.42 times the predicted rate. One conclusion is that the German stocks, like BMW and Hoesch, have already moved too far.

The New York Times

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2615 words

HEADLINE: Taming Hollywood's Spending Monster

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Don Simpson and Jerry Bruckheimer were arguably Hollywood's hottest production team during the late 1980's, with a string of hits for Paramount Pictures that included "Top Gun" and the two "Beverly Hills Cop" films. Early last year, they were rewarded by Paramount with a new five-year contract that was lucrative even by the bloated standards of the movie business. But in November, barely 10 months later, the studio severed its ties to the pair.
 Publicly, both sides said the split had nothing to do with the disappointing performance last summer of "Days of Thunder," starring Tom Cruise. But it wasn't difficult for anyone in Hollywood to read between the lines. Paramount, by then suffering from a string of expensive flops, had decided it could no longer stomach the high-cost movies it had looked to Mr. Simpson and Mr. Bruckheimer to make. And in dumping the producers, the studio's management hoped to demonstrate to its nervous parent, Paramount Communications Inc., newfound commitment to financial restraint. 
 The incident is perhaps the most vivid sign yet of how Hollywood studios are trying to reform their history of free spending. Shaken by poor box-office performances and declining profit margins, studios say they are taking a harder line in negotiating deals with actors, producers and directors. And they are increasingly turning thumbs-down on proposals for expensive action movies and those laden with special-effects, looking instead for more "story driven" films, to use Hollywood's euphemism for movies that actually have coherent plots.
Yet Hollywood's new austerity seems to be more rhetoric than reality. Few in the industry disagree with what Jeffrey Katzenberg, the chairman of the Walt Disney Studios, recently called "a tidal wave of runaway costs and mindless competition." But the reforms so far have not been terribly deep and there are doubts that anything short of a tidal wave of red ink for studios will give them the will or the discipline to rein in costs.
As the financial risks of movie-making increase, studio executives, if anything, feel more compelled to play it safe by hiring established stars or peppering their movies with spectacular effects and lavish locations.
 
The Power of Agents
 Indeed, movie theaters this year will be filled with some of the biggest financial bets in movie-making history. Despite denials by Carolco Pictures, industry executives insist that its upcoming "Terminator 2: Judgment Day" cost almost $90 million to produce, which would make it the most expensive film of all time. Arnold Schwarzenegger, the star, is reportedly being paid $15 million.
Studio executives, it seems, are unwilling to challenge the immense power of talent agents like Michael Ovitz of the Creative Artists Agency in negotiating deals -- a fundamental change that many in the industry say is required for any long-term impact on costs.
Hollywood, in fact, may be among the last American industry to come to grips with bloated costs because it still has little incentive to do so. It has had no trouble retaining worldwide dominance in entertainment. New investment has been brisk, as shown by the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company's purchase last year of MCA Inc., the parent of Universal Pictures, and Sony's acquisition of Columbia Pictures. And while profit margins are eroding, the top studios are still profitable. Amid the flops, there were plenty of successes last year. "Home Alone" cost 20th Century Fox less than $20 million to make and has grossed more than $250 million at the domestic box office. Disney had a surprise hit with "Pretty Woman," and Paramount had "Ghost."
Still, the industry's outlook could darken dramatically if costs go unchecked.
The average cost to the major studios of producing a feature film last year rose 14.2 percent, to $26.8 million, according to the Motion Picture Association of America. Because the major studios are releasing more films, they are having to spend more money to attract the attention of moviegoers. Marketing and distribution costs -- primarily advertising -- climbed by an average 25.9 percent last year, to $11.6 million per film. That brought the total cost to an average $38.4 million, up 17.4 percent in a year and nearly triple the 1980 average.
At the same time, domestic box office receipts in 1990 fell by 0.2 percent, to $5.02 billion, and theater attendance dropped 6.6 percent, to 1.06 billion. Perhaps even more worrisome, industry executives say, growth rates are slowing in the revenue sources that financed much of the recent run-up in costs, including foreign box office receipts and the sale of video and television rights.
"Everyone's been looking for a bigger piece of the pie, but the pie has stopped growing," said Frank Mancuso, who was the chairman of Paramount Pictures until a management shake-up forced him out last month.
The studios have spent lavishly in recent years to find the next blockbuster, a film to repeat the huge success Warner Brothers had in 1989 with "Batman," which grossed $250 million in the United States. But they have often miscalculated the appeal of the underlying stories.
Today, Hollywood's back lots are littered with the financial wreckage of the resulting big-budget flops. Paramount is reeling from losses on "The Godfather Part III" and "The Two Jakes." Warner Brothers is awash in red ink from "The Bonfire of the Vanities." Robert Redford's latest movie, "Havana," was a disaster for Universal Pictures. Walt Disney Studios executives insist that "Dick Tracy" made money, but almost no one believes them.
 
Pressure on Profits
 Because the major studios are part of larger corporations or are owned by foreign companies, it is difficult to track their bottom lines, but analysts and industry executives say the downward trend is clear. Profits from Disney's studio in 1990 were the lowest in three years, according to a recent internal memorandum from Mr. Katzenberg, although Disney was the year's box-office leader.
Paramount's box-office troubles have depressed results at its parent company, Paramount Communications, which lost $7.3 million in the quarter ended Jan. 31. Martin S. Davis, the company's chairman, told analysts earlier this month that he expects a loss in the current quarter, blaming in part "the weak performance of our motion picture releases."
Paramount Pictures' string of flops clearly undermined the position of Mr. Mancuso, who had headed the operation since 1984. While he might have been responsible for Paramount's failures, Mr. Mancuso, in their wake, enacted the industry's most far-reaching program to hold down costs -- one that has continued since his departure. In the months before he left, Mr. Mancuso and the studio's other top executives decided to reverse their strategy of concentrating on big-budget films and sequels and work primarily on films that could be made for around the industry average of $27 million.
Paramount has let it be known that it would no longer pay to sign top stars like Tom Cruise, who can command $8 million or more per film. The studio cut the number of films in development in half, to about 125. And executives tried to take a stricter line on production expenses, pressuring directors to stay on their shooting schedules, for example.
"It's become relatively clear that other studios have gone through similar examinations of their practices and have also concluded that things must change," Mr. Mancuso said in an interview last month before losing his job.
 
A New Caution
 At Disney, for example, Mr. Katzenberg has said the studio will be much more hesitant to take on big-budget extravaganzas like "Dick Tracy," and another top executive says Disney will no longer pay to have two big stars in a film, as it did recently with "Scenes from a Mall," with Woody Allen and Bette Midler. Columbia Pictures has recognized that on a financial basis, "more and more projects don't add up for us," said Frank Price, the chairman.
Even Carolco Pictures, which in the past has concentrated almost exclusively on big-budget films with stars like Arnold Schwarzenegger and Sylvester Stallone, now wants to produce a few less high-cost films each year and a few more moderately budgeted movies. And virtually every studio is developing more romantic comedies -- a genre considerably less expensive than action films.
Some studios have also responded by laying off more of the financial risk, limiting their financial exposure and their profits. Warner Brothers, for one, is making deals with independent producers and foreign entertainment companies under which it will put up the money for marketing and distribution, but not for producing movies. It is to some extent following a strategy used by Disney.
 Despite the tougher bargaining posture that studio executives say they are taking, their willpower in negotiating with highly paid stars and their powerful agents is suspect. Some studio will almost certainly give in to Macaulay Culkin, the 10-year-old star of "Home Alone," who industry executives say is asking as much as $4 million for his next film.
 In the view of frustrated studio executives, the problem lies primarily with agents who, they argue, push constantly for the last possible dollar that can be wrung from a deal. Agents disagree, saying that deals come down to what studios are willing to pay. But to hear agents tell it, the industry's big problem is not rising costs but that studio executives, with their multimillion dollar salaries and private screening rooms, have lost touch with the public.
 
Looking Inward
 The dismal results of the last year have certainly prompted a greater degree of self-analysis among executives, producers, directors and others in the industry. Mr. Katzenberg, Disney's studio chief, wrote in an internal memo earlier this year about the need for his company to focus less on big budgets and hype and more on developing good stories capable of grabbing audiences emotionally. The memo, which was widely circulated throughout Hollywood, gave voice to the uneasiness about creative bankruptcy and excessive costs as studios chased frantically and fruitlessly after the next "Batman."
"It seems that, like lemmings, we are all racing faster and faster into the sea, each of us trying to outrun and outspend and outearn the other in a mad sprint toward the mirage of the next blockbuster," Mr. Katzenberg wrote.
But the memo was disparaged by agents and executives at other studios. They saw it as an attempt by Mr. Katzenberg to deflect criticism about Disney's own lack of financial discipline in developing upcoming movies like "Billy Bathgate," starring Dustin Hoffman, and "Rocketeer," an adventure film that despite having no big stars will cost more than $35 million to produce.
Can Hollywood really change? The evidence so far suggests that the reare real, but superficial.
Consider Mr. Simpson and Mr. Bruckheimer. Unwanted at Paramount, they quickly signed with Disney. Industry executives say their deal is lucrative by any measure, although they are no longer guaranteed a huge payday even if a film flops, as they were at Paramount.
Many experts think the industry will have to make more fundamental changes. Peter Dekom, a lawyer who is one of Hollywood's leading deal makers, said that studios may reduce expenses by employing less well-known actors, but will then have to advertise more to draw audiences to the movies because they will lack the built-in drawing power of a top star.
But he said the only way the economic structure of the business can really be altered is for the studios to invest more time and energy in developing their own stars from scratch under long-term deals, something movie makers have not widely done since the demise of the old studio system decades ago.
"The studios say cut costs, cut costs, cut costs," Mr. Dekom said. "But so far all I see is people tearing things down, not building any new, more efficient structures."
 
 
 
Anatomy of a Big-Budget Deal
 Judging from some of the movie deals now in the making, you would never know Hollywood was taking a dimmer view of high-budget films. "Hook," by the Sony Corporation's Tri-Star Pictures unit, a movie about the pirate captain from "Peter Pan," will undoubtedly be among this year's most expensive. It is an illustration of the power of brand-name artists and their agents and why Hollywood has such trouble making money on big-budget films.
Industry executives said Tri-Star agreed to pay Steven Spielberg, the director, and the two stars, Dustin Hoffman and Robin Williams, a huge percentage of the film's gross revenues in lieu of cash salaries.
As outlined by a person familiar with the deal, the director and the two stars would collectively receive 40 percent, or $20 million, of the first $50 million in revenues received by the studio. That would leave $30 million for Tri-Star to begin covering the film's production costs, which are not publicly known. It is unclear how the 40 percent would be split.
The studio's revenues would hit $50 million when the film has sold roughly $110 million in tickets, since theaters typically keep slightly more than half the ticket revenues. A film that did $110 million in ticket sales would be a substantial hit. One factor in Tri-Star's favor: "Hook" is likely to draw well around the world.
For any revenue Tri-Star takes in between $50 million and $120 million, including videocassette and television rights, the cut taken by the director and the stars would decline to less than 20 percent, allowing the studio a greater opportunity to recover not just the production costs but interest expense, studio overhead and the tens of millions of dollars it will undoubtedly spend on advertising. Should the movie reach $120 million in revenues, Tri-Star would keep roughly $85 million, with Messrs. Spielberg, Hoffman and Williams splitting $35 million.
Above $120 million in studio revenue -- or roughly $250 million in worldwide box-office sales -- the deal calls for the share going to Messrs. Spielberg, Hoffman and Williams to kick back up to 40 percent.
Does it all add up to a profit? Rivals are doubtful, but Michael Medavoy, Tri-Star's chairman, seems confident. "Everyone who points a finger at 'Hook' would love to have it," he said. "This is not the picture to hold up as an example of costs run amok."

 
 
A 'STAR TREK' SOLUTION
 When Paramount Pictures first worked up a budget for "Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country," the numbers didn't add up. Its solution may serve as a prototype for other studio's trying to pare costs.
The asking prices of all the stars, including William Shatner and Leonard Nimoy, and costs for the special effects and elaborate sets envisioned by the producers would have added up to $41 million. That is not an outrageous sum to make a movie generally, but it is for a "Star Trek" movie. The series has had little appeal abroad and would be unlikely to sell $100 million in tickets at the box office in the United States, the minimum needed for a $41 million film to break even.
So Paramount and the producers agreed to cut back on the special effects, use more sets from previous installments and even use old costumes. Most important, Mr. Nimoy and Mr. Shatner agreed not to take any cash up front.
Instead, the actors will receive a portion of the film's revenues, a deal that will leave them with relatively little if the movie flops, but that could be extremely lucrative if it is a hit.
The bottom line: The film's production budget was reduced to $27 million, and filming begins this month.

HEADLINE: All About/Initial Public Offerings;
Company Hunger, Investor Interest Mean a Hotter New-Issues Market

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
Initial public offerings -- companies' first sales of stock to the public -- have all the excitement of opening night on Broadway. Will the offering be a success? Will it flop? After months of meticulous preparation, Wall Street bankers and corporate executives hold their collective breath as the stock is tossed out onto the market and there, in the instant of a trading day, is judged a winner or shrugged off into oblivion.
Some offerings are, indeed, show stoppers. One of the most dramatic came in 1956 when investors lined up outside brokerage houses to get the first public offering of Ford Motor Company shares. In 1980, Apple Computer went public with similar fanfare. "Not since Eve has an apple posed such temptation," as The Wall Street Journal put it. 
 The volume of initial public offerings tracks the stock market -- as the market rises, more companies sell equity; as it falls, they wait for a better price. Not surprisingly, these offerings peaked in 1987, when 517 companies went public, raising $14.5 billion, according to Investment Dealers Digest, an industry newsletter in New York. After the October crash that year, volume dropped precipitously. In 1990, only 169 companies went public, raising some $4.6 billion.
But most analysts say the initial-sale totals are poised for a takeoff, reflecting pent-up demand by companies for capital as well as a feeling that the market euphoria following the gulf war is a time to strike. And earnings-starved Wall Street firms are eager to collect the issuing fees.
"Today's new-issue market is as hot as a hot tin roof and its getting hotter," said Charles Allmon, editor of the Growth Stock Outlook, a newsletter based in Bethesda, Md."This market is warming up."
Investor interest is being whetted by the recent performance of many initial public offerings, which, as a group, have risen more than the stock market as a whole. Robert Natale, a vice president of equity research at the Standard & Poor's Corporation, has has the data, in the form of a new-issue index, composed of investment-grade nonfinancial issues. In the four weeks ended April 5, that index rose 10.8 percent, compared with a 4.4 percent gain for the over-the-counter composite index and a gain of only 0.1 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500 index, which tracks larger companies.
First quarters are usually slow for initial public offerings. Investment Dealers Digest, reports that there were 27 issues, raising $1.5 billion in the 1991 first quarter, compared with 44 issues raising $1.7 billion in the previous year's first quarter. The number of issues may be off, but the trend is not, said Mr. Natale, pointing both to dollar volume and the month-to-month trend: 4 offerings in January; 18 in February; 14 in March and five in the first week of April alone.

 
 
Risks in a Rite
Responsibilities Rise In the Public Arena
 Going public is a rite of passage -- a sign that a corporation is large enough to move into the public marketplace. Usually, the change is a way to bring new visibility and new capital to a fledging operation. When a company sells equity -- amounting to a claim by stockholders against the assets of the company -- it is raising money to pay for future growth and expansion. A successful offering helps set the stage for the company's return at a later date for more money.
The initial public offering is also how the initial private investors cash out -- it is their shares that are sold, often providing them with a sudden windfall.
But with the riches come new responsibilities: oversight by the Securities and Exchange Commission, a listing on a major stock exchange, scrutiny by the financial press and brokerage analysts and the constant rise and fall of its stock price. "There are all kinds of responsibilities associated with going public," said Michael B. Connolly, a senior manager at KPMG Peat Marwick. "And a company's reputation can really be damaged if the stock sinks in the aftermarket. A lot of companies are concerned about what happens to them after they go public."

 
 
Watch That Price
The Honeymoon Tends to Be Short
 Initial offerings tend to go through a brief honeymoon period, often rising on the first day of trading, which provides an easy profit for investors who quickly "flip" the stock. For instance, Medical Marketing Group, a data-collection company, went public at $12.50 a share in late March, and lept to $20 a share that same day.
William Benedetto, of the private investment firm, Benedetto Gartland & Greene, says this sort of action comes from the pricing strategy of Wall Street. The Street usually tries to keep investors happy, even at the expense of the issuing company.
In the current market, Mr. Benedetto said, with so many companies hungry for new money, Wall Street firms have been underpricing issues so buyers will reap an immediate 10 percent or so. "Anything less than that is a mistake," said Mr. Benedetto. "Pricing has been very, very favorable to the investor, and that's why the market is so hot."
It is not altruism that propels Wall Street, here, but, not surprisingly, greed. "Investment banks make money from big institutional buyers every day," said Mr. Benedetto. "So they have an enormous economic incentive to keep buyers of stock happy. The issuing company provides income to the bank maybe once every three years or so."
Investment bankers -- who typically get 6 percent to 7 percent of the face value of the equity offering -- are walking a tightrope between keeping investors happy and yet not underpricing so much that an issuer is appalled. But they still sometimes miss the mark. Recently, highly touted Regeneron, a biotechnology company, came to market at $22 a share, only to sink that day to $17.
Over the long haul, initial public offerings are poor investments, according to Porter Wheeler, chief economist of the Jefferson Group, a Washington consulting firm. Mr. Wheeler studied the aftermarket performance of 3,186 offerings issued between 1980 and 1990 and found "the performance was distressingly poor, to be frank," he said.
By the end of 1989, only 58 percent of this group was still listed. The rest had disappeared from the markets. Of those no longer traded, about half went out of business or became too small to be listed. The other half were merged into other companies. Of those still trading, only about a third had a market price above the original offering price.
"I was surprised successes didn't balance out the losers," said Mr. Wheeler. "Either companies were too green or couldn't sustain the growth that they were marketed with."

 
 
After the LBO
The 80's Buyouts Reverse Themselves
 By all accounts, the 1980's was the decade of the leveraged buyout, when public companies were purchased by investors and managers and taken private. In the five-year period from 1984 to the end of 1988, total completed LBO transactions amounted to $181.9 billion, including the celebrated $24.8 billion RJR Nabisco deal, according to figures from the oversight and investigations subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee.
This legacy is helping fuel the initial-offering market of the 90's as companies reverse themselves and go public once again.
Unlike the case in the 80's, when most initial offerings were small companies going public, the initial offering market of today has a growing number of "reverse LBO's." Mr. Connolly of Peat Marwick estimates that reverse LBO's amount to up to 20 percent of the current market.
"There's clearly an investor preference for companies that have been through the buyout process," said Mr. Benedetto. "Investors want large companies that have been through the buyout process. This isn't a trend. It's a fact."
Interest has also been generated by the strong aftermarket performance of some recent reverse LBOs. Safeway Stores, a Kohlberg Kravis Roberts buyout that went public last year at $11 a share, is now trading at around $20. And RJR Nabisco's debt-for-equity swap in February, not a reverse LBO but a deal viewed as a benchmark for that market, was priced at $5.75 a share and has been trading lately at around $12 a share.
"The perception is that reverse LBOs have been good for the early investors," said Mr. Natale. "Many materialized after the successful restructuring of RJR Nabisco. Investors have noticed this and are hoping the same could come true for a number of other reverse LBOs."
Among those offerings that investors are hoping will perform as well are the Caldor Corportion, a discount retailer that Mr. Natale recommends buying at $17 to $19 a share, and Duracell, a battery manufacturer that he sees as a buy at $13 a share. Unless, of course, an investor is interested in "flipping" Duracell. For that, Mr. Natale said he would pay more.
 
A SUDDEN LOVE FOR AUTOZONE

One of the more successful of the recent spate of initial public offerings was AutoZone, a do-it-yourself auto-parts retailer based in Memphis. The company came to market on April 1 at $23 a share, despite initial estimates by bankers that shares would trade between $17 and $19. Demand in preselling "road shows" for large investors was so strong that a higher price tag was possible. And since the offering, AutoZone's shares have traded at between $26 and $30.
What attracts investors to the company, which has 550 stores in 19 Sunbelt states, is more than spark plugs and batteries. The pull is Henry Kravis, and the perceived golden touch of Kohlberg Kravis & Roberts, which, with the help of a group of AutoZone executives, had taken the company private. ( The company had been a subsidiary of Malone and Hyde, a food and drug wholesale business).
Only about 10 percent, or 3.7 million, of AutoZone's shares were sold to the public. The rest are held by KKR, employees and company executives. KKR holds the bulk, some 68.4 percent. Before the offering, KKR held 75.7 percent of the company, with mangement and employees owning the rest.
The $85 million raised by the offering is being used to pay down AutoZone's debt, which ranged from $75 million to slightly more than $100 million before the offering. As a result of the offering, the company now has about $180 million in equity and is virtually debt-free.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Fred Carr Is Going for the Gold

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Among the men whose careers were built -- and ultimately destroyed -- by junk bonds, Fred Carr may have the distinction of being the one who believed in them the longest. When the going was good, he did not take the money and run.
But as the First Executive Corporation was crumbling under the weight of defaulting bonds, Mr. Carr engaged in one financial maneuver that seems to have been designed to save his own financial future, perhaps at the cost of policyholders'. The move may net him $10.7 million. 
 Mr. Carr's gambit came in late February, a couple of weeks after the company said it would report a large loss for last year. By then, speculation was flying that its major insurance subsidiaries would be seized by regulators -- as happened to one of them, Executive Life of California, last week -- and there was little doubt that if that happened, First Executive eventually would have to file for bankruptcy.
The move made then was to set up a new subsidiary, called Rhodes Financial, which was supposed to seek outside investors and then go into the insurance business, investing only in high-quality bonds.
By then it was probably too late for any such strategy. But First Executive's subsidiaries nonetheless put $22 million into Rhodes, which immediately guaranteed some obligations of Executive Life.
None of them, as it happened, were insurance policies the company sold. Instead, Rhodes guaranteed $11.2 million in deferred compensation for 11 Executive Life officials, including $10.7 million for Mr. Carr. Should Executive Life fail to make the payments, Rhodes promises to pony up the money immediately, even if a court rules that it would be a fraudulent transfer for Executive Life to pay Mr. Carr. The plan was disclosed deep in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The takeover of Executive Life last week was viewed as old news by stock traders, who instead focused on low inflation figures that renewed hopes for Fed easing. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 24.01 points, to 2,901.79.
But First Executive's problems are of great importance to many, of whom Mr. Carr is only the most prominent. It should be noted that the evidence is that his ethical standards were significantly higher than many others' in the junk bond market, and his $600,000 annual cash compensation pales next to the tens of millions that some junk buyers were taking in. He owns almost a million shares of First Executive, now almost worthless, which he could have sold for high prices when the company seemed to be prospering. He no doubt thinks he deserves his deferred compensation.
But Mr. Carr, who did not return telephone calls, is not the only one who is going to suffer as a result of his junk buying. There are hundreds of thousands of people -- most of whom never made anything close to $600,000 a year -- whose retirement income depends on Executive Life living up to its obligations. Wouldn't it be nice if First Executive had shown an equal determination to assure those payments?

HEADLINE: Big Boats Take It on the Chin

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

DATELINE: ROWAYTON, Conn.

 BODY:
Brokers and buyers normally crowd the docks and boatyards this time of year along the waterfront of this small Fairfield County village on Long Island Sound. This year, though, the area seems virtually abandoned, and a strange quiet, broken only by the faint clanks of rigging rattling in the wind, fills the air.
"I've been in the business 21 years, and I have never seen anything like this," said R. Grove Ely, the president of Boatworks Yacht Sales, which has offices here and in Essex, Conn. "The business has been extremely slow. Our new-boat business is dead." 
 Buffeted by the recession and now the 10 percent Federal luxury tax on the anything over a $100,000 price tag on a a new boat, yacht sales nationally have fallen steeply in the last year.
Yacht dealers and boating association officials say the imposition of the luxury tax on Jan. 1 has caused further devastation in what was already a recession-ravaged industry. Some extra sales were made in December to people who wanted to beat the tax, but sales so far this year appear to be behind even last year's dismal pace.
The tax adds $10,000 to the cost of a $200,000 yacht, for example, and that's on top of any state and local sales taxes. In states with high sales taxes, like Connecticut (8 percent), dealers say the extra cost makes even their wealthier customers flinch.
"They couldn't have hit us at a worse time," said Carlton M. Barlow, a salesman at Boatworks Yacht in its Essex office.
Many old established manufacturers, like Pearson Yachts in Portsmouth, R.I., have filed for bankruptcy. "If you had asked me in 1987 who our biggest direct competitors are, I would have named five companies, four of which have filed for bankruptcy or ceased operation," said Katherine J. Exner, treasurer of Pearson Yachts. "People aren't buying big boats."
The National Marine Manufacturers Association in Chicago says sales nationally of new large powerboats with built-in engines declined to 7,500 in 1990 from 13,500 in 1988. Sales of new large sailboats with auxiliary engines, fell to 1,600 in 1990, from 2,300 in 1988.
No figures for the inboard powerboats or sailboats have been compiled yet for the first three months of this year, but industry officials say sales from the winter boat shows were poor.
Greg Proteau, director of public and financial relations for the manufacturers' group, said the deepest drop in sales had occurred in the Northeast and Florida. "People are just out of the consuming mode," he said. By contrast, California and the Pacific Northwest have experienced some downturn but less than in the East.
Though the very word yacht conjures up images of the Trump Princess and other 200-foot-long ocean-going vessels that cost millions, most are not so elaborate. Descriptions by manufacturers and dealers vary greatly, but few boats less than 36 feet long would be considered yachts. Prices for vessels longer than that start about $100,000 before running into the millions that buy the very fancy the bedrooms and advanced the navigational gear is.
On a $200,000 boat, the luxury tax would be $10,000, which is 10 percent of the amount above the $100,000 nontaxable floor. The tax was passed as part of last year's Federal budget accord.
Mr. Ely said he had not sold a single new boat that cost more than $100,000 this year. He believes he would have sold three or four except for the recession and the luxury tax.
"We had two car dealers who were going to buy $280,000 boats but backed down because their businesses were down 30 percent," he said.
Mr. Ely noted that he had sold five yachts at more than $100,000 at the end of 1990, as customers tried to beat the luxury tax. But, he added, "These days, there are lot of people out there looking and shopping, but something is stopping them."
The impact of the luxury tax and the recession have also been felt on the boat business on the New Jersey shore, particularly around Egg Harbor. Several boat manufacturers and suppliers there have closed or laid off substantial numbers of workers. The boating industry employs about 31,200 people in New York, 19,000 in New Jersey and 12,000 in Connecticut. About a third of the workers are involved in manufacturing boats, equipment and supplies.The others are involved in sales and service.
At least one boat dealer, Ocean Yachts of Egg Harbor City, N.J., offered to pay the luxury tax on some models of 42 to 58 feet in length from Jan. 1 to April 1. Stu N. Coren, a spokesman for the company, added that many dealers were pricing their boats more aggressively to make up for sales lost both to the recession and the luxury tax. "It was moderately successful," he said about Ocean Yacht's program to pay the luxury tax. "But it was far from overwhelmingly successful."
Mr. Proteau said the recent sales slump was far more pronounced than the one that hit during the 1981-82 recession. He said annual sales of all boats, from canoes to cruisers, dropped from 615,000 in 1979 to 500,000 in 1982. Sales then rose by almost 50 percent, to about 750,000 in 1987 before falling back to 504,000 last year.
He also said the industry's overall employment level had declined to 500,000 people last year, from 600,000 in 1988. "And now, we stand to lose another 6,000 to 8,000 jobs, mainly in the manufacturing end, because of the luxury tax," he said.
Robert T. Healey, the owner of the Viking Yacht Company, a boat manufacturer in New Gretna, N.J., has formed a national organization, the Committee to Save Jobs in Boating, to fight for repeal of the tax. Already, political action committees have been formed in more than 20 states.
Mr. Healey's company has reduced its work force in the last year to 400 from 1,400, although 700 of those jobs were lost when the company's boatyard in St. Petersburg, Fla., was shut down. "I can tell you 20 companies that are in our shape or worse," he said.
Boating industry officials have fiercely criticized the tax, which some members of Congress are seeking to repeal. The tax also applies to new cars that cost more than $30,000, airplanes over $250,000 and jewelry and furs costing more than $10,000, and these industries have also complained about the new tax.
Boat dealers said it seemed unfair that the tax did not apply to some expensive recreational vehicles. Dealers added that aside from hurting their sales and thus forcing manufacturers to dismiss employees, the revenue would not cover the Federal Goverment's costs to administer the tax.
Several dealers said the tax was imposed under the assumption that affluent people who buy expensive goods like yachts would continue to do so despite an additional tax.
That is not the case, said Mr. Proteau of the marine manufacturers' group, adding, "There is price sensitivity at these levels."
Mr. Ely of Boatworks agreed. "The tax does hurt," he said. "It is a lot of money for our customers. Don't forget, if they are buying a $200,000 boat, they are spending $16,000 with the 8 percent Connecticut sales tax. With the luxury tax, they are paying $26,000 in taxes. And that stops them right in their tracks."
Other parts of the boating industry are being affected unevenly. James S. Stamos, executive vice president at Yegen Marine, a marine banking company with its headquarters in Paramus, N.J., said the demand for financing for new boats was down 30 percent since 1988, despite recently improved terms of 10.25 percent for a fixed-rate 15-year loan.
The average boat loan at Yegen Marine is for $90,000 to $140,000. "The luxury tax is really something people are considering," he said.
But there has been an opposite impact on the yacht-chartering business. "Business is booming, up 20 percent from last year," said George Rosen, the president and commodore of the Yacht Owners Association of New York, which offers owners' boats for short-term leasing. "This is the first time I've ever had to work on Saturday and Sunday to show the boats. Some people are spending $10,000, $20,000, $30,000 on four-hour company parties, weddings, proms."
The used-yacht business also remains relatively unaffected by the recession. Industry officials said this segment of the market had remained stable because the luxury tax does not apply to sales of used yachts and because there is an abundance of long-lasting fiberglass boats. Indeed, Mr. Ely said he sold eight used yachts in January and February for $200,000 to $250,000 each.

HEADLINE: Milk Profiteers Hurt Farmers and Consumers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Despite the convincing rhetoric of "Milking Poor Families" (editorial, March 21), I disagree with your assumptions about who gains and who loses by Senator Patrick Leahy's amendment to an emergency appropriations bill. 
 The proposal to raise dairy prices at the farm gate would have done just that -- nothing more. You are wrong to assume that higher farm prices translate directly into higher retail milk prices. Here's why:
Last year, the farm price of dairy products fell 25 percent to 30 percent. At the same time, Department of Agriculture "market basket" surveys indicated that retail milk prices rose more than 9 percent!
Your assertion that higher farm prices "devastate" consumers -- particularly poor consumers -- would have us believe that shoppers are going down to the farm to buy their milk directly from a greedy farmer. Consumers are paying only 24 cents of every food dollar to farmers -- the other 76 cents goes to advertising, processing, packaging. From the cost of a loaf of bread, for instance, wheat farmers collect less than 5 cents.
Lastly, you equate the economic crisis that dairy farmers are facing with what other Americans are suffering as a result of the recession. But when every dairy farmer in the country is operating with red-ink prices, that's not a recession -- that's an emergency.
 
LELAND SWENSON
President, National Farmers Union
Denver, April 2, 1991

HEADLINE: The Word on Strategies From A.T.& T.

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Senator Everett Dirksen had a favorite rhetorical device for speeches back home in Illinois. He'd pull a newspaper clipping from his pocket and begin to read a spirited editorial denunciation of some political miscreant. After a few sentences, he'd stop, look around in mock astonishment and say: "Why, do you know who they're talking about? They're talking about me."
It's tempting to say I had a similar reaction when I read A. Michael Noll's "The Failures of A.T.& T. Strategies" (Forum, March 31). As he attacked the wisdom of our trying to acquire the NCR Corporation and accused us of lacking direction, he mischaracterized A.T.& T. as it is today and as it is developing for the future. 
 A.T.& T.'s mission is broad and deep: to be the world leader in information technology -- a technology that inescapably involves the best of both computer and communications technology.
A.T.& T. has a well-defined strategy for establishing leadership in this field:
1) Maintaining leadership in its core businesses like network services (which Mr. Noll extols) and the manufacturing and sale of network telecommunications equipment (which he ignores).
2) Establishing world leadership in networked computing, which is the technology driving the growth of electronic transactions. We expect such transactions, now running about 50 billion a year, to reach 200 billion annually by 1995. The critical enabler for satisfying this demand is the marriage of convenient user terminals like NCR's automatic teller machine computer systems and error-free communications networks.
3) To firmly establish A.T.& T. as a truly global company.
The merger with NCR would combine NCR's leadership in the hardware and software of electronic transactions with A.T.& T.'s expertise in the global networking of information.
NCR's technology would benefit from the support of A.T.& T. Bell Laboratories, the world's leading research and development organization. A.T.& T.'s globalization drive would benefit from NCR's vast international presence and customer base.
Mr. Noll apparently would have A.T.& T. stick to its telecommunications knitting, ignoring the fact that telecommunications and computing have been linked irrevocably for years.
More disturbing, he seems to endorse the idea that economic growth is dependent almost exclusively on services, and that manufacturing should be left to others. This approach doesn't add up for America or for A.T.& T. In the new age of information technology, products and services are increasingly hard to separate. Consider: Is a cash machine, or supermarket point-of-sale terminal, a product or a service?
Mr. Noll's implication that A.T.&T.'s "premier network" is not producing new information services is at odds with the facts. A.T.& T. has kept the United States network infrastructure the envy of the world. A.T.& T. has been putting more and more intelligence into its public switched network, available to large and small users at whatever level they wish and without the need for huge capital investments in private networks.
To borrow a phrase, the company has done well by doing good. A.T.& T. had record earnings in 1989, and held them last year, despite a sliding economy, with the help of a 40 percent increase in international equipment sales.
As Everett Dirksen also used to say: "I'll sketch it for you in brief form." We have computers and communications; we have products as well as services. And, yes, we do have strategy and direction.
 
RICHARD BODMAN
New York, April 8
 
The author is senior vice president for corporate strategy and development at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
