HEADLINE: Chinese Grow Healthier From Cradle to Grave

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SHANGHAI

 BODY:
In a bare obstetrics ward at the Ninth People's Hospital, Zhang Junyong stretched out on a cot and let the doctor listen through a wooden egg cup to the heartbeat thumping from the bulge in her abdomen. "I'm just a bit nervous," Ms. Zhang confessed with a smile.
Yet in contrast to her mother or grandmother, the 25-year-old Ms. Zhang has little to fear when she gives birth to her first child a few weeks from now. In recent decades China has engineered a remarkable health-care revolution, one that has increased the odds that her infant will be alive in the latter half of the next century. 
 While the Communists have yet to deliver on their promises to provide Chinese with lives that are prosperous and free, they have achieved the remarkable feat of offering their people lives that are long and healthy.
 Plague, tuberculosis and other diseases still exist at the margins of Chinese society, but by channeling funds toward prevention of disease and basic care, the Government has saved tens of millions of lives and established a health care network that is widely regarded as a model for the third world.
 
Life Expectancies
 By the prime measures of healthfulness, Ms. Zhang's infant will have better odds of survival than a baby born in New York City. In Shanghai, 10.9 infants out of 1,000 die before their first birthday, while in New York City infant mortality is 13.3 per 1,000 live births.
And life expectancy at birth in Shanghai is now 75.5 years, compared to a life expectancy in New York City of about 73 years for whites and 70 years for nonwhites as of 1980, the last year for which data are available. A spokeswoman for the city Department of Health said it did not have a life expectancy statistic combining all races.
To be sure, New York City's statistics are worse than those for the United States as a whole, where life expectancy is 76 years and infant mortality is 9 deaths per 1,000. Shanghai's figures are the best in China, where the nationwide life expectancy is 70 and infant mortality is 31 per thousand.
But New York and Shanghai are their country's largest and most crowded cities. How can Shanghai, a dilapidated third-world metropolis in a country with a per capita income of $350, give its infants such good odds?
The answer has nothing to do with modern equipment or with money, for Shanghai spends just $38 a person on medical care, compared to more than $2,100 in the United States. It appears that only about 5 percent of the Chinese gross national product is devoted to health expenditures, compared to 11 percent of America's.
"There's no question that in a time when people are despondent about what's happening in China, the health-care system really is a shining light from the Maoist era that continues to shine to this day," Gail E. Henderson, an expert on Chinese health care at the University of North Carolina School of Medicine, said in an interview. "It's a model for the developing world."
Doctors, health officials and foreign specialists say the Chinese system has succeeded for several reasons. Most fundamentally, it has emphasized prevention of disease, including large-scale projects to improve sanitation and to inoculate children. In the unglamorous but critical foundations of a public health system, like prenatal care, China excels.
 
 Jacks-of-All-Trades Of the Health World
 In visits over the last two years to hospitals and village doctors in seven provinces, the first impression is of rustic examination rooms where the doctors are semi-educated peasants wearing frayed and stained white jackets. Yet the more enduring impression is that these unscrubbed, sandal-clad doctors have a broad range of useful skills -- treating infections, diagnosing pneumonia, assisting in births and pulling teeth -- that in rural areas are more useful than anything at the cutting edge of Western medicine.
In China, money and equipment are limited, and the result is that many die of ailments that could be treated in the West. In most of China, a person who needs dialysis to survive, or a coronary bypass, or an organ transplant, will not get it. He or she will die.
Instead of focusing scarce resources on those relatively expensive procedures, or on extensive diagnostic testing or on care for the aged -- an enormous proportion of American medical spending is devoted to people in the last six months of their lives -- China has tended to put its money into programs like prenatal check-ups, pediatric care and campaigns against epidemics.
"Preventative work is crucial," said Jiang Lianyi, the head of administration of the Shanghai Health Bureau. "The sums are relatively small, and the returns can be enormous."
 
 Exercise, Diet, And Plenty of Tea
 The returns are seen in China's life expectancy at birth of about 70 years, compared to 43 in the West African country of Guinea, 58 in India, 65 in Brazil and 76 in the United States, according to World Bank figures. Third-world health statistics are uncertain, but the World Bank reports that as of 1988 about 31 Chinese infants out of each 1,000 die before their first birthday, compared to 143 in Guinea, 97 in India, 61 in Brazil, and 10 in the United States. (In 1990, infant mortality in the United States declined to 9.1 from 9.7 in 1989.)
"The Chinese health system has done an incredible job," said Dr. B. P. Kean, the World Health Organization representative in China. "If you go just through the figures -- life expectancy, infant mortality, first three causes of death -- without knowing which country it is, it would be very difficult to pick the country as China and almost impossible to pick it as a developing country. The top causes of mortality in the cities are the same as in developed countries: cardiovascular disease, cerebrovascular disease and cancer."
Clearly one reason for China's good statistics has more to do with lifestyle than with medical care: most people get plenty of exercise, keep low-fat diets, drink tea or boiled water rather than tainted tap water, eschew alcohol and narcotics, and are extremely unlikely to be murdered or killed in car accidents. Another factor is the lack of a large "underclass" that lacks ready access to medical care.
Nearly all urban Chinese have their medical bills paid by their employer or by the Government, and in rural areas the fees are low enough that they are not an enormous burden. Delivering a baby, for example, costs the equivalent of a few dollars in the countryside.
Dr. Kean credits the Government with stressing health and hygiene far more than most governments, and he notes that a typical Chinese mayor is far more conversant with health issues than mayors of other countries. High-level government backing has been crucial in one of the most critical initiatives, to vaccinate children against infectuous diseases. About 85 percent of infants are inoculated before their first birthday against six ailments: whooping cough, diphtheria, tetanus, tuberculosis, measles and polio.
 
 Watching Progress Week After Week
 One of the greatest successes of the health campaign has been to promote prenatal care. Even in remote villages, far from any road or electricity, pregnant women are often given a card reminding them to visit a local doctor for frequent check-ups. The doctors monitor the pregnancy and encourage the woman to give birth in a clinic if a low birth weight or other problems are anticipated. Local governments hold training sessions for midwives to aid skills and understanding of hygiene.
In the big cities, a woman normally has monthly check-ups in the first trimester of her pregnancy, examinations every two weeks for the next few months, and weekly check-ups as the due date approaches. While many villages lack incubators and equipment for caesarean sections, the system of check-ups and counseling of pregnant women has reduced infant mortality.
Among the most fundamental problems facing the Chinese system is the shortage of doctors in some rural areas, particularly since the dismantling in the early 1980's of the communes that used to provide health care services. In some poor areas, villages have neglected health care since the communes fell apart, and schistosomiasis -- a disease caused by parasites that live in the blood vessels of humans and animals -- spread as communities stopped mass mobilization efforts to combat the parasite.
Those problems seem to have been partly resolved, and now there is again a determined effort to stamp out schistosomiasis. But problems have surfaced, including surging costs as hospitals compete with each other to buy fancy equipment like brain scanners.
As in the United States, a major reason for rising medical expenses is that there are not many incentives to control them. In Shanghai, where few urban residents pay their own doctor bills, health care expenses are rising 30 percent each year. The authorities are now trying to set administrative limits, curtailing the use of brain scans and other procedures.
 
 Will Future Wealth Bring Future Pain?
 Another challenge is the growing number of migrant families, who move to the cities with or without permission to find whatever jobs they can. They pay for their own health care, and often break the rules and give birth to more children than they are allowed to.
"Our biggest headache is the migrants, because they don't get check-ups and they're afraid we'll report them if they have an extra child," said Zhang Huizhong, director of pediatrics at Shanghai's Ninth People's Hospital. "Even if they're sick they don't come to see a doctor."
Perhaps the greatest long-term challenge to the medical system here is simply the changing lifestyle in China. As they grow wealthier, Chinese are eating more, smoking more, drinking more and exercising less. The numbers of drug addicts and migrants are growing rapidly, and some foreign experts believe that the AIDS virus could spread rapidly here. Young mothers enthusiastically buy infant formula instead of breast-feeding their babies, because they think the powder is more modern and healthy.
"We need to spend more money on health education," said Hu Jinghua, the director of Shanghai Public Health News, an official newspaper. "Ours is a poor country, and we can't afford a lot of equipment. Where the money has the biggest impact is health education."

HEADLINE: Nigeria Weighs Ending Curbs on Pretoria

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAGOS, Nigeria, April 13

 BODY:
In a major policy shift, Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation, has announced that it is considering lifting sanctions against South Africa.
In a speech here Friday night, President Ibrahim Babangida said Nigeria was "gratified by recent positive developments" in South Africa and would consider lifting sanctions to reward initiatives toward dismantling apartheid undertaken by the South African President, F. W. de Klerk. 
 "The international community sees these developments as demonstration of President Frederik de Klerk's commitment to a peace process that will lead to the creation of a free and democratic South Africa," Mr. Babangida said.
He said sanctions could be lifted as early as next month, but only if "the remaining apartheid laws are abrogated." Mr. Babangida did not say specifically which laws would have to be removed, although they are believed to include ones imposing racial restrictions on land ownership and residency.
 
O.A.U. to Meet in June
 If those conditions are met, Mr. Babangida said, he would personally lead an effort to get other African nations to lift sanctions at the June meeting of the Organization of African Unity, scheduled to be held in Abuja, which is to become Nigeria's new capital. Mr. Babangida is assuming the rotating presidency of the group, a yearlong role.
Nigeria was among the first nations on the continent to impose trade sanctions and among those most committed to maintaining Pretoria's diplomatic and economic isolation. Tactics have encompassed financial, trade and investment sanctions, oil and arms embargoes and sports, cultural and academic boycotts.
Analysts said Mr. Babangida's newly conciliatory stance is likely to come as bitter blow to some militant leaders of the African National Congress, who recently appealed for sanctions to be maintained.
The lifting of sanctions being considered by other nations, including those of the European Community, is expected to be high on the agenda of a conference between black American political and business leaders and their African counterparts, scheduled for next week in Abidjan, the Ivory Coast.
 
Some Puzzled by Conditions
 The conference, sponsored by the Rev. Leon H. Sullivan, one of the architects of the South African disinvestment movement in the United States, is expected to be attended by at least seven African heads of government, including Mr. Babangida.
Several African and Western diplomats said today that they were somewhat puzzled by Mr. Babangida's conditions for the lifting of sanctions since, in their view, it was unlikely that Pretoria would completely dismantle the 42-year-old apartheid system by June.
Nevertheless, Mr. Babangida's announcement is "a real breakthough," a Western diplomat said, "because until now Nigeria had been pretty rigid and unyielding on the sanctions issue despite the crumbling of apartheid." He added: "It is not clear, though, what they're trying to accomplish, since nobody believes apartheid is going to go away next month, or even six months from now."

HEADLINE: Political Talk

BYLINE: By Elizabeth Kolbert

 BODY:

Looking for a Spokesman
One month after Mayor David N. Dinkins's press secretary, Albert Scardino, was carried out of the administration on a wave of bad publicity, at least one person has been informally offered the job. 
 He is Randy Daniels, a former CBS-News television correspondent and a former press secretary to the City Council President, Andrew J. Stein.
Senior New York City officials said that Mr. Daniels, who had lunch with the Mayor a few weeks ago, had been offered the job informally but that he had reservations about taking it.
Mr. Daniels, who works for Caroline Jones Inc., an advertising agency, has been detached from the agency to serve as press secretary to the Prime Minister of the Bahamas, Sir Lynden Pindling.
Reached in the Bahamas, Mr. Daniels deflected questions about the offer, saying he had contractual obligations and "until such time as those obligations have been fulfilled, I am not in a position to do anything other than what I'm doing."
Leland T. Jones, a longtime press aide to both Mr. Dinkins and former Mayor Edward I. Koch, has been acting press secretary since Mr. Scardino resigned.
 
Symbols of Excess
Perhaps the most visible target of anti-tax sentiment in Trenton -- next to Gov. Jim Florio -- is Joseph V. Doria. This is not just because Mr. Doria is the Assembly Speaker. It is because, at 5 feet 11 inches and 250 pounds, Mr. Doria is hard to miss.
 As New Jersey's tax rebellion has grown in rancor, some local newspapers and radio stations have gone so far as to use Mr. Doria to personify fat in government. Now Mr. Doria, a Bayonne Democrat, is confronting the problem head on.
 In preparation for a difficult re-election campaign next fall, Mr. Doria is appearing in a television commercial in which he carves up a pumpkin pie while explaining that the state budget goes to pay for education, roads, environment and other good things.
"And I am big enough to admit we can't afford an extra piece of this pie," Mr. Doria adds. He then drops a piece of pie that is labeled "big government" with a crash.
Fifteen pies were used in the taping.
 
Their Idea; No, Theirs
For those in Albany who were not yet convinced that fear of blame was the major obstacle to a new state budget, last week's contretemps over the so-called "Wisconsin tax" was highly instructive.
The proposed "Wisconsin tax," a gross-receipts tax on businesses patterned after one in Wisconsin, seemed to have arrived from nowhere, but suddenly it was under serious discussion at budget negotiations.
Just as suddenly, when reporters asked about the tax's origins, negotiations broke down, as each side rushed to attribute the proposal to the other.
"It came from them," Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said, referring to the legislative leaders.
"It's their idea," John McArdle, a spokesman for the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, said, pointing back at the Governor's staff.
"If they want to advance it, we'll look at it," Steven Greenberg, a spokesman for the Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, said.
Seemingly embarrassed by all the finger-pointing, Governor Cuomo finally stepped in to accept responsibility for the proposal, but in the process denied that it was really his.
"It wasn't ours, but I will take credit for it," he said.
 
The Meek Learn to Roar
It might not be quite of the magnitude of the meek inheriting the earth, but in Connecticut's General Assembly, the led have definitely become the leaders.
As the two chambers struggle with a formidable budget deficit, a stubborn recession and a Governor, Lowell P. Weicker Jr., who is publicly preoccupied with an income-tax proposal, the majority leaders have become all but paralyzed.
The Democrats control both the House and Senate, but almost all the initiatives in challenging Mr. Weicker, an independent, have come from the disenfranchised: the minority Republicans and the middle-of-the-road Democrats who have few leadership positions -- and thus less to lose in stepping up to bat.
On Thursday, when Mr. Weicker announced that a Republican no-income-tax plan would die on his desk if passed in the Legislature, it fell, predictably, to the unempowered middle-of-the-roaders to speak out in the most ringing terms about the inviolable rights of the legislative branch.
"The General Assembly is not going to be bullied by Lowell Weicker or anybody else," thundered Senator James H. Maloney, Democrat of Danbury, who is co-chairman of the low-profile Labor and Public Employees Committee.
 
Vying for a Judgeship
Mark Alan Siegel is looking to come back.
Mr. Siegel, an eight-term Assemblyman known for his love of publicity, surprised his colleagues last year when he decided not to run for re-election from his Upper East Side district. Now he is looking for appointment by Mayor Dinkins as a Civil Court Judge.
 Mr. Siegel has the backing of the Manhattan Democratic leader, Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., a Dinkins ally, but is opposed by some East Side Democratic leaders, who feel that he is trying to jump to the front of the line of judicial hopefuls in the Sixth District.

HEADLINE: Trump and Civic Groups Team Up to Oversee Big Riverside Project

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Turning their unusual relationship into something unique in New York City, Donald J. Trump and six of his natural antagonists -- civic, environmental and neighborhood groups -- have formed a corporate partnership to oversee the design of Mr. Trump's 76-acre site on the Hudson River.
By creating the Riverside South Planning Corporation, the developer and the civic leaders said they hoped to stay on the cooperative path they blazed last month, when Mr. Trump embraced the groups' counterproposal to Trump City. 
 "Riverside South" is an 8.3 million-square-foot project with a 23-acre waterfront park, separated by a highway that would replace the elevated viaduct now on the river's edge. Apartment towers would line this highway in a kind of large-scale emulation of Riverside Drive.
"The real character, quality and impact of the project have yet to be determined," said the chairman of the new corporation, Richard A. Kahan, who once headed the New York State Urban Development Corporation and the Battery Park City Authority.
 
Alternative to 'Combat'
 Besides Mr. Trump and Mr. Kahan, the board consists of representatives from the Municipal Art Society, the Natural Resources Defense Council, the Parks Council, People for Westpride, the Regional Plan Association and the Riverside Park Fund.
While both sides acknowledge the riskiness of their alliance, they believe the potential gain is worth the gamble. "This is an opportunity to demonstrate that there is an alternative process to combat," Mr. Kahan said.
Mr. Trump would sacrifice some control over his project but would get a proposal that might move more quickly through city review, face less litigation and yield parcels that would be easier to sell or lease.
The civic groups would give up their detached, critical role and might lose credibility among their constituents. But they would end up with an extension of Riverside Park, where Mr. Trump proposed a cluster of giant skyscrapers.
There is apparently no precedent for their joint effort. To the extent that civic groups have influenced development in the past, it has been through litigation or bargaining behind the scenes.
The corporation will reach its decisions by consensus, Mr. Kahan said. Should irreconcilable differences arise, Mr. Trump has the right to withdraw from the corporation. He is underwriting its $1 million operating budget.
Under the timetable it set for itself, the corporation is to develop a plan that could be ready for the city's review procedure by the end of the year. Design guidelines set by the board "will, in one way or other, be legally binding," Mr. Kahan said.
 
Trump City Now 'Dormant'
 A new architectural team consists of David M. Childs and Marilyn Jordan Taylor of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill and Paul Willen of Daniel Pang & Associates. Mr. Willen designed Riverside South and was also the architect in charge of the Lincoln West project for the same site in the early 1980's.
They are to be assisted by Steven Robinson, an architect and opponent of Trump City, and Daniel Gutman, an environmental consultant who worked with Mr. Willen on Riverside South.
This team replaces the firm of Cooper, Robertson & Partners, which had drawn up Trump City, a 14.5 million-square-foot project that included a 1,835-foot skyscraper and 11 apartment towers. Mr. Trump said that plan was "dormant."
"I think the job we did initially was very positive," Mr. Trump said last week. "It galvanized everyone."
Civic leaders had told Mr. Trump that they would fight Trump City fiercely, said Kent L. Barwick, president of the Municipal Art Commission and a Riverside South board member.
On the other hand, Mr. Barwick said, "We told him he could be assured, if he adopted the plan we were proposing, that we would be equally fierce in seeing to it that it would be delivered."
What also motivated the civic groups was a keen desire to see the elevated West Side Highway lowered to ground level and moved well inland, opening up an uninterrupted waterfront park. With that in mind, they came up with Riverside South. "I saw people coming out and loving that plan," Mr. Trump said. "I wanted to take advantage of that."
"This is not a development," he said. "It's a great street or avenue or drive, with individual, separate and distinct buildings on it."
 
Unwanted Highway
 Such a project would be easier to split into discrete parcels. "What I envision is the very distinct possibility that certain sites would be sold or leased to various high-quality developers," Mr. Trump said, although he also contemplates building on a number of sites himself.
Mr. Trump said he was the "No. 1 fan of getting the highway down." Linda Davidoff, executive director of the Parks Council and a Riverside South board member, repeated Mr. Trump's observation that apartments facing a waterfront park can be sold for more money than those facing a highway.
Asked whether his decision to form a partnership with civic groups was a measure of desperation, Mr. Trump replied: "I am in much better shape than almost all other developers. The only reason I'm doing this is because it will be a better development that will be approved in record time because of its almost universal popularity."
As to their agenda, civic leaders noted several important points. "There is no other opportunity in the city or the state to create a park," said Frances Beinecke, deputy executive director of the Natural Resources Defense Council and a Riverside South board member.
The civic leaders say their job is not to supplant formal review by Community Board 7, the City Planning Commission and the City Council.
Nonetheless, Ethel Sheffer, a community board member, is somewhat wary of the corporation.
"One can only hope that it's a good thing," she said, "but amidst all the huzzahs, it's important that this entire effort be scrutinized carefully, because there are many issues that are not only unresolved but that require serious work" -- chief among them being the fate of the highway.

HEADLINE: Medicaid Morass/Troubled Policy in Hard Times
A special report.;
New York's Medicaid Costs Surge, But Health Care for the Poor Lags

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 12

 BODY:
As New York struggles through a fiscal crisis, its ever-expanding Medicaid program, already the most expensive in the nation, has emerged as discouraging proof of just how profound and intractable the state's budget problems are.
Over the last five years, annual spending on Medicaid has increased by 60 percent, to roughly $12 billion. So expensive is the program that it now consumes almost one of every seven state tax dollars. Many county governments are being forced to raise taxes as they, too, strain to pay their share. 
 But to look just at the spending side is to miss the full magnitude of the Medicaid problem. That can be found only in the distressed faces of recipients like William Cummings, an unemployed 31-year-old typist who suffers from asthma. Mr. Cummings receives virtually all of his care through hospital emergency rooms, waiting up to eight hours each time to see a physician.
"I very much would like to have my own doctor," Mr. Cummings said during a recent wait at Jacobi Hospital in the north Bronx. "But where I live, there is no doctor nearby that takes Medicaid."
Medicaid is the primary government health-care program for the poor, financed with Federal, state and in some cases local funds. Despite the vast sums spent on Medicaid in New York, there is widespread agreement that the program fails to deliver adequate services to the people for whom it was intended -- poor people like Mr. Cummings. More and more of its resources are funneled to the elderly -- many of them middle-class -- while for the poor, health care is still often limited to overcrowded clinics and emergency rooms. And at a time when many other social services for the poor are shrinking, many experts say that what is needed is not less Medicaid spending but more.
Stripped of its technical details, New York's gathering Medicaid crisis is a grim metaphor for the quandary facing the state as its social problems and its budget deficit -- now estimated at $6 billion for the current fiscal year -- grow simultaneously. It illustrates the essential conflict between New York's need to cut costs and its reluctance to retreat from the policies that have made its social-welfare programs some of the most generous, and expensive, in the nation.
Efforts to revamp Medicaid and rein in its runaway costs have been stalled for years by a slow-moving bureaucracy and a battery of special-interest groups. And while the state is finally making some genuine efforts to revise the system under the enormous pressure of its budget squeeze, even the most optimistic forecasters acknowledge that Medicaid will remain a drag on the budget process at least through the 1990's. "Your best hope with Medicaid is that you can control the rate of spending increase," said Michael J. Dowling, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's deputy secretary for human services.
New York is by no means the only state where expenses for Medicaid are growing rapidly. Several forces are responsible for this seemingly inexorable growth: the aging population, the AIDS epidemic and the unchecked inflation in health-care costs.
But by almost any standard, New York's Medicaid spending dwarfs that of other states. While New York, for instance, has roughly one-tenth of the country's Medicaid recipients, it accounts for almost one-fifth of the money spent.
The high cost of Medicaid in New York reflects many of the state's peculiar problems, including high labor costs, a heavy reliance on hospital care, and poor people who are on the whole sicker and more troubled than in other states. But it is also a reflection of state policy: Not only is it easier to qualify for Medicaid in New York than in most other states, but once you qualify you are entitled to greater benefits. "New York provides levels of services that would be unthinkable in other parts of the country," said Joshua M. Weiner, senior fellow at the Brookings Institution in Washington.
New York also reimburses hospitals at higher rates than many other states, pegging Medicaid reimbursement to private insurance rates.
The costs of New York's Medicaid program are staggering not only for the state, but also for its local governments. Washington pays for half of all Medicaid costs; New York splits the other half with its localities, one of 14 states to require a local contribution. For New York City, where more than 1.5 million of the state's 2.3 million Medicaid recipients live, the local share of the program came to $1.6 billion last year.
Over the years, to take advantage of Federal funds available for the program, the state has shifted so many health programs into Medicaid that a comprehensive overview is almost impossible. But an examination of major elements of the program shows how Medicaid has become so expensive, and why it is so difficult to bring the cost down.
 
The Program
Broad Access and Many Services

The Federal Medicaid program, begun in 1965, is a vast collection of benefits that, like a weather system, changes form as it passes from region to region. Each state administers its own program, and Federal guidelines give states wide latitude to fashion their own package of services and eligibility rules.
States are required to provide Medicaid to all Federal welfare recipients, as well as to any elderly, blind or disabled people who are eligible for Supplemental Security Income payments. But New York extends Medicaid coverage to many groups beyond this.
For example, more than 600,000 New Yorkers whose incomes exceed the welfare threshold receive Medicaid under a classification called "medically needy." Thirty-six states provide some Medicaid coverage to the "medically needy," but most set their income limits far below New York's. A family of three in New York is classified as medically needy if its monthly income is below $725. In Pennsylvania, the family can have an income of only $467, and in Georgia $308.
Because of New York's high cost of living, the state's liberal eligibility standards have rarely come under attack. But its broad benefits have.
Under Medicaid, states are required to offer several services, including hospitalization, family planning and nursing-home care. But many other benefits, like dentistry, optometry, podiatry and emergency hospital care, are considered optional.
Of the 31 optional services, New York offers 26. Only four states -- California, Massachusetts, Washington and Wisconsin -- offer more. And while most states impose limits on optional services, New York has almost none.
Many experts call this unlimited access an invitation to abuse, which by some estimates consumes as much as $2 billion of New York's annual Medicaid budget.
But proposals to limit access have run into heavy opposition from physicians, who fear more paperwork, and advocates for the poor, who argue that such limits will penalize recipients with chronic medical problems.
Late last year, for the first time, Governor Cuomo succeeded in imposing limits on the services that childless adults can receive without special permission: 14 physician visits and 18 laboratory tests a year. The Governor has proposed extending these limits to other Medicaid recipients as well, but the prospects for that plan are uncertain.
 
The Elderly
The High Cost of Nursing Homes
 When Medicaid was introduced in New York in 1966, it was billed as a significant step toward a truly egalitarian society, a program that would, in the words of Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, "make it unnecessary for any citizen to go without needed medical care because he is unable to pay for it."
In the intervening years, however, New York's Medicaid program has drifted away from that original intent. More and more of the program's resources are being devoted to the elderly, many of whom are essentially middle class, rather than to the poor.
"Medicaid is not a program that just takes the mother with three kids who doesn't know who the father is," Mr. Dowling, the Governor's adviser, said. "That's a typical myth."
In New York, children make up 46 percent of the population eligible for Medicaid, but consume only about 13 percent of the dollars. By contrast, the elderly make up only 13 percent of the eligible population but spend 41 percent of New York's Medicaid dollars.
The cost of nursing home care -- which is not covered by Medicare, the main Federal health program for the elderly -- is the major factor behind these skewed statistics. Even critics concede that New York's nursing home care is better than in most states, but it is also expensive. Last year, nursing-home care consumed more than $3 billion, or almost 30 percent of all Medicaid dollars spent in New York.
Although New York pays private physicians extremely low rates under Medicaid -- just $11 for many visits -- its payments to institutions like nursing homes, which have powerful lobbying groups, are among the highest in the country. A study by the National Governors' Association found that in 1989, New York's Medicaid nursing-home rate of $112 a day was second only to New Hampshire's.
 
'Spending Down'

Because nursing-home care is so expensive in New York -- private rates average $143 a day -- it is commonplace for patients to enter nursing homes as private patients and eventually become eligible for Medicaid.
This process is known as "spending down" -- patients spend their assets until they fall below Medicaid eligibility standards. More than half of the people who enter nursing homes in New York as private patients and stay more than two years eventually spend down to become eligible for Medicaid.
While the high cost of nursing-home care makes it easy for elderly patients to spend down, New York has made it even easier.
Three years ago, the Federal Government established regulations intended to prevent elderly people from becoming impoverished because of a spouse's illness. These regulations allowed states, within limits, to chose how much income the healthy, or "community," spouse could keep while the ailing spouse became entitled to Medicaid.
New York, unlike most states, chose the most liberal standards allowed.
The Federal regulations provided, for example, that states could allow the community spouse to keep from $12,000 to $60,000 in assets like stocks; New York's Legislature, after heavy lobbying by organizations for the elderly, chose the $60,000 maximum. Similarly, New York allowed the community spouse to keep the maximum monthly income of $1,500.
"For a good part of our experience, Medicaid is a program for the middle class, not the poor," said Jo-Ann A. Costantino, deputy commissioner of social services.
 
Home Care
Expanding Care, Rising Costs
 In an effort to keep people out of expensive nursing homes, New York has aggressively promoted the use of health-care workers who attend to the elderly and disabled in the patients' own homes.
This campaign appears to have been successful: New York has fewer nursing-home beds per elderly resident than most states.
But success has come at a cost: Last year, New York spent almost $2.1 billion on home health care, or roughly 80 percent of all the Medicaid dollars in the country devoted to such care. (Some states finance home health care using other sources of funds; still, New York's costs far exceed the rest of the nation's.)
Home-care costs in New York have been growing explosively in recent years; since 1985, they have more than tripled. State officials attribute the increase to better wages for home-care workers. But the high cost of home care in New York also reflects the state's comprehensive approach toward Medicaid.
While in theory home care saves money by keeping people out of nursing homes, New York has expanded the service to many elderly people who would not necessarily have needed nursing-home care. Under Medicaid, New York provides not only the kind of home care mandated by the Federal Government -- a kind of at-home nursing care -- but also a simpler form of home care, providing help with dressing and bathing, that is considered optional. And the state sets few limits on the amount of home care.
 
Considering the Cost

In an increasing number of cases, the cost of home health care has come to exceed the cost of a nursing home bed, prompting criticism that the program has grown out of control.
State figures show that there are currently 2,400 home-care cases that cost more than $45,000 a year, the average cost of nursing-home care in New York City. Of these, 150 cost more than $100,000 a year. In one case, Medicaid is providing 24-hour-a-day care to an upstate man with Lou Gehrig's disease at an annual cost of almost $200,000.
Current law bars the state from considering cost when determining whether a Medicaid recipient should receive home health care. This year, Governor Cuomo has proposed changing the law, so that some patients could be moved to nursing homes.
But even if this change is approved, home health care costs are expected to continue to rise steeply, in part because of the state's aging population, and in part because of a changing social structure in which many increasingly mobile children can no longer care for their parents.
 
The Poor
Emergency Rooms As the Sole Option
 There is widespread agreement that the poor families for whom Medicaid was intended are the least well served by New York's system.
New York's reimbursement rates for private physicians are so low -- in some categories they are second-lowest after West Virginia's -- that only 25 percent of the state's doctors regularly treat Medicaid patients. As a result, many recipients have come to rely on expensive emergency-room treatment as their primary form of medical care.
A visit to the emergency room at any municipal hospital in New York City offers testimony to the failures of New York's Medicaid program. On a recent afternoon at Bellevue Hospital in Manhattan, for example, about two dozen patients sat outside the emergency room, waiting to be seen by a physician, while inside, the more seriously ill, wheezing and groaning, were being attended.
The patients in the waiting room -- some Medicaid recipients, some without any insurance -- did not require emergency care; when asked to describe their problems, they labeled them "non-urgent." But they had nowhere else to go, said Dr. Lewis Goldfrank, Bellevue's director of emergency services.
Although there has been little systematic study of the issue, experts say it is clear that over-reliance on emergency rooms is helping to drive up Medicaid costs in New York. Because Medicaid patients often receive inadequate primary care, they say, ailments that could easily have been prevented often become serious illnesses that require expensive hospitalization.
"People come to us with foot injuries because no one taught them to wash between their toes," said Dr. Goldfrank, whose emergency room handles 100,000 visits a year.
In an effort to change this, the state's Department of Social Services has been pushing a new approach toward Medicaid, known in bureaucratic lingo as "managed care." The concept is simple: to enroll Medicaid recipients with group practices, hospital clinics or private physicians who will, for a set fee, oversee their medical care. The goal is to establish long-term relations between doctors and Medicaid patients that will improve preventive care and avert unnecessary expenses later.
Although the department has had some success with managed-care programs, efforts to enroll large numbers of Medicaid recipients have been blocked by a powerful combination of political concerns and institutional inertia.
Insisting that Medicaid patients be able to choose their own health-care program, lawmakers from New York City have long resisted efforts to make managed care mandatory. To date, hospitals have been slow to establish neighborhood clinics, and the state has provided little start-up money.
This year, the state appears to be making some headway toward introducing managed care on a grand scale. A proposal by the Governor to phase in mandatory managed care has received a polite reception in the Legislature, and the state is offering $20 million in grants to hospitals to establish neighborhood clinics. But few experts expect to see any savings from managed care for many years.
"The immediate purpose is to improve access to the right kind of services, " Mr. Dowling said. "It's not to save money in the short run, and anyone who thinks that has the wrong idea."
 
The Prospects
Few Options to Save Money
 By most estimates, New York's current predicament -- reduced resources coupled with increasing needs -- will persist far beyond this year's budget struggle. So, too, will the struggle over how to curb Medicaid costs.
To cut costs significantly, there are few options: reduce eligibility, cut the services offered, limit access to these services or reduce the rates paid to hospitals and nursing homes. All of these options are likely to be pursued in some form in the coming years. But all of them also face substantial political opposition from advocates for the poor and health-care providers.
One of the more radical options, now being tried in Oregon, is to ration Medicaid care, with some procedures given high priority and others shunted to the bottom of the list. But given New York's long history of resistance toward such restrictions, such rationing seems unlikely here.
In the absence of more sweeping changes imposed from Washington, many experts predict that New York's Medicaid program will be the focus of years of wrangling -- and the cause of chronic spending problems.
"There are two choices," said Assemblyman James R. Tallon, a Binghamton Democrat and a nationally recognized Medicaid expert. "Either the country has to look itself in the mirror and say, 'Are we going to adopt a national health-care financing system at long last?' or else we are going to fight these endless guerrilla battles around the edges."
In the abstract, Mr. Tallon said, "everybody supports cutting Medicaid expenditures."
"But when we are finally faced with the ugly reality of how do you cut cost with the tools that are available," he said, "we still as a society don't want to put people out on the street without health care."

HEADLINE: JAPAN RETREATING ON PROMISED LOANS

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 13

 BODY:
Angry over agreements that allow Poland and Egypt to escape foreign debt obligations, Japanese officials say the Government will not provide loans it had promised to those nations and will refuse new loans to other countries that seek debt forgiveness.
The Japanese have been bitterly criticizing President Bush's plan to forgive billions of dollars of the official debt of Poland and Egypt. Officials in Japan's Finance Ministry and its Export-Import Bank, the key agency intended to handle Japan's loans to developing countries, say the Japanese will not fulfill Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's promises to lend Poland $500 million and to provide several loans to Egypt.
 
Tokyo Asserts Itself
 The rift between Japan and the United States is a sign of Japan's growing assertiveness on foreign-aid issues and in setting its own agenda for helping the developing world. The two countries are at odds over a fundamental point in the strategy for dealing with the debt crisis: how big a role politics should be allowed to play in making these economic judgments, and whose political standards should be applied. 
 When Mr. Kaifu pledged the aid to Poland during a visit to Eastern Europe last year, he surprised many Japanese aid specialists because the promise came before financial considerations had been carefully reviewed. With the reversal, it now appears that the formidable Finance Ministry has reasserted itself.
Japanese officials say they feel the Americans are using debt forgiveness to reward certain nations. They complain that this policy encourages financial irresponsibility and makes it difficult to say no to other countries with similar problems.
What some Japanese officials find particularly galling is that they are being criticized for holding to policies long espoused by the United States.
The United States Government has maintained that financial discipline and consistency are essential for fostering improvements in long-term management of the economies of indebted countries. That is one reason the United States had pushed for the restructuring of debts, but not abandonment of them.
Japan has emerged over the past several years as one of the world's largest donors of aid to developing countries, as well as a major government-to-government lender. Japan has budgeted foreign aid of $6.5 billion for the current fiscal year.
Most of the aid and loans are aimed at Asia, where Japanese corporations are centering their investments. But Japan is increasingly providing assistance to Latin America, too.
For its part, the United States has described the debt reduction measures as a selective humanitarian gesture to ease pressure on ailing economies and protect fragile democratic institutions.
 
Political or Economic Decision?
 David C. Mulford, Under Secretary of the Treasury for international affairs, earlier described Poland and Egypt as "unique politically and economically."
In the Japanese view, Washington's selection of these two countries represents a political decision to reward Poland for its commitment to a rapid transition to capitalism and Egypt for its support in the war against Iraq.
The disagreement has stirred an unusual level of emotion on both sides.
An American official described the Japanese stance as "unconscionable" and "coldly financial," arguing that compassion was called for. A senior Finance Ministry official in Japan characterized America's call for debt forgiveness in conjunction with offering fresh loans as "irrational" and "contradictory."
The United States agreed to forgive 70 percent of the $3.8 billion it has lent Poland. It is seeking overall to eliminate half of Poland's $33 billion in debt to other governments.
 
Restructuring Comes at a Price
 Japan currently has 189 billion yen, or about $1.4 billion, in official loans to Poland. It reluctantly agreed to provide some relief under President Bush's initiative, not by forgiving the principal of loans, but by reducing interest payments and converting some interest payments into principal.
In addition, the United States has said it will forgive about $7 billion in loans to Egypt. Japan will also provide relief to Egypt in accord with the United States initiative, officials said. The Japanese Government has roughly $2 billion in loans outstanding to the Middle Eastern country. Again, the Export-Import Bank will hold off on new loans.
The officials said Japan will fulfill a promise made last fall to supply approximately $700 million in subsidized loans to Egypt. That is part of a total of $2 billion in aid Japan pledged to the front-line states that joined the coalition opposing Iraq. But other new loans will be halted.
 
Forgiveness and Contamination
 Japanese officials say that if the American measures are not contained, they could undermine the carefully crafted Brady plan for resolving the debt crisis. The plan was named for Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady.
While the Brady plan relies on some reduction in commercial bank debt in return for new government-to-government loans, the debtor countries must agree to impose market-oriented policies to improve the efficiency of their economies. Under this process, the prospect of repayment of the remaining commercial bank debt is enhanced because fresh collateral is put up.
The Export-Import Bank pledged $2.8 billion in new loans last year to Mexico, Venezuela and the Philippines after they restructured their borrowing under the Brady plan model.
But Japanese officials said they worry that forgiveness will "contaminate" other countries, encouraging them to seek outright reductions rather than struggle to manage their burden. Indeed, the Philippines is reported to have said it would like to erase part of its $28.9 billion in official debt.
 
Japan Clings to Standards
 "We don't want to see such easygoing attitudes among debtor countries," said Hiroyuki Hayakawa, who oversees lending to governments at the Bank of Tokyo, Japan's leading commercial bank in this field.
During a visit to Europe last year, Prime Minister Kaifu pledged $500 million in loans each to Poland and Hungary, to support their difficult transitions from centrally planned to market-based economies.
"Hungary has been making strenuous efforts to pay off its debts, and this should not be discouraged," said a Finance Ministry official. "How do you explain to Hungary what the U.S. did for Poland?"
Japanese officials say they hold to their policies against forgiving debt, in part, because of their own record.
"We are proud of the fact that we never failed to repay any of our debts that we took on for reconstruction after the war," said a Finance Ministry official. "It is good discipline."
"It's sort of the Eastern version of the Calvinist doctrine," an American official said, adding: "Their attitude is entrenched and rigid."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
BUSH STANDS FIRM ON MILITARY POLICY IN IRAQI CIVIL WAR

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 13

 BODY:
Strongly reaffirming United States policy, President Bush said today that Washington would not "interfere" in Iraq's civil war, but he warned Iraq not to try to impede the delivery of emergency aid to refugees fleeing to Turkey and Iran.
Mr. Bush, who has been criticized for declining to support the military uprisings by Kurdish and Muslim Shiite dissidents against the Government of President Saddam Hussein, said: "Internal conflicts have been raging in Iraq for many years, and we're helping out, and we're going to continue to help these refugees. 
 "But I do not want one single soldier or airman shoved into a civil war in Iraq that's been going on for ages," he said. "And I'm not going to have that."
As the President spoke, United States cargo planes and helicopters were stepping up the airlift of supplies to the hundreds of thousands of refugees along the Turkish border. Thousands of others continued to cross into Iran. [Page 10.]
 
Accuses Hussein of 'Savagery'
 An audience of 2,500 students and guests here at the Maxwell Air Force Base War College applauded the President's address several times.
"We will continue to help the Iraqi refugees," he said, "the hundreds and thousands of victims of this man's, Saddam Hussein's, brutality. I see food and shelter and the opportunity to return unharmed to their homes. We will not tolerate any interference in this massive international relief effort."
The President said, "Saddam's continued savagery has placed his regime outside the international order." But he continued: "We will not interfere in Iraq's civil war. The Iraqi people must decide their own political future."
The Administration has been widely criticized as sluggish in its response to the fate of the refugees, in terms of protecting the Kurds and Shiites massing on the borders of Iran and Turkey, and, its critics say, for not moving swiftly enough on humanitarian aid.
 
What Is New World Order?
 Some critics assert that Mr. Bush conducted the Persian Gulf war as a moral crusade, and that his postwar policies on Iraq and the refugees have weakened his position.
Mr. Bush seemed to strike back today, saying that "with Saddam in power, Iraq will remain a pariah nation, its people denied moral contacts with most of the outside world."
"We set our objectives," he said of the war. "These objectives, sanctioned by international law, have been achieved. I made very clear that when our objectives were obtained that our troops would be coming home. I want our troops out of Iraq and back home as soon as possible."
Although Mr. Bush had urged the Iraqi people to rise up and overthrow Mr. Hussein, today he was more restrained, noting that the Iraqis must decide their own future.
Mr. Bush's address was the first of four planned speeches meant to explain what he sees as the new world order. He made the stop here on his way to Pintlala, Ala., to take part in a bass fishing tournament at the home of his friend, Ray Scott, the founder of BassMaster Magazine.
In his speech, the President warned the Soviet Union that it would not share fully in "the new opportunities" of a refashioned world unless it shows progress in moving toward democracy.
 
New Tone Toward Moscow
 During the Persian Gulf crisis, Mr. Bush sought not to criticize Moscow too sharply -- even when Soviet tanks fired on Lithuanian pro-independence protesters in January, the week before the war began -- for fear that he would unravel the delicate international coalition assembled against Mr. Hussein.
But today, the President addressed the tumultuous tug-of-war in the Soviet Union between the hard-liners and those seeking liberalization.
"Let there be no misunderstanding," he said. "The path ahead for the Soviet Union will be difficult and, at times, extraordinarily painful. History weighs heavily on all the peoples of the U.S.S.R. -- liberation from 70 years of Communism, from a thousand years of autocracy.
"It's going to be slow," he said. "There will be setbacks. But this process of reform, this transformation from within must proceed. If external cooperation and our progress toward true international peace is to endure, it must succeed. Only when this transformation is complete will we be able to take full measure of the opportunities presented by this new and evolving world order."
 
New World Order Defined
 Mr. Bush defined the new world order, in light of the Persian Gulf war, as "a responsibility imposed by our successes."
Declaring that it was made possible by the collapse of Communism and the new spirit of cooperation with the Soviet Union, Mr. Bush said the tenets of the new world order are: "Peaceful settlements of disputes, solidarity against aggression, reduced and controlled arsenals, and just treatment of all peoples."
A summit meeting between Mr. Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, which was supposed to be held this spring in Moscow, was postponed because of the gulf war and because a treaty on conventional arms forces in Europe was not ready.
After President Bush called Mr. Gorbachev this week to suggest some compromises on arms destruction, it looked as if the impasse could be solved. The treaty, under negotiation in Vienna, would lead to the destruction of thousands of weapons for conventional warfare, helicopters, tanks and other combat vehicles.
Mr. Bush is to use the occasion of commencement addresses in May to discuss ways of applying the new world order to the Middle East, to United States national defense policy and to international economic policy.
The President has been assailed this week for using situational ethics with regard to the Middle East.
"Can it really be that the global order America went to war for is designed to protect only the kingdoms of emirs, regardless of the consequences to millions of people?" said a New Republic editorial this week titled "Desert Shame."
But Mr. Bush said today that the new world order was based on American ideals.
"Never before has the world looked more to the American example," he said, adding, "What makes us American is our allegiance to an idea that all people everywhere must be free."

HEADLINE: The World;
Bush's Uneasy Welcome For Violeta Chamorro

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
PRESIDENT VIOLETA BARRIOS de CHAMORRO of Nicaragua will be the toast of Washington when she arrives tomorrow. She will be guest of honor at a formal state dinner at the White House and accorded the rare opportunity of addressing a joint meeting of Congress. No Nicaraguan leader has received such honors since Anastasio Somoza Garcia -- the founder of the Somoza dynasty -- rode with Franklin Delano Roosevelt in a motorcade down Pennsylvania Avenue in 1939.
United States and Nicaraguan officials say Mrs. Chamorro's state visit is evidence of a new respectful relationship. But despite the accolades for Nicaragua's new democracy, and despite Washington's self-congratulations about having helped force the Sandinista Daniel Ortega Saavedra out of the presidency, there remains an uncomfortable reality. 
 Behind the facade of Mrs. Chamorro's elected civilian Government, the Sandinistas continue to wield a large share of power because they still control Nicaragua's army, security forces and most aggressive unions. And hundreds of contras, incensed by the assassination in February of one of their former leaders, Enrique Bermudez, are reported to be planning a new insurgency against Sandinista officials. All the while, the economy remains in shambles.
In a sort of mirror image of the ambiguity that has emerged in Nicaragua since Mrs. Chamorro defeated Mr. Ortega in the February 1990 election, Administration officials in Washington are privately expressing their own strained ambivalence about Mrs. Chamorro. On the one hand, they are charmed by her madonna-like nurturing style -- lending the image of a Latin American Corazon Aquino -- and they hope this will help her to heal Nicaragua's fractured society. Publicly, these officials insist that the United States no longer wants to mold Nicaragua's political future. But despite the public applause, when it comes to making policy, the Administration doesn't always treat her like an ally.
"There are remnants of the old policy" of intervention, noted Ernesto Palazio, Nicaragua's Ambassador to Washington. "It's a knee-jerk reaction." He added, however, that "this trip means that we are establishing the foundations of a stable, close and respectful relationship."
Washington strenuously protested Mrs. Chamorro's early decision to appease the left by retaining Gen. Humberto Ortega Saavedra, Daniel Ortega's brother, as commander of the army. The Administration has not yet dispersed nearly half of the $300 million in aid it was scheduled to send to Nicaragua this fiscal year, pressing Managua to overhaul its banking system and reform its state-directed economy.
 
Human Rights Questions
 Most recently, the State Department took Nicaragua to task in a human rights report that lent credence to reports that Sandinista units have executed many contras and contra sympathizers, and that Sandinista agents continue to torture prisoners.
Tempers flared in Managua last month when the Administration privately urged the Soviet Union to cut off shipments of spare parts to the Sandinista-led army in protest against its continued smuggling of weapons to guerrilla groups operating in Honduras and El Salvador.
And in recent days, Nicaraguan officials have complained that the Administration is leaking reports to the press that there is circumstantial evidence linking the Sandinista high command, including General Ortega, to the slaying of Mr. Bermudez. "Why can't they share the information with us?" asked a Nicaraguan official.
"We see eye to eye on the big issues," said a State Department official. "But I don't want to downplay the problems we have. The arms transfers are very serious. The human rights situation in the countryside is very serious."
Representative Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey, the Democrat who heads the House subcommittee on Western Hemisphere affairs, said there was a central paradox: "We want the stability of a democracy but the cooperation of a dictatorship."
Mrs. Chamorro's visit is likely to underline her Government's mixed record, and reopen the Central America debate in Washington, at least for a few days.
Republican conservatives led by Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina say Mrs. Chamorro's record is so blotched that she does not deserve the honors she is to receive. Mr. Helms says it is unjust for Congress to invite Mrs. Chamorro to speak before a joint meeting when it is unwilling to do the same for the Dalai Lama, the anti-Communist leader of Tibetan resistance to Chinese rule, when he arrives in Washington later this month.
Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the Connecticut Democrat who heads the Senate subcommittee on Western Hemisphere and Peace Corps affairs, said he hopes Mrs. Chamorro's visit will encourage the Administration and Congress to grant more assistance in the future. The Administration, he complained, takes the position that "This is our gal but the problem is she is not being a good gal."
"They give her all the trappings, all the dinners, the photo ops," Senator Dodd said. "But the one thing she would prefer is the money."

HEADLINE: The Region;
AIDS Protesters Test State Needle Laws

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
TWO trials that opened last Monday on the East and West Coasts could mark a turning point in the debate over how to prevent AIDS among drug users, their sex partners and their unborn babies. The issue at stake in New York City and Redwood City, Calif., is whether the threat of AIDS justifies giving away clean needles in violation of state laws.
Across the country, advocates for AIDS victims have openly defied authorities by giving out needles. At the same time, the campaign to legalize needle distribution has won victories in courts and legislatures as well as on the streets. 
 "There's a real civil disobedience movement that's having an effect on public policy," said Dr. Don C. Des Jarlais, a member of the Federal Commission on AIDS. Eleven states outlaw the sale or possession of hypodermic needles without a prescription: New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Pennsylvania, Delaware, Rhode Island, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Maine, Illinois and California. In the other 39 states, needles are considered illicit if found with contraband drugs.
Legal needles that retail for less than 20 cents each fetch up to $5 on the black market. Addicts often borrow used needles, which may be contaminated with the AIDS virus. Once infected by sharing needles, addicts can transmit the virus through sex and pregnancy.
In the cases that went to trial last week, defendants staged public needle giveaways and invited arrest. Other test cases are pending in Newark and in the Massachusetts towns of Lowell, Roxbury and Worcester. Jon C. Parker, who founded the National AIDS Brigade, which gives away needles and collects dirty ones, was acquitted in Boston last year after arguing that he was saving lives. Later he was arrested in Rhode Island and Delaware but charges were dropped. A public health graduate student at Yale and an ex-addict, he is one of eight defendants in the New York trial and was an organizer of the incident that led to the case in Redwood City.
There are signs that the campaign is having an effect. The Connecticut legislature authorized New Haven's health department to start providing needles last fall, with the endorsement of the mayor and police commissioner. Supporters of needle distribution programs include the mayors of Boston, Baltimore and San Francisco. Even states that already allow people to buy needles without a prescription are trying to make access easier. Hawaii's legislature approved needle distribution. Local projects have sprouted in Seattle, Portland, Ore., and Boulder, Colo. Tacoma, Wash., offers swift needle delivery to addicts who call in.
The nation's biggest needle program, Prevention Point in San Francisco, distributes nearly 8,000 needles a week. Last year San Francisco residents adopted a referendum asking the state to legalize the program, which was started in 1988. The rate of infection with the AIDS virus among addicts there had doubled to nearly 13 percent from the year before. Since then, the level has remained stable. Samplings of East Coast addicts show infection rates of 50 percent or more.
Official needle distribution programs are growing in Europe. "Internationally, the U.S. is the exception," Dr. Des Jarlais said. Although the National Academy of Sciences recommended researching the effects of needle distribution, the Bush Administration has barred Federal funds to pay for needles or study programs sponsored outside the Government.
 
Treatment on Demand
 Opponents also include some prosecutors, religious leaders, politicians, minority leaders and drug treatment experts who contend that giving away needles encourages drug abuse. Mayor David N. Dinkins and Dr. Woodrow A. Myers Jr., the New York City Health Commissioner, are opposed to the programs. After canceling a small needle-exchange program, Dr. Myers said he would prefer the city to work toward a policy of treatment on demand for any addict who wanted it.
Proponents of the programs argue that there is no evidence that needle restrictions reduce drug abuse. Addicts intent on shooting up will find needles, they say, resorting to used ones if necessary. Studies show that recipients of free needles are less likely to share them. Sometimes the giveaway programs serve as bridges to encourage addicts to seek treatment. Proving that the programs reduce AIDS cases is hampered by the years-long lag between infection and symptoms. But cases of hepatitis B dropped among needle recipients in San Francisco and Amsterdam. Baltimore researchers found that addicts with diabetes, who have legal access to needles for insulin, were infected with the AIDS virus at a rate less than half that for other drug users.
People on both sides of the debate agree that the ideal is to get addicts off drugs. But Dr. Stephen C. Joseph, a former New York City Health Commissioner, says that not all addicts are willing or able to quit. And those who seek treatment face monthslong waiting lists at underfunded clinics. He testified for the eight New York defendants last week, calling them courageous.
Strategists hope that winning more cases will enable needle distribution to flourish without fear of reprisal, and perhaps even to win government financing. But adverse court rulings could turn the test cases into setbacks rather than breakthroughs.
Giving needles to addicts "is not something we like to do, but if we don't, people are going to die for lack of a stupid needle," said Dr. Mathilde Krim, cofounder of the American Foundation for AIDS Research. Dr. Krim helped hand out needles in San Francisco last year during the international AIDS conference. "Laws should help people," she said, "not hurt them."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Advocates for AIDS victims demonstrating in Manhattan in January to legalize the distribution of clean needles to drug users. The campaign to legalize needle distribution has won some victories in courts and legislatures. (Tom McKitterick/Impact Visuals)

HEADLINE: The Region;
How a Tribe in Connecticut Is Taking On Atlantic City

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

DATELINE: LEDYARD, CONN.

 BODY:
EACH week, busloads of bingo players from New England and the New York metropolitan area arrive at the tiny Mashantucket Pequot reservation near the Rhode Island border for the high-stakes games that were legalized in 1986. By next fall, these gamblers and thousands more may find something else: a new casino, the first on the Eastern seaboard outside of Atlantic City.
"We expect to start construction probably in early May and be open by October," said Alfred J. Luciani, a casino consultant and chairman of the Mashantucket Pequot Gaming Enterprise. The all but assured Pequot casino would arrive after a lengthy legal battle and despite continuing opposition to casinos in the state. Connecticut Attorney General Richard Blumenthal has said that casinos could attract organized crime, and has argued that since the state prohibits such gambling elsewhere it should be banned on the 1,700-acre reservation. Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. is also opposed. 
 Other officials, however, note that the state is already deeply involved in legalized gambling and collected $265.7 million in revenue in the 1989-90 fiscal year on lottery games, jai alai, dog racing and off-track betting. They argue that Connecticut should license its own casinos since it lacks a broad-based tax on personal income and has a projected $2.6 billion budget shortfall for the next 15 months. Because of the Pequot's sovereignty, the tribe is not required to pay taxes or a share of its profits to the state, local or Federal government.
"Casino gambling is now a reality, and they would have the only casino between the North Pole and Atlantic City," said state Representative Ronald L. Smoko, a Democrat from Hamden. "Perhaps the proper remediation is to have casino gambling on a limited basis in limited locations."
Proponents of casino gambling in Connecticut cite numerous other states that have already approved casinos. In 1988 South Dakota legalized some casino games in Deadwood, and Colorado has authorized casino-style gambling to begin in three towns this fall. Iowa also started allowing gambling on Mississippi riverboats this month, and other states are expected to soon follow.
The Pequot, a tiny 200-member tribe, were the first Indian tribe east of the Mississippi to secure a gambling compact with a state under the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act, which was approved in 1988 and gives federally recognized tribes the right to negotiate the operation of games of chance if that form of gambling is already permitted in the state.
Citing a Connecticut law that allows nonprofit organizations to hold "Las Vegas nights" to raise money by conducting standard games of chance like blackjack and roulette, the Pequot met the requirement to negotiate for a casino. But after negotiations between the state and the tribe failed to produce a compact, the Pequot requested and obtained a mediator. After a long and complicated process, a Federal District Court ruled in May 1990 that Connecticut was not negotiating in good faith, citing the length of time the process was taking. A Federal mediator then asked state officials and the tribe to submit separate plans for casino gambling. The mediator selected the state plan, which, paradoxically, was almost identical to the Pequot plan, but the state officials then refused to consent to it. After failing to persuade a Federal appeals court to grant a stay in the case, the state appealed to the Supreme Court, arguing that they had not negotiated in bad faith, that the Federal law allowing casinos had been misinterpreted and that the issue should never have been mediated.
The Supreme Court is to decide on April 22 whether it will hear the case. Two weeks ago, Solicitor General Kenneth W. Starr filed a friend-of-the-court brief siding with the Pequot. Last week the Department of the Interior announced it was going to implement the mediator's plan. "The Government would be very surprised if the Court decided to hear the case," said Michael D. Cox, the general counsel to the National Indian Gaming Commission, which was created under the 1988 Federal law to oversee gambling on reservations.
The Pequot casino in Ledyard, a small, rural town of 14,500 residents about 15 miles north of New London, would greatly enhance the economy in New London County, which has been hit hard by job losses at major defense-related companies like the Electric Boat submarine shipyard in Groton and United Nuclear Corporation in Montville. Mr. Luciani said it would create about 1,500 jobs and provide tribal members with funds for a museum, a research center and additional housing. It is unclear how much profit the casino will make for the Pequot, although Mr. Luciani has said that the operation will gross about $80 million annually.
The casino itself will be modest, about half the size of the smallest casino in Atlantic City, with a capacity of about 1,000 customers. Mr. Luciani, who as a member of the New Jersey Attorney General's office helped draft the state's Casino Control Act, said the structure would be understated, forgoing neon and blending into the wooded surroundings. "It's New England architecture and intended to be parklike in its decor," he said.
Mr. Luciani added that a casino in Ledyard is minutes away from the coastal towns of Mystic and Stonington, and it would be a serious competitor with Atlantic City because southeastern Connecticut is a far more attractive region. "The people in Atlantic City -- not because of the industry but because of Atlantic City -- have an inferior product," he said.

HEADLINE: Driving Banks to Desperate Risks

 BODY:
The House Banking Committee is reportedly on the verge of making a grievous decision to delay action on comprehensive bank reform until after Congress fixes the deposit insurance system. If that happens, banks will be forced to pay higher costs but will have no way to increase earnings. With hundreds of banks already reeling, that's an incendiary combination.
The decision to delay would be misguided for another reason: Congress can't intelligently decide how to reform deposit insurance without knowing how it wishes to reform the banking system. Disconnecting the two decisions risks a big, and lasting, mistake. 
 Many U.S. banks are in trouble; some of the largest banks are close to bankrupt. They are losing their best customers to other financial institutions and foreign banks; and they are earning less profit on customers that remain.
In part, their predicament is due to antiquated laws that forbid interstate banks and limit investments. Nine of Texas's 10 largest banks have collapsed; no such catastrophe would have occurred had they been able to branch out to other states or to invest less in real estate.
As banks begin to fail, they try to survive by gambling with insured deposits -- making risky loans to real estate developers or underdeveloped countries. Losses mount, and taxpayers foot the bill.
One remedy is to allow banks to diversify their investments so they can earn reasonable profit without unreasonable risk. The Treasury Department has made just such a proposal. It would permit banks to set up branches anywhere in the country and enter the insurance, securities and mutual fund industries. These changes would insulate banks from regional downturns and open up new sources of profit.
Another remedy is to tighten regulation. The Treasury plan would empower regulators to close down banks before they went bankrupt, threatening taxpayers. Critics charge, justifiably, that the Treasury plan doesn't go far enough: regulators must be required, not just enabled, to intervene once shareholder equity begins to fall.
Here's a place where Congress can make a pivotal improvement in the Treasury plan. Indeed, there is a compelling argument that limits on insured deposits can be completely removed if bank reform is passed -- a benefit that could not even be imagined were Congress to turn matters upside down and fiddle with deposit insurance first.
Any change in bank reform forces Congress to pick winners and losers. Permitting interstate banks threatens small banks; letting banks into related financial sectors threatens insurance and securities firms. The politically safe course is to duck, and pay attention only to the near-bankrupt Federal deposit insurance fund. But what's politically safe is economically destructive.
A healthy economy needs healthy banks. The American banking system, however, is on the ropes and cannot afford a Congress that dithers.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LENGTH: 261 words

HEADLINE: Costly Foot-Dragging in Albany

 BODY:
Once again, New York's leaders have failed to deliver a state budget on time. They're already 14 days late, and every day costs New Yorkers money. How can legislators and Gov. Mario Cuomo justify wasting millions of dollars even as the state sinks deeper into its recession?
Delay is expensive because, while waiting for state aid, localities have to borrow at high interest costs. To meet its payroll, New York City will soon have to sell about $1 billion worth of notes to make up for missing state money. That will cost the strapped city up to $20 million in interest. 
 Albany's foot-dragging also makes it difficult for local governments to adopt their own budgets because they don't know how much state aid to expect.
What's delaying Albany's leaders, of course, is their dread of dealing with a budget gap of at least $6 billion -- 20 percent of a $30 billion budget. Mr. Cuomo, adamantly opposed to raising income taxes, proposes a 10-cent-a-gallon gas tax increase, painful spending cuts and an unwise welter of one-shot revenues. Assembly Speaker Mel Miller says no to the gas tax and yes to an income tax. The Senate majority leader, Ralph Marino, is against an income tax hike and noncommittal on the gas tax; and now he's making the empty gesture of promising his own plan -- two weeks past the budget deadline.
What's everybody waiting for? There is no rescue in sight, no surprises, just more bad economic news to compound the state's troubles. It is increasingly difficult to understand why New York's leaders cannot face up to their jobs.
