HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
The New Saturn: Lustre Under the Skin

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
It has taken a very long time, but Saturn is finally here. Saturn, the ultimate answer from General Motors to all those pesky gnats from Japan.
Yes, yes, you've heard all this before. There was the J-car of the early 80's. There were the likes of the J2000 from Pontiac, the Cavalier from Chevrolet. There was even the Cimarron, and Cadillac would probably be just as happy if I hadn't mentioned that one at all. 
They were among the cars that were going to save the General's stars and, moreover, be the salvation of Detroit. Uh huh.
But Saturn is a whole new family of cars, the first since G.M. added Chevrolet in 1918. In fact, Saturn is a wholly new corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary formed to create a wholly new way of building cars and doing business.
The idea was to get rid of the old labor-management hostilities, to involve all the workers, to build a new plant in Spring Hill, Tenn., and to change the way automobiles were conceived and constructed. The marketing, too, would be different, with every accent placed on customer satisfaction.
The new corporation was formed in 1985, but even then the idea had been three years in the making. And, when I got behind the wheel, it seemed the wait had been too long.
It was, I thought, sort of the Gone-With-the- Wind syndrome. All my life, I had heard about that movie. And when I finally did get to see it, the reality was exceeded by the expectation. Much like Saturn, I thought.
I have been driving Saturn's reality for the past week, a white SL2 touring sedan, the top of the line if you don't count the four-seat sports coupe, which is designated an SC. The sedan seats five, and my first notion was that it had accomplished what no American car had accomplished before: Saturn had successfully imitated what had been available from Japan all along.
A nice little Japanese car from Tennessee, I thought. It has a long beak that provides a family resemblance to the rest of G.M.'s small cars. It is tidy and without quirk on the road. It is quiet and roomy, given its small shell, and it is reasonably thrifty. But I had nits to pick with this gnat.
Forgive the cliche, but G.M. started with a clean sheet of paper. And how could you create a new car, particularly one with nine years of gestation, and not have an air bag? How can you have a car whose rear windows don't go all the way down?
Why are antilock brakes not a standard item? And how could you come up with a car whose glovebox lid has indents for cups and then have that lid open and stop at a 30-degree angle?
The lack of an air bag means that the car has to have mechanized seatbelts, those infuriating contraptions that startle and sometimes strangle the unwary. But the Saturn does provide a chime and warning lights to remind you to buckle the lap belt, an important addition.
So somebody was thinking for all those years. And the car does have a steel spaceframe with ding-proof plastic body panels attached, a la the late and, for my part, lamented Pontiac Fiero. Where metal is used, it is galvanized, a plus that staves off corrosion. And there is a stainless-steel exhaust system.
Things, I thought, were beginning to look better. And I realized that a lot of what is really good about the Saturn doesn't show. The glossy paint is designed to be crack-proof as it bends with the plastic doors, fenders and quarter-panels. And everything is meant for easy service, both by the car's owner and by the dealer.
All fluids -- oil, coolant, transmission, power steering, brakes and windshield washer -- can be checked by standing in one spot. Dipstick handles, located in a common area, are coded by color for easy identification.
Repair simplicity was worked out in conjunction with insurers, so that premiums on the car would be lower.
There is a plug-in port, so the car can be diagnosed with a handheld computer that analyzes all of the annoying stuff, including the intermittent problems that happen only when you are watching. Microprocessors are used throughout the car, and the technology is top notch, as is assembly.
The car's quality is said to be higher than that of any other G.M. product, and the company has reported that many Saturns are coming off the assembly line with zero defects. That compares with two to four defects for most other General Motors automobiles.
And the more I looked, the more I realized that the white sedan was indeed a pleasant addition to the driveway. Inside, it had all the amenities, including central locking and a power sunroof that opens as a vent or slides back on top of the roof, saving valuable headroom.
The radio has knobs instead of rocker switches, and that's all to the good, as are the comfortable front buckets and the rear bench seat that is split, 60-40, to form a pass-through to the trunk. In fact, the Saturn proves itself eminently easy to live with.
On the road, it feels more substantial than its surprisingly light 2,300 to 2,400 pounds would indicate, and the fuel economy is reasonable if not great.
With the standard five-speed transmission and the base engine, the mileage figures are 27, city, and 37, highway, and those numbers range downward to 23 and 32, when you order the "performance" engine and an automatic transmission.
Like the rest of the car, the all-new engines and transmissions are made in Tennessee. The aluminum powerplants are 1.9-liter fours, producing 85 horsepower in the base version and 123 in the performance configuration, which adds dual overhead camshafts and has four valves per cylinder.
The company likes to call the engine-transmission combination a "power module," and the modules are mounted transversely to drive the front wheels.
How well they drive them depends on the combination, and zero-to-60 acceleration ranges from a leisurely 13.7 seconds to a surprisingly quick 9.2.
Maybe the most surprising aspect of the Saturn, though, is its price. The coupe and sedans, in several levels of trim, start at a mere $7,995 and top out at $11,775. Optional equipment can add another $2,600 or so, but that still means a sticker that is competitively low.
Maybe this time. . . .

HEADLINE: DESIGN;
A TALE OF TWO CITIES

BYLINE: BY CAROL VOGEL

 BODY:
APRIL HAS BECOME THE MONTH OF FURNITURE fairs on both sides of the Atlantic. In the United States, the International Market, the country's largest to-the-trade event, opens in High Point, N.C., on Thursday and runs through April 26. Thousands of buyers and merchandise managers come to see new designs they might buy for stores this fall.
For the first time this year, April is also the month Milan becomes a furniture mecca. The Salone del Mobile di Milano, indisputably the world's most influential furniture fair, which for the last 30 years has been held in September, has been moved to April. It opened Friday and runs to Wednesday. "There's no question Milan will be the most exciting; it always is," says Carl Levine, a Bloomingdale's senior vice president. "The Italian manufacturers consider design a priority, whereas Americans are looking for recession-busters -- designs they simply hope will sell." 
 As in the last few seasons, furniture at High Point will be dreary, as traditional designs continue to take the spotlight. Many have designer labels, a result of manufacturers' continuing to commission big names like Mark Hampton, Vicente Wolf, Mario Buatta and Adam Tihany to design lines.
By contrast, the Milan show is expected to make news. Indeed, architects and designers from around the world will be featuring innovative objects -- everything from the truly wacky to the sleek but livable. Although the Milan market has also been suffering from sagging sales for the last year, experts predict designs will not suffer; indeed, they will be especially unusual. "The furniture must be original and fresh to succeed," says Ivan Luini, a United States representative for many furniture companies, including Cappellini and Kartell. "When Milan gets conservative, it will signal the end of Italian design."

HEADLINE: SUNDAY VIEW;
Secret Sharers: Solo Acts in a Confessional Age

BYLINE: By DAVID RICHARDS

 BODY:
I always assumed the one person play was the theater's way of dealing with the shrinking dollar. You really can't get more basic -- a performer, a platform, a text. Take away anything else and what do you have? A loon emoting in the street or a mime show.
Lately, though, I've been wondering if the form, which usually brings a historical figure back from the grave to chat with us -- presumably in his or her own words -- isn't curiously attuned to our times in a deeper way. We have never been so besotted with celebrities. We have even come to believe that celebrityhood carries with it one duty above all others: an obligation to spill the beans. 
 It's still too early to pin a label on the current season. But if you're looking for distinguishing characteristics -- beyond the hullabaloo caused by the coming to town of "Miss Saigon" -- there's no avoiding the rash of solo endeavors. Julie Harris, assuming the strange, silvery persona and exotic wardrobe of the Danish writer Isak Dinesen in "Lucifer's Child," is only the latest example. She has been preceded by reincarnations of Virginia Woolf ("A Room of One's Own"), Huey Long ("The Kingfish"), Lyndon Baines Johnson ("Lyndon") and Florence Aadland ("The Big Love"), among others.
Economics, of course, is not to be discounted in any of these cases. The new penury is upon us. The city is cutting back on services, department stores on their inventories, restaurants on the $50 entrees. It follows that the theater would scale back, too, although when a show like "The Big Love" ends up costing $800,000, "scaling back" is a relative term.
There is, however, another explanation for this vogue of one-person plays. We're very close to it when, for example, Miss Harris first mentions the lifelong syphilis, "the flowering of Nemesis . . . inside me," that ravaged Isak Dinesen's health. "There are two things a woman can do in such a situation," she explains forthrightly, "accept it or shoot the man." Then, fixing the audience at the Music Box Theater with a look that is both elegant and defiant and perhaps a little mischievous, too, she explains what she did instead. "I gave my soul to Lucifer. In return, he promised to transmute my sorrow into tales the whole world would read. So, you see, I am Lucifer's child."
The British actress Eileen Atkins, who is the sly, piercingly intelligent and altogether bracing Virginia Woolf in "A Room of One's Own" at the Lamb's Theater, is ostensibly talking about women and literature when she asserts that "it is fatal for anyone to be a man or a woman pure and simple. One must be woman-manly, or man-womanly." The act of fruitful artistic creation, she argues, depends on "some collaboration . . . in the mind between the woman and the man." For a second, her fierce intensity goes beyond the confines of literature and seems to dare us, presumably so sure of our definitions, to define gender. A revolutionary's zeal is clearly stirring in this concentrated creature.
In both instances, the characters are approaching confession, and confession, these days, has become something of a national obsession. Rare is the sin that cannot be absolved by being publicly aired. Keeping secrets, once a component of good manners, is suspect. And in the theater, the quickest way to get characters to reveal themselves is to put them in one-person plays.
What other choice do they have? They're there to reminisce, settle scores, set a record or two straight and generally sum themselves up. Occasionally, they will answer the telephone or call out to an invisible maid. But those are just diversionary maneuvers. We're the ones they're really addressing -- owning up to, you could say. Conventional plays expect us to be no more than onlookers. But the one-person play casts us as confidants.
There was some critical disagreement over the value of what Florence Aadland had to tell the world in the recently departed "Big Love." As the mother of Beverly Aadland, onetime 1950's starlet and underage mistress of Errol Flynn, she witnessed Hollywood lowlife from the sidelines and fooled herself into thinking she was at the center of big-time glamour. But Tracey Ullman's extraordinary performance gave no hint whatsoever that the woman was holding anything back. For better or worse, sympathy or ridicule, there she was -- a flashy, foolish nobody, pouring out her tinseled heart to us and, since her candor was stronger than her vanity, admitting to an artificial foot, as well.
Likewise, Miss Harris's magical presence is the glory and redemption of "Lucifer's Child," a more ambitious play, but not necessarily a more successful one. The script is by William Luce, who has already stitched the retiring existence of Emily Dickinson into the luminous "Belle of Amherst" for Miss Harris and fashioned the travails of Lillian Hellman into the feisty "Lillian" for Zoe Caldwell. This time, however, his work seems particularly piecemeal and unfocused. The setting is Denmark just before and just after a lecture trip that Dinesen, then in her mid-70's, made to America in 1959 -- hardly a pivotal event in her life. Why, it may well be asked, are we tuning in here?
The movie "Out of Africa" painted Dinesen as a romantic heroine struggling to make a go of a coffee plantation in Kenya and braving man, beast and elements. "Lucifer's Child" seems to view her as a cross between a crumbling grande dame of letters and a disease-ridden Auntie Mame who calls her fur piece "Beowulf" and gathers mushrooms by the light of an electric torch. It is only Miss Harris's confidential performance that makes a whole of this patchwork of memories, yearnings and regrets. Her voice has always sounded like heartbreak feels. And her powdery-white face remains triumphantly mutable. Depending on the light, you can see in it the child, the flirt, the crusader or the crone. That helps.
The one-person play, after all, has a lot of places to go and people to see, even if it's only the mind's eye that's doing the visiting. Or, more to the point, the re-visiting -- which brings us to a fundamental drawback of the form: it is backward-looking. The emotions being experienced are recollected emotions. The time for doing is long over. (The folksy demagogue John McConnell portrays in "The Kingfish" at the John Houseman Theater is already dead at the play's start and coming to us, apparently, from the other side.) What's left is the recounting, which is why the one-person play tends to be nostalgic in thrust. It prefers the question "Who was I?" to the more nettlesome "Who am I?"
A way exists out of this trap, although it is not open to everyone. Some one-person plays, instead of recreating a life, recreate a public moment in the life. That usually means repairing to the lecture hall or the legitimate theater itself, where the individual might once have appeared. Such was the tactic taken by Hal Holbrook in "Mark Twain Tonight," which is probably responsible, as much as anything, for the flowering of the one-person show in our times. Preceded by a puff of cigar smoke, Mr. Holbrook ambled on stage, as Twain himself had done at the end of his career, to tell a few tall tales, talk about piloting a steamboat down the Mississippi, and then read a selection from "Tom Sawyer" or "Huckleberry Finn."
The advantages of this approach are obvious. The stage is treated as a stage, not a confessional, and the audience can be addressed, with no violation of logic, as an audience. More importantly, the subject is still active and operating in the present tense. Packing and unpacking are all that Isak Dinesen can find to do in the here and now, before an old dress or a faded photograph activates her memories. Her dramatic motivation is the memorabilia all around her. But Mr. Holbrook's Twain had a lecture to give -- which is to say a purpose and a dramatic necessity.
So does Miss Atkins, as she makes her way through the audience and up onto the wood-paneled stage, removes her cloche hat and wraparound coat and prepares to share an opinion "upon one minor point" with the young ladies of Girton College. "A woman," she says, "must have money and a room of her own if she is to write fiction." The elaboration of that deceptively simple thesis leads her to consider the status of women throughout history, ponder the implications of men and wealth, and recount the tragic destiny of one Judith Shakespeare, imaginary sister of Will and every bit as inspired, who tried to follow in his footsteps and came to a sorry end.
The script has been adapted by Patrick Garland from Woolf's book, "A Room of One's Own," which is an expansion of two papers the writer herself delivered in Cambridge in 1928. Miss Atkins, crafty as the fox she resembles with her sharp eyes and long nose, makes an exhilarating adventure out of it -- leading us surely along the path of Woolf's thought, pausing here and there to let us drink in the magnificent vistas, before pushing onward, past boulder and precipice, to the dizzying summit. Knowing that the audience expects "a peroration," Miss Atkins obliges in the final dazzling moments by expanding a shrewd feminist manifesto into a thrilling call for freedom that includes everyone in the hall.
"A Room of One's Own" is the least anecdotal of one-person shows, resorting to autobiography only when it's necessary to reinforce an intellectual point. While sentiment is discouraged, wit and irony are plentifully indulged. ("There are people whose charity embraces even the prune," she notes at one point, with a faint curl of distaste that indicts the charity as much as the prune.) In the workings of her quick mind, however, we sense Woolf's essence as keenly as if she were reading excerpts from her diary.
 Today's performance artists are probably reluctant to acknowledge a debt to the one-person play. But really how different was, say, Wallace Shawn's extended mea culpa, "The Fever"? We never did learn the identity of the speaker, marooned in a revolution-torn country in the third world and feeling profoundly guilty about his privileged life. It is safe to assume, though, that a large part of the character, well born and cultivated, was Mr. Shawn himself. On the other hand, there was never any question that Spalding Gray was the subject of "Monster in a Box" -- Mr. Gray being the subject of all his monologues. In fact, there isn't anything he won't tell you about himself, which certainly makes him the right man at the right time in the right society.
Not too long ago, when someone said, "That's a personal matter," "personal" meant "none of your business." No more. Biographers don't consider their work well done unless they have painted "an intimate portrait." Supermarket tabloids thrive on blabbing -- and sometimes inventing -- the embarrassments of the rich and the notorious. But most of all, television, I think, has sanctioned this urge to pry. The mighty willingly submit to the indignities of the so-called in-depth interview, while common citizens think nothing of going on talk shows to divulge the troubles they are having with the law, their sexual partners or their kidneys. Even humiliating home videos are now the stuff of highly rated TV specials. What are we to conclude? We are peeping Toms without even leaving our living rooms.
The one-person play merely represents the high end of what has become a ravenous appetite for the low down.

HEADLINE: DANCE VIEW;
American Ballet Theater Spreads Its New Wings

BYLINE: By Anna Kisselgoff

 BODY:
When Jane Hermann and Oliver Smith were appointed as directors of American Ballet Theater a little over a year ago, their mandate seemingly was to bring back the Ballet Theater everyone knew before Mikhail Baryshnikov's 10-year reign as artistic director. Now, with a nine-week season that opens a week from tomorrow at the Metropolitan Opera House, the new team could be charged, paradoxically, with offering only the familiar.
Mr. Baryshnikov has withdrawn the rights to his versions of the full-length classics, but much of his repertory from last season is back, as are ballets from the pre-Baryshnikov regime of Lucia Chase and Mr. Smith. While the schedule for this season includes two company premieres (Jiri Kylian's "Sinfonietta" and Vladimir Vasiliev's "Don Quixote"), plus restagings and guest stars like Sylvie Guillem and Carla Fracci, there are no world premieres, as there have been in previous years. 
 Does this season reflect a lack of an adventurousness or an obligation to work within the strictures of economic retrenchment? A strong advance sale for the Met season and certain performances that are already sold out (Ms. Guillem's "Bayadere" on May 18) indicate that Ms. Hermann knows Ballet Theater's audience. Critics might look for creativity; an opera-house audience might well prefer individual performers and a repertory with which it is comfortable.
What Ms. Hermann knows is that the survival of a major American institution like Ballet Theater should not be taken for granted. But in her view, budget restrictions can accommodate artistic policies, rather than the other way around.
"I'm not going to apologize for the fact that we're alive," Ms. Hermann said vehemently during a recent interview in her Ballet Theater office in Manhattan. Although Mr. Smith, a distinquished stage designer who has been closely involved in the season's new production of "Coppelia," contributes to overall planning, it is generally acknowledged that Ms. Hermann is the dominant member of the team.
In discussing the specifics of the forthcoming season, Ms. Hermann also defined long-range policies that she considers necessary to assure Ballet Theater's survival. One significant proposal is for an innovative touring subsidy from the troupe's board and the nurturing of support in communities across the country: Ballet Theater, she emphasized, is a national institution, worthy of recognition and underwriting in cities whose first loyalty is often to a local ballet company.
Ballet Theater, having settled a labor contract dispute last fall, has reduced its current budget to the unusually low figure of $16.5 million. Last year, Ms. Hermann had cut the $23 million Baryshnikov budget to $18 million. This season, she said, "Ballet Theater has put on a first-rate repertory and produced it in a way that shows off the dancers beautifully, a way that allows us to save the life of A.B.T."
Referring to financial problems encountered within the past year by numerous ballet troupes, including the Pennsylvania Ballet and the Joffrey Ballet, Ms. Hermann continued: "We have never operated without meeting the payroll, had dancers stay in people's houses, not paid taxes or defaulted on health insurance. I could have walked around with a tin cup too, but we didn't."
The regular layoff periods for the company have, however, grown longer, and the roster of dancers now numbers 85, compared with 102 three years ago. Ms. Hermann said this reduction was made through attrition. Martine van Hamel, a senior principal who started out on this year's national tour during the winter, left the company after she was offered a guest contract but did not get the roles she desired. Fernando Bujones, Cynthia Gregory, Ms. Fracci and Ms. Guillem are listed as guest artists and are paid per performance rather than on a weekly basis.
If the new season is the first planned by Ms. Hermann and Mr. Smith, it does not yet reflect the long view of the company that Ms. Hermann has in mind.
One factor, she said, that "determined the repertoire of a season that was affordable" involved the "qualities of the dancers." "Coppelia," a box-office favorite, was revived with new scenery by Tony Straiges, because, Ms. Hermann said, "I had such casting in depth. In addition, the men were underutilized." Danilo Radojevic, Johan Renvall and Gil Boggs were "capable of doing more dancing than they were getting," she said of three bravura dancers who will be seen in "Coppelia."
Enrique Martinez, who staged the company's previous version of the comic ballet, was asked mainly to supervise the same choreography in an elaborate new setting. But Vladimir Vasiliev, the former Bolshoi star, has staged a "Don Quixote" that is markedly different from the streamlined entertainment that Mr. Baryshnikov's 1978 version offered.
Mr. Baryshnikov (who left the Ballet Theater in a dispute with Ms. Hermann in September 1989) has withdrawn the rights to all his stagings of the classics, although the costumes and scenery remain with Ballet Theater. As a result, Ms. Hermann invited Mr. Vasiliev, who had made Basilio (the ballet's hero) in "Don Quixote" one of his greatest roles with the Bolshoi. According to Ms. Hermann, "Vasiliev has doubled the amount of bravura dancing, and his rehearsals have added enormously to the projection you will see on on stage."
Ms. Hermann said that Mr. Kylian, in selecting dancers for the company premiere of his "Sinfonietta," had chosen some of the same dancers because of their energy level. This exuberant ballet, with its fanfares of trumpets by Janacek, was the hit of the Netherlands Dance Theater debut 10 years ago at the Met, where Ms. Hermann was director of presentations.
While the world outside ballet might wonder at the concern over arcane points that divide dancegoers or prompt criticism of company directors, these are the very details that help define a troupe's artistic policy.
A restaging this season that will be closely watched is George Balanchine's "Ballet Imperial." John Taras, long one of Balanchine's balletmasters at the New York City Ballet, staged it for Ballet Theater, where he was associate director until last year.
The revised version that Balanchine sanctioned at the City Ballet is very different in style. While there is much to be said for Ballet Theater's attempt to regain the textbook manner of dancing prevalent at the work's premiere in 1941, Barbara Horgan, head of the Balanchine trust, was among those worried that the staging looked old-fashioned.
"At Barbara Horgan's request," Ms. Hermann said, "we brought in Patricia Neary to restage the ballet."
The relationship between music and dancing is complex in a Balanchine ballet, and after a misunderstanding between the pianist and the conductor during a performance of "Ballet Imperial" on tour this winter, Ms. Hermann decided that "one of our major expenditures will have to be for music. Economics has dictated that we have cut rehearsal time with musicians. I have asked the board for extra full-orchestra rehearsals."
A repertory art like ballet, by definition, includes repeats from last season; Ms. Hermann notes that subscribers must get a chance to see what they missed, and it is economically unfeasible to "rehearse five full-length ballets and 16 short ones from scratch."
It is easy to criticize Ms. Hermann for playing it safe. A revival of Kenneth MacMillan's "Concerto" and still another staging of Act III of "Raymonda" (this time by Mr. Bujones) hardly qualify as exciting novelties this season.
Yet Ms. Hermann is one of the few company directors who recognize the excitement that a young dancer like Julio Bocca can generate. More important is the originality of Ms. Hermann's long-range thinking.
Above all, she makes a key point that destroys any illusions that Ballet Theater may have had about itself. Because it performs in theaters that are on an opera-house scale and because of the size and international stature of its wide repertory, she said, Ballet Theater is perceived as comparable to European companies like the Royal Ballet or the Paris Opera Ballet.
"But we are not that," Ms. Hermann said. "We are essentially a touring company, and we don't have the financial solidity that European companies have."
Moreover, she stressed, regional companies in the United States -- and the communities that support them -- tend to regard Ballet Theater as a competitive intruder. Ms. Hermann considers it imperative that the company and its board make clear that "we are essential to the American scene as opposed to a company making road visits to other cities."
New York City, she pointed out, welcomes both American Ballet Theater and the New York City Ballet. "It's that kind of perception on a national level that I hope we can promulgate in the next decade. I don't see Ballet Theater's growth if we constantly have to struggle to find venues where we are welcome."
One solution, Ms. Hermann suggested, is to establish closer relations with community leaders in these cities. But the major innovation she feels is necessary is a touring subsidy that would be added to the budget from the board or the communities visited. "We should not keep picking up bookings as we go," she said, adding, "The nomadic sense is very wearing. There is a difference between touring and being a nomad."
In addition, Ms. Hermann has plans for more touring in Europe and reaching younger audiences. A new "Nutcracker" would recruit children as performers and audience members in various cities. A new "Cinderella" is being discussed but, surprisingly, not to Prokofiev's ballet score. Instead, Ms. Hermann would like to use the music from Rossini's "Cenerentola." Above all, she envisages short programs for children with a revival of "Peter and the Wolf," a staple of the 1940's.
Never a professional dancer, her artistic choices tend, naturally, to be influenced by her experience as a dancegoer and the stars and choreographers she met while producing their companies at the Met. Ms. Fracci, in her view, remains unsurpassed as an actress-dancer. Here again, Ms. Hermann has a finger on the pulse of a public that was fiercely loyal to the Italian ballerina, who had appeared regularly with Ballet Theater before Mr. Baryshnikov took over.
The danger is that Ms. Hermann will turn to only the kind of ballet she knows. Although she has commissioned a new work from the modern-dance choreographer Ulysses Dove, she refuses to consider experimental choreographers unfamiliar with the ballet idiom. ("I can't imagine the New York Philharmonic commissioning a work from someone who never got beyond the key of C on the piano," she said.)
Plunging into the unpredictable during a recession is not Ms. Hermann's style. One could argue that a ballet company that follows public taste does just that -- it follows and does not lead. But a part of every dance-watcher over the age of 30 can also appreciate the value Ms. Hermann places on the glories of the past: "What did we go to see when we were young? Dance used to appeal to everybody."

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
For Budget Lodging, Retreats or College Dorms

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
VACATIONERS with a constricted budget may want to consider not only economy motels but also alternative lodging such as religious retreats or college dormitories. Some of these may be Spartan, but for travelers who are game, necessity can be turned into an adventure.
The first set of choices consists of guesthouses, retreat houses and retreat centers maintained by religious organizations. A list of such places in Europe, Australia, Ghana, India, Israel and New Zealand has been compiled and was published in December by James J. and Victoria D. Hughes, a retired Army colonel and his wife. They started out pretty much the way the Zagats started out with their noted restaurant guides: Visiting places and sharing names and addresses with friends. This got out of hand, so in 1988 they began a formidable piece of research, writing to bishops with the goal of publishing a directory. 
 The result, "Travelers' Guide to Overnight or Short Stay at Religious Community Guest and Retreat Houses Around the World, European Edition," is a stapled paperback of 136 pages with 800 entries. It has no pictures, maps or prices, no explicit note of the denomination of the sponsoring group and no indication of the number of rooms available at each place, which may be as few as six. There is also no differentiation between retreat houses, where staff members lead the guests in periods of withdrawal, meditation or prayer, and guesthouses, which welcome travelers who have no religious purpose in mind.
Mr. Hughes said in an interview that the places listed for Rome, Paris, Venice, Florence and Israel were mostly guesthouses. In the next edition, he said, guesthouses would be given an asterisk or other marking.
Mr. and Mrs. Hughes have stayed in a few of these places in Rome, Assisi and London, but readers will quickly be aware that they are not perusing a Mobil guide with ratings and amenities; each large-type entry has two lines: city, name of religious house, phone number, address and postal code. Information on rates, sharing of bathrooms and what meals are served must be obtained from the place itself.
The authors warn that places fill up early and that reservations should be made promptly. They give only an idea of the cost: "In Rome in 1987, we paid $44 for bed and breakfast," they say in the introduction. As dated as this seems, it cannot be faulted too much because even annual bed-and-breakfast guides are vulnerable to rapidly shifting prices.
Whatever its deficits, the book is the first of its kind I have seen and, for people who want to stay overseas in a priory, abbey, foyer or similar place, this provides an invaluable start to the research. The book, costing $17.95 postage paid, is available from Hugen Press, Post Office Box 2286, Bloomfield, N.J. 07003.
A more detailed guide, to places in the United States, is "A Guide to Monastic Guest Houses" by J. Robert Beagle. This book, published in 1989 on the model of the dozens of bed-and-breakfast guides, covers 129 guesthouses, mostly Roman Catholic and Episcopal. Sketches, descriptions, prices and directions are included. Rates are given; sometimes the houses seek "free will donations" or gifts "as the spirit moves." Where a dollar amount is specified, it is low. The Immaculate Heart Hermitage in Big Sur, Calif., for example, asks $25 a person a day for room and meals. The nine rooms are singles with toilets and basins; showers are shared. St. Joseph's Episcopal Retreat House in Mount Sinai, N.Y., with 10 single rooms, one double and one quadruple room, all sharing baths, charges $30 to $40 a person a day.
The paperback guide, 132 pages, is issued by Morehouse, 78 Danbury Road, Wilton, Conn. 06897. It is available at bookstores for $11.95.
Religious Retreats
Travelers who are not looking just for a place to stay, but want to make a religious retreat in the United States or Canada, either privately or in a group, can get information on 600 sites from "Catholic America; Self-Renewal Centers and Retreats" by Patricia Christian-Meyer ($13.95, John Muir Publications, distributed W. W. Norton). The author includes several chapters on retreats and theology, but the bulk of the book is a state-by-state directory, with photographs and descriptions provided by the religious centers themselves. Families should know that under information on who may join a retreat, an entry frequently says "everyone except youths and families." This book is also at bookstores.
A list of Christian religious organizations in Israel that provide board and meals for under $30 a night a person is maintained by the Israel Government Tourist Office; it gives somewhat more information than the Hughes book. For example, in Jerusalem, St. Andrew's Hospice has 14 rooms and the Sisters of Zion Convent has 13. The free list is available from Israel tourist offices in Chicago, Los Angeles, Dallas, Miami, New York, Toronto and Atlanta.
Dormitories
Dormitories provide another cost-cutting expedient. The negative side is that staying in a college dorm usually means eating in a cafeteria and using a bathroom down the hall. But in contrast with the religious houses, dorms usually permit children. And some colleges have apartments for rent.
In Canada, a university association has organized to provide a free listing of the 50-odd colleges that have rooms to let either in vacation time or year round. Generally, the schools seek to attract conferences, but the leaflet "University Conference Facilities" is also aimed at family travelers. The chart shows such details as if a swimming pool is avilable, if parking is free and the number of rooms and apartments.
Prices are not given because of the variation in accommodations, but for each school, phone numbers are given for more information and fax numbers for reservations. The prices are modest. St. Mary's University in Halifax, Nova Scotia, for example, offers bed and breakfast -- all you can eat, they say -- from May to August. An adult in a single room would pay $24 a night, including taxes, in American dollars; a twin room would cost $37.50 a night and four people could rent an apartment for $77 a night. Linen and towels are included.
The Atlantic Provinces create a separate brochure, "Vacationing on a Budget," which gives prices and a few descriptive details on the 15 campuses in New Brunswick, Newfoundland, Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island.
To receive this free brochure and the chart listing all Canadian campuses with space to rent, write to Jean Voisey, Canadian University and College Conference Officers Association, Room 311, Hatcher House, Memorial University, St. John's, Newfoundland A1C 5S7.
One way to find United States universities that rent dormitory rooms is to order a $13 directory called "U.S. and Worldwide Travel Accommodations Guide." This 76-page, large-format stapled paperback has been appearing for 10 years, so information is more complete than the Hugheses' book, but it is also a work in progress. John and Mary Jensen, former teachers, began it as a list for people on sabbatical, and have been expanding it since. In cases where they have arrangements with university groups overseas, notably with a technical college consortium in England, they simply pick up the charts that the groups use, complete with symbols, and the data may not match the format in the rest of the book.
A prime entry for the United States is the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, N.J., which provides quick access to Manhattan with dormitory rentals starting at $15 a person a night on the basis of two in a room.
The per person per night price given on the cover is $12 to $24 but with fluctuations in the value of the dollar the overseas prices may exceed this limit. One worthwhile caveat is for the Canadian entries, which are given in United States dollars but do not add in or mention a new 7 percent federal tax.
The book is available for $13 by mail from Campus Travel Service, Box 8355, Newport Beach, Calif. 92660; 714-720-3729. For first-class postage add $1.50.

HEADLINE: Way Cleared for Long-Delayed Housing

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
BY resolving several lingering disputes with community activists, some dating back more than a decade, the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins has cleared the way for the construction of nearly 4,000 new or renovated apartments and town houses in New York City.
Emerging from the details of those projects are the broad outlines of the Mayor's policies for housing production. The pivotal change is the expansion of low- and moderate-income housing sought by community and nonprofit groups and less reliance on the sale of city land for market-rate developments to finance the lower-cost projects. 
 At the same time, however, the recession and weak real estate market are taking their toll on programs, cutting the city's construction funds and stalling three other proposals for about 3,000 dwellings.
The city's budget for construction has dropped steadily from the peak of $738 million and 26,352 dwellings started in 1989, during Mayor Edward I. Koch's re-election campaign and when the economy was flush. For the year starting July 1, the city plans to spend $480 million for 14,635 units, and even that may be subject to cutbacks.
The new agreements will allow building or rehabilitating 1,711 dwellings in the South Bronx and west of Central Park and bordering the East Village in Manhattan. Officials hope to announce settlement soon on the fourth pending project, in Central Harlem, involving 2,200 new and rehabilitated apartments.
Taken together, the city's actions signal both the content and style of housing programs under the new administration, according to present and former officials and experts outside government.
The policy's cornerstone is the bolstering of low- and moderate-income housing to retain a neighborhood's mix of residents by income levels -- an economic version of "the gorgeous mosaic" the Mayor invokes to describe New York's ethnic and racial diversity.
Other essential features are the fostering of homeownership and tenant management, consulting with community groups, revising proposals to win local support and involving the groups in operating the housing.
"It's a change in policy and a change in attitude," said Felice L. Michetti, Mr. Dinkins's Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development, who was deputy commissioner under Mayor Koch.
The prior administration's approach promoted middle- and upper-income housing in neighborhoods where the booming private real estate market of the 1980's sustained gentrification. The city used some of the proceeds to help finance housing for lower-income residents.
Commissioner Michetti's efforts have drawn generally favorable reviews.
"If Koch's priority was based on the market, now the priority is to meet the needs of those who need housing the most," said Harold DeRienzo, chief executive of Consumer-Farmer Foundation, a nonprofit housing and community development agency.
"I think the city's is doing all it can to maintain a commitment to affordable housing," he said.
The last Housing Commissioner, Abraham Biderman, had kind words for Ms. Michetti and contended that the current policies were similar to his. He said his administration had worked on the projects now coming to fruition and had also emphasized housing for varied incomes.
Manhattan Borough President Ruth W. Messinger disputed Mr. Biderman's assessment.
UNDER Mayor Koch, she said, the controversial proposals "sat there and really did not move" and lower-income housing "was not the focus."
When Mr. Dinkins appointed Ms. Michetti a year ago, she decided at the outset to confront the backlog of projects bogged down by tenant and community opposition. Despite being an 18-year veteran of city government, she said she approached the disputes afresh, ready to discard or amend city positions. In dealing with neighborhood groups, she adopted Mr. Dinkins's techniques of conciliation and consensus.
"I said to the staff: 'There are several outstanding struggles here that I would like to approach with an open mind, not carrying any baggage or policies of the past,' " Ms. Michetti recalled. "I said: 'Let's begin a dialogue in good faith and see where it takes us. Start over and give it a chance.' "
That approach apparently paid off with agreement on new housing projects near St. Mary's Park in the Mott Haven section of the Bronx, in Strycker's Bay on the Upper West Side, Cooper Square in lower Manhattan and Bradhurst Avenue in Central Harlem.
Ground was broken in February for 540 new homes on vacant lots for a Nehemiah project near St. Mary's Park. The sponsor is the South Bronx Churches, a coalition of 40 Protestant, Catholic and Muslim congregations modeled on the Nehemiah program in Brooklyn, which builds town houses that working-class people can afford to own. The Bronx group had fought bitterly with the Koch administration over another South Bronx site, where the city insisted on higher-density housing.
Two breakthroughs occurred in the agreement with the Dinkins administration. With half the development slated for triplexes, it is Nehemiah's first deviation from its theme of one-family homes, although each unit will be owned by its occupant.
And the project marks Nehemiah's first expansion outside of Brooklyn.
"Basically it was a compromise to address the issue of density raised by the city while preserving our principle of homeownership," said the Rev. Bertram G. Bennett Jr., a leader of the church group. I. D. Robbins, the developer and civic activist who conceived Nehemiah, often assails public officials and denounced Mr. Biderman sharply, said of Ms. Michetti that she was not hostile.
The negotiations also produced an increase in city aid. The estimated cost of the homes is $65,000 each. The city provides the land free, plus a subsidy reducing the homebuyer's purchase price to $50,000. The city will recoup its subsidies from future profits on resales.
TO get construction started, churches around the city are establishing a revolving loan fund of $4 million, which will be repaid as the housing units are sold. Trinity Church, on Broadway at Wall Street, and St. James' Episcopal Church, on Madison Avenue at 71st Street, have pledged $1 million each to the fund. The state will offer low-cost mortgages for working families with annual incomes ranging from $18,000 to $56,000.
In Strycker's Bay, agreement has been reached and an announcement is expected soon on the rehabilitation of 181 apartments in 15 walk-up buildings scattered from 87th to 95th Streets between Columbus Avenue and Central Park West.
Fourteen years ago the city took possession of the buildings, intending to demolish them for urban renewal. But residents objected to the plans and formed the United Tenants Association to press for preserving the structures.
From that movement, an organization is being created with tenant and neighborhood representation to own and manage the buildings.
A $9 million city grant will pay for the rehabilitation, which starts this spring. Once the renovations are done, the rents will rise, but the new rates will be capped at $50 a room a month, according to Joan Wallstein, an assistant housing commissioner. That will keep the apartments affordable for low-income residents, though not quite the bargain as the current rents -- some under $100 a month.
IN Cooper Square, after 31 years of a neighborhood battle against urban renewal plans that would have displaced 1,200 families, agreement was announced in December for several sites near the Bowery and Houston Street in Manhattan.
Plans call for building 560 new apartments for $16 million and renovating 430 in 37 buildings for $17 million. The renovated units will be for low- and moderate-income tenants. Of the new apartments, 200 will be rentals and 360 will be owner-occupied cooperatives or condominiums, with a fifth reserved for low-income residents and the rest for residents of middle and moderate income.
The Cooper Square Community Development Committee and Businessmen's Association helped negotiate the agreement, and local residents will help oversee the project and select tenants and owners. The project will include a community center.
In the Bradhurst Avenue project, the largest in the group -- exceeding the three others combined -- the city is negotiating with the Consortium for Central Harlem, representing churches and economic development organizations. Officials indicated that while details remain to be worked out, there appear to be no conceptual stumbling blocks.
The tentative plan is for 2,200 apartments at sites scattered from 139th to 155th Streets, between Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard and Edgecombe and Bradhurst Avenues, in Manhattan. The project would include both renovations and new construction, with rentals as well as owner-occupied dwellings for a range of incomes.
Commissioner Michetti has her eyes on the next thorny project to resolve: "Another test will be Clinton. Many of these same issues are embedded in that site as well."
Clinton covers Manhattan's Theater District and neighborhoods to the west. For years, city officials and local groups have debated the fate of urban renewal sites there, especially regarding housing, business relocation and the theater and dance industries. Now the community board, its powers enhanced by the revised City Charter, is forging its own plan.
Funds are in place for Bronx Nehemiah, Strycker's Bay and Cooper Square, Ms. Michetti said, and she is trying to keep Bradhurst's budget intact.
Financing problems stalled the West Queens project in Long Island City sponsored by the Real Estate Board of New York. In its place, a new plan is being developed by the city with Queens Borough President Claire Shulman and the New York Partnership, Ms. Michetti said.
Policy changes and the economy felled two Manhattan proposals: the Milstein project near 10th Avenue and 44th Steet and the Seward Park project, also called Bridgepoint, near the Williamsburg Bridge.
The market no longer supports the rising values those proposals were based on, Ms. Michetti said. Further, they did not meet Mayor Dinkins's standards for incorporating the views of local groups and providing sufficient low- and moderate-income housing. The commissioner said she wants to work with local groups to devise new plans for the sites.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 28, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on April 14 about New York City's housing plans rendered information on rents at the Strycker's Bay project incompletely. The Department of Housing Preservation and Development had said that rents would be limited to $50 a room during renovations. But in two years, when a local nonprofit organization takes over, rents will rise to about $90. Further increases will come under rent-stabilization rules.
