PUB-DATE: April 14, 1991

SECTION: Section 6; Page 43; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 5019 words

HEADLINE: The Unfinished Politician

BYLINE: By Robin Toner Robin Toner, national political correspondent of The New York Times, profiled Dianne Feinstein for this magazine last fall.

 BODY:
SENATOR BOB KERREY WAS DRIVING THROUGH THE flat fields of northern Nebraska, a somber landscape in midwinter: white sky, white fields, a few brown stands of trees. The land was quiet, frozen, and farmers had time for a town meeting with their Senator, time to gripe about the price of soybeans and the inequities of the new Federal farm program.
But it was the trouble in the Persian Gulf that was uppermost on their minds. It was a few days before Congress was to vote on the resolution authorizing President Bush to go to war with Iraq, and many Nebraskans were inclined to support him. But Senator Kerrey did not. 
 Everywhere he went, the 47-year-old Democrat talked about the cost of war. Everywhere he went, he talked about the reality of war, a very simple reality, he said, for all the wizardry of high technology. "In the end, you've got to take ground, and you've got to hold ground, and you've got to kill," he said. Saddam Hussein could be contained with something short of a full-scale offensive, Kerrey argued. The price of such an offensive, he said, was simply too high.
Kerrey's audiences listened respectfully, although many in this conservative state clearly disagreed. Still, this was not just another liberal Democrat cautioning against the use of force; this was one of their own, a Lincoln boy who went off to Vietnam 22 years ago and came home with a Medal of Honor and an artificial leg. In these meetings, Kerrey did not talk much about his own experiences. He did not have to. The memory of Vietnam was everywhere, an old ache aroused by the prospect of a new war.
Two months later, Bob Kerrey struggled with that memory once again -- this time pondering how it might have led him astray. The war in the Persian Gulf was over, a popular success, and Congressional Democrats, most of whom voted against the war authorization, were grimly hunkered down. But Kerrey was wrestling, aloud, on the Senate floor and in political speeches around the country, with what had happened: where he had gone wrong and where he had not. He continued to stand behind his vote against the war, but he talked about his "voyage" of recent months, about what he had learned of "the fallibility of my own nature."
"My own war experiences affected me throughout, and I say, as I have said to Nebraskans, not always in a constructive fashion," he said last month in a speech in Oklahoma City. "The political lies of Vietnam, and their tragic impact, have put me on constant alert for a battle cry that is tainted with insincerity or evasiveness."
It was a characteristic speech -- emotional, introspective, at times maddeningly inexact and naive, willing to concede error and far removed from the cool policy debate that is the norm in Washington. It was the speech of an unfinished politician, still in the middle of a personal odyssey that began in Vietnam, an odyssey of significance to a party and a generation.
Shaped by a devastating wound and a failed war, Bob Kerrey is a complicated, intense, often troubled politician who has become one of the most distinctive voices in the Democratic Party. He stands at the fault line of the 1960's: a decorated Vietnam veteran who later opposed the war but was wary of the antiwar movement because "it felt anti-veteran to me."
Emblematic of the conflicted political attitudes of the baby boomers, Kerrey was suspicious and sometimes contemptuous of politics for much of his life, then jumped in at the age of 39 to run for office for the first time. The job was governor and he won it. He still cultivates an outsider's air; some Democrats think of him as the "un-politician."
He lapses from time to time into moments of "cosmic Bob," putting aside the details of health care, education and foreign policy to talk of God, altruism and the need for spirituality in American politics. Some Democrats worry that they have produced another Jerry Brown, another mystic, when what they need are street-smart pols. The flattering way to describe him is inner-directed. But between the lines, one can almost hear the plaintive question from the political veterans, bred on straight-ahead, eyes-on-the-prize Humphreys and Mondales: What's wrong with this generation, anyhow?
Kerrey bears many telltale signs of a man with Presidential ambitions -- a national speaking schedule, a top aide out of the Gary Hart campaigns (Bill Shore) and a practiced line that disavows current interest in the White House while refusing to rule anything out. But when a reporter suggests he is playing out the string on this game and enjoying it, he turns petulant. "You're looking cynically at me," he snaps. "I'm not asking you to put me on any bloody short list, and it doesn't bother me if you take me off it."
Friends worry that he is being pushed too fast. Critics portray him as a lightweight with gushy press notices, a compelling life story and few real political accomplishments. Republicans dismiss him as the latest incarnation of the Democratic Party's ultraliberal, pacifist wing.
Clayton K. Yeutter, the new Republican Party chairman, scoffs at Kerrey's "negative and depressed viewpoints," while Roger Stone, a Republican strategist, says, "His war record provides some immunity, but he still fits into the Mondale/McGovern wing of the party when it comes to foreign policy."
As the spotlight settles on him, Kerrey whipsaws between angst and attitude. Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic poll taker, sums up the tension this way: "The question on Kerrey is, there's a fine line between being unconventional and being unpresidential."

THE GENERATION that fought in World War II came home to a foreign policy consensus -- the virtues of containment, a muscular United States presence around the world to stem the onslaught of communism and prevent another world war. But those who fought in Vietnam, and those who fought against the war in Vietnam, and those in between never resolved what it meant for American foreign policy.
"The Vietnam War never ended," says Todd Gitlin, a sociologist at the University of California at Berkeley and former president of Students for a Democratic Society. "It simply stopped. And the country was left to thrash around without ever coming to a consensus on why we got involved in the war in the first place, and why we lost it, and with what consequences."
This unfinished business hung heavily over the gulf debates. A few days before the vote, Kerrey reflected, "I think it's going to be very difficult over the next 20 years or so to come to that conclusion: the conclusion of when do you die? When do you put it on the line? When do you use force?"
Many Democrats faulted George Bush for viewing the Persian Gulf crisis through the prism of World War II, the war of his youth, for drawing easy analogies to Hitler and Chamberlain in a kind of geopolitical transference. Kerrey, however, all but acknowledges that he is sometimes a prisoner of his own war.
"I believe that if we launch a military offensive, we will sustain thousands of casualties without military necessity, moral justification or public endorsement," he said in written testimony submitted to the Senate Armed Services Committee last November. He worried that the war would "reopen social divisions we have only recently healed."
Throughout the late summer and fall, he attacked the Administration for not outlining a worthy rationale for the war and not confessing the policy errors that led to it. In January, he joined 44 other Senate Democrats in voting against the war resolution, urging that sanctions be given more time to work. The resolution passed by a vote of 52 to 47.
After the war, Kerrey took to the floor of the Senate for a characteristically candid post-mortem. "I have had the experience of having Government mislead me, of not leveling entirely," he said. "I have had the experience of just being in a war and then discovering you get halfway into it and Americans stop supporting it. It influenced my judgment on what we should do, perhaps too much."
Even before the war in the gulf, Kerrey admitted that his thinking on America's role in the world had begun to change. As a result of Vietnam, he said, he'd been skeptical about the doctrine of containment, until the emergence of Eastern Europe and the testimony of such dissidents as Vaclav Havel and Lech Walesa about the importance of America's cold war stance. "My own experience had caused me to skeptically conclude something that was wrong," he said. "It was worth doing, and perhaps it was worth pressing it even further than we did."
In an interview after the cease-fire in the gulf, Kerrey said he would continue to stand behind what he called, with a slight smile, "the mother of all votes." He said he still believed that sanctions would have worked, but noted that, like other Democrats after the vote, he immediately rallied round the President and his policy. In a series of speeches after the war, he hailed the efforts of the troops and of General H. Norman Schwarzkopf and praised President Bush for articulating a moral crusade that roused the American people.
It is critical, Kerrey said, that this moral framework not be overlooked and that America keep pushing for the cause of individual freedom in Iraq and Kuwait. "If all we do after this war is over is take advantage of construction contracts, cheap oil and new buyers of military hardware," he said in a recent speech, "the sweet taste of victory could become as bitter as the defeat in Vietnam."
The suspicion of the Vietnam vet remains, along with an unflinching sense of the reality of war. "I remember sitting in that Philadelphia Naval Hospital," he says, "listening to the politicians saying, 'We know what war is all about,' and thinking, 'You bastards haven't got any idea.' "
KERREY ENLISTED IN October 1966. He was 23 years old, one of seven children of a building contractor and a teacher (both now deceased), and a recent graduate of the University of Nebraska at Lincoln, with a degree in pharmacy. He was about to be drafted into the Army; instead, he joined the Navy and entered officer candidate school. When he earned his commission a year later, he volunteered for the Seals (the acronym stands for sea, air and land, meaning its members operate in all three) -- the Navy's commando team. "Mostly it was just duty," Kerrey says with a shrug. "I was an American. We had a war."
An old friend from the Seals, Gary Parrott, recalls: "We didn't go out there just to fight the enemy. We went out to capture important people and damage their war-making capability."
Lieutenant (j.g.) Kerrey was a Seal team leader. In January 1969 his seven-man team was sent to Vietnam. On the moonless night of March 14, Kerrey's unit set out to capture a group of Vietcong intelligence officers operating on a small island off the coast of Nha Trang. A defector had informed the Americans of the Vietcong's location, on a ledge beneath a 350-foot cliff. Kerrey and his team, intending to surprise them from above, had designed an operation to scale the cliff.
The Americans split into two teams, one to engage the Vietcong from the front while Kerrey and the other group came down from the top. They were near the end of their descent when the Vietcong began firing. A grenade exploded at Kerrey's feet. "All I knew was it was loud and it hurt like hell," he says.
His citation for the Congressional Medal of Honor declares: "Although bleeding profusely and suffering great pain, he displayed outstanding courage and presence of mind in immediately directing his element's fire into the heart of the enemy camp. Utilizing his radioman, Lieutenant Kerrey called in the second element's fire support, which caught the confused Vietcong in a devastating crossfire.
"After successfully suppressing the enemy's fire, and although immobilized by his multiple wounds, he continued to maintain calm, superlative control as he ordered his team to secure and defend an extraction site. Lieutenant Kerrey resolutely directed his men, despite his near-unconscious state, until he was eventually evacuated by helicopter. The havoc brought to the enemy by this very successful mission cannot be overestimated."
Kerrey had been in Vietnam for three months. He would spend the next nine months in a hospital, along with a lot of other young men trying to cope with lost limbs, burned bodies and pain. As Kerrey's roommate at the Philadelphia Naval Hospital, Jim Crotty, says, "It was, very simply, another war."
 KERREY ARRIVED IN Philadelphia shortly after his injury, and the doctors immediately scheduled surgery. When he woke up, he asked his mother how much of his leg was left. They had managed to save the knee.
The hospital specialized in amputees, and each morning, Crotty recalls, the orthopedic surgeons conducted "stump rounds," examining wounds and changing dressings. "You could tell how close they were to your room by the screams you heard," says Crotty. "And one thing I remember about Bob is, I never heard him utter a sound. He just had a real good capacity for pain."
Kerrey describes the hospital as a defining experience. "It's awfully difficult to be arrogant when they're sticking a bedpan under your butt. I learned what it's like to be dependent. Learned what it's like to suffer. Learned what it's like to feel compassion for someone who's suffering even more. Learned what it's like to feel alone and different."
In the hospital, he says, his doubts and anger about the war began to grow. "I was strongly of the opinion that Vietnamization would not work, that all we were doing was stalling for time and that we were going to negotiate away every damn thing we said we wouldn't negotiate away, that all we were trying to do was protect the politicians for a little while until they could get re-elected.
"And that's exactly what we did. And another 20,000 guys died."
He went home to Nebraska in December 1969 -- angry, bitter and still in a lot of physical pain. He worked with the liberal activist Allard Lowenstein in a voter registration drive and spoke out against the war, "but I didn't feel any strong kinship with the antiwar movement." Years later, he saw a taped interview he had done in 1973 with Jim Lehrer. "They asked me, are you bitter? And I said, 'NO!' And Jesus, you see the thing and you'd say, 'Here's a guy who's the definition of bitterness.' "
He went back to school, then into business with his brother-in-law, eventually building chains of restaurants and health clubs in Nebraska. He had several operations on his leg during the 1970's that enabled him to walk with only a slight limp and eventually even to run five miles a day. He married a woman from Nebraska, Beverly Defnall, and had a son and a daughter (Benjamin, now 16, and Lindsey, 14), but the marriage ended after four years. Kerrey had been only minimally involved in politics and had never run for office when he decided to seek the governorship in 1982. A combination of the ailing farm economy and his own fresh appeal helped him oust Republican Charles Thone.
"I believed I would be good at it and I would enjoy it, and finally I just said, 'I'm going to try,' " Kerrey says. "I'd had a lot of involvement with government, and I'd seen it do stupid things."
 IT WAS LATE, AND OMAHA was a good 40 miles away. Bob Kerrey had already done a half-dozen events that January day, the last being a long meeting in the small town of Tekamah, where he'd responded to anxious questions about the Persian Gulf. The small traveling party of aides and reporters was ready for Omaha and bed. Kerrey, however, had other ideas: Everybody was going to Ronnie's, a Tekamah bar. The patrons looked up approvingly as their Senator walked in at 9:30 on a Tuesday night and ordered a beer. It is the kind of surprise Nebraskans have come to expect. It is part of the mystique.
Kerrey appears ideally suited for an era of personality politics. There is, of course, Bob Kerrey, war hero. There is also Bob Kerrey, regular guy, whooping it up with a couple of beefy ranchers about a mutual acquaintance, a trapper renowned for his drinking ability and earthy habits. There is Bob Kerrey, celebrity bachelor, who has an off-again, on-again relationship with the actress Debra Winger; they met in 1983 in Lincoln, where she was filming "Terms of Endearment" and he was in the Governor's mansion. Even Bob Dole, the unimpressable Senate minority leader, looked slightly dazzled when Kerrey showed up at the Capitol one weekend during the budget crisis with Winger in tow. People magazine could not have done a better job inventing Bob Kerrey.
David K. Karnes, the former Senator who was defeated by Kerrey in 1988, contends that all the glitter has an impact. "I was never able to transcend the charisma and get to the issues," he says. Karnes remembers one campaign event when "somebody came up and asked me about soybean marketing loans; then they turned to Bob and asked about Willie Nelson and Debra Winger."
Kent Grisham, the former communciations director of the Nebraska Republican Party, adds: "He has star quality. I don't think he has leadership qualities. I don't think he has statesmanlike qualities, but unfortunately star quality can get you elected."
"Charisma" is a word devalued by overuse, endlessly invoked by a generation of journalists and consultants seeking the Kennedy myth of their youth. But Kerrey does have the ability, in person and on screen, to connect.
The looks help. Kerrey has a boyish face saved from weatherman prettiness by his eyes, which are the eyes of a man who spent nine months in a hospital. He is much hotter emotionally than most of his fellow politicians, who have been taught to downsize their gestures and cool their tones for the television era, only to find a generation of voters turned off by standardized, sound-alike pols.
"I remember seeing the first cuts of the TV ads in his first campaign, and they leapt off the screen," says John J. Cavanaugh, a former Democratic Representative from Omaha. "I said, geez, can we tone this guy down?"
Kerrey always has an edge -- sometimes ironic detachment, sometimes a barely cloaked streak of up-yours:
Reporter: "You've been the subject of a lot of speculation about running for the Presidency. Do you want it and do you think you're ready for it?"
Kerrey: "I don't want it and I don't know if I'm ready for it. If I wanted it, I'd worry about being ready."
Reporter: "So you'd rule out a run in '92?"
Kerrey: "I don't absolutely rule out a run in '92, but something's going to have to happen to make me want to be President. And it hasn't happened yet."
Reporter: "Why wouldn't you want to be President?"
Kerrey: "Gee, I don't know. Let somebody else figure that out. That's what you guys do for a living. Analyze."
Reporter: "No, that's what therapists do for a living."
Kerrey: "That's right. [Laughing, lowering his voice] 'Maybe it's because he gets too angry.' "
Kerrey and his handlers have a sure sense of how to package his persona. His 1988 campaign commercials had the aura of Midwestern myth: Kerrey in fields, Kerrey on a farm with a huge extended family, Kerrey talking dead into the camera about losing his leg and witnessing the birth of his children -- all under the tag line, "Nebraska at Its Best."
The Republican Party's Grisham argues, with considerable frustration, that Kerrey "represents a much more liberal, left-of-center group of people than Nebraskans tend to be." But according to an Omaha World-Herald poll, Kerrey's approval rating in the state has generally stayed above 70 percent and Nebraskans dote on his national image. Almost everywhere he goes in the state, people ask if he will run for President.
Kerrey's detractors say his personal magnetism has masked an unimpressive record in both offices he's held. He was Governor during the height of the farm crisis, but a Governor can usually do little more on farm issues than rail at Federal policies. Kerrey takes credit for balancing a strained budget without a permanent tax increase. But even he acknowledges that he "made a lot of mistakes" in his handling of the state's banking crisis in the mid-80's.
Those mistakes came under renewed scrutiny last year when Kerrey launched an attack on the Bush Administration's own handling of the national savings-and-loan collapse. Republicans noted that Kerrey had kept close ties, including a business partnership, with one of the owners of a Nebraska bank that eventually folded while he was Governor. The Omaha World-Herald reported last year that investigations had found no evidence of wrongdoing by Kerrey, but the issue lingers.
His critics point to something else about Kerrey: an impatience, a restlessness. In 1985, just three years after becoming Governor, he announced that he would not run again, explaining he needed a break from politics, saying it was time to move on. He taught for a while and tended his restaurant business; then in 1988, after the death of incumbent Democratic Senator Edward Zorinsky and the short-term appointment of Karnes, he returned to run for the Senate. "He ran for Governor and inspired the troops to beat an incumbent," says Karnes. "Then three-quarters of the way through, he decided it wasn't what he really wanted to do. I guess the question comes down to, what is his motivation? What drives this guy?"
 KERREY ARRIVED IN Washington in 1989 amid great expectations; right from the start, the Democratic networks were humming about the talented newcomer who might be able to help juice the party, a party shut out of the White House for a decade, a party constantly searching for the angle, the philosophy, the personalities to bring it back. The Democratic Party makes its stars with dizzying speed, and often breaks them just as quickly.
Kerrey sought and won appointments to the Appropriations and Agriculture committees -- good assignments for a Midwestern freshman, though not the kind that win a Senator national visibility. Last year, Kerrey built a fairly liberal voting record, according to the annual ranking by the National Journal: more liberal than 66 percent of his colleagues on economic issues, than 74 percent on social issues and than 75 percent on foreign issues.
He made his mark during one of the most emotional debates of the 101st Congress, over a proposed Constitutional amendment to outlaw flag burning. Eventually, most Senate Democrats voted against that amendment, but Kerrey opposed it at a time when few Democrats were willing to get out front and polls showed overwhelming support for the measure. The Democratic leadership was delighted to see the charge led by a winner of the Medal of Honor.
Kerrey was also a vocal critic of the Administration's Southeast Asia policy. He has argued that the United States should explore the possibility of improving relations with Vietnam and the Vietnamese-backed government of Cambodia.
Kerrey has tried to tackle health care as well, holding numerous informal hearings on the issue in his home state and producing a draft plan this winter intended to provide universal health care. But as some of the keepers of conventional wisdom in Washington have noticed, he often gives the impression of being in the middle of a vast tutorial on national policy.
"My sense of Kerrey is of a guy who hit .385 in triple-A ball, is proclaimed by all the scouts as the next phenom, comes up to the Major Leagues and so far hasn't really shown that he'll be a star in the World Series," says Norman Ornstein, an analyst at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative Washington think tank.
Yet Kerrey, by virtue of his raw political talent and the wide-open Democratic field, regularly makes the short list of potential Presidential candidates kept by the press and the political professionals. This has caused some jitters among his friends. "I have told him, be careful," says J. James Exon, Nebraska's senior Democratic Senator and something of a mentor to Kerrey. "The press loves to build people up for these offices, and then once they build them up to a pinnacle, they love to tear them down."
Another senior Democrat, a declared fan of Kerrey's who insisted on not being identified, adds: "I'm sure he's getting a lot of pressure to do it, but I don't think he's getting that much pressure from his real friends. What little opportunity he's had to prepare to run for the Presidency would make him fall, and if you fall hard, it's hard to come back."
Already there are hints of downward reappraisal. "I'm a little worried that he could turn out to be a kind of recycled Jerry Brown," says one Democratic consultant who also spoke on condition of anonymity. Other Democrats privately worry about a gravitas problem. To which a somewhat exasperated Kerrey replies, "I'm not going to sit here and list the things that cause me to believe I've got gravitas."
Kerrey's strong position against the gulf war would almost certainly be used against him in any Presidential campaign. But only to a point, his allies suggest; his war record provides a certain protective cover.
Those close to Kerrey take him at his word on 1992: that he has no plans or even desire to seek the Presidency but reserves the right to change his mind. Yet there is something about Kerrey that seems incompatible with modern Presidential campaigning -- sitting in the front of an airplane day after day, watched by 50 reporters waiting for a gaffe; serving up a message of the day with relentless discipline. No more impromptu stops at Tekamah bars. No freedom to change his mind on major policy questions -- or think aloud, as Kerrey is wont to do -- without provoking a furor. Opening your personal life to unending scrutiny.
He is plainly uncomfortable with questions about Winger, whom he began seeing again last year after a long hiatus, during which she married the actor Timothy Hutton, had a son and was divorced. One day several months ago, Kerrey winced at the sight of a gossip item about his Paris rendezvous with the actress for the opening of her film "The Sheltering Sky."
"The generalization is that your personal life and your political life are always mixed up together," he said later. "And the danger is that you begin to act on the personal side as if you're still a politician. It's hard to shut it off. So you begin to think about your children and loved ones in political ways. I think that's a genuine danger."
At this point, the most intense Democratic fantasy about Kerrey probably revolves around the No. 2 slot. Party officials practically salivate at the idea of watching their Medal of Honor winner in a Vice Presidential debate against Dan Quayle, whose service in the National Guard during the Vietnam War proved so controversial in the 1988 campaign. It is an understandable fantasy for a party that has absorbed such a hammering on the issue of patriotism, that has repeatedly seen its candidates attacked as something less than red-blooded heroes.
"I think you could fund the Democratic National Committee for four years just by selling tickets to Democrats to see Kerrey on a stage with Quayle," says Harrison Hickman, a Democratic poll taker and longtime adviser to the Senator.
Kerrey, while claiming no interest in the Vice Presidency, still shows a keen sense of how to use his combat record against the Quayles of the world. When the Vice President was traveling the country pledging, "This will not be another Vietnam," Kerrey asked, "How does he know?" When Representative Newt Gingrich, the Republican whip, drew a scathing contrast between Operation Desert Storm and Operation Desert One, Jimmy Carter's failed attempt in 1980 to rescue the hostages in Iran, Kerrey fired back, taking note of the fact that Gingrich had the benefit of student and family deferments during Vietnam.
"This avoider of miltiary service gained my permanent enmity," Kerrey said, "debasing the memory of those men who died in that noble, dangerous, heroic and -- yes, in the end -- unsuccessful try to liberate their fellow Americans."
 EACH TIME BOB KERREY runs for office, his old Seal buddies show up; they help him campaign and they help him celebrate. The night Kerrey was sworn in as Governor, Gary Parrott remembers, "he just opened the door to the mansion, let us in and locked it." The night he claimed victory in the Senate race, five of his fellow Seals, who had campaigned across the state for him, were there. On live television, at the end of his victory speech, Kerrey sang a song that he dedicated to them. It was the Australian lament from World War I, "And the Band Played Waltzing Matilda," about a young man who goes to war and comes home without his legs.
For Kerrey, the political pilgrim, the journey begins in Vietnam and always leads back there. It gives his politics an emotional charge, a passion rare in public life. But Kerrey is still learning how to use it, how to harness the energies and ideas that come from his own experiences into a vision of public policy.
Like any good pilgrim, he acknowledges doubts, wrong turns, missteps. It is a refreshing trait in the Senate. In a Presidential campaign, it would not be easily forgiven.
In the days after the cease-fire in the gulf, exuberant pundits all over the country pronounced the Vietnam syndrome dead. Bob Kerrey was reaching for some closure, too. In an interview, he talked about the astonishing effectiveness of the allied military campaign, of the nation's justifiable pride in its troops.
"We started this thing and we finished it," Kerrey said. "We have a powerful military leader in Schwarzkopf, who did exactly what he said he was going to do. We drove them out of Kuwait. We accomplished our objectives, and there's tremendous pride in that."
But Kerrey was raising questions, too. "The larger issue for me is, how are we going to use this power? Are we going to use it for good?"
He rambled on, thoughts and theories spinning round and round, searching, apparently, for his own "new world order."

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
A Soviet Version, Perhaps, of a TV Soap

BYLINE: By LEAH D. FRANK

 BODY:
BEWARE of the play that relies on press releases, program notes and imposed staging to convince its audience that it carries an important message. Such a play is Alexander Gelman's "Man With Connections" now at Theater Three in Port Jefferson.
This contemporary Russian play is, we are told in the program, an allegory about keeping the Russian union together. To underline the issues, a large on-stage screen projects recent newspaper headlines like "Perestroika With Tears," "Sounds of Silence: Soviet Shows of Strength vs. Lithuania" and "Get Along or Kill Each Other -- There's No Other Choice." 
 If you were not told that "A Man With Connections" is a play with a message, you might have missed its significance. You might have thought this is a turgid drama about a petty bureaucrat who refuses to take responsibility for his own disastrous decisions.
"A Man With Connections" looks at the deteriorating relationship of Andrei and Natasha Gladkov, whose shaky marriage is on the verge of final collapse over the current family tragedy.
Their son has lost both his hands in a construction accident, and the bullying, authoritarian Andrei was the project foreman who sent his son's crew to work on an unsafe road in violation of safety regulations.
Natasha has just been told the ugly details of the accident by one of Andrei's employees, and she is torn between the wish to throw her husband out of their apartment and the desire to kill him.
If the earnest imposition of current events had been left off stage, "A Man With Connections" would be a ponderous Soviet drama with occasional flashes of intelligent insight into the Russian equivalent to America's skewed Wall Street tycoons.
The play offers glimpses of the way of economic life in Russia, where crippling shortages and inefficiency foster a bizarre method of doing business. Here it truly is not what you know, but who you know, that gets the job done.
Andrei's failures stem from his methods of handling shortages in both his marriage and his construction business. He cannot build in either sector, because he has not established a concrete foundation, literally and figuratively.
There is no trust or mutual support between husband and wife. Andrei's manner of dealing with family problems is crude and manipulative, as are his managerial methods in the office.
"It is a business venture we have," Andrei tells Natasha, "not a family."
And, indeed, life for Andrei and Natasha is a series of semisuccessful negotiations. Shortages of paper, cement, telephones, love and personal fulfillment are all one and the same to them. Andrei knows he is unhappy, but he has no idea what to do about it other than to make sure Natasha does not leave him.
Natasha seems to serve primarily as a sounding board for the incessantly chattering Andrei. Why she stays and what she wants out of her marriage and her life are confused and confusing. Hers is a relationship as hollow as the god of materialism she worships.
Bradlee E. Bing has directed the play to be a portentous political allegory, which only serves to highlight the script's paucity of ideas.
The set was also designed by Mr. Bing. It is a collection of black oblong boxes that the characters move around like chess pieces. Red fabric is stretched across the back wall, and in the center is the large screen showing news headlines.
The two actors, Amelia Chiaramonte as the distressed Natasha and Robert Marr as the beleaguered Andrei, speak in the staccato rhythms of announcers reading news bulletins.
Some of the leaden quality of "A Man With Connections" may be owing to Stephen Mulrine's translation. Some of the play's pretentiousness may come from the production's heavy-handed imposition of topical relevance.
But most of the problems in "A Man With Connections" grow out of the playwright's old-fashioned tale of petty bureaucrats trapped on a treadmill of corruption and self-aggrandizement.
The play is at Theater Three Second Stage through May 1.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Amelia Chiaramonte and Robert Marr in scene from "A Man With Connections." (Joseph D. Sullivan)

HEADLINE: DINING OUT;
The Italian Style Is Now Family Style

BYLINE: By JOANNE STARKEY

 BODY:
FAMILY-STYLE dining is the latest trend in Italian restaurants. Serving family style is as old as grandma's kitchen, but transporting this overflowing abundance to restaurant meals is the hot new ticket.
A few restaurants predate this 1990's craze. They are found mainly in old Italian neighborhoods in the five boroughs and on Long Island at La Parma in Williston Park and La Parma II in Huntington. But since last winter, when Coco Pazzo opened on Manhattan's Upper East Side to rave reviews, family style has rocketed in popularity. 
 On Long Island, even the ubiquitous pasta cafes are being given a run for their money by the new family-style restaurants. One of the trendy newcomers is 2-month-old Piccola Bussola in Westbury.
Piccola Bussola has the same owners as La Bussola in Glen Cove, which received a rating of excellent in July of 1987. Diners expecting the serene surroundings and sedate service of La Bussola will be in for a surprise in Westbury, especially on a no-holds-barred Saturday night.
The scene is a frenetic, although congenial, one of laughing, noisy, large groups, including children, all casually attired and watching waiters hustle with huge platters of food. Our waiter, a transplant from Glen Cove, looked absolutely shellshocked.
Piccola Bussola follows the family-style formula of gargantuan menus on the walls rather than individual ones. Each dish on those menus is designed for two or more to share. Thus, prices that seem a tad high at first glance, $13.75 for chicken scarpariello or $7.50 for a combination salad, are really bargains.
That salad, which is enough for four to share, may take top honors as buy of the year. It is a tri-color beauty bolstered with onions, roasted peppers and, most of all, flavor. The Caesar at $9.50 is also recommended, but takes second prize.
Other great openers are the fried red peppers and onions loaded with garlic; the melt-in-the-mouth stuffed eggplant, which is light on crumbs and heavy on flavor, and the impeccably fresh seafood salad glistening with first-class olive oil and splendid seafood.
Baked clams are a mixed lot. The large ones on the platter are chewy, the tiny ones tender. Stuffed mushrooms are tasty with bacon and scant on filler.
Pastas like linguine marinara and zitti with broccoliat are platter-size Italian classics at $12 to $13. Although done well, they offer little excitement.
The entrees that set our table singing were the chicken scarpariello, moist, juicy and loaded with garlic, and the firm, tasty shrimp oreganata. Striped bass oreganata had the same flavor-packed tastes, but the fish was unevenly cooked. Family members grabbing the thick center pieces were happy. Those left with the overcooked edges were downcast.
Veal did not fare well. Veal chop Bussola, two large chops for $26.75, is covered with red peppers, mushrooms and onions. It had lots of spunk, but was overcooked. Veal piccata, four cutlets for $15.75, was tough.
It is a shame that most diners will be too full for dessert. Baked daily at La Bussola in Glen Cove, these sensational sweets are show stoppers. Lovers of La Bussola's luscious chocolate mousse cake topped with slabs of dark chocolate will find it here. Also top of the line are the creamy tiramisu and the moist cheese cake perfumed with orange peel.
Ordering wine at Piccola Bussola is an adventure. There is no printed list, and waiters know only two possibilities, red and white. Both are Villa Banfi table wines at $9.50 a bottle or $3 a glass.
But diners willing to search through the wine racks will discover that Piccola Bussola inherited an interesting wine cellar from the previous tenants.
Family-style restaurants offer recession-weary Long Islanders a reassuring abundance of food with small price tags in a warm homey atmosphere. And no one is stuck with the cooking or kitchen cleanup.
 
Piccola Bussola
Very Good
649 Old Country Road, one mile east of Post Avenue, Westbury. 333-1335.
Atmosphere: Family-style dining in a bustling Italian newcomer.
Service: More speedy than sophisticated.
Recommended dishes: Combination salad, Caesar salad, seafood salad, fried peppers, stuffed eggplant, stuffed mushrooms, shrimp oreganata, chicken scarpariello, chocolate mousse cake, tiramisu, cheesecake.
Price range: Lunch entrees are $7.50 to $19.50. Dinner: Appetizers, $7.50 to $14; pastas, $12 to $13; entrees, $10.75 to $26.75. All are proportioned for two or more.
Credit cards: All major cards.
Hours: Noon to 10 P.M., Monday through Thursday; noon to 11 P.M., Friday; 2:30 to 11 P.M., Saturday, and 2:30 to 10 P.M. on Sunday.
Reservations: Necessary on weekends.
Wheelchair accessibility: No steps.

HEADLINE: Rusting in Russia

BYLINE: By William Taubman; William Taubman is the author of "Governing Soviet Cities" and the co-author, with Jane Taubman, of "Moscow Spring." He is the Bertrand Snell Professor of Political Science at Amherst College.

 BODY:

STEELTOWN, USSR
Soviet Society in the Gorbachev Era.
By Stephen Kotkin.
Illustrated. 269 pp. Berkeley:
University of California Press. $24.95. 
 The Russian city of Magnitogorsk symbolizes the rise and decline of Soviet Communism. It is the subject of "Steeltown, USSR," a firsthand account by a young Princeton historian who, Soviet authorities say, was the first American to visit the city in 45 years.
Magnitogorsk was founded in 1929 just behind the southern tip of the Urals, in the open steppe. By 1939 this "hero-city" of Stalinist industrialization was producing 10 percent of Soviet steel. During World War II it turned out half the steel used to make Soviet tanks.
Among quite a few Americans who helped to build Magnitogorsk was a young expatriate, John Scott, who worked there as a welder from 1933 to 1937 and described his experience in a 1943 book, "Beyond the Urals: An American Worker in Russia's City of Steel." Scott recounted the dark side of daily life -- incredibly primitive living and working conditions, the pall cast by Stalin's purges, the presence of forced laborers alongside enthusiastic volunteers. But he emphasized the belief of many of his co-workers that they were "laying the foundations for a new society farther along the road of human progress than anything in the West; a society which would guarantee its people not only personal freedom but absolute economic security."
Fifty years after Scott left, Stephen Kotkin arrived. He found "entrenched alcoholism, recurrent shortages of consumer goods, a severe housing crisis extending well into the future, a ubiquitous black market, a crumbling or nonexistent urban infrastructure, almost unfathomable pollution, and a health catastrophe impossible to exaggerate."
As for the famous steel plant, Mr. Kotkin describes it as "a wheezing dinosaur." By the late 1980's it was the largest steel complex in the world, producing almost as much steel per year (16 million tons) as all of Great Britain -- but at precisely the time when Britain and the other Western countries were turning away from steel to accommodate the imperatives of the global economy.
Yet the most depressing change Mr. Kotkin found was the loss of hope, a loss brought on by the long years of suffering and sacrifice, and, ironically, deepened in recent years by the impact of Mikhail Gorbachev's reforms.
Most of what we know about perestroika and glasnost derives from the experience of huge metropolises like Moscow and Leningrad. Moreover, the little we have heard from the provinces has been contradictory. Some travelers, Soviet as well as Western, portray the Russian hinterland as a stronghold of conservatism. Others report that because smaller cities have experienced less economic decline than has Moscow (in part because they were worse off to begin with), their residents remain more upbeat about reform than jaded Muscovites or Leningraders.
Mr. Kotkin spent four months in Magnitogorsk -- two in 1987, when city authorities still half suspected him of being a spy, and two more in 1989, when virtually all doors were open to him. He talked with steelworkers as well as intellectuals. He accompanied candidates to electoral meetings and wrote for the local paper, with whose staff he became particularly friendly. He prowled the halls of such formerly closed institutions as courts, hospitals and even the central police station.
What Mr. Kotkin learned is that Stalinism still has a social base in Magnitogorsk. It includes the ruling nomenklatura, along with much of the intelligentsia and working class. The establishment has managed to get its own kind chosen in more or less democratic elections. The rest of the population, says Mr. Kotkin, simply goes along.
The dislocations caused by perestroika have only worsened economic conditions in Magnitogorsk, an outcome that has reinforced residents' fear that they have more to lose than to gain from change. In bigger cities a plethora of new political parties and informal groups has arisen to challenge the Communists. In Magnitogorsk only two tiny "informals" have appeared -- one made up of extreme Russian nationalists, the other of orthodox Marxists.
The main force, virtually the only force, for reform in Magnitogorsk has been the local newspaper, The Magnitogorsk Worker. But rather than inspiring people, its brave muckraking has deepened their sense of being hemmed in by troubles they are powerless to affect.
"How much evil has accumulated!" said a middle-aged skilled worker to Mr. Kotkin. "It hurts to think about it. . . . At first there was some hope. We felt we could breathe at last. It was a release. Now I don't know. I'm tired, even though I'm not old. And anyway, how can you live only on faith? We're boxed in."
Part of the glue that holds the old system together is a kind of self-hate on the part of its victims. "They make a son of a bitch out of you," said the same worker. "No one makes a move until we see where the power lies. As soon as it is clear, we all quickly take that side."
This worker summarizes the meaning of Magnitogorsk as follows: "We worked, we toiled, we built. And now they can't figure out what the hell we built! No one knows what to call it: barracks socialism, Stalinism, totalitarianism. You could spend the rest of your life thinking about it, but you'll never come up with the right name. What we built -- it's unnameable."
Mr. Kotkin's message is sobering. Alas, the medium that conveys it is disappointing. In contrast to John Scott's book, which contained gripping narrative sections, Mr. Kotkin's chapters (on the economy, glasnost, elections, etc.) consist of repetitive bits and pieces that never develop any overall momentum. With a few exceptions, such as the just-quoted blue-collar worker, people appear and reappear without our getting a sense of them as individuals. Perhaps this is the result of Mr. Kotkin's training; he seems more comfortable analyzing social aggregates than sketching personal portraits. In any event, it detracts from the impact of what is otherwise a valuable book.

GRAPHIC: Phot: Construction workers in the Soviet city of Magnitogorsk. (From "Steel Town, USSR")

HEADLINE: Bullish on Sex

BYLINE: By Peter Cameron; Peter Cameron is the author of "One Way or Another," a collection of stories, and "Leap Year," a novel.

 BODY:

PRIVATE ACTS
By Linda Gray Sexton.
317 pp. Boston:
Little, Brown & Company.
$19.95. 
 Sometimes the world turns too quickly -- or the cogs of publishing turn too slowly -- for contemporary writers. Novels that painstakingly re-create a specific moment in time appear, through no fault of their own, to be set in an alien world when they are finally published. Linda Gray Sexton's fourth novel, "Private Acts," an account of very wealthy people doing not-so-nice things in the New York City of 1986, arrives in 1991 like a relic from some lost, prewar, pre recession civilization.
Like most fiction set in New York, "Private Acts" concerns itself with a particular milieu; here it is "the upper echelons" of Wall Street investment banks. The novel is peopled exclusively by investment bankers, the people who sleep with investment bankers and, in one case, the children of investment bankers (one of the things we learn is that investment bankers have no time for children). These are men and women who consider Scarsdale a sixth borough of the city, who think Stuyvesant Town is the Lower East Side. Their meals in expensive restaurants are frequently interrupted by their beepers or their sex drive, forcing them to abscond with doggie bags filled with sea urchins and lobster. In short, they "can afford to look past the worst" in New York. And they do.
At the center of all these investment bankers is Maggie Whitten, who is not one. She had been the fiction editor of Esquire, but she left that job to move to Scarsdale with her husband, Sy (his bank is First Boston) and raise their children, Kate and Mikey. Maggie and Sy met at Harvard in the early 70's, where they double-dated with Maggie's roommate, Alexis, now of Hewett Lowell, and Sy's best friend, Nicolas, who owns a chain of clothing stores.
When the book begins, over a day of tennis in the Whittens' backyard, everyone is -- or appears to be -- happy: Maggie and Sy, Alexis and Nicolas, and Christa, a colleague of Sy's at First Boston, and Jon, a defense-industry analyst.
As the summer progresses, Sy, who is desperately attempting to become a partner, ignores Maggie and the children; Maggie becomes frustrated at home and longs to return to work; Alexis grows sick of Nicolas, who seems to have lost interest in (or claws for) "hanging on for her ride to the top"; and Jon loses interest in Christa and concentrates on -- and succeeds in -- seducing Alexis, who finds his "smell of . . . power" to be "an aphrodisiac."
Maggie begins her job search with a couple of disheartening interviews, only to abandon it in favor of an affair with Nicolas, who has begun hanging around the house in Sy's absence. They spend their afternoons on a mattress in the attic, and he gives her the orgasms Sy cannot. She becomes "his slave, his thing to do with as he wills, his child," and it's not long before Maggie is enjoying a little bondage and thinking of herself as a "sweetmeat on a pile of laundry." (She was, after all, fiction editor at Esquire, not Ms.)
Meanwhile, the plot spins as Alexis is indulging in insider trading, trying to make partner (a year early) while romancing Jon and coping with endometriosis. Nicolas urges Maggie to leave Sy. And Maggie is torn between her children, her husband, her best friend, her career and her newfound sexuality. No wonder she bolts out of the house into the snow, slamming the door behind her like Ibsen's Nora, to spend "some time to think, by myself, about what I want to do."
Ms. Sexton gets much right in "Private Acts." The suburban domestic scenes are particularly convincing. She is always generous with details, and sets up and plays out scenes with skill. If none of her characters are particularly sympathetic or compelling, there are moments when they all seem human and vulnerable. They are smug, but not hypocritical -- not one even pretends to have a social conscience. Unfortunately, however, there is not a trace of satire here -- all this lusting for power and money is portrayed with vapid sincerity. The (third-person) narrator is characterless, humorless (we are constantly told that people are laughing, lest we not discern the humor) and totally nonjudgmental. Greed, vice, even rape go not only unpunished but unacknowledged.
When the characters are re assembled on the tennis court a year later, it is revealed that Maggie is writing the book we have been reading. This goes a long way toward explaining the murky and incestuous point of view of "Private Acts": it finally becomes a book not only about, but for, investment bankers.

HEADLINE: Trade Restrictions Would Hurt All the Chinese

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Anthony Lewis is right when he says that we must remember Wei Jingsheng and press for his release ("The Prisoner," column, March 25). Nor should we forget other political prisoners in Chinese prisons. But Mr. Lewis is wrong, I think, in presuming that removal of China's mostfavored-nation tariff status is a way to secure their freedom. If he does not envision such action as a way to secure their release, but as punishment of China's leaders, he is ignoring other components of Chinese society and of United States-China relations. 
 Mr. Lewis's resolve does not address the situation of the many Chinese intellectuals, educators, writers, artists, as well as people in commerce, who were not imprisoned and who desperately yearn to keep open ties with the West. We must consider whether rescinding most-favored-nation status would push China's leaders toward further cutting their ties with the West and what this would mean for the many in China who no longer support the Government.
After the 1989 massacre, for example, many educational organizations debated whether or not to cease exchanges with China. Some did, some did not. But now almost all these organizations have resumed educational exchanges for many reasons. The main one, I believe, is the sense that there is less hope for change in China if ties with Western democracies, as well as Western technologies and Western wealth, are cut.
Commerce too is a form of educational exchange and a vital component in increasing aspirations toward political, intellectual and economic freedom in China. We should not follow Deng Xiaoping and his comrades, who mistakenly believed they could separate the political and intellectual from the economic sphere. Contact with the West for the last decade has allowed Chinese intellectuals, academics and officials in the central and provincial governments to experience free exchange firsthand.
As long as there is continued intellectual discourse and economic intercourse between the West and China, there is greater hope for those Chinese who remain in China and who want their country to change in a liberal direction.
Since the 1989 massacre, there have been rumors and policy declarations by the Chinese of a desire to control the number and the background of Chinese allowed to study in the United States. One such policy is to give more middle-level government officials a year of study in America for being less "corruptible" and more likely to return. This strategy, however, has a very interesting dimension. Such officials, spending a year in the United States, return to China with strong, warm feelings about America and American systems, as well as enthusiastic ideas about freedom in all areas.
To cut off China's most-favored-nation status will not help Wei Jingsheng and others, but may hurt the delicate, carefully developed relationships between Chinese and Americans that have been growing since China opened its doors to the West and further remove all the Chinese from the possibility of basic human rights.
 
TERESA F. O'CONNOR
Director, Chinese American
Educational Exchange
New York, March 29, 1991

HEADLINE: Is Recovery in Sight? Don't Look at Payrolls

 BODY:
While many economists see a recovery budding in the next several months, company executives say they will wait until an expansion is in full bloom before they resume hiring.
Managers at dozens of American companies say they intend to meet increased demand with only slight increases in employment, if any. 
 At the Dana Corporation's plant in Fort Wayne, Ind., some of the assembly lines that make components for light trucks are likely to remain silent through most of the year. Since August, the company has laid off 5,000 workers, or 21 percent of its North American labor force.
 
Employment Historically Lags
 "I don't see people coming back for the next several months," said Howard Moore, Dana's vice president of corporate relations. The company's economists expect renewed demand in the fourth quarter, but Mr. Moore said that renewed hiring is only a possibility. "Some people may come back to work,"' he said. "But we expect the upturn will be slow."
Economists say that unemployment usually keeps rising even after the economy has begun expanding. Companies initially extend overtime and improve productivity to raise output.
This recovery in particular might be far kinder to employers than employees, reviving sales and profits but leaving many people jobless.
Many companies are nearly suffocating under huge debts; others are beset by efficient competitors, domestic and foreign. They have become as conservative in their employment as in their inventories, as if extending just-in-time practices to labor.
A few companies -- with hot products, healthy markets or failing competitors -- have continued hiring throughout the downturn. Several airlines, intent on grabbing market share, are expanding despite losses.
But like the wealthy who shun ostentation during tough times, even the more prosperous corporations practice austerity.
 
'The Only Lever'
 The Hewlett-Packard Company, despite recent increases in sales and earnings, has trimmed about 1,000 jobs in each of the last four quarters, leaving 91,000 employees worldwide. Blame competition for the cutbacks, said Tom Pierson, the company's manager of human resource planning.
"High-technology industry is moving to lower cost, higher volume manufacturing," he said. "It was going on to a great degree before the recession set in. Against lower profit margins, the only lever you have is cost."
Companies that hope to resume hiring want to see piles of new orders first. The Inland Steel Company, the nation's fourth-largest producer, has laid off about a tenth of its 11,000 employees. The company offers the idle little hope of returning until customers come back to the showrooms and stores. "We would need a significant increase in consumer durables -- appliances and automobiles in particular -- before we would make any increases," a spokesman said.
Cross & Trecker Inc., a maker of machine tools, cut more than 600 of about 3,600 employees last year even as the industry's orders from aerospace, auto and applicance companies strengthened. Richard Priebe, a spokesman, said the company would call workers back only when manufacturers become far more eager to upgrade their plants.
Several of the nation's largest companies say many of their payroll cuts are permanent. The General Motors Corporation plans to eliminate 15,000 of its 99,000 salaried positions in the next three years. More than 60,000 of the company's 254,000 hourly workers have been temporarily or indefinitely laid off. "We have not added new workers for a number of years, and I don't see us adding any soon," said John Maciarz, a company spokesman.
The International Business Machines Corporation -- 33,000 jobs lighter since 1986 -- plans to trim another 14,000, leaving fewer than 360,000 employees by the end of the year.
Steve Eams, I.B.M.'s spokesman on personnel matters, brags of a 45 percent increase in annual revenue per employee since 1986. He says that cutbacks in the support staff -- secretarial, bookkeeping, "or corporate spokesmen like me" -- will continue.
Few retailers see much need to rebuild their staffs. The industry's borrowing binge compounded the injuries of recession. The Southland Corporation cut its payroll by about 2,500 employees last year, to 45,665. The company, which operates the 7-Eleven stores, has ceded control to a Japanese retailer, Ito-Yokado, in a bankruptcy reorganization.
 
Growth at BankAmerica
 Southland has no immediate plans for further cuts, but its hand is clearly on the cleaver. "In retailing and convenience retailing specifically, business conditions are very, very soft," said Cecilia Stubbs Norwood, a Southland spokeswoman. "Our forecast indicates that softness will continue throughout this year and into the next."
Sears, Roebuck & Company, suffering from the loss of customers to discount chains and the slack economy, went from 500,000 to 460,000 employees last year, with plans to eliminate another 33,000 jobs this year.
Healthier companies say they can stay that way only by staying slim. After dropping 30,000 employees during the 1980's, the BankAmerica Corporation, one of the nation's more successful big banks, grew from 53,000 to 57,000 employees last year.
Most of the growth has come through acquisitions; some because experienced auditors, lawyers and real estate experts looking for jobs were simply too talented to resist. "We take advantage in some cases of the downsizing in other companies," said Robert N. Back, executive vice president, corporate human resources.
Many companies are finding that Government programs -- once a favorite economic remedy -- provide no refuge from recession. In California, aerospace and military employment is off sharply, reflecting both the recession and tighter Pentagon spending despite the gulf war.
The Hughes Aircraft Company, a G.M. subsidiary near Los Angeles, has withstood the recession well enough to keep its employment at 68,000 for the last year. But the company expects to lay off at least 1,200 workers this year, possibly as many as 3,000.
"The single biggest issue is the downturn in defense," said Ted G. Westerman, the vice president of human resources and administration. The Navy cut off Hughes's contract last year for Phoenix missiles, and the Pentagon decided to stop making F-14 fighters, which carry Hughes radar systems. Other projects have been slowed, Mr. Westerman said.
 
Some Airlines Counter Trend
 Many companies that continue to hire hope to profit from others' misfortunes, gaining market share and seasoned employees. The liquidation of Eastern Airlines and the woes of several other carriers have allowed the strongest ones to expand their fleets and buy extra routes and slots. Despite their losses, American Airlines and Delta Air Lines continue to grow.
American has grown from about 78,000 to 85,000 employees in the last year, despite a record $215 million loss in the fourth quarter. Teri Teat, the vice president for personnel resources, expects 90,000 employees by year-end, with experienced pilots and computer programmers readily available. As other airlines cut back, she said, "Their former employees come and knock on our door."
Home Depot Inc., a rapidly growing chain of discount hardware stores that added 3,500 employees, for a total of 22,000, last year, claims that a recession works to its advantage. "We're finding that people would rather do a small plumbing project themselves and save the $75 or $100 it would have cost them to call a plumber," said Barney Fogel, a company spokesman.
Housing sales slow? No problem for Home Depot, said Bernard Marcus, the company's chairman and chief executive. "This is the time people decide to add another room or make an improvement," he said.
The company has no trouble hiring sales help with lists of qualifications as long as the stores' aisles. Mr. Marcus speaks of hiring electricians with decades of experience. "We're looking for someone who's tired of the cyclical nature of new-home starts," he said, "and wants a stable, secure job."

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Will a Political Promise Bring Political Demise?

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 14

 BODY:
Like many politicians, Senator Kent Conrad made bold campaign promises when he first ran for the Senate in 1986. Like many politicians, he made promises that have not come true.
But unlike most, the North Dakota Democrat made one promise that he most certainly regrets: that he would not seek re-election if the Federal deficit was not brought under control. 
 What's worse, he left himself no wiggle room. If the Federal deficit and the trade deficit did not drop by 80 percent, he vowed at the time, he would not run again. "I'm either going to get results or get out," Mr. Conrad, who was then State Tax Commissioner, declared. "I believe it is time for politicians to stop posturing and promising, and start guaranteeing performance and results," he said at another stop.
On stump after stump he repeated the promises like mantras, seeking to make the economy the leading issue of his campaign against Senator Mark Andrews, the incumbent Republican.
While Mr. Conrad has more than a year to make good on his pledge, even the most optimistic economists would not dare predict a fiscal turnaround of such miraculous proportions. Since he first ran, not only has the budget deficit not declined, it has risen, to nearly $300 billion from an estimated $221 billion . The trade deficit did drop, but not by 80 percent, to $100 billion in 1990 from $148 billion in 1985.
The 43-year-old Mr. Conrad has not announced whether he will run next year, though his backers say he is inclined to do so, and a Republican has yet to emerge to challenge him.
But already, Mr. Conrad is feeling the heat back home. Questioned Monday by honor students at Grand Forks Central High School, the Senator conceded he is all the wiser after learning the political realities of serving in Congress.
"I made a statement on something I could not, in and of myself, deliver," he said, referring to his promise. "That is, I could not make it happen alone. No one person can make it happen alone."
For now, that is all Mr. Conrad has to say on the subject, about which he is clearly touchy. Wayne Barnett, a spokesman, said the Senator was too busy to talk about broken campaign promises. And no one from the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, which is responsible for electing Democrats to the Senate, had anything to say either.
Mr. Conrad has taken a stab at damage control: To prove that he is doing something about the nation's economic woes, he has assigned a senior aide to be a "fat finder," someone who will identify ways to eliminate waste in Federal spending.
But Mr. Conrad's predicament does elicit smirks from other politicans. Reminded of the Senator's pledge, people at the Republican National Committee could barely contain themselves.
"I'm sure that he must have qualified that in some way," said Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, the Republican whip. Told that there were no qualifications, he shook his head and said that broken campaign promises was "the kind of thing that haunts us all."
Brian Lunde, a Democratic consultant and a North Dakota native who has been a friend of Mr. Conrad for years, said he was hopeful that the state's voters would be forgiving if the Senator was open about his mistake.
"The flip side is, if he doesn't handle it right, there could be problems," Mr. Lunde said. "His re-election could become a referendum on his promise."
Gov. Lawton Chiles of Florida, a Democrat, joked that he learned after three terms in the Senate never to make pledges he could not keep.
"The lesson is that the first time you run, you know you have no conscience," said Mr. Chiles, who was back in the Capitol last week for a visit. "And I think you ought to be free to make statements that you can't fulfill."
Surveying his former colleagues as he sipped an iced tea in the senators' dining room, he remarked, "The nice thing about this place is usually you're not handicapped by those promises, you're not bound by them." But he said that he has found things different as a chief executive.
"I've learned," Mr. Chiles said, "to keep my mouth shut."

HEADLINE: Unions Threaten Strike At Freight Rail Lines

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
Leaders of eight railroad unions with more than 150,000 members who have worked without a contract for three years have threatened to cripple the nation's freight lines with a strike on Wednesday.
But the Bush Administration is trying to head off a strike, which it says would severely jolt an already weak economy. 
 Railroad executives want Congress to halt a walkout within hours, which unions said would begin against one or more rail lines at 12:01 A.M. on Wednesday. The Administration is also urging swift action by Congress to settle the dispute.
Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said lawmakers should order the railroads and the unions to adopt staffing, wage and benefit terms recommended in January by a Presidential panel. Leaders of three other rail unions with about 70,000 members agreed to similar terms in the last few days.
"Any interruption of the nation's rail service would be a disaster for the country," Mr. Skinner said Friday in Los Angeles. "It would affect every American in one way or another."
More than one-third of all goods shipped each month in the United States. or 115 million tons, travel by rail. Many industries, including automobile makers, which rely on timely supplies of parts and materials at assembly plants, could be forced to curtail production in days if rail shipments are cut off.
The Administration estimated that a two-week rail strike would cause 500,000 layoffs in industries relying on rail service. The Ford Motor Company said it would have to close some assembly plants and begin laying off workers within two days of a rail strike. The Chrysler Corporation said widespread plant closings and layoffs would occur three days after a strike began.
Some railroad executives said they expected the unions to initially limit their walkout to a single railroad that is financially weak and thus might seem more likely to accept union contract demands. But a strike against one rail line would soon affect freight shipments across the nation, said Gerald Grinstein, chief executive of Burlington Northern, the largest of the nation's approximately 15 major carriers. "We probably will have to treat a strike against one as a strike against all." he said.
Union leaders want Congress to stay out of the dispute, figuring that an extended strike would inflict heavy losses on the railroads and force them to reduce their demands. The two sides are divided over wages and benefits, but the biggest feud is over the railroads' insistance on cutting jobs and easing work rules.
"The railroads are going to be disappointed if they think Congress will panic" and force a quick settlement, said Fred T. Hardin, president of the United Transportation Union. The largest of the 11 railroad unions with 100,000 members, the transportation union has the majority the workers whose union leaders have not agreed to terms Presidential panel's recommendations.
To inhibit public pressure for a quick settlement, the unions have promised to continue working at rail lines serving commuters and other passengers. Although Conrail is involved in the contract dispute, Amtrak and commuter lines in the New York area and in other parts of the Northeast are expected to run on normal schedules.
A shutdown of the nation's freight lines would force 100,000 of the nation's commuters into other modes of travel, 75,000 of them in the Chicago area, where 45 percent of all commuter travel is by rail, the region's Metra commuter rail system says.
Commuters there are bracing for calamity. Half of Metra's commuter routes pass over freight lines owned by Burlington Northern, Chicago and Northwestern, Southshore and Norfolk Southern. Those companies have said the Metra segments cannot be operated safely if their freight operations are struck.
Chicago hotels could become crowded if a strike lasts through the week. Many commuters said they would book rooms in the city rather than struggle with crowded highways, bus and subway lines.
Amtrak officials said routes that carry half of its 60,000 daily passengers could be disrupted by a strike against the freight lines. But Amtrak owns and operates lines between Washington and Boston, and those routes, which carry 30,000 riders a day, should not be disrupted, said Renee Banks, a spokeswoman in Washington.
As the deadline neared, the National Mediation Board convened a final round of contract talks this weekend in Washington that included the 11 unions and representatives of the industry's bargaining organization, the National Railway Labor Conference. Leaders of three unions were engaged in talks around the clock, but the other five unions were not talking with the company representatives.
