HEADLINE: Showdown for Dinkins: A 'Nip and Tuck' Fiscal Drive

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
New York City's slowly unfolding fiscal drama has become a taut and immediate crisis.
In less than three months, Mayor David N. Dinkins must come up with up to $300 million in revenue and savings for the cur rent fiscal year or risk severe damage to the city's reputation and to its ability to borrow money or even the loss of control over its finances to a state oversight body, the Financial Control Board. 
 "It is nip and tuck," said Alan J. Proctor, executive director of the control board. "The crunch is now. Fundamentally, if the city is going to take any actions, it has to do it now. As time goes by, your options diminish."
For months, Dinkins administration officials have talked about slashing the city payroll, laying off workers, winning concessions from municipal unions and convincing Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to help in refinancing bonds to provide quick cash.
 
More Talk Than Action
 But that talk was mostly about its problems in the next fiscal year, which begins on July 1, when the city faces a $3 billion gap in its $29 billion budget. And little of the talk has been transferred into action, fiscal analysts say.
Thousands of layoffs were announced and then averted; negotiations with the unions stalled, and with budget-cutting efforts lagging, the Mayor asked the City Council for a one-month delay in the submitting of his budget, due on Apil 26. The Council offered Mr. Dinkins a 10-day extension.
Now, with the city battered by a worsening economy and plummeting sales-tax revenues, including a $55 million shortfall in sales-tax revenues that turned up last week, a chronic problem has turned into an immediate crisis. In a matter of days, Mayor Dinkins must find solutions to elusive problems, bring together divergent interest groups, make some excruciatingly difficult choices, or face the consequences.
"I wouldn't call it nip and tuck," said Philip R. Michael, the city's Budget Director. "But I would say that there is a real sense of urgency to it. Because of the timing I would say that it is getting somewhat hairy."
The Mayor plans to meet with labor leaders in the next few days to ask them for immediate concessions, including unpaid vacations and the deferral of some wage increases, to help the city cut costs immediately.
And mayoral aides say they have begun urgently pressing Governor Cuomo for a firm commitment to provide some of the $300 million the city needs to close its gap this year. But over the weekend the Governor reiterated his longstanding position that he would help only after the unions make concessions.
Speaking to reporters in Albany last night, the Governor said a delay in the adoption of the state budget, which was due on April 1, made it less and less likely for the state to be able to help the city, making a takeover by the Financial Control Board more likely.
"Our capacity to help the city is reduced every day by this delay," he said. "Every day New York City gets closer to control, and that is something we very much want to avoid."
With so little time remaining in the fiscal year, huge budget-cutting efforts may produce only puny savings. For example, eliminating a $60,000-a-year job on June 1, a month before the end of the fiscal year, would save only $5,000.
"We are entering a very difficult period, to say the least, because it is so late in the year," First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said yesterday. "It should be obvious we are trying to move on all fronts."
All but a few favored agencies like the Police Department have stopped hiring, said budget officials, who are also trying to halt or delay most purchasing and contracting. The officials, who recently attacked a City Council budget proposal, even asked the Council's staff for ideas on how to generate cash quickly, Council aides said.
As Mayor Dinkins struggles to find a quick solution to his immediate financial problems, he is also under pressure to build a consensus behind a broader plan to solve permanently the city's fiscal difficulties, even if the economy continues to worsen.
"I don't think there is a plan in place for '91 and '92," said City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman. "There is not a lot of time. Labor and business and elected officials have to find a common ground and move quickly."
Barry Feinstein, president of Local 237 of the teamsters' union, said the unions would not agree to any concessions until there was a comprehensive solution. "Nobody has yet done a plan that brings us from the wasteland to the promised land," he said yesterday.
In both the fiscal crisis of the 1970's and the current one the city was forced to cut spending drastically in an economic recession. But in the earlier crisis the city was shut out of the bond market and could not e find cash to pay its bills. Today, the city, while struggling to cut its budget, is still able to borrow money and meet its obligations.
 
Delay in Aid Payments
 Though the city technically has until the end of June to come up with the $300 million, the pressure to do so immediately is intense. Since Governor Cuomo and state legislative leaders have been unable to agree on a state budget, state aid payments to the city have been delayed, forcing the city to sell about $1 billion in short-term notes to pay its bills in the next few weeks.
The city is scheduled to put out an official offering statement for the notes within the next week or so, detailing, among other things, the city's financial condition, including an outline of its plan to close the $300 million gap.
Even if the city failed to come up with any plan, it would have little problem selling the notes since they are backed with specific state aid payments, not general city revenues, officials said. But the city could face higher interest costs now and greater uncertainty next month, when it is scheduled to sell long-term bonds.
If the city is unable to sell notes or bonds, or if it ends its fiscal year with a deficit of more than $100 million, the state's Financial Control Board, established during the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, could assume sweeping powers to approve city spending and contracts.
Mr. Proctor said that even if the deficit appeared to exceed $100 million, the board could not step in until the fiscal year ended on June 30. That is four months before the exact deficit will be known since he city's official accounting report is prepared in October.
While city officials would view a takeover by the control board as a humiliation, bond analysts say the presence of the control board in the governing structure has reassured bond buyers and helped stabilize the market for city bonds.
The $100 million deficit specified in the law is not a cash deficit in the city's bank accounts but is a deficit under the tougher accounting standards the city has been held to since the mid-1970's.
Under these generally accepted accounting principles, which severely limit the city's flexibility at times of crisis, the city counts all bills toward its deficit when they are incurred, not when they are paid.
Mr. Michael said that the city's newly disclosed problems did not appear to jeopardize the city's ability to meet it payrolls.
Warnings about the city's mounting fiscal problems date to the 1989 mayoral campaign and before. In the last year, the Dinkins administration has been repeatedly forced to trim spending and press for tax increases.
In January the administration presented a plan that closed a $500 million gap in the current budget and brought it back into balance.
Since then, projections of increased spending, higher debt service and tax shortfalls have created a new gap of about $450 million, according to preliminary figures compiled Friday. This is being offset by $110 million out of a $150 million reserve fund, and $60 million in surplus funds from the Board of Education, leaving the city with a gap of nearly $300 million, city officials said.
This new problem this year could complicate the city's efforts to close next year's gap. To the extent that the city postpones spending, rather than cutting it, and uses one-time revenues that it had planned to use next year, the problems could be worse.
Mr. Michael said the administration has not been given enough credit for cutting spending. He said that even though the city was able to avoid most of its layoffs, it has begun slowly to reduce its payroll through attrition. He attributed the latest problems to an unfortunate but unforeseen turn in the economy.
But Mr. Proctor and other administration critics say that in recent months the administration did not move ahead fast enough to slash spending, especially since the city committed itself to tens of millions of dollars in new purchases and contracts in March.
Felix G. Rohatyn, the financier who is chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was set up in the 1970's to sell bonds for the city, said he too was disappointed with the progress of the city. He noted that as the city moved closer to a deadline, the "problems were getting bigger instead of getting smaller."
"There is a real question about whether enough has been done to face up to the reality of the moment, which at the moment is very grim," Mr. Rohatyn said.

HEADLINE: Base Closings Pit Some Republicans Against Bush

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 14

 BODY:
Senator Arlen Specter talked to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney about military base closings on Friday and again on Saturday. And he has an appointment with President Bush's chief of staff, John H. Sununu, to talk about it some more this week.
Mr. Specter, a Pennsylvania Republican who is working to keep the Philadelphia Naval Station and the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard open, is one of a number of Republican lawmakers normally loyal to President Bush who feel they must now fight the Administration. 
 "It looks like the Department of Defense is declaring war on Pennsylvania," Mr. Specter said at a news conference on Friday after learning that his state stands to lose nearly 13,000 military and civilian jobs at the two Philadelphia sites and two other installations.
On Friday, Secretary Cheney formally announced his recommendations on 71 military installations, including plans to close 32 major and 12 minor installations and scale back 28 others by 1997.
 
Republicans Up in Arms
 Unlike last year's base-closing plan, which was rejected out of hand largely because of stiff Democratic opposition, Mr. Cheney's new proposal has stirred up Republicans and Democrats alike.
Senator Specter is not alone among concerned Republicans. Senator Richard G. Lugar traveled home to Indiana to visit Grissom Air Force Base, which is scheduled to close with the loss of 3,200 military and civilian workers. He has sent a letter to the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission, which will review the Pentagon plan, asking it to check for possible errors in the evaluation.
And Senator Connie Mack, Republican of Florida, cited the American success in the Persian Gulf war and has vowed to fight "to maintain Florida's fair share of defense jobs." Florida will lose the Naval Training Center in Orlando, costing the state 17,000 military and civilian jobs.
Such strong opposition to the proposal from Republicans, combined with the scorn of Democrats like Senators Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and John B. Breaux of Louisiana has put Mr. Cheney's plan in a vulnerable position as it goes to the commission for consideration Monday.
The Pentagon proposal has also set the stage for a conflict of politics and principle as lawmakers wrestle with the consequences of their votes that will reduce the Pentagon budget to its lowest share of Federal spending since 1939, down from 27 percent of the Federal budget during the Reagan Administration to 18 percent by 1995.
 
Grim Outlook for Philadelphia
 For Philadelphia, a Pentagon estimate offers even more grim figures than those found in the number of jobs directly affected. When indirect employment associated with the shipyard is factored in, more than 47,000 jobs would be affected by the Philadelphia shutdown, resulting in a 2.1 percent increase in unemployment in the metropolitan area.
"I don't think these installations should be kept open as a matter of local economy," Mr. Specter said in an interview. "The central issue is national defense. I don't think there's any way you can close it and maintain readiness."
Last year Secretary Cheney was criticized for submitting a proposal in which more than 90 percent of the bases targeted for closing would have been in Democratic Congressional districts. The House Armed Services Committee determined that this year 60 percent of the large bases recommended for closing are in Democratic districts and 37 percent were in Republican districts. Democrats hold 267 of the 435 seats in the House. or 61 percent.
Mr. Cheney, appearing today on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," predicted Congress would not reject his plan. "I think the process that we set up last fall when we agreed to a commission, a bipartisan commission, which has now been appointed by the President and confirmed by the Senate, removes any taint of partisanship," he said. "Nobody can accuse us of having made decisions based on political circumstances."
 
A Safe Seat Now at Risk
 It is an interesting problem for Mr. Cheney, a former Republican member of the House of Representatives who has enjoyed uncommonly good relations with his former colleagues until now. But as the Presidential and Congressional election cycles begin, the base-closing problem is as troublesome for Republicans who had hoped to gain from having supported the use of force in the gulf as for Democrats who opposed using the armed forces.
Partisanship has already intruded. The situation is Pennsylvania is more complicated than most because of the death of Senator John Heinz in an plane crash on April 4 left the state's Republicans looking for a way to hold on to what had been considered a safe seat.
"The message was delivered to the White House that it would be very hard for a Republican candidate to campaign in this state when the largest city just had the President and the Secretary of Defense close down one of its biggest employers," said an aide to one member of the Pennsylvania delegation who would speak only if not identified.
Several of the members of Congress who represent affected districts and states rushed home to blunt the bad news on Friday when the Pentagon released its list. Many more hunkered down in Washington, drafting letters of appeal to the commission.
"We knew we were going to be on the list," said an aide to Representative James H. Saxton, a New Jersey Republican whose district includes Fort Dix. Mr. Cheney has recommended closing Fort Dix except for some National Guard operations. "We never imagined the cut would be that deep," Mr. Saxton said.
Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, said politics should not play a role in the commission's decision. But he pointed out that he was a member of the Appropriations Committee's defense subcommittee.

HEADLINE: Stocks Higher in Tokyo

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, April 15

 BODY:
Stock prices rose today in Tokyo. The Nikkei index of 225 issues finished up 113.03 points, or less than 1 percent, to 26,695.53. At midday, the Nikkei was stronger, at 26,864.09, up 281.59 points. On Friday, the index fell 48.53 points, to 26,268.86. Trading today was dominated by a stronger yen and hopes that interest rates would soon be lowered, traders said, because of Friday's drop of one-tenth of a percent in the United States Consumer Price Index for March.

HEADLINE: Chicago's Cultural Life Bucks Downward Trend

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 14

 BODY:
This burly city of big shoulders and grand ambitions is experiencing what few other American cities could imagine in these days of recession and belt-tightening. Its cultural institutions are expanding in size and audience at a time when those in some other cities are trying to stay in business.
In what many consider a coming of age of the arts in Chicago, the burst of activity was set off tonight at the Steppenwolf Theater, whose Broadway production of "The Grapes of Wrath" won the 1990 Tony Award for best play. The company, whose gritty, rough-hewn interpretations have come to characterize a Chicago style of theater, has become a hatchery for talents like John Malkovich and Glenne Headly. It firmly planted itself in Chicago tonight when it opened its new 500-seat theater with the American premiere of Ronald Harwood's "Another Time," with Albert Finney. 
 Just south of the Loop, the city is nearing completion of a new central library, the Harold Washington Library, a neo-classical palace of brick and granite and gargoyles, designed by Thomas Beeby, that with its 760,000 square feet will be the largest public library in the world.
The Museum of Contemporary Art, whose cramped quarters have caused it to exclude major works from touring exhibitions or to forego some exhibitions altogether, is to announce late next month the winner of a worldwide search for an architect to design its new museum overlooking Lake Michigan.
 
'A Center That's Throbbing'
 "Very few cities in the world have had this kind of regeneration in the arts without preparing for the Olympics or a World's Fair," said Anthony Jones, the president of the School of the Art Institute of Chicago, which recently bought a new building in the Loop to accommodate a rapidly growing enrollment. "It shows an astonishing amount of confidence in this city. It's still a nuclear city; it's still got a core, a center that's throbbing all the time."
Aside from the major new buildings emerging on the Chicago landscape, cultural institutions from the Lyric Opera to the city's regional theaters are experiencing record growth, according a study released last month by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, whose yearly $5 million contribution to the arts is confined almost exclusively to Chicago.
"The strength of the organizations is they deliver the goods," said Nicholas Rabkin, the senior program officer for the MacArthur Foundation. "There has been growth in the size of the audience, growth in the number of cultural organizations and financial growth in organizations at all levels and sizes and disciplines, which is not to say, however, that arts organizations here are financially secure or can be free spenders."
The expansion, many in the arts here say, is long overdue in a city of this size and importance and reflects a cultural maturing in Chicago.
 
Prosperity Flanked by Recession
 While there is no single reason for the explosion of activity and certainly no single financial source, the city's cultural institutions have had several things going for them.
For one, Chicago has not been devastated by the severe recession on the East and West Coasts and has not been forced to make the painful cuts that many other cities have. For another, Chicago's large number of established and widely known institutions have been able to attract a steady stream of donations from companies and individual patrons to finance growth borne of their enormous popularity.
The Museum of Contemporary Art, for example, raised $37 million from its trustees alone for a new 125,000-square-foot home before even naming an architect.
The museum typifies the growing pains of many of Chicago's cultural institutions. While its attendance has increased 42 percent over the last two years, to 144,138 from 102,149, it operates out of a 33,000-square-foot building that is so crowded the museum has never been able to show its permanent collection adequately. And, as often happens, during a recent touring exhibition of Japanese sculpture, the museum had to eliminate some large wooden and stone pieces that could not get through its doors.
All of this is expected to change in 1995 when the museum's new building is to be completed on a two-acre lot, now occupied by the Illinois National Guard, that was essentially given to the museum by former Gov. James Thompson.
 
A Suitable House for Art
 Museum officials have been traveling from Osaka to Stuttgart looking at the work of the architects competing to build the new museum. The list of finalists is an unusually strong one with several international firms represented, but no local ones. Among the finalists are Morphosis, a Los Angeles firm, Tadao Ando and Fumihiko Maki, both of Japan, and Emilio Ambasz of New York.
"We don't want anything that intimidates, is trendy or dates easily," said Maureen King, a spokeswoman for the Museum of Contemporary Art. "We want something timeless without being classical, a container that is a work of art itself."
Part of the reason that Chicago's cultural organizations have fared so well, many say, is that they have not tried to be New York or Los Angeles and have accurately read their audiences.
"Chicago is a major metropolis but it is far enough from the spotlight that we can just address the work," said Randall Arney, the artistic director at Steppenwolf. "Actors and artists are away from the glare of the media spotlight that can kill a company in the beginning. You can make your mistakes in the dark."
 
The Growth of Steppenwolf
 It was in this environment that Steppenwolf grew from a tiny company operating out of a suburban church basement to a North Side establishment working out of a converted dairy to its present home, a raw, industrial theater of cinder block and exposed pipes that is all gray, black and white and as unpretentious as the city that spawned the company.
During its 15 years, the company and many of its members inspired a new generation of theaters in Chicago and successfully transplanted so much of its work to New York that many in Chicago feared they would lose the company. Now, with a new theater, there appears less cause for Chicagoans to worry, and the company can do what it has always wanted.
It can produce a wider selection of works and can present plays with more than one set and do all of this with the latest technology. Now it can do "Death of a Salesman," for instance, without putting Willy Loman in a ranch-style house instead of a two-story Brooklyn frame.
"Half the theater literature was unavailable to us," said Bruce Sagan, the president of the troupe. "Now we have put a Broadway stage in a 500-seat theater."
The real development in Chicago theater has occurred in only the last two decades. In the 1970's, it was basically limited to the downtown touring houses dominated by shows that had originated elsewhere, mainly meaning in New York. Now there are about 130 theaters in Chicago, from the Auditorium Theater where "Les Miserables" is playing to the dozens of small, experimental theaters that stand next to trendy cafes and lofts on the city's North Side.
"To say that Chicago theater is rough and tumble is a bit of a cliche, but there is some truth to it," said Robert Falls, the artistic director of the 683-seat Goodman Theater, which last fall presented an acclaimed production of "The Iceman Cometh," with Brian Dennehy, and is currently looking for a larger space. "There is a lack of pretentiousness to the work. It's not a theater of fancy sets, lights and costumes. There is very little avant-garde theater there. It is more direct, straight. It is emotionally accessible, openly physical and not particularly cerebral."
 
Theater as Direct as the City
 Despite the strength of the larger, established institutions, there have been casualties in the Chicago art world. City Musick, a chamber orchestra specializing in 18th-century music, and MoMing, a contemporary dance company, folded last year after financial and leadership crises. And while attendance and earnings are up for those that remain, the arts in general are facing a possible 10 percent cut in state financing in the coming year, said Alene Valkanas, the executive director of the Illinois Arts Alliance.
"People are doing well but doing well with great difficulty," said Ms. Valkanas. "What we have is an arts and cultural scene that shows signs of enormous vitality and diversity and at same time real jeopardy and threat."
Not at Orchestra Hall, though. There, the Symphony is celebrating its 100th season with the highest rate of ticket sales in its history, 102 percent, owing to the tickets turned in and then resold by the orchestra.
Asked about the orchestra's wish list, Henry Fogel, the orchestra's executive director, said, "There is nothing that we need that we don't have."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Ammirati Is Finding Its Grip On Club Med Is Loosening

BYLINE: By Kim Foltz

 BODY:
AMMIRATI & PURIS may soon lose the Club Med resorts business, a small but important account that helped establish its reputation as a New York agency that specialized in stylish, often glamorous, advertising.
Michael Cubin, the president of Club Med's North American operations, said Friday that the company would begin talking to agencies about new approaches for the account, which has billings of $5 million to $10 million. 
 Industry executives said the loss of Club Med would be significant because the resort company, along with BMW and United Parcel Service, has been viewed as integral to Ammirati. These high-profile accounts have undoubtedly been instrumental in helping Ammirati attract many clients, executives said.
The loss would not be a big financial blow for Ammirati. The agency has billings of about $230 million.
Mr. Cubin said Club Med had not been unhappy with Ammirati. "I can't say enough good things about them," he said. The problem, Mr. Cubin said, is Club Med wanted to see new work and Ammirati insisted on sticking with the current campaign that emphasizes the variety of activities the resorts offer.
As a result, Martin Puris, the president and chief executive of Ammirati, said the agency would not actively participate in the review. In a statement, Mr. Puris said, "We are proud of our work for Club Med." Instead of creating a speculative campaign, he said the agency would let its work stand as a "benchmark against which other agencies' work is evaluated."
Club Med and Ammirati did not see eye-to-eye before. In 1985 the two disagreed on what direction the advertising should take, and Club Med abandoned Ammirati for the Ayer agency. Unable to get what it wanted elsewhere, Club Med returned to Ammirati two years later.
This time around, Mr. Cubin said the agency and Club Med had agreed on the basic marketing strategy. Club Med has been trying to move away from its earlier image as a resort chain that catered to the swinging singles crowd.
New advertising from Ammirati during the last several years has portrayed Club Med as something more than just a romantic supermarket. The ads show the resorts as places where people can pursue a far wider variety of interests. One commercial tells travelers they can come to Club Med for the sports, for the fine food, or just to lie in the sun in a hammock.
But some agency excutives said Club Med's management in the United States has been under pressure from its French parent, Club Mediterranee, to begin a more aggressive campaign aimed at quickly pumping up sales. Hurt by both the recession and the Persian Gulf crisis, Club Med's business has been in a slump.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 16, 1991, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday referred incorrectly to the president of Club Med's North American operations. He is Michael Kubin.

HEADLINE: New Drug Chief Turns To Softer Side of Issue

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
When Bob Martinez, the new chief of national drug policy, was Governor of Florida, he developed a reputation as a leader whose solution to the drug problem was to build more prisons and execute the worst offenders.
But in two weeks as Director of the Office of National Drug Policy, he has been talking mainly about the softer aspects of the problem -- treatment of addicts and the prevention of drug abuse through education. 
 In an interview this week in his office near the White House, Mr. Martinez said he had "a tremendous amount of interest in education and prevention" and wanted to "open up a very good dialogue with the treatment providers so that we can work together."
President Bush, at the drug chief's swearing-in ceremony on March 28, said that Mr. Martinez "understands that we cannot defeat drugs through law enforcement alone" and that "any long-term solution also depends on successful education and treatment."
 
Emphasis Still on Winning
 But Mr. Martinez said that in his meetings with Mr. Bush about the drug post there had been no discussion about changing emphasis in the national policy or presenting a different image. "It wasn't a question of priorities," he said. "It was of winning."
The director said he was not recommending an increase in Federal spending for treatment and education, adding that he did not wish to "in any way minimize" the importance of law enforcement.
"It's pretty hard to get the message to a youngster in a school house, despite whatever prevention and education programs exist," Mr. Martinez said, "if when the school bell rings he sees a pusher standing on the corner, which clearly indicates that society must not think it's all that bad."
The most persistent criticism of the Bush Administration's drug policy from experts in the field and some members of Congress has been its emphasis on law enforcement. Mr. Martinez's predecessor, William J. Bennett, disparaged drug treatment programs as "touchy-feely" exercises.
The National Association of State Alcohol and Drug Abuse Directors estimates there are 6 million to 10 million serious drug abusers and says only 15 percent to 20 percent are receiving treatment.
Mr. Martinez said he fully supports the $11.6 billion anti-drug budget for the coming fiscal year, now before Congress. It was prepared by Mr. Bennett and continues an Administration pattern of allocating about 70 percent for police and military operations and the rest for treatment and education.
The proposed budget represents an increase of 11 percent over the previous year and includes a request for $100 million to expand treatment centers. But the expansion requires matching money from the states, many of which are in financial crisis.
In the interview, Mr. Martinez said he had always been concerned about treatment and drug education and professed dismay that only his tough tactics had left an impression. "I visited more cocaine babies as Governor than I can count on all my toes and fingers," he said.
 
Close Ties to Bush Family
 Mr. Martinez, a 56-year-old Republican, was defeated last fall in a bid for a second term as Governor. Both Mr. Bush and his wife campaigned for him and one of the Bushes' sons, Jeb, held the largely symoblic post of campaign chairman after serving as Mr. Martinez's Secretary of Commmerce.
In his confirmation hearings, senators questioned Mr. Martinez's qualifications and Senator Eward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said the nominee's drug strategy in Florida was "characterized by the same imbalance that mars the national drug plan."
Representative Charles B. Rangel, the Manhattan Democrat who heads the House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control, said in an interview this week: "It doesn't matter who he was or what he didn't do as Governor. We have to look forward to what he wants to do and what he can do."
Mr. Bennett quit the drug post to become head of the Republican National Committee. But he then decided not to take the party job because it would have meant giving up income from speeches and writing.
Mr. Bennett, a former Secretary of Education, drew attention to drug issues with a flamboyant and combative style.
Friends of Mr. Martinez, a tall, lean jogger and one-time semipro baseball player, say he prefers to work quietly and is unlikely to get into public disputes.
Describing himself as "an implementer," a person who "likes to operate, to execute and to monitor what is to be done," Mr. Martinez said he hopes to bring order to a field in which there is little reliable data and only broad accountability, aiming to get more out of existing money.
Mr. Martinez said he plans to press Congress for enactment of pending legislation requiring every state to develop a comprehensive drug treatment program and to explore the possibility of sending drug addicts who are poor to private drug treatment centers, which often have vacancies, at a preferential rate to be paid by government.
Hours after being sworn in, Mr. Martinez flew to Salt Lake City to address a conference of state drug treatment officials. William Butynski, the executive director of the group, the National Association of State Alcohol and Drug Abuse Directors, said Mr. Martinez's appearance diminished concern "that he might be oriented only to enforcement."
Last weekend Mr. Martinez told a group of national fraternity and sorority officials he thought mandatory drug testing of college students, as suggested by Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, a Democrat, was unnecessary.
"He clearly declined an opportunity to try to trump a Democratic political leader, to be tougher," said Eric E. Sterling, the coordinator of the National Drug Strategy Network, which regards treatment and education as the most important elements of the anti-drug effort. "This was an improvement over Bennett."

HEADLINE: Careers;
M.B.A. Study Is Urged for Some Jobless

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
THE Simon Graduate School of Business Administration at the University of Rochester has some advice for young middle managers who have lost their jobs, and for a few seniors graduating without job commitments: Think about getting a master's degree in business administration. And they can start a program at some schools in January if they are too late for the September term.
Along with at least two other graduate business schools among the top 20, Rochester accepts students into its M.B.A. program in January as well as in September. The business schools at New York University and Columbia University also allow students to enter at midyear. 
 This means that displaced middle managers or some college graduates who find themselves jobless this spring could take the required Graduate Management Admissions Test as late as October and still be accepted for the January term.
Without some pertinent work experience, however, graduating seniors may find the application process frustrating. Leading business schools like Harvard and Stanford have long refused to accept graduates right out of college unless they had work experience. This policy, widely adopted during the last decade by admissions directors at other leading schools, has meant that students in M.B.A. programs tend to be older than the typical recent graduate.
"We don't admit many right from undergraduate school," said Debra Felix, director of admissions at Columbia's business school.
Recent graduates are admitted if they can show good summer or other work experience and campus leadership qualities. This might include a successful entrepreneurial venture started on campus, for example.
Partly because of the recession, business schools are finding plenty of good applicants.
"We have been seeing an older crowd in January than in September," Ms. Felix said. "They tend to be more experienced." Last fall she began to notice "applicants who had lost jobs and said to themselves 'now is a good time to go back for an M.B.A.' "
She said applicants might have a better chance of getting into a good graduate business school in the January term, because competition is less stiff. At Columbia this year, 131 students entered in January; 493 entered last September.
The Stern School of Business at New York University also tends to accept applicants with experience. "We look for three and a half years of work experience," said Janet R. Marks, associate dean for M.B.A. education. "It would be possible but unusual for a few seniors to gain admission."
Dr. Marks encouraged unemployed middle managers to consider the option of N.Y.U.'s Accelerated M.B.A. Program, which begins in January and can be completed at the same time as the September program. "It is a great opportunity for people who have lost jobs or want a career change," she sad. "I think it is a good way to wait out the recession and use time productively." The Graduate Management Admissions Test can be taken as late as Oct. 15.
In January 1991 the Stern School had 63 full-time and 238 part-time students.
Foreign students are also being drawn to midyear entry programs in American business schools. At Columbia there has been a slight increase, to 24 percent from 22 percent, in foreign students who entered in January.
Most foreign students at Rochester receive government, corporate or other financial support, and a shorter time on campus in this country saves sponsors money, not just in tuition but in living expenses and time away from jobs as well.
"The idea of completing an M.B.A. program in 18 months instead of 22 attracts students from abroad," said Priscilla E. Gumina, assistant dean for M.B.A. programs at the Simon school in Rochester.
In a typical two-year M.B.A. program, students spend the summer between the first and second year as interns working for corporations or government. That means the January entrants can catch up with their counterparts who begin in the fall by opting to study through the summer. Midyear students take the same required courses as those entering in the fall.
At Rochester, 50 students entered in January, compared with 35 last year and 20 in 1989, the first year it permitted midyear entry. New York University and Columbia have had January entry programs for years.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
Bois Cascade Reports Loss

DATELINE: BOISE, Idaho, April 15 (AP)

 BODY:
The Boise Cascade Corporation said today that rising expenses and weak demand for its paper and wood products caused a $16.85 million loss in the first quarter of 1991.
The loss was in contrast to a profit of $33.57 million, or 79 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter last year. Sales amounted to $992.73 million, compared with $1.066 billion a year earlier. 
 The quarterly loss was the first in more than six years and officials said financial problems could persist if market conditions did not improve.
The company cited the weak economy, excess production capacity that created the poor market for paper, deterioration of the wood products market reflecting rising log and wood chip prices, and higher interest rates and depreciation expenses because of a $2 billion plant modernization campaign.
The company laid off workers this year in a cost-cutting campaign and has consolidated two paper divisions, reduced administrative budgets and cut expected capital expenditures from $824 million last year to $300 million in 1991.
The stock rose 37.5 cents a share on the New York Stock Exchange today, to $25.625.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Amid Worries About Interest Rates in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against other leading currencies yesterday amid concerns about United States interest rates.
Gold prices edged higher, with the April contract gaining 30 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York to close at $361.60 an ounce. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $360.30, up 80 cents. 
 The dollar fell after the Federal Reserve took steps to drain cash from the banking system, leaving less money available for banks and pushing the cost of borrowing higher. The markets interpreted the move as a signal that the Fed was not altering its monetary policy or pushing interest rates lower.
Ordinarily, the prospect of stable or higher rates is a signal for traders to buy the dollar, since it, like other currencies, is supported by higher yields.
"It's somewhat surprising that the dollar didn't react more," said Mike Faust, a currency market analyst with MMS International in Chicago.
 
Fed Action Still Expected
 Some traders still expect the Fed to take some action relatively soon to relax its monetary policy and allow interest rates to fall.
That theory was bolstered by sales figures released by the big American auto makers showing that demand for new cars and trucks remained weak in the first 10 days of April. The numbers were seen as proof of continuing economic weakness that could force the Fed to push rates lower to stimulate business.
Comments by a German official, indicating that rates in that country will remain firm, helped the mark at the dollar's expense, Mr. Faust said.
The official, Hans Tietmeyer, a member of the policy-making directorate of Germany's central bank, said a stable mark would be achieved by "continued relatively high interest rates."
The dollar fell more than a pfennig against the mark. In New York, it slumped to 1.6710 marks, from 1.6880 late Friday, and in earlier European trading, the dollar closed at 1.6755 marks, down from 1.6855.
The dollar also fell against the Japanese yen, closing at 134.25 yen in New York, down from 136.40 late Friday. Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar fell to a close of 135.22 yen, from 135.85 on Friday, and it was quoted later in London at 134.48.
The British pound rose against the dollar. In New York, the pound advanced to $1.7910 from $1.7725 late Friday. Earlier, in London, the pound rose to $1.7920, from $1.7775.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with the late Friday rates, included: 1.4185 Swiss francs, down from 1.4320; 5.6385 French francs, down from 5.7020; 1,237.25 Italian lire, down from 1,252.25, and 1.14815 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15085.
Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $360.50 an ounce, from $361.25 late Friday. In Zurich, gold closed at a bid of $361.20, unchanged from late Friday. In Hong Kong, gold fell $1.19 an ounce, to close at $361.99.
Silver picked up four-tenths of a cent to close at $3.981 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange. In London, silver fell to a late bid price of $3.98 an ounce, down from $4 late Friday.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 12.38, to 2,933.17, on a Volatile Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks turned volatile yesterday as traders tried to figure out whether the Federal Reserve would bring interest rates down to revive the economy. Weakness in I.B.M. stock was a strong factor in keeping the market from moving higher.
Many concluded that the Fed would do nothing for now because it might feel the economy would improve on its own. And long-term bond prices moved up a bit, carrying stock prices slightly higher. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average, which jumped 18 points early in the day and then quickly sank 30, closed at 2,933.17, ahead 12.38.
 
Other Indexes Inch Up
 Other market indexes continued to inch ahead to new highs:
*The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose to 381.19, up 0.79.
*The New York Stock Exchange composite rose to 208.59, up 0.51.
*The American Stock Exchange market-value index rose to 366.87, up 0.24.
The Nasdaq composite fell less than a point, but strength in the Amex and in the Nasdaq, despite the drop, showed that investors were still pouring money into small stocks.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange slid to 161.8 million shares, from a solid 198.6 million on Friday.
Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, said that heavy computerized selling early in the day lopped 15 points off the Dow.
Explaining the Fed's current stance, H. Erich Heinemann, chief economist at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company in New York, said: "The Fed is reluctant to see short-term rates come down at present, partly because it sees growth in the money supply and doesn't want to see it grow too rapidly. Fed economists appear to believe the economy is bottoming and will soon moveupward."
Dennis E. Jarrett, chief market analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Company, said he was "not sure the Fed is a strong factor right now."
He argued that "strong program trading on a light-volume day" was a leading factor yesterday and that the big question on interest rates was not whether but when the Fed would bring them down.
Mr. Heinemann argued that the nation faced "four to six months more of recession"; that in that context rates would "continue to come down substantially, if not today," and that the money supply would continue to grow.
On the strength of increasing signs that inflation is now weak, traders bid up stock prices early in the day in expectation that the Fed would trim rates. But at 10:35 A.M., or an hour before the Fed typically moves in, it drained money from the banking system in what traders took to be a clear signal that the Fed would not ease. The Dow dropped instantly, trading erratically for the rest of the day.
Six minutes after the Fed's action, a seven-minute flurry of program selling toppled the Dow 11 points.
 
Advice to Salespeople
 In a conference call with Kidder, Peabody salespeople yesterday, Mr. Jarrett said: "This is a stock-pickers' environment, but crosscurrents in the marketplace are very mixed. Some of the averages reached new, all-time highs while others, like the Dow industrials and the transportation index, are lagging."
I.B.M., the second-most-active Big Board stock, on volume of three million shares, fell 1 5/8, to 106 7/8, after Daniel Mandresh, a computer analyst at Merrill Lynch, cut his earnings estimate.

HEADLINE: Brady Calls for Lower Rates To Stimulate World Growth

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, April 15

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that the top economic priority for the industrialized world should be to lower interest rates.
He stressed that lower rates were vital to stimulate economic growth and generate the extraordinary amount of capital needed in Eastern Europe, the Soviet Union, the war-ravaged Middle East and Latin America. 
 As he met with finance ministers of the six other leading industrialized nations -- Germany, Britain, France, Italy, Canada and Japan -- and attended the opening ceremony for the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, Mr. Brady expressed concern about sluggish economic growth in the developed world.
 
Lag in Europe and Japan
 While there were signs that the United States was emerging from its recession, he said, Western Europe had been slowing and Japan, though still buoyant, appeared to have lost some of its vigor.
Some of his remarks appeared to be aimed at Germany, where concerns about the inflationary pressures of unification have led the Bundesbank, the German central bank, to keep interest rates high, forcing other countries to also keep rates up.
Mr. Brady said too much emphasis was being put on lowering inflation and not enough on cutting interest rates and stimulating economic growth to generate the tremendous amount of capital needed throughout the world. There are fears in European financial markets that the Bundesbank may soon raise interest rates.
 
Obsession With Inflation
 A senior Treasury official who gave a background briefing to reporters today said Mr. Brady had told his counterparts on Sunday night that he believed some were overly obsessed with lowering inflation.
The Treasury official said everyone at the meeting agreed on problems of a potential worldwide capital shortage. While there was no conclusion reached at the session on how to deal with it, the official said, the finance ministers agreed to focus on it at their formal meeting in Washington later this month.
The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which formally opened its doors today, is a multilateral financial institution founded to help rebuild Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union and to promote market economies and democracy in the region. Jacques Attali, the bank's president, has estimated that Eastern Europe will require as much as $3 trillion in investment over the next 20 years.
Thirty-nine countries and two European Community organizations have pledged to provide the bank with a total of about $12.3 billion in capital. The United States has agreed to provide $1.2 billion, making it the single biggest donor.

HEADLINE: EUROPEAN NATIONS TO LIFT SANCTIONS ON SOUTH AFRICA

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, April 15

 BODY:
Ignoring appeals from the African National Congress, the 12-nation European Community agreed today to lift its remaining economic sanctions against South Africa in response to the Pretoria Government's continuing moves to dismantle apartheid.
Meeting in Luxembourg, community foreign ministers said the move would result in ending a five-year-old ban on imports of gold coins, iron and steel from South Africa. Last December, the ministers revoked a prohibition against new investments in South Africa. 
 Although the nations of the community are still bound by the United Nations embargo on arms sales to South Africa, today's action marks a new step toward South Africa's reincorporation into the world economy. In 1985, the year before European sanctions were adopted, South Africa exported some $700 million worth of gold coins, iron and steel to community countries.
 
U.S. Conditions on Sanctions
 In Washington, a State Department official said the South African Government must still fulfill two conditions -- freeing all political prisoners and repealing laws that classify people by race -- before American sanctions can be lifted under the measure by which Congress applied them.
Washington's sanctions are wider than the European Community's. In addition to prohibiting import of South African gold coins, iron, steel and agricultural products, they ban the export to South Africa of crude oil, petroleum products, munitions and computers and computer services to security services. And the United States continues to ban new investment in South Africa.
The European Community's decision today was signaled last February when community officials told Pretoria that remaining sanctions would be lifted as soon as South Africa proposed legislation to repeal important apartheid laws. The South African Parliament is expected to approve this legislation in July.
 
Opposition to Move
 Last week, however, the Secretary General of the African National Congress, Alfred Nzo, urged the European Community to maintain its sanctions, arguing that the apartheid system was still in place. Many members of the European Parliament also spoke out against today's community move.
But the community foreign ministers were reportedly unanimous today in supporting the lifting of sanctions and in denying the European Parliament an opportunity to debate the issue. Community officials said the ministers argued that they had exclusive authority to decide about the sanctions.
A European Community official in Washington said it was likely it would take several months to re-establish trade lines cut off since the mid-1980s.
The official said there would be a good market for South African gold, in Europe and business could easily reach the pre-sanctions levels, but for iron and steel the outlook was less promising.
There have been major changes in the structure of the European industry, the official noted, with less need today for types of steel supplied by South Africa.
"They must have lost their traditional trade lines, and I can't imagine there would be an immediate pickup," she said.
At the meeting today in Luxembourg, which currently holds the rotating presidency of the community, foreign ministers also agreed to press for a war crimes trial for President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, accusing him of aggression against Kuwait, using chemical weapons against civilians and condoning genocide against the Kurds.
European officials said that, after Germany's Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, made the proposal, it was agreed that Luxembourg's Foreign Minister, Jacques Poos, would raise the issue with the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, when they meet Tuesday.
The officials said Mr. Genscher had not clarified in what court and under what international conventions that Mr. Hussein should be tried, but they recalled that, in the months leading up to the gulf war, the community repeatedly warned the Iraqi leader that he would be charged with war crimes.
Eager to play a diplomatic role in the wake of the gulf war, community foreign ministers are also to meet the Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in Luxembourg Wednesday to coordinate their policies towards the Middle East in general and the Kurdish refugee crisis in particular.
Much of today's meeting in Luxembourg, though, was given over to discussion of the community's broader moves towards closer integration, above all plans to draw up common foreign and security policies that would enable it to play a more active role in future crises than it did in the gulf war.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
De Klerk Welcomes Move
 JOHANNESBURG, April 15 (Special to The New York Times) -- President F. W. de Klerk tonight welcomed the European Community's decision to lift economic sanctions against South Africa, calling the latest move "positive and most encouraging."
In a statement, Mr. de Klerk thanked the European governments for standing by commitments to lift the sanctions.
"It is another important step for South Africa and all its people towards improved economic conditions and normal international relations," Mr. de Klerk said.
Mr. de Klerk said he would refer to the issue in greater detail when he visits Western Europe later this month.
The African National Congress, which has repeatedly opposed any lifting of sanctions without its approval, expressed concern that the decision could make the white minority Government more intransigent.
Saki Macozoma, a spokesman for the congress, said that Mr. de Klerk "knows what is needed in this country and does not need rewards to do it."
Mr. Macozoma said Alfred Nzo, the congress's secretary general, and Thabo Mbeki, its international affairs secretary, had gone to Brussels last week in an effort to dissuade the European Community from its decision.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.S. Response to Move
 WASHINGTON, April 15 (Special to The New York Times) -- A State Department official said today that South Africa, to win an end to American sanctions, still needs to comply with two conditions of the original five set by Congress in imposing the curbs.
Pretoria has complied with three of five conditions set by Congress: repealing state-of-emergency regulations, legalizing once-banned opposition political parties and entering negotiations with representative political groups.
The law imposing the sanctions also mandates that all political prisoners -- there are between 300 and 1,200 -- must be released. In talks with the African National Congress last fall, the Government promised all would be freed by April 30.
Under the law, President Bush may consider modifying the sanctions once the political prisoners have been released. He has committed himself to consulting with Congress before he does that, the State Department official said.
Congress also demanded that Pretoria repeal the Groups Areas Act and the Population Registration Act, laws that classify people by race and limiting blacks' access to land ownership. The Government has introduced legislation to repeal these laws during the current parliamentary session.

HEADLINE: Baker Is Returning to Middle East To Push Arab-Israeli Peace Talks

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 15

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d will head back to the Middle East on Tuesday for the second time in two weeks, seeking to overcome remaining obstacles to an Arab-Israeli peace conference, Administration officials said today.
Mr. Baker completed his last trip through the region on Friday, having found broad support for some kind of peace conference that would include Israeli, Arab and Palestinian representatives, but still unable to reach a final agreement on the framework and agenda for such a meeting. 
 Administration officials say the main reason Mr. Baker is returning to the region so soon is because he believes that he is making some headway and is convinced that unless he makes a major effort to reach a final agreement right now all of the parties will drift away or fall prey to domestic infighting.
Mr. Baker will first travel to Luxembourg, where he will consult with European Community officials about Kurdish refugees fleeing the Iraqi Army into Turkey and Iran. The officials will try to come up with a consistent position on how the United Nations and International Red Cross can extend humanitarian aid inside Iraq and to better coordinate and finance relief efforts for refugee camps. Mr. Baker is also likely to discuss with them a European Community decision made Monday to seek to bring President Saddam Hussein to trial as a war criminal.
 
Visit to Jordan Is Likely
 From Luxembourg, he is scheduled to fly to Israel, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Syria, and almost certainly Jordan. The stop in Jordan, which is expected by American officials, would be particularly noteworthy since it would represent at least a partial reconciliation between the two countries. The Administration resented King Hussein's public support for Iraq during the Persian Gulf war, and threatened to cut economic aid.
Administration officials noted that no country wanted to be held responsible for a breakdown of any peace initiative but that each had differing perspectives of how the meeting should procede and what its goals should be.
Israel continues to refuse to consider a trade of land for peace. Meanwhile, a number of Arab countries say they will attend only as long as its goals are based on United Nations Resolutions 242 and 338, which call on Israel to return Jordanian and Syrian lands it has occupied since the 1967 Arab-Israeli war.
Among other issues that remain unsettled are what if any connection Palestinian representatives would have to the Palestine Liberation Organization, where the conference would take place and whether the Soviet Union would attend. Mr. Baker would like the Soviet Union to be a co-host of the conference to build confidence among the Arab countries and shield them from criticism from radicals who would say they are betraying their ideals by directly negotiating with Israel.
"The Arab countries have been timid about sudden initiatives and the longer something draws out, the more hardened their positions become," said a State Department official monitoring the peace process.
 
'Much Work to Be Done'
 Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said the decision to send Mr. Baker back to the Middle East was made over the weekend during consultations between President Bush and the Secretary of State.
"The President and the Secretary are convinced that all parties are taking a serious approach to peace in the Middle East," she said, but, in a seeming attempt to keep expectations low, she quickly added, "While we believe all parties are serious, there is much work to be done, many questions to be answered and still a long way to go."
Mr. Baker's return trip was welcomed by Foreign Minister David Levy of Israel, who said: "This is a good sign. It shows his labor is bearing fruit."
There was no immediate official high-level Arab response to the announcement.

HEADLINE: New York Judge Rejects State Prenatal Program That Excludes Abortion

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN

 BODY:
A New York State judge ruled yesterday that a state program to provide prenatal care for the working poor was unconstitutional because it did not include abortion services.
The judge, Justice Carmen Ciparick of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, ruled that the exclusion violated state constitutional guarantees of due process, privacy and equal protection. 
 "While the Legislature can express preference for childbirth over abortion and allocate resources accordingly," Justice Ciparick said, "it cannot transgress constitutional principles to achieve this result."
Donna Lieberman, a lawyer for the New York State Civil Liberties Union, said the ruling was the "first time time a New York court explicitly recognized that the State Constitution, independent of Federal guarantees, protected the right of a woman to an abortion." That is significant because, should the United States Supreme Court reverse its stance upholding abortion rights, the question is likely to be decided on a state-by-state basis.
 
No Decision on Appeal
 Terrance McGrath, a spokeman for the State Commissioner of Social Services, Cesar Perales, said the ruling had not been reviewed and no decision had been made on whether to appeal.
The ruling dealt with a state law that took effect in January 1990, which extended an array of prenatal medical services to poor women whose income is above the Federal poverty line. The program excluded abortions, although they are available to women below the poverty line under Medicaid.
The state program was adopted after years of wrenching debate in the Legislature. Lawmakers in the Democratic-led Assembly wanted it to cover abortions as well as prenatal care, but the Republican Senate wanted abortions excluded. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo sided with the Senate, offering a bill excluding abortion financing, which was eventually adopted.
In a broad constitutional attack on the law, the Civil Liberties Union argued that the state "cannot wield its economic power to dictate the choice it prefers, in this instance, childbirth." The group estimated that at least 30,000 women who might have chosen to have abortions last year were denied them because of the exclusion.
Commissioner Perales and David Axelrod, the State Health Commissioner, had contended that the exclusion "did not deprive this group of women of their right to obtain an abortion simply because the state is not supplying the funds," and Justice Ciparick agreed.
But, she said, "The Prenatal Care Assistance Program impermissibly pressures eligible indigent women toward childbirth, abridging a constitutionally protected right."
She cited the case of one patient, a 19-year-old pregnant woman with sickle-cell anemia who was poor but did not qualify for Medicaid. Judge Ciparick said the woman was advised to have an abortion because her health was so poor. The judge said that the prospects for a healthy baby were not good, and that though the woman could choose state-financed prenatal care, she was denied a state-financed abortion.
Poor women in New York City can receive abortions financed by the city through the Health and Hospitals Corporation.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Earnings Up At Eli Lilly and Upjohn

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Eli Lilly & Company and the Upjohn Company each reported double-digit earnings increases for the first quarter, confirming the ability of drug makers to do well despite problems in the economy.
Lilly, based in Indianapolis, said net income rose 14 percent from the same period last year. Upjohn, based in Kalamazoo, Mich., said earnings had increased 16.6 percent. But analysts said both drug companies had important products that faced marketing problems.
 
 
Eli Lilly
 Lilly said net income in the quarter was $388.6 million, or $1.35 a share, compared with $340.8 million, or $1.16 a share, a year ago. Quarterly sales rose 15.7 percent to $1.44 billion, from $1.24 billion a year ago. 
 Richard D. Wood, Lilly's chairman, said sales growth in each of the company's operations had generated a record first quarter. But analysts expressed reservations.
 Barbara Ryan at Prudential Securities said sales of Prozac, Lilly's strong-selling antidepressant drug, seemed flat. "The Prozac numbers have to start to move up," she said, to match the product's strong growth in the second half of 1990, when Prozac sales were $450 million.
 Mary Ellen McCarthy, a drug analyst with Shearson Lehman, said Prozac sales had been hurt by lawsuits charging that the drug has dangerous side effects. Lilly denies the charges, and many psychiatrists say Prozac's benefits far outweigh any possible problems.
 A Lilly spokesman said the company does not disclose sales of individual products. But the company said worldwide pharmaceutical sales were up in the quarter and listed among the "important contributors" Prozac, the ulcer drug Axid; the antibiotic Ceclor and the generically engineered insulin Humulin. Lilly said sales of medical devices and animal health produces also increased.
Eli Lilly stock rose $1.375 a share yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, to $81.625.
 
 
Upjohn
 Upjohn said quarterly earnings were $133.3 million, or 73 cents a share, compared with $114.3 million, or 61 cents, a year ago. Sales rose 10.5 percent to $799.4 million, from $723.4 million a year earlier.
Upjohn said it was helped by a decline in its estimated annual tax rate to 27 percent, compared with 32.5 percent in 1990, because the company increased the portion of earnings from its factories that qualify for tax breaks in Puerto Rico. Upjohn said pretax earnings from continuing operations rose 5 percent, pulled down by new requirements to provide rebates on drugs to state Medicaid programs for the poor.
Ronald Nordmann at Paine Webber Securities said price rises generated nearly half of Upjohn's sales increase in the quarter. He said the company had raised prices by at least 9 percent on three major products -- Xanax , its tranquilizer, Halcion sleeping pills and Ansaid, for arthritis.
Ms. Ryan said Halcion and Xanax sales were depressed in New York State, which required pharmacies to file triplicate records on sales of the Upjohn products, curtailing their availability for illegal sales that drug enforcement officials had been reporting. She said similar national restrictions on Xanax and Halcion have been proposed in Congress.
Upjohn's stock rose 37.5 cents yesterday on the Big Board, to $46.375 a share.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fed Move Dims Hope Of Easing

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Credit market traders and analysts said the Federal Reserve Board sent a clear signal yesterday that it had no current intention of lowering short-term interest rates.
Many analysts had expected that the good inflation news reported last week, with the Consumer Price Index falling one-tenth of 1 percent in March and the Producer Price Index dropping three-tenths, would lead the Fed to cut the discount rate and lower the overnight Federal funds rate. 
 "I was somewhat surprised," said Darwin L. Beck, a vice president and economist at the First Boston Corporation. "All of the signs last Friday pointed to an ease. But the signal only said we haven't eased now. It says nothing about what the future might hold. I think an ease could be triggered at almost any time."
 
Draining Reserves
 The Fed pointedly entered the open market for Treasury securities an hour earlier than normal yesterday and drained reserves from the banking system, a signal that points toward tighter, rather than easier, credit.
At the time of the Fed move, the funds rate was trading around 5 1/2 percent, a level where it hovered for much of last week. Subsequently, the funds rate moved back above the 6 percent level that has been widely regarded as the Fed's target since early March.
"The Fed decided to put an end to the mystery," one Government bond trader said. "But all it means is that they have decided not to cut rates now. But the economic data are very bullish, and inflation is under control."
 
Fed Move Dominates Activity
 The Fed's move dominated trading activity yesterday, and led to a selloff of short-term securities. Longer-term note and bond issues posted modest gains.
"At this point the Fed is more concerned with getting long rates down than short rates," said David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International. "I think bond yields will have to go down to or below 8 percent, and give every indication that they will stay there, before the Fed will move."
A decline in long-term bond yields would tend to push down mortgage interest rates, which, in turn, would provide more stimulus to the housing sector. In February, housing, which has been depressed, showed signs of improvement. March data on housing activity is expected to be released today.
Auto sales, however, which have also been depressed, are not experiencing any sort of postwar recovery.
In a report that went virtually unnoticed in the credit markets yesterday, the nation's auto manufacturers said the annualized selling rate was a mere 5.6 million vehicles in the first 10 days of April, down from the 6.4 million recorded for the last 10 days of March. Most Wall Street analysts had been expecting sales would come in at a rate of 6.2 million.
"The Fed can't be very happy with the auto sales numbers," Mr. Beck said. "They show that a revival in consumer confidence doesn't necessarily translate into sales of goods."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the impact of the Fed's signal was most noticeably felt in rates on outstanding Treasury bills.
In the bill market, three-month bill rates rose by 9 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to a late offered rate of 5.58 percent. And six-month bill rates rose by 8 basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.66 percent.
The reaction among bond traders was slightly more positive.
In late trading, the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 97 6/32, up 7/32, to yield 8.12 percent, down from 8.14 percent late Friday.
Among note issues, the 7 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at a price of 98 5/8, up 1/32, to yield 7.95 percent. And the 7 1/8 percent two-year notes were unchanged, at a late offered price of 100 1/2, to yield 6.84 percent.
At the Treasury's weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills, new three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 5.57 percent, down from an average rate of 5.60 percent at last week's sale. It is the lowest rate on a new three-month bill since the auction on Nov. 30, 1987, when three-month bills sold at an average rate of 5.49 percent.
Bids on new six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 5.67 percent, off from an average rate of 5.68 percent a week ago. It is the lowest rate on a six-month bill since the auction of July 13, 1987.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, activity yesterday was highlighted by offerings from two Canadian provinces, which collectively offered $800 million worth of securities to investors.
The Province of Quebec priced a $500 million offering of 12-year, 8.80 percent debentures through an underwriting group led by the First Boston Corporation.
The securities were priced at $99.689, to yield 8.842 percent, 90 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 3/4 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities, which mature April 15, 2003, are noncallable for life. They are rated AA-3 by Moody's Investors Service and AA-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The Province of Nova Scotia offered $300 million of 30-year debentures through an underwriting group led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
The 9 1/8 percent securities, which mature May 1, 2021, were priced at $98.818, to yield 9.242 percent, 1.125 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds at the time of pricing.
The securities, which are noncallable for life, are rated A-2 by Moody's and A-minus by Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said that prices of most issues rose by 1/4 of a point to 3/8 of a point in fairly active trading.
Participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt bonds said that prices of most widely quoted municipal issues rose by about 1/8 of a point.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills:
