HEADLINE: Beef Prices at Record Highs As Cattle Shortage Continues

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
With barbecue season around the corner, a near 30-year low in the nation's cattle herd has resulted in the highest prices ever for steak, hamburger and other cuts of beef.
The Government expects the herd to be larger by the end of the summer, but there is a puzzling discrepancy between the growing number of cattle in feedlots and the number actually slaughtered. 
 And until more cattle are slaughtered, beef prices, ranging from hamburger meat to choice steaks, are likely to stay high. Ground beef is selling nationally at an average of $1.64 a pound, according to the National Cattlemen's Association, up 6 percent from $1.55 in March 1990. T-bone steak is selling for $5.40 a pound, a 5 percent increase from $5.16 a year ago.
 
Thousands Sold Their Herds
 The beef shortage is the aftermath of economic problems that beset farmers in the mid-1980's. Thousands of financially strapped ranchers sold their cattle herds to pay off bank loans. A severe drought followed, making it too expensive for many remaining farmers to buy feed to expand their herds.
As a result, the number of cattle in the United States -- on both pastures and feedlots -- has been hovering at slightly below 100 million head for the past several years, compared with more than 110 million in 1980 and 132 million in 1976.
Faced with the high meat prices, many grocers say they are promoting chicken breasts, which average $2.04 a pound, or less than half the price of a T-bone steak, and that more and more shoppers are choosing chicken.
"I used to spoil myself, but I gave it up since it got so high," said Katie Tschimperle of Minneapolis, in regard to the price of beef. Within the last six months, because of high prices, she has switched from T-bone steak and porterhouse to chicken and pork.
One New York City restaurateur said she was trying to de-emphasize her beef offerings. "People are ordering less steak; it's very expensive," said Ruth Jeffries, owner of Mrs. J's Sacred Cow Steak House in Manhattan, who prefers that the restaurant now be known simply as Mrs. J's. "I am trying to get away from the word 'steak,' " she added.
Grocers have been trying to hold down the price of beef to avoid driving away customers. "Retailers have eaten some of the price increases," one supplier said. Prices have gotten so high that many retailers have simply stopped advertising beef.
But Dennis Smith, the chief meat buyer for Super Valu Stores Inc., a large food distributor and retailer based in Minneapolis, said grocers would be unwilling to continue to accept smaller profits at their meat counters if the price of cattle on the cash market continued to rise.
Such a move would drive consumers into the waiting arms of the chicken producers.
 
Government's Count Questioned
 For nearly a year, Agriculture Department surveys have shown that an increasing number of cattle are fattening up in feedlots, the last stop before slaughter. But despite a 10 percent increase in the number of cattle in feedlots from a year earlier, the size of the slaughter has not grown. That has caused a dispute about the accuracy of the Goverment's monthly feedlot cattle count and a great deal of uncertainty over how much longer prices will stay high.
"They are out there," insists Robert Cole, head the Agriculture Department unit responsible for counting the inventory. He said time would eventually prove the Government's counts correct.
Mr. Cole says the cattle were bound to appear at slaughterhouses in several months. He believes the nub of the problem is not that the Government's cattle count is wrong but that cattle are arriving at feedlots sooner and are weighing less. That means they remain on feedlots longer to gain the required weight for butchering.
 
No Surge of Cattle Yet
 But Mr. Cole acknowledges that the number of cattle being slaughtered this month is still less than he expected. "We have not seen that large surge yet," he said.
Faced with what several analysts are calling "the phantom herd" problem, the nation's biggest slaughterhouses, which have cut back production and hours for their employees because cattle are scarce, say they are planning output on a week-to-week basis.
"Nobody knows what is going to happen," said Gene Meakins, a spokesman for Monfort Inc., which is based in Greeley, Colo., and is the meat-packing subsidiary of Conagra Inc. of Omaha. "We can't get all the cattle we need," Mr. Meakins said. "People in the company say they cannot remember when it has been this difficult to get cattle."
 
Mystery of 'Missing Cattle'
 The "missing cattle" mystery stems from the fact that for nearly a year the Government has reported that the cattle herd is gradually building back from the ravages of the drought three years ago, and that more and more cattle are awaiting slaughter.
The recovery is gradual since it takes nearly two years to breed and fatten a calf and move it through the chutes to slaughterhouses. As the steers get closer to the kill, the Government's counts are important to the meat processers, who use them to set production and shipping schedules for fresh beef.
But the latest projections for the slaughter have been off by up to 240,000 cattle, or 5 percent, of the five million cattle the Government projects for slaughter each quarter.
Cattle ranchers complain that the Government count is off because it relies on outdated methods. "Counting cattle is one of those things that most people in Washington don't think is very significant," said Richard Farr, of Farr Feeders, a feedlot with 30,000 head of cattle in Greeley, Colo.
 
Double Counting Possible
 For one thing, Mr. Farr said, the Government is factoring in cattle from producers that have been out of business for years. Other ranchers and livestock analysts say some cattle are being counted twice. Double counting occurs, they say, when cattle occasionally are moved from feedlot to pasture and back to a feedlot.
Mr. Cole, the Agriculture Department official, said the Government numbers and methods were accurate. He said the survey took steps to avoid double counts by subtracting cattle if taken from a feedlot.
He acknowledged, however, that it was possible that the Government might occasionally include in its estimates cattle produced from farmers who have left the business.
"We try everything to avoid it, but it is possible," he said.
When agents are unable to find ranchers counted in the past, they are allowed to assign a herd size to the rancher based on the size of other herds in the region, Mr. Cole said. He said that estimate amounted to a fraction of the total count.
 
Method of Cattle Counting
 Each month, the agency counts cattle in the seven top cattle-producing states, primarily by asking major feedlots to report the size of their herds. They also telephone major cattle ranches and ask them to count their cattle.
The Government then develops a "statistical indication" of the number of cattle in seven states that the slaughterhouses may expect in a matter of months. Each quarter, the survey, formally known as the Cattle on Feed Inventory, is expanded to include cattle in the 13 biggest cattle-producing states.
Outside the Government, there is confusion about whether the herd is growing. With high prices for cattle, some ranchers are cashing in much of their herds, including cattle that would have been used for breeding. And some farmers and others who raise cattle on the side are getting out of the business, at least temporarily, because they do not want to buy cattle at these prices and be holding them when prices fall.
 
'Critical Time for the Industry'
 "There is a mixed set of projections right now" as to the size of the herd and the direction of prices, said Michael Boehlje, an agricultural economist at the University of Minnesota in St. Paul, adding, "It is a critical time for the industry."
The Government and some ranchers predict that a rise in the size of the nation's cattle herd will force prices down slightly sometime this summer. Ronald Gustafson, an Agriculture Department economist, said that although the worst was over, cattle supplies would remain tight for the rest of the year, and that the expansion of the herd would not have much impact on meat prices until the middle of next year.
"The outlook is for continued record high prices at the meat counters through out the spring," said Charles Levitt, a livestock analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers in Chicago.
 
Growing Popularity of Chicken
 Last year, for the first time, Americans consumed more poultry than beef, an Agriculture Department survey found. Although health and nutrition issues have played an important role in the growing popularity of chicken, economists say the cheaper price of chicken is the primary factor.
"Forget about nutrition; it is just plain old economics," said William Roenigk, vice president of the National Broiler Council in Washington.
Mr. Boehlje, the agriculture economist, said poultry would continue to gain market share at the expense of beef as meat prices rise. "The higher beef prices move, the more people are going to switch," he said. "We have seen substantial switching in the past and I think that is going to continue."
And Mr. Smith of Super Valu predicted, "This summer, you will see a little more chicken on the grill and fewer steaks."

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
Big Jump In Profits At Chase

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Chase Manhattan Corporation yesterday announced a first-quarter profit of $117 million, a sharp improvement from a year earlier. The news was a sign that conditions for the banking industry are improving, even though problems with bad loans remain severe.
First Fidelity Bancorporation, the largest banking company in New Jersey, also announced an increase in profits. 
 Like many other banking companies, Chase and First Fidelity benefited from a wider spread between the interest rates they paid for deposits and the rates they collected on loans; a cutback in low-profit corporate lending and an expansion of higher-profit consumer lending, and reductions in payroll and other expenses.
Following are details of the companies' results:
 
 
Chase Manhattan
 At Chase, the nation's third-largest banking company after Citicorp and BankAmerica, first-quarter profits were more than double the $44 million earned a year earlier, and earnings per share improved to 73 cents, from 20 cents.
After losses totaling $999 million in 1989 and 1990, analysts have been predicting a return to profitability at Chase. Yesterday's announcement was better than expected and helped raise the company's stock price $1.375, to $19 a share, its highest level of the year. As recently as October 1989, Chase's stock had traded at $44.875. That was before the company began announcing a rapid increase in losses on bad loans, and declining activity in corporate lending, an area of traditional strength for the company.
"They are still not operating at a level of profitability the company needs over the long term, but the improvement gives hope that management is executing the turnaround plan," said Norman Jaffe, a banking analsyt at Fox-Pitt Kelton, a securities firm.
The most glaring sign of trouble at Chase was an increase in domestic loans labeled as non-accrual because they are either badly delinquent or in such trouble that management does not expect repayment in full. Non-accrual loans backed by commercial real estate projects increased $294 million, or 16.5 percent, to $2.074 billion, and now account for 23.6 percent of all such loans. Other kinds of domestic loans in enough trouble to be lableled non-accrual rose $38 million, to $761 million.
Despite the increase in non-accrual loans, Chase did not increase the size of its reserve for loan losses. After adding $240 million to the reserve and loan charge-offs of $270 million net of recoveries, the reserve declined slightly to $2.8 billion. In the fourth quarter, Chase set aside $200 million for its reserve and charged off $286 million net of recoveries.
There are no firm rules for how much a bank should set aside in reservs for bad loans, and it is up to each bank to estimate how much of a loss it expects on its loans.
Chase continued to reduce the size of the company and its payroll during the first quarter, though at a much slower pace than during the last half of 1990.
 
 
First Fidelity
 Profits at First Fidelity more than doubled, to $56.1 million, from $21.1 million a year earlier. First Fidelity's earnings improved to 87 cents a share in the first quarter, from 30 cents a year earlier.
A $37.2 million decline in non-interest expenses, to $211.6 million, helped compensate for an increase in troubled loans. The company set aside $85 million in its reserve for additional losses, up from $63 million in the fourth quarter. Badly delinquent and other troubled loans rose $50 million, to $786.7 million, or 4.5 percent of all loans, up from 3.907 percent at year-end.
On the New York Stock Exchange, First Fidelity's stock rose 62.5, cents to $25.375.

HEADLINE: Film Workers Reject Settlement, Prolonging New York Shutdown

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
Members of a film-crafts union local rejected a tentative contract yesterday with leading Hollywood producers, prolonging a bitter and costly stalemate that has virtually shut down major-studio film making in New York City since November.
The surprising rejection came at a critical time of the year for New York's $2.5 billion movie-making industry when commitments are made to bring big budget productions to the city for summer filming. The lack of a settlement would mean that only low-budget, independent films would be shot -- a small fraction of the city's film-making business. 
 "I'm sick about this, I had hoped it wouldn't happen," said Jaynne C. Keyes, director of the Mayor's Office for Film, Theater and Broadcast. "It's very bad news for the city. If the producers don't come back to the bargaining table, we've lost our summer, and that's most of our business."
In mail ballots counted yesterday, the rank and file of Local 52 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees and Moving Picture Machine Operators voted 606 to 393 not to accept the settlement, which was reached on March 18.
Although many of the union members have been out of work for as long as five months, they were opposed to provisions that would have offered the film producers reductions in required overtime and weekend payments. In return, the workers would have received greater health and pension benefits.
"I guess the producers were asking too much," said Walter Stocklin, president of Local 52, "We do want to reach an agreement with the producers. We have some ideas -- it doesn't mean we're dead in the water."
The major producers involved in the negotiations are five Hollywood studios: Columbia Pictures, the 20th Century Fox Film Corporation, Paramount Pictures, Warner Brothers, MGM-United Artists and Orion Pictures, participating as a distributor.
"We're extremely disappointed with the vote," said Joel Grossman, vice president for labor relations at Columbia Pictures, who was the producers' chief negotiator with the union local. "Theoretically, talks could resume right away, but the question is whether there is any reason to resume."
"Speaking for Columbia Pictures," he added, "we will not bring productions into New York until there is a signed agreement with Local 52."
Before the tentative settlement was reached in March, the 19-week stalemate had called a halt to major-studio movie making in New York City, a vital part of the city's economy that is estimated to generate $500 million to $2.5 billion a year in fees to the city, as well as many ancillary jobs. Mayor David N. Dinkins had pressed for a settlement along with the city's film office.
The 2,000-member Local 52 provides much of the behind-the-scenes people for movies in New York, including sound people, electricians, shop craftsmen, prop people, camera grips and set dressers. Only about 1,000 members of the union, whose jurisdiction is New York City and Long Island, voted.
Many of Local 52's members, as well as the members of other New York film unions, have been out of work since November. Although they are accustomed to interrupted employment, most of them do not hold other jobs and will have to leave the city to seek film work in other cities.
The tentative agreement had been reached in Sherman Oaks, Calif., by the producers and the bargaining committees of Local 52 and another film union, Local 644 of the International Photographers of the Motion Picture and Television Industries. Local 644's members are now voting on the tentative settlement by mail, with their ballots to be counted on May 3. Ratification is expected.
Local 644, which represents cinematographers and camera crews, has 1,500 members. It has jurisdiction over the entire East Coast.
Efforts to reach Louis D'Agostino, business manager of Local 644, for comment were unsuccessful last night.
Mr. Stocklin, the Local 52 president, said he "did not anticipate" any action by the international union that might force acceptance of the settlement.
After Local 52's contract expired on Oct. 31 -- a month after Local 644's contract -- the producers promised to steer films away from New York City until an agreement was reached, amounting to a boycott of New York movie making other than independent productions, which have continued.
In 1989, 110 films were shot partially or totally in New York City, the film office reported. In 1990, 139 films were shot in New York City. Since January, 35 feature-film permits have been granted by the film office, compared with 34 by this time last year. Ms. Keyes said all of the new films were nonstudio productions, with budgets of $1 million or less.
Before the tenative agreement, which Mayor Dinkins had hailed as "a clear sign that a resolution to this conflict is near," city officials were deeply worried about the effects of a continued boycott on the city's economy.

HEADLINE: Chemical Leak in Korea Brings Forth a New Era

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KUMI, South Korea

 BODY:
When South Korea decided that the country's only chance at economic pre-eminence lay in supercharged industrialization, it started here, in a scrubby valley formed by the Naktong River.
As a result, the region, the home district of President Roh Tae Woo, could now be mistaken for anywhere in the Silicon Valley of California. But a recent chemical spill that some critics link to South Korea's "industrialize at all cost" policies is causing the area and the nation much anguish. 
 Until a few weeks ago, the country's industrial leaders liked to escort visitors through the endless line of low white buildings to show off Korea's prowess in building televisions and VCR's, telephones and refrigerators, and more recently, computers and advanced memory chips.
 
Many Violently Ill
 That was before one morning last month, when South Koreans turned on their taps and were overcome by a tremendous stench. It came from a caustic, highly toxic form of phenol, a chemical used in processing circuit boards, that had leaked overnight from a storage tank at an electronics plant in Kumi. It had coursed its way through the reservoir system of Taegu, South Korea's third-largest city, which is about 200 miles southeast of Seoul.
The water flowed to 1.7 million people, and hundreds, perhaps thousands, became violently ill. The incident has turned into South Korea's most politically charged industrial pollution case, one that could galvanize the country much the way the more severe mercury poisoning cases in Minamata, Japan, became a symbol of industrialization gone awry a generation ago.
And true to their passionate style, demonstrators took to the streets in Taegu, demanding punishment for the offending company, the Doosan Group, and beginning a boycott of Coca-Cola and Kentucky Fried Chicken, among other products that Doosan holds the franchises for in Korea.
After hurried Cabinet meetings in Seoul, Mr. Roh announced a rapid rethinking of South Korea's industrialization policies. The plant was closed and the managers overseeing it were quickly imprisoned. To drive home the point that a new era of environmentalism had suddenly begun, prosecutors also locked up many of the region's environmental inspectors, suggesting they were negligent or were paid to look the other way. Six have been indicted on charges of industrial pollution and negligence, among other offenses, and all remain in jail.
"For years, Koreans accepted this kind of thing as the price of development," said Yoon Myung Hyun, the administrator of the area's environmental agency. "For Korean businesses, protecting the environment is just another way to cut into profits. Now, maybe, those days are over."
Whether Mr. Yoon is right, or whether he is simply optimistic, is still a matter of significant debate.
For years, South Korea has been notoriously lax about what is dumped into the air and water, and while few officials will acknowledge it openly, the absence of expensive environmental regulations has made investing in industry here attractive.
Kumi, just west of Taegu, is jammed not only with Korean companies but also with Japanese and American joint ventures. The plant in the current pollution case, the Doosan Electro-Materials Company, is 40 percent owned by a unit of Allied-Signal Inc. of Morristown, N.J.
 
No Denial by Doosan
 Doosan has not denied that it was the source of the phenol leak. But it says that under Korean tradition, it cannot really defend itself while it is the focus of public controversy. Instead, company officials say, they must sit back and absorb the criticism, and make explanations later.
"If we explain everything, it will only inflame people," said a senior Doosan official, giving a recent visitor a tour of the plant while it was closed. But the official, the head of another part of the Doosan Group, said many of the charges were false, including contentions that Doosan was slow to alert officials or people who rely on the water supply.
Last week, the large Doosan plant, which has been shut since the accident occurred on March 14, was reopened to reduced production. Doosan makes 80 percent of the printed circuit boards produced in Korea. The boards house the internal controls for everything from television sets to microwave ovens.
Mr. Roh's Cabinet is also considering a plan to create special regions near tap-water sources where no new factories could be built.
But such policies may be too late. The Korea Times, an English-language daily, has reported that 343 factories along the 326-mile Naktong River, the nation's longest, have been found to have illegally discharged atoxic waste last year.
The leak that prompted the newest protests started when an underground pipe leading from an outdoor tank to the Doosan factory burst. The pipe leaked at least 30 tons of pure concentrated phenol into the river. Prosecutors charge that the company waited hours to report the accident, making it impossible for the authorities to shut off water supplies in time.
But the amount of phenol was so large, it may have saved many residents from further illness or even death. The reaction of the chemical with the water created an overpowering stench that made the water virtually undrinkable, residents say.
"It smelled so awful that you vomited when you go near it," said T. H. Jo, an area environmental official.
The intense reaction against Doosan seems to underscore the growing conflict here between industrial companies unaccustomed to being questioned and a public that got its first taste of real political power only four years ago.
Soon after the elections that brought Mr. Roh to power, the country was shaken by strikes in some industries. The bitterness of those wage disputes have added to public suspicions about the "chaebol," Korea's giant industrial groups. Chemical-laden rivers and air fouled with exhaust make for a potent target. A plan to build a titanium operation in Korea has encountered strong opposition from environmentalists.
"I think it has to do with a sudden sense of affluence in Korea," said Mr. Yoon, the environmental agency administrator. "People are tired of bad working conditions and bad living conditions."
But some industrial officials remain philosophical. "You can't hide this kind of thing," the Doosan Group official said. "We have no choice but to accept our guilt and try to build up again."

After it was cleaned up, Chung Dae-suk, left, the director of Taegu's reservoir, observed a laboratory test of the effects of the phenol-contaminated water on goldfish in beakers. (David E. Sanger/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: EUROPE'S ECONOMY IS FOUND TO STALL

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, April 15

 BODY:
A year ago, as the United States was sliding toward recession, many European officials boasted that the European Community, spurred by German unification, would take over as the locomotive of the world economy.
Instead, Western Europe's economy has stalled, with the Persian Gulf crisis pushing much of the Continent, already weakened by Germany's high interest rate, to the brink of recession. 
 Worried by the crisis in the gulf, consumers shunned department stores and auto showrooms. As consumer confidence declined and oil prices jumped, businesses had second thoughts about investment. Some industries began idling workers late last year.
 
Peak in Interest Rates Seen
 Now, the allied victory in the gulf has made European officials optimistic that a recession will be avoided and economic growth will pick up soon. Many economists predict that Europe's high interest rates have peaked and that American imports of European goods should grow when the recession in the United States ends.
But few economists foresee a robust European rebound. The "Europhoria" that swept the Continent in the late 1980's, when the prospects of a barrier-free market in 1992 touched off a boom in investment, has given way to a cautious period of "Eurorealism." Executives wonder when consumers are going to rush back to buy cars and computers.
"The situation is very uncertain at the moment," said Ian Harwood, chief economist for Warburg Securities, a London investment bank. "Once the gulf war was over, business confidence was supposed to pick up, but we haven't seen a sharp lift in spirits."
Europe's slump is one factor helping to hold back the United States economy. European shoppers are buying less and that is not only hurting American exports but also profits at some of America's largest corporations with major European operations, like the International Business Machines Corporation. In addition, Europe's high interest rates have nudged up interest rates in the United States, reinforcing America's recession.
Despite today's bumps and uncertainties, many economists say Western Europe might still enjoy a dynamic decade. "Over all, Europe's prospects for the 1990's are very good indeed," said Richard Portes, director of the Center for Economic Policy Research in London. "That's not to say that Europe is going to grow faster than Japan, but it's likely to grow faster than the U.S."
And even Japan's economic growth is slowing as it concentrates on public works and as its banks recover from plunging stock and real estate prices.
The European Community's plan to drop tariffs and trade restrictions to form a single market of 340 million people by late 1992 is on schedule, but other ambitious measures have stumbled.
Plans to form a European central bank and adopt a single European currency by the mid-1990's are snarled in debate. Eastern Europe, expected to be a hungry new market for Western Europe, is finding its journey toward Western-style capitalism and prosperity far longer than anticipated. German reunification is proving difficult and expensive as eastern German industry verges on collapse.
Under last year's rosy outlook, a newly united Germany was likely to buy so many imports that the 11 other European Community nations would prosper. Bonn's deficit spending for eastern Germany and the East's appetite for Western goods did in fact help western Germany's economy grow by 4.5 percent last year, the fastest since the mid-1970's.
But Germany is not exporting its prosperity. "Germany is still the engine of Europe, but it's not as strong an engine as it had been," said Norbert Walter, chief economist for Deutsche Bank in Frankfurt.
Many economists say the German locomotive has lost its horsepower for a single reason: the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank. The nation's central bankers, fearing that Bonn's $85.5 billion in emergency spending to help eastern Germany would overheat the economy and stoke inflation, have repeatedly jacked up interest rates. These increases are expected to slow western Germany's growth to 3 percent this year.
Most of the European Community's other central banks have followed the Bundesbank's increases to keep their currencies from falling against the German mark. Most community currencies are linked through the 10-nation European Monetary System, in which the Bundesbank reigns supreme because it sits atop Europe's most powerful economy and most respected currency.
The Bundesbank last raised rates in late January, bringing its discount rate to 6.5 percent and its short-term Lombard rate to 9 percent. These increases have pushed up rates worldwide, slowed Europe's growth, and irked French and British officials, who feel their own economies are underheated.
"By keeping rates high, the Bundesbank is having a negative impact that outweighs the import boom into Germany," said Christopher Mills, an economist with DRI Europe, a London-based economic consulting firm. "This year German unification is proving a negative rather than positive factor for Europe's economy."
High interest rates have undercut growth in another way: At least until six weeks ago, they caused Europe's currencies to soar against the dollar, hurting exports of BMW cars and Belgian chocolates.
The strength of Europe's currencies also ate into corporate profits, by making the prices of European goods less competitive. Last week, Renault, the state-owned auto maker, announced that its 1990 profits plunged 87 percent, to $212 million, from $1.63 billion. Two of Germany's chemical giants, BASF and Bayer, reported that pretax 1990 profits dropped by 37 percent and 18 percent, respectively.
The sick man of Western Europe, economists agree, is Britain, which is bogged down in recession. The Thatcher boom in the late 1980's, together with financial deregulation and rapid monetary growth, produced 10 percent inflation. After the Bank of England raised interest rates to subdue inflation, the nation plunged into a deep recession last spring, a slump expected to last at least several more months.
France and Italy were beginning to slow down even before Iraq invaded Kuwait last August because of the slumps in Britain and the United States as well as high interest rates. "But what happened in the gulf really reinforced the downturn," said Albert Merlin, chief economist for Compagnie de Saint-Gobain, the French glass and packaging giant.
The gulf crisis helped reduce France's growth to 2.6 percent last year from a robust 3.9 percent in 1989, the nation's strongest growth in a decade. Italy's growth shrank to 1.9 percent in 1990 from 3.6 percent in 1989.
 
A Change in Psychology
 During the fourth quarter, industrial production fell in France and Italy, but most economists expect both nations to escape recession. "People's psychology has changed somewhat," Mr. Merlin said. "That change is not very strong, but we should see it show up in industrial production in a few months."
Many economists forecast that Europe's slowdown will bottom out in the first quarter. "I think we have passed through the worst part," said Philippe d'Arvisenet, an economist with Banque Nationale de Paris. "In France, the first quarter may be flat, then we expect a rebound."
DRI Europe forecasts that France's economy will grow by 1.9 percent this year, and Italy's by 1.6 percent while it expects British output to fall by 1 percent.
These weak figures are not expected to dent the community's stubbornly high 9 percent jobless rate. "Unemployment remains high across Europe," said Mr. Mills of DRI Europe. But because governments remain preoccupied with taming inflation, he said, fighting it seems to be a fairly low priority.
 
Optimism on Interest Rates
 Corporate planners are optimistic that Europe's interest rates have peaked. Some economists say the Bundesbank will not raise rates further because that would only aggravate eastern Germany's troubles and infuriate the rest of Europe. The Bundesbank may feel less need to raise rates now that Bonn is raising taxes to reduce the huge deficit caused by outlays for eastern Germany.
One reason why France and some other nations are eager to form a single communitywide central bank is to reduce the Bundesbank's conservative dominance over Europe. Because this new central bank would include French and Italian governors, it should be more responsive than the Bundesbank to French and Italian economic needs.
But the Bundesbank's president, Karl-Otto Pohl, wants to crawl, rather than run, toward a single central bank. He fears it would be less independent than the Bundesbank and would accommodate those who crave growth more than stable prices.

SECTION: Section D; Page 2; Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 476 words

HEADLINE: Net Rises 5.2% at G.E.; Financial Services Gain

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
Buoyed by productivity improvements and strong gains in its financial services sector, the General Electric Company said yesterday that its first-quarter net income rose 5.2 percent.
Profits totaled $999 million, or $1.15 a share. In last year's first quarter, G.E. earned $950 million, or $1.06 a share. Its revenues were up 5.6 percent, to $13.3 billion, from $12.6 billion a year earlier. 
 The company does not break out specific quarterly figures for its divisions on a quarterly basis. But it acknowledged that operating profit and revenues at its National Broadcasting Company subsidiary were sharply lower than year-earlier levels primarily because of reduced advertising revenues, lower ratings and higher news costs resulting from coverage of the Persian Gulf crisis. All of the television networks were hurt by competition from the Cable News Network in covering the war.
 
Bought Shares Back
 The company, based in Fairfield, Conn., said growth in earnings per share outpaced growth in net earnings because of G.E.'s five-year $10 billion stock repurchase program. During the quarter, the company bought back four million shares.
John F. Welsh Jr., the chairman and chief executive, said the company did not see any evidence that the surge in consumer confidence after the war was being followed by any meaningful pickup in economic activity. But he added that the company's diversified global busineses should provide relatively strong earnings.
Despite Mr. Welsh's caution about the future, G.E.'s stock rose 75 cents on the New York Stock Exchange, to close at $73.75 a share.
What particularly pleased some analysts was G.E.'s statement that first-quarter earnings in its financial services unit rose by 15 percent.
 
Kidder Termed Improved
 G.E. said Kidder, Peabody & Company, its Wall Street subsidiary, recorded what it called much-improved results, reflecting higher trading profits. The company also said that there was strong portfolio growth at GE Capital and that it had a gain on the merger of its auto-auction business with another company. The gain, however, was more than offset by lower operating results in highly leveraged transactions and commercial real estate businesses.
Russell Leavitt, a Salomon Brothers Inc. analyst, said the results were better than expected. He said the financial services results were welcomed since many other finance companies have had substantial writeoffs and earnings problems.
The company said its primary strength came from increased revenues and productivity improvements in its long-cycle businesses: aircraft engines, power systems and medical systems, as well as financial services.
"G.E.'s operating margin of 12.1 percent, a record for the first quarter and an improvement over 1990's 11.8 percent, was particularly encouraging," Mr. Welsh said.

HEADLINE: Bush Urges All Sides to Act to Avoid a Rail Strike

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 15

 BODY:
President Bush said today that "it would be prudent that all efforts and actions be taken" to avoid a nationwide rail strike, saying it would seriously disrupt a fragile economy.
Speaking to the Association of General Contractors, Mr. Bush stopped short of asking Congress to head off a strike against most of the 15 major freight railroads. He added that the Administration was "willing to work with the parties to help in any way possible." 
 Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner had said that if no progress had been made when the weekend was over the Administration would consider asking Congress to pass legislation to avert the strike before it occurs, as it did in 1970.
Under the Railway Labor Act of 1926, the Federal Government has wide powers to deal with labor relations at railroads and airlines. The act keeps labor contracts in force during negotiations, essentially postponing their expiration indefinitely and provides for the appointment of a Presidential emergency board to recommend a settlement. In similar railroad negotiations in the past, after an automatic 90-day cooling-off period, Congress has used a commission's recommendations to legislate a settlement.
Congressional committees have been keeping track of the negotiations, but they have not introduced any legislation, hoping that the railroads and unions will reach a settlement.
The Administration is prepared to force the issue through Congressional action if the unions do not make a deal to stop a nationwide strike, scheduled to begin at 12:01 A.M. Wednesday, when the cooling-off period between freight railroads and 11 unions expires.
Leaders of unions for about two-thirds of the country's 235,000 freight line workers have threatened to leave their jobs then if a deal is not struck on the thorny issues of wages and health benefits. Leaders of 3 of the 11 unions have agreed to terms similiar to those recommended by the Presidential board, but members have not voted on the agreements.
Contract talks continued into the night and were to resume Tuesday. The largest union, the United Transportation Union, did not take part in negotiations today, but said it would join the talks on Tuesday.
The railroads say the wage recommendations of the commission go too far, and they are pressing to cut workers and change work rules. The unions' strongest objections have been to the reductions and plans to change work rules.
Mr. Skinner met this morning with a large group of union leaders as they were coming out of intense weekend bargaining sessions with the National Mediation Board, which oversees contract disputes covered by the Railway Labor Act. The negotiations on a new contract have been going on for three years.
Transportation officials said that while the Administration was not keen to interfere in a labor-management dispute, Mr. Skinner was persuaded that the strike would prolong the economic slump. More than a third of all goods shipped each month in the United States go by rail, and many industries, among them automobile makers, rely on timely delivery of parts and materials at assembly plants. They could be forced to curtail production within days of a strike.
"That strike that looms for right after midnight tomorrow could seriously disrupt the economy just as the economy, in our view, is trying to turn around and get out of this recession," Mr. Bush, who was accompanied by Mr. Skinner, told the general contractors.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush telling the Association of General Contractors yesterday in Washington that a rail strike would "seriously disrupt" the economy. Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner was at the rear. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
A near 30-year low in the nation's cattle herd has resulted in the highest prices ever for steak, hamburger and other cuts of beef. The Government expects the herd to be larger by the end of the summer, but there is one puzzling discrepancy. [Page A1.] 
 Sales of American-made vehicles fell 17.1 percent in early April, as buyers remained sidelined by debt. [D7.]
The Senate is expected to decide this week whether the C.F.T.C. or the S.E.C. will control some new financial instruments. [D21.]
Labor Secretary Lynn Martin said she would soon announce procedures to protect miners from black lung disease. [A20.]
 
Companies
Chase Manhattan profits rose sharply, a sign that conditions in banking are improving. First Fidelity also gained. [D1.]
Fred Carr, chairman of First Executive, agreed not to try to collect $10.7 million in long-term compensation yet. [D1.]
NWA could get control of the Trump Shuttle in exchange for assuming much of the shuttle's debt. [D1.]
Schneider said 78.1 percent of Square D's shares had been tendered, despite Square D's refusal to consider its offer. [D1.]
General Electric's net income rose 5.2 percent. The company was helped by productivity improvements. [D2.]
Paine Webber and Smith Barney reported sharp increases in first-quarter earnings. [D3.]
Eli Lilly and Upjohn posted big earnings gains, confirming the ability of drug makers to defy the economy. [D3.]
Reynolds Metals said its net income plunged 65 percent. It cited lower prices for fabricated products. [D3.]
Apple Computer reported increased revenues but a slight decline in earnings. [D4.]
NCR earnings fell 12 percent, largely because of the cost of fighting A.T.&T. [D4.]
Carnival Cruise Lines said it would acquire Premier Cruise Lines for about $372 million. [D3.]
 
International
Western Europe's economy has stalled, with the war pushing much of the continent to the brink of recession. [A1.]
The top economic priority for the industrialized world should be to lower interest rates, Treasury Secretary Brady said. [D6.]
A recent chemical spill in South Korea is causing the area and the nation a lot of anguish. [D1.]
Toyota said it was negotiating with Volkswagen to market VW's and Audis in Japan. [D7.]
The European Community agreed to lift its remaining economic sanctions against South Africa. [A1.]
 
Markets
The Fed sent a clear signal that it had no current intention of lowering short-term rates, traders said. [D1.]
Stocks turned volatile as traders tried to figure out whether the Fed would bring rates down. The Dow rose 12.38, to 2,933.17. [D8.]
The dollar fell amid concerns about U.S. interest rates. Gold prices edged higher. [D15.]
Wheat prices retreated as traders grew more cautious about the chances of the Soviet Union gaining fresh U.S. subsidies. [D15.]
 
Today's Columns
An accounting rule on retirees' medical expenses may raise warning flags. Milt Freudenheim: Business and Health. [D2.]
The vision of eating without growing fat propelled the shares of Biospherics. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D8.]
Eurocom is said to be the most likely candidate to make a bid soon for Scali, McCabe, Sloves. Kim Foltz: Advertising. [D17.]
